Authors: Head-Gordon M., Pople J.A., Frisch M.J.
Title: MP2 energy evaluation by direct methods
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Multiflow Computer, Inc., 175 North Main Street, Branford, CT 06405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Head-Gordon, M., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Pople, J.A., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie-Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Frisch, M.J., Multiflow Computer, Inc., 175 North Main Street, Branford, CT 06405, United States
Abstract: An efficient algorithm is presented for evaluating the second-order Møller-Plesset (MP2) energy directly from two-electron integrals in the atomic orbital basis, i.e. the integrals are not stored. The floating point operation count and memory requirements are analyzed, and illustrative calculations are presented. This direct MP2 method should be useful for large molecule calculations, where, due to storage limitations, conventional disk-based MP2 procedures are often not feasible. © 1988.

Authors: Priedhorsky W.C., Bloch J.J., Smith B.W., Strobel K., Ulibarri M.
Title: ALEXIS: An Ultrasoft X-Ray Monitor Experiment Using Miniature Satellite Technology
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, United States; Sandia National Laboratory, United States; Space Sciences Laboratory/UC Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Priedhorsky, W.C., Los Alamos National Laboratory, United States, Sandia National Laboratory, United States, Space Sciences Laboratory/UC Berkeley, United States; Bloch, J.J., Los Alamos National Laboratory, United States, Sandia National Laboratory, United States, Space Sciences Laboratory/UC Berkeley, United States; Smith, B.W., Los Alamos National Laboratory, United States, Space Sciences Laboratory/UC Berkeley, United States; Strobel, K., Los Alamos National Laboratory, United States; Ulibarri, M., Los Alamos National Laboratory, United States
Abstract: Los Alamos and Sandia National Laboratories are, building an ultrasoft X-ray monitor experiment. This experiment, called ALEXIS (Array of Low-Energy X-Ray Imaging Sensors), consists of six compact normal-incidence telescopes. ALEXIS will operate in the 70 - 110 eV band. The ultrasoft X-ray/EUV band is nearly uncharted territory for astrophysics. ALEXIS, with its wide fields-of-view and well-defined wavelength bands, will complement the upcoming NASA Extreme Ultraviolet Explorer and ROSAT EUV Wide Field Camera, which are sensitive broadzband survey experiments. The program objectives of ALEXIS are to 1) demonstrate the feasibility of a wide field-of-view, normal incidence ultrasoft X-ray telescope system and 2) to determine ultrasoft X-ray backgrounds in the space environment. As a dividend, ALEXIS will pursue the following scientific objectives: 1) to map the diffuse background, with unprecedented angular resolution, in several emission line bands, 2) to perform a 3-color survey of point sources, 3) to search for transient phenomena in the ultrasoft X-ray band, and 4) to provide synoptic monitoring of variable ultrasoft X-ray sources such as cataclysmic variables and flare stars. The six ALEXIS telescopes are arranged in pairs to cover three 40° fields-of-view. During each spin of the satellite, ALEXIS will monitor more than half the sky. Each telescope consists of a layered synthetic microstructure (LSM) mirror, a curved microchannel plate detector, background-rejecting filters and magnets, and readout electronics. The mirrors will be tuned to 72 eV, 85 eV, and 95 or 107 eV bands, chosen to select and deselect interesting line features in the diffuse background. The geometric area of each ALEXIS telescope will be about 15 cm2. The telescopes employ spherical mirrors with the curved detector at prime focus and are limited by spherical aberration to a resolution of about 1°. Assuming nominal reflectivities, quantum efficiency, and filter transmission, the 5σ survey sensitivity will be about 2 × 10-3 photons cm-2 s-1 for line emission at the center of the bandpass. ALEXIS is designed to be flown on a small autonomous payload carrier (a minisat) that could be launched from either a Shuttle Get-Away-Special Can or from an expendable launch vehicle. The experiment weighs 100 pounds, draws 40 watts, and produces 10 kbps of data. It can be flown in any low Earth orbit. Onboard data storage allows operation and tracking from a single ground station at Los Alamos. © 1988 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Aspherics; Astrophysics; Digital storage; Mirrors; NASA; Orbits; Surveys; Telescopes; Cataclysmic variables; Expendable launch vehicles; Extreme Ultraviolet; Sandia National Laboratories; Satellite technology; Scientific objectives; Spherical aberrations; Transient phenomenon; Aberrations

Title: Soft X-Ray Monochromators For Synchrotron Radiation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Berlin, FR, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Feldhaus, J., Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4-6, D-1000 Berlin 33, Berlin, FR, Germany
Abstract: This paper gives an overview of soft x-ray monochromators for synchrotron radiation. Showing some typical examples for different energy regions and applications, general design criteria are explained, and specific problems, limitations and future developments using undulator radiation from third generation storage rings are addressed. For a more complete information the reader is referred to various recent review articles. © 1988 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Diffraction; Diffractometers; Monochromators; Multilayers; Spectrometers; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Complete information; Energy regions; General design criteria; Soft x-ray monochromators; Specific problems; Third generation; Undulator radiation; X rays

Title: Natural gas - the clean and dependable fuel
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: When British Gas industrial customers come to assess their plant needs and costs, the benefits from natural gas are clear. The fuel is clean, it has no storage problems and the supply is reliable. The energy is supplied full of potential for the customer to get the best possible use from it. To assist with this, each region of British Gas is on hand to provide expert technical advice with the choice of gas fired plant. This support extends back through the regional Technical Consultancy Departments to the British Gas Midlands Research Station where novel equipment is designed, tested and licensed or jointly developed with manufacturers.
Index Keywords: Furnaces, Melting--Gas Fuel; Natural Gas--Applications; Direct Firing; Indirect Firing; Foundries

Authors: Wicomb W.N., Cooper D.K.C., Novitzky D.
Title: Added effects of organ (heart) storage after brain death in the experimental animal
Affiliations: Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, University of Cape Town Medical School, Cape Town, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Wicomb, W.N., Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, University of Cape Town Medical School, Cape Town, South Africa; Cooper, D.K.C., Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, University of Cape Town Medical School, Cape Town, South Africa; Novitzky, D., Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, University of Cape Town Medical School, Cape Town, South Africa
Abstract: Studies of myocardial ischemia after experimental brain death are reported below. The induction of brain death resulted in deterioration of myocardial function and depletion of energy reserves. Twenty-four-hour hypothermic perfusion storage of freshly excised hearts did not result in significant changes in myocardial function, but hearts excised from brain-dead animals and subsequently stored showed significant functional changes. The reduction in function was more severe when intravenous (IV) fluids and dobutamine or vasopressin were administered to maintain the blood pressure in the brain-dead animal.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; glycogen; lactic acid; animal experiment; brain death; heart; nonhuman; organ preservation; priority journal; swine; Adenosine Triphosphate; Animals; Brain Death; Glycogen; Heart; Heart Transplantation; Hemodynamic Processes; Lactates; Organ Preservation; Swine

Title: Photovoltaics for high capacity space power systems
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Flood, Dennis J., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: The anticipated energy requirements of future space missions will grow by factors approaching 100 or more, particularly as we establish a permanent manned presence in space. The specific technologies required to satisfy any particular set of power requirements will vary from mission to mission. Nonetheless, in almost all cases the technology push will be toward lighter weight and higher efficiency, whether of solar arrays or storage devices. This paper will describe the content and direction of the current NASA program in space photovoltaic technology. The paper will also discuss projected system level capabilities of photovoltaic power systems in the context of some of the new mission opportunities under study by NASA, such as a manned lunar base, and a manned visit to Mars.
Index Keywords: Semiconducting Gallium Arsenide--Applications; Semiconducting Indium Compounds--Applications; Solar Cells; Spacecraft--Power Supply; High Capacity Space Power Systems; III-IV Solar Cells; Interplanetary Applications; NASA Space Program; Orbit Transfer Applications; Photovoltaic Power Systems; Photovoltaic Cells

Authors: Berg H., Dörner R., Kelbch C., Kelbch S., Ullrich J., Hagmann S., Richard P., Schmidt-Böcking H., Schlachter A.S., Prior M., Crawford H.J., Engelage J.M., Flores I., Loyd D.H., Pedersen J., Olson R.E.
Title: Multiple ionisation of rare gases by high-energy uranium ions
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Frankfurt, D6000, Frankfurt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Berg, H., Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Frankfurt, D6000, Frankfurt, Germany; Dörner, R., Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Frankfurt, D6000, Frankfurt, Germany; Kelbch, C., Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Frankfurt, D6000, Frankfurt, Germany; Kelbch, S., Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Frankfurt, D6000, Frankfurt, Germany; Ullrich, J., Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Frankfurt, D6000, Frankfurt, Germany; Hagmann, S.; Richard, P.; Schmidt-Böcking, H.; Schlachter, A.S.; Prior, M.; Crawford, H.J.; Engelage, J.M.; Flores, I.; Loyd, D.H.; Pedersen, J.; Olson, R.E.
Abstract: Multiple ionisation cross sections sigma (q) for the production of recoil ions in charge state q by 120 MeV u-1 U90+ impact have been measured for Ne, Ar and Kr targets using a recoil-ion-projectile-electron triple-coincidence technique. The data are compared with previously measured cross sections for U-ion impact in the projectile energy (Ep) range from 1.4 to 420 MeV u-1. For low recoil-ion charge states sigma (q) decreases over the whole Ep range somewhat more slowly than 1/E p, whereas for higher recoil-ion charge states sigma (q) reaches a maximum at about 10-15 MeV u-1. The data are nicely described by parameter-free n-body Classical Trajectory Monte Carlo (nCTMC) calculations. The calculations indicate the importance of accounting for the Auger events in the description of the multiple ionisation process. Because of the smooth E p dependence of sigma (q) towards high Ep, the development of a recoil-ion source using a primary U-ion beam in the storage ring for the production of high charge state recoil-ions appears to be feasible.

Authors: Svensson A., Muller M., Bowering N., Heinzmann U., Wijesundera W., Radojevic V.
Title: Angle- and spin-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy of the 4f subshell in atomic ytterbium
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Fakultat fur Phys., Bielefeld Univ., Germany
Authors with affiliations: Svensson, A., Fakultat fur Phys., Bielefeld Univ., Germany; Muller, M., Fakultat fur Phys., Bielefeld Univ., Germany; Bowering, N., Fakultat fur Phys., Bielefeld Univ., Germany; Heinzmann, U., Fakultat fur Phys., Bielefeld Univ., Germany; Wijesundera, W.; Radojevic, V.
Abstract: The spin polarisation components of photoelectrons from atomic ytterbium have been measured over the photon energy range from 15.5 to 22.5 eV. The measurements were performed by making use of circularly polarised synchrotron radiation from the storage ring BESSY in conjunction with an angle-resolved electron spectrometer. Theoretical predictions based on the relativistic random-phase approximation (RRPA) are in fair agreement with the experimental data even though a certain offset between theory and experiment exists.

Title: Use of pure nickel and LiOH for thermal energy storage
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, 44135, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whittenberger, J.D., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, 44135, OH, United States
Abstract: The solid to liquid phase transformation of LiOH has been proposed as an ideal candidate thermal energy storage media for a Rankine Cycle powered electrical generation unit envisioned in Space Station based solar dynamic systems. Due to the corrosive nature of molten hydroxides, long term containment of LiOH is of concern. Pure nickel is thought to be a suitably resistant material, and a program has been instituted to measure the effects of prolonged exposure of liquid and gaseous LiOH on the mechanical properties of pure nickel alloys. Results to date indicate that negligible weight and thickness changes occurred in Ni alloys exposed to LiOH for as long as 2500 hr at 775 K, and essentially no difference in 77-900 K tensile properties could be detected between LiOH exposed and vacuum annealed Ni specimens. Although there was little sign of outward damage, microstructural examination revealed that all hydroxide contaminated tensile test specimens had surface connected intergranular cracks along the gage lengths. Two other potential problems, which have strong implications with respect to a LiOH/Ni energy storage system, were also noted during the corrosion experiments. In particular stress corrosion cracking of weld joints in pressurized vessels and permeation of hydrogen through nickel, which leads to the loss of LiOH, were observed. © 1988 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.

Authors: Korzekwa R., Schaefer G., Kristiansen M.
Title: Optimization of gas mixtures for electron-beam-controlled diffuse discharge opening switches
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech. University, Lubbock, TX 79409-4439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Korzekwa, R., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech. University, Lubbock, TX 79409-4439, United States; Schaefer, G., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech. University, Lubbock, TX 79409-4439, United States; Kristiansen, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas Tech. University, Lubbock, TX 79409-4439, United States
Abstract: Electron-beam-controlled diffuse discharges are promising candidates for high-power opening switches in inductive energy storage circuits. An additive of an attaching gas must be used to obtain short opening times when the electron beam is turned off. A high switch efficiency requires low loss operation during conduction. This paper presents methods to optimize gas mixtures for such discharges. Gas mixtures utilizing one or two attaching gases are used and the effect of gas additives which influence the drift velocity is investigated. Experiments on the Jsw-E/N characteristics, the dc E/N breakdown limit, and the glow-to-arc transition E/N limit depending on the energy loading of the discharge are presented and the implications of these results to opening switches are discussed.

Title: A miniature transformer/dc-dc converter for implantable medical devices
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Florida International University, Miami, FL 33199, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mohammed, O.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Florida International University, Miami, FL 33199, United States; Jones, W.K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Florida International University, Miami, FL 33199, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a new technique for the design of a miniature dc-dc converter used in energy producing implantable devices such as defibrillators and advanced pacemakers. This converter is inserted in such a device and is used to boost the voltage from a low voltage implanted battery to high voltage energy storage capacitors in a short period of time. The stored energy is then delivered, when needed, through an energy delivery circuit in order to stimulate or defibrillate the heart. The converter takes the form of a flyback topology which includes a miniature transformer and a specialized control circuit. The transformer was designed using a new numerical synthesis method which utilizes finite elements and dynamic programming for predicting the geometries of the transformer's magnetic circuit. The final transformer design satisfied the performance criteria and provided means for selecting the converter components. The obtained performance results for the transformer and the dc-dc converter were in excellent agreement with laboratory performance tests.

Title: Subharmonic responses of ion-implanted arrays reflecting magnetostatic forward volume waves
Affiliations: THOMSON-CSF, Laboratoire Central de Recherches, Domaine de Corbeville, 91401 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Hartemann, P., THOMSON-CSF, Laboratoire Central de Recherches, Domaine de Corbeville, 91401 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: A subharmonic response at twice a fundamental wavelength was observed by reflection of magnetostatic forward volume waves on 45°oblique incidence ion-implanted arrays. The waves were reflected by two nonperiodic arrays and traveled along a U-shaped path. Each array made of 25 bars with an average fundamental wavelength of 69 μm was implanted with 3×1015 11 B+ ions per cm2 at 150 keV. For such a dose the damaged propagation material was nonferrimagnetic and the subharmonic reflection is attributed to an energy storage consequence of the magnetic field distortion introduced by the crystalline-nonferrimagnetic material-interface corrugation. It vanished after an annealing at 620°C without great degradation of the fundamental wavelength reflection level.

Authors: Nishioka Y., Da Silva Jr. E.F., Ma T.-P.
Title: Time-dependent evolution of SiO2/Si interface traps after repeated radiation damage
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520-2157, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nishioka, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520-2157, United States; Da Silva Jr., E.F., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520-2157, United States; Ma, T.-P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Yale University, New Haven, CT 06520-2157, United States
Abstract: The post-irradiation evolution of the interface traps in metal/SiO 2/Si (MOS) capacitors after repeated x-ray irradiation has been investigated. The results indicate that, immediately after the first irradiation, a characteristic peak (peak-1) in the energy distribution of the interface traps above midgap appears, which subsequently decreases with time in storage at 75 °C. Accompanying this decrease is the formation and growth of a second peak (peak-2) below midgap. Evidence will be presented which suggests that this is due to an interfacial defect transformation process. Measurements done after repeated irradiation-storage cycles indicate that peak-2 is not generated directly by the x-ray irradiation; rather, the existence of peak-1 is a necessary condition for the formation of peak-2 through the defect transformation process. There is also evidence that only a portion (although a significant portion) of peak-1 defect undergoes the transformation process.

Title: Calibration of pulsed x-ray spectra
Affiliations: University of Texas at Dallas, Center for Quantum Electronics, P. O. Box 830688, Richardson, TX 75083-0688
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, J.A., University of Texas at Dallas, Center for Quantum Electronics, P. O. Box 830688, Richardson, TX 75083-0688; Collins, C.B., University of Texas at Dallas, Center for Quantum Electronics, P. O. Box 830688, Richardson, TX 75083-0688
Abstract: A new technique has recently been described for the absolute calibration of intense sources of pulsed radiation in the 0.2-1-MeV range of photon energies. An x-ray activation technique, it depended upon the storage of samples of the irradiating spectrum in the form of populations of nuclei excited to isomeric states with lifetimes of seconds to hours. Accuracy was dependent upon the precision assumed for tabulated values of nuclear parameters. Described here is an extension of this technique to the larger range of photon energies, 0.2-1.5 MeV and to intensities from 1012 keV/keV to 10 16 keV/keV using the target nuclei 7 9Br and 77Se. In this work self-consistency of the nuclear parameters was directly determined. Important changes were found to be necessary for improved accuracy, particularly over the larger ranges of experimental variables being considered. Values of the now-consistent set of nuclear parameters are reported.

Title: Simulation of bit jitter in magneto-optic recording
Affiliations: IBM Corporation, General Products Division, Tucson, AZ 85744, United States
Authors with affiliations: McDaniel, T.W., IBM Corporation, General Products Division, Tucson, AZ 85744, United States
Abstract: The interplay of several writing and reading phenomena that influence bit-position accuracy has been analyzed with a computer model of the magneto-optic (MO) recording process. A micromagnetics simulation determines a minimum energy magnetization state of a MO storage film following local laser heating in an externally applied bias magnetic field. Bit jitter is assessed by measuring the length, width, and position of written domains, and by analyzing the modeled readout signal and its derivative. The influence of variation in the magnetization, anisotropy, and exchange in an amorphous rare-earth-transition- metal film on the position and size of recorded marks has been simulated by specifying random variations of a film's magnetic properties in the thermomagnetic writing step. Variations in medium thermal sensitivity and the reading laser spot size were also considered. Histograms showing the effects of write-read imperfections on bit-position accuracy in MO recording were developed. Comparisons with experiment and separation of other system noise effects have enabled model validation.

Authors: Schafers F., Heckenkamp C., Schonhense G., Heinzmann U.
Title: Energy dependence of the electron spin polarisation parameters for Hg 5d photoionisation with circularly polarised light
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics
Affiliations: BESSY, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schafers, F., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Heckenkamp, C., BESSY, Berlin, Germany; Schonhense, G.; Heinzmann, U.
Abstract: Circularly polarised VUV radiation from the storage ring BESSY was used to measure all three spin polarisation parameters of photoelectrons from the Hg 5d shell in the photon energy range from threshold to approximately 35 eV. The experimental results are compared with theoretical calculations in the relativistic and non-relativistic random-phase-approximation scheme (RRPA and RPAE respectively) and Dirac-Slater (DS) calculations. A discussion of the influence of relativistic and potential barrier effects on the experimental data is given.

Title: Total system load analysis increases plant efficiency and complements utility load profile
Affiliations: Parsons Brinckerhoff Quade &, Douglas Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harris, Kenneth J., Parsons Brinckerhoff Quade &, Douglas Inc, United States
Abstract: The overall operation of cogeneration systems may be enhanced through a load analysis of the total system, defined as a total system load analysis. In this case, a central chilled and hot water plant was studied to provide thermal energy to a group of hotels. Electrical requirements were based on the internal loads of the central plant. Hotels traditionally have a highly variable energy load and have been difficult to adapt to cogeneration techniques. The initial analysis based on peak load demands for chilled and hot water coinciding determined one configuration. A total system load analysis of chilled water, hot water and electricity over a daily cycle, however, showed that these peaks did not coincide and that by using hot water storage, the plant could be operated closer to its design capacity. In addition, it was determined that under certain conditions, it could be less expensive to purchase off-peak electricity from the utility rather than operate the cogeneration plant. This provides a better framework for cooperation with the local utility.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Electric Loads; Electric Power Systems--Load Flow Analysis; Heating--Hot Water Systems; Hotels--Heating; Load Profile; Thermal Loads; Total System Load Analysis; Cogeneration Plants

Authors: Mirza C., Lau K.C., Crawford A.M.
Title: Canada Centre Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage Project
Affiliations: Strata Engineering Corp, Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Mirza, C., Strata Engineering Corp, Toronto, Canada; Lau, K.C., Strata Engineering Corp, Toronto, Canada; Crawford, A.M., Strata Engineering Corp, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage (Acronym ATES) is an energy conservation technology which involves the use of groundwater in meeting partly or fully, the cooling and heating demands of buildings. Groundwater is pumped at ambient temperature from one set of wells at the site, through a heat exchanger, into another set of wells. The cycle is reversed in a seasonal fashion to optimize energy utilization. This paper describes the Canada Centre building - a Public Works Canada ATES Project in Scarborough, Ontario. An overview of the technology is given, followed by hydrogeological considerations. Accompanying analytical and numerical models for the prediction of the behaviour of the Canada Centre ATES system are evaluated.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy utilization; Geology; Groundwater; Heat storage; Hydrology; Mathematical models; Canada Centre Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage (ATES); Hydrogeology; Energy conservation

Title: Pathogenesis of cholesterol gallstones
Affiliations: Department of Medicine, T-013, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hofmann, A.F., Department of Medicine, T-013, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, United States
Abstract: Symptomatic cholesterol gallstone disease occurs because of the combination of a number of biochemical and physiologic defects: formation of supersaturated bile, nucleation, crystal retention, stone growth, and gallbladder inflammation. There are several possible explanations for the high prevalence of supersaturated bile in the Western adult human as compared to other adult mammals. First, the human liver is defective in converting cholesterol to bile acids; the majority of cholesterol is eliminated as cholesterol. Second, the large flux of cholesterol in vesicular form is not matched by a large flux of recycling bile acids. Third, humans live sedentary lives and voluntarily reduce their caloric requirement to prevent obesity. Low caloric intake decreases the circulation of bile acids (including the flux through the hepatocyte). Fourth, the human species is a defective bile secretor in terms of biliary volume (μl/kg-min) compared to other mammals. This is because human enterohepatic circulation of bile acids is 'sluggish' and because bile acid-dependent flow is also lower than in all other mammals. The accumulation of deoxycholic acid, a secondary bile acid formed in the colon, appears to cause secretion of bile that is super-saturated in cholesterol, and may also contribute. Five additional risk factors explain why cholesterol gallstone disease is so prevalent. First, the human species has a gallbladder, and the irregular meal pattern of humans may be responsible for prolonged storage of bile. Second, bile from cholesterol gallstone patients nucleates cholesterol more rapidly. Third, defective gallbladder contraction is associated with cholesterol gallstone disease in the majority of gallstone patients. Fourth, the healthy gallbladder adsorbs cholesterol and desaturates bile - protective functions that may be lost with chronic cholecystitis. Finally, the presence of gallstones stimulates mucous secretion, which traps cholesterol crystals.
Index Keywords: bile acid; cholesterol; cholecystitis; gallstone; human; nucleation; priority journal; review; Animal; Bile; Bile Acids and Salts; Cholelithiasis; Cholesterol; Energy Intake; Human; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Authors: Blum H., Schnall M.D., Renshaw P.F., Buzby G.P.
Title: Metabolic and ionic changes in muscle during hemorrhagic shock
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blum, H., Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States; Schnall, M.D., Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States; Renshaw, P.F., Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States; Buzby, G.P., Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA 19104, United States
Abstract: We have employed concurrent noninvasive 31P and 23Na NMR spectroscopy in conjunction with the paramagnetic shift reagent dysprosium triethylenetetramine hexaacetic acid to observe the intracellular sodium and phosphorus signals in rat leg muscle. Male Wistar rats were bled to a mean arterial blood pressure of 40 mm Hg and were maintained at that pressure. Until decompensatory shock was reached, no increase in intracellular sodium (Na(i)) was found. Although the high energy storage metabolite phosphocreatine fell with time during shock, ATP did not decrease until decompensation. When the phosphorylation ratio, PR = [ATP]/[ADP][P(i)], fell below log(PR) = 3.21 ± .42, Na(i) increase commenced at a rate of 7.97 ± 0.60 meq/l/hr. This corresponds to a two-fold increase in Na permeability compared to normal muscle. A calculation of the free energy available from hydrolysis of ATP at the above value of PR yields -11.7 kcal/mol which is essentially equal to the value of 11.8 kcal/mol which we calculate is needed to run the Na+-K+ antiport through one cycle under normal physiologic conditions.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; phosphorus; sodium; animal experiment; diagnosis; methodology; muscle; nuclear magnetic resonance imaging; permeability; rat; shock; triethylenetetraminehexaacetate dysprosium; Adenosine Triphosphate; Animal; Energy Metabolism; Hydrogen-Ion Concentration; Kinetics; Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy; Male; Muscles; Phosphocreatine; Phosphorus; Phosphorylation; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Shock, Hemorrhagic; Sodium; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Authors: Appleyard R.F., Campbell K.B., Ringo J.A.
Title: Area of the aortic pressure-flow loop measures energy storage by the proximal arteries
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Heart and Circulatory Physiology
Affiliations: Department of Veterinary and Comparative Anatomy, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164, United States
Authors with affiliations: Appleyard, R.F., Department of Veterinary and Comparative Anatomy, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164, United States; Campbell, K.B., Department of Veterinary and Comparative Anatomy, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164, United States; Ringo, J.A., Department of Veterinary and Comparative Anatomy, Washington State University, Pullman, WA 99164, United States
Abstract: We show that power measured by the area of the pressure-flow loop (A(PQ)) is directly proportional to reactive power [Im(W)], which measures pulsatile energy storage in the proximal arteries. Analytically, Im(W) differs from A(PQ) by K · 2π, where K is a postulated constant of proportionality. To determine the value of K, 338 heartbeats obtained from 8 dogs under a wide range of hemodynamic conditions were analyzed. The relationship between A(PQ) and Im(W) remained highly linear (R = 0.98), and the pooled value of K was -1.19 ± 0.01. For the individual dogs, values of K differed at most by ± 9% from its average value. There was also a small offset in the relationship between A(PQ) and Im(W), probably caused by truncating the calculation of Im(W) at the 10th harmonic. Ignoring the small differences in the values of K and the offset, we found that A(PQ) still proved to be an excellent predictor of Im(W). We also found that A(PQ) was sensitive to changes in heart rate, left ventricular stroke output, and peripheral resistance. This reflects the dependence of pulsatile energy storage on these variables and indicates that A(PQ) cannot serve as an index for changes in just the reactive properties of the proximal arteries.

Title: Design of aquifer thermal energy storage. A case study
Source title: Bulletin - Kungl. Tekniska Hogskolan, Institutionen for Vattenbyggnad/Bulletin - Royal Institute of Technology, Hydraulics Laboratory
Affiliations: Royal Inst of Technology, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Johansson, Sam, Royal Inst of Technology, Sweden
Abstract: This study demonstrates the fundamental principles for calculating the temperature distribution in Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage System (ATES) and some calculation methods which can be used when designing ATES. An advantage with approximative calculation methods is that they require only a few hydrogeological and thermal data for input. Complicated models require more input data. The geometry and all the properties of the aquifer must be known in each node point. If we will make simulations with, e.g., a FEM-model in the 2-D horizontal plane, a lot of these input data have to be estimated.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method; Temperature Distribution--Calculations; Water Resources--Thermal; Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage; Groundwater Temperatures; Aquifers

Authors: Andrianov V.V., Baev V.P., Berezin G.L., Buyanov Yu.L., Goncharov V.A., Kir'enin I.A., Lantsev S.Yu., Levitov V.I., Starobinskii V.Ya., Fat'kin A.A.
Title: High-voltage current lead to inductive energy store
Authors with affiliations: Andrianov, V.V.; Baev, V.P.; Berezin, G.L.; Buyanov, Yu.L.; Goncharov, V.A.; Kir'enin, I.A.; Lantsev, S.Yu.; Levitov, V.I.; Starobinskii, V.Ya.; Fat'kin, A.A.
Abstract: The construction of a high-voltage current lead to a cryogenic inductive energy store is described. Results are reported for investigation of the partial-discharge characteristics and the discharge voltages over the surface of film insulation in helium at room temperature and in atmospheric air.
Index Keywords: Cryostats; Energy Storage; Cryogenic Inductive Stores; High Voltage Current Leads; Inductive Energy Stores; Electric Conductors

Title: Thin film coatings for space electrical power system applications
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gulino, Daniel A., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: This paper examines some of the ways in which thin film coatings can play a role in aerospace applications. Space systems discussed include photovoltaic and solar dynamic electric power generation systems, including applications in environmental protection, thermal energy storage, and radiator emittance enhancement. Potential applications of diamondlike films to both atmospheric and space based systems are examined. Also, potential uses of thin films of the recently discovered high temperature superconductive materials are discussed.
Index Keywords: Coatings--Thin Films; Electric Power Generation; Superconducting Materials; Diamond Like Carbon Films; High Temperature Space Radiators; High Temperature Superconductors; Photovoltaic Power System; Solar Electric Power Generation; Spacecraft

Title: Calculation of nonsteady-state natural convection in a solar thermal-storage tank
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Affiliations: Bukhara Technological Inst of the, Food & Light Industries, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Radzhabov, N.K., Bukhara Technological Inst of the, Food & Light Industries, Russian Federation
Abstract: In this concept, a thermal storage tank installed in a greenhouse is filled with thermal storage material (TSM) with known thermal parameters. Considering the liquid TSM as a solid medium in order to determine the temperature field, one can solve a two-dimensional nonsteady state problem of natural convection in a rectangular space. A complete space of hydrodynamics equations was solved, including the Navier-Stokes movement equation and energy and continuity equations.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Convection; Tanks; Solar Thermal Storage Tanks; Greenhouses

Authors: Edrok A.G., Kompantseva G.A., Yudin A.P.
Title: Some problems in the further improvement of servicing and diagnosis of storage batteries
Authors with affiliations: Edrok, A.G.; Kompantseva, G.A.; Yudin, A.P.
Abstract: We attempt to formulate problems associated with improvement in servicing and diagnosis of storage batteries with consideration of the most interesting solutions of these problems in the patent literature. They include: development of instruments of simple construction for monitoring the state of storage batteries and their degree of charge; the development of indicators determining the working capability of SB, preferably based on modern miniature microprocessors; development of instruments for monitoring the temperature, density, and level of electrolyte; the development of devices for fast SB charging; the development of methods of storage-battery defectoscopy; development of techniques for more complete extraction of metallic lead from spent batteries.
Index Keywords: Computers, Microcomputer--Applications; Electric Batteries, Secondary; Energy Storage; Instruments; Lead and Alloys--Recovery; Defectoscopy; Indicators; Iron-Nickel Batteries; Lead-Acid Batteries; Nickel-Cadmium Batteries; Storage Batteries; Electric Batteries

Title: Liquid ice district cooling systems
Affiliations: Studsvik Energy Nykoping, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Margen, Peter, Studsvik Energy Nykoping, Sweden; Backman, Lennart, Studsvik Energy Nykoping, Sweden
Abstract: District cooling systems using chilled water extract heat cheaply at a central point due to economy of scale and more favourable sinks for heat rejection than those available for individual buildings. The system described in this article uses 'liquid ice', namely, a solution of a suitable substance such as a salt or sugar in water to form crystallization cores for ice formation at temperatures somewhat below 0°C (32°F). The mixture of ice crystals and liquid behaves like a liquid and can flow along pipes. It can therefore be used both as a cold transport medium and cold storage medium, with an energy capacity per unit volume which is a factor of 5 greater than that for chilled water. Therefore piping dimensions are much reduced and cold storage becomes economically feasible, allowing the cutting of daily and sometimes even seasonal cooling peaks by such stores and, to a large extent, concentration of heat pump operation to periods when lower off-peak electricity rates apply.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Pump Systems; Heat Sinks--Applications; Salts--Applications; Water Piping Systems; Distributed Storage; District Cooling Systems; Drilled Rock Heat Store; Energy Collector; Liquid Ice; Slush Ice; Air Conditioning

Title: Performance modeling of lead-acid batteries in photovoltaic applications
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chamberlin, Jay L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: A test of five lead-acid batteries of four generic types was conducted to determine the effectiveness of an energy storage subsystem model which consists of a lead-acid battery and its associated charge controller used in Sandia's PV systems simulation code PVFORM. While PVFORM accurately represented an adequately charged battery operating in a system with little excess array energy, considerable care was required in establishing the model's user-defined input parameters to describe the more typical performance of a battery when used with a controller that does not maximize the array's utilization. Causes for this poorer-than-expected battery performance are presented along with their impact on both system design and performance modeling.
Index Keywords: Photovoltaic Cells; Charge Controller; Lead-Acid Batteries; Software Package PVFORM; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Corrosion of high-density sintered tungsten alloys. Part 2. Accelerated corrosion testing
Authors with affiliations: Batten, J.J.; Moore, B.T.
Abstract: As a consequence of corrosion during long-term storage in uncontrolled environments, where high humidity may be combined with cyclic temperature changes, some high-density sintered tungsten penetrators have been found to be unreliable. The corrosion behaviour of four candidate alloys has been evaluated and compared with that of pure tungsten. Rates of corrosion during the Cyclic Humidity Test and the Salt Mist Test were ascertained from weight loss measurements. Insight into the corrosion mechanism was gained from the nature of the corrosion products and an examination of the corroded surfaces. In the tests, the alloy 95% W, 2.5% Ni, 1.5% Fe was the most corrosion resistant. The data showed that copper as an alloying element accelerates corrosion of tungsten alloys. Both attack on the tungsten particles and the binder phase were observed together with tungsten grain loss. The propensity of the above alloy to corrode when encapsulated and also when enclosed by its ammunition box was also evaluated. Conclusions and recommendations regarding the corrosion of tungsten alloy penetrators for use in ammunition are offered.
Index Keywords: Corrosion--Testing; Materials Testing--Corrosion; Ordnance; Powder Metallurgy--Tungsten; Tungsten Nickel Iron Alloys--Corrosion Resistance; Ammunition; Cyclic Humidity Test; Kinetic Energy Penetrators; Salt Mist Test; Tungsten Alloys; Tungsten and Alloys

Title: Evolution of coordinated control
Source title: Instrumentation, Control, and Automation in the Power Industry, Proceedings
Authors with affiliations: Gery, H.C.
Abstract: The concept of coordinated control began in the late 1950's as a means by which European designed once-through boilers could be adapted to American operating practice. The concern was that the perceived limited storage of once-through boilers could not respond to the rapid load swings needed to meet the tight control of area regulation and close frequency regulation that is the usual American operating practice. The concept of coordinated control was to keep the turbine and boiler operations together by providing them with a common demand signal. In this manner, the energy input to the boiler would be matched to the energy demanded by the turbine. Thus the expression 'Direct Energy Balance.' This article discusses the evolution of the coordinated control concept, and functions which this type of system performs.
Index Keywords: Boiler Control; Control Systems; Governors; Coordinated Control; Electric Power Plants

Authors: Unsworth J., Moroney C., Guy I., Osman P.
Title: Investigation of breakdown values and charge storage properties of P.V.D.F
Affiliations: Macquarie Univ, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Unsworth, J., Macquarie Univ, Aust; Moroney, C., Macquarie Univ, Aust; Guy, I., Macquarie Univ, Aust; Osman, P., Macquarie Univ, Aust
Abstract: The breakdown values and charge storge properties of thin-film PVDF (polyvinylidene fluoride) were investigated with a view to the possible manufacture of small volume, high-energy-density capacitors for use in medical implant devices. The dielectric breakdown fields of 3.5-μm- and 6-μm-thick films of PVDF have been measured using a field which increases linearly with time. The rate of rise of the electric field varied from 3 MV m-1 -s-1 to 1000 MV m-1 -s-1 at room temperature. Experiments were carried out both in air and silicon oil. For both film thicknesses, the breakdown fields show a maximum at a field rate of approximately 120 MV m-1 , the value being slightly higher for the thicker film. For rates both above and below this value, the observed breakdown field decreases. In oil the breakdown strength increases with increasing rate of field rise to approximately 140 MV m-1. At higher rates the breakdown strength remains constant. In oil, as in air, the breakdown strength is higher in the thicker film.
Index Keywords: Electric Breakdown; Insulating Oil; Breakdown Strength; Dielectric Breakdown; High-Energy-Density Capacitors; Medical Implant Devices; PVDF (Polyvinylidene Fluoride); Electric Insulating Materials

Authors: Coe James Q., Rankin Arthur W.
Title: California's adaptable model for operations planning for the State Water Project
Affiliations: California Dep of Water Resources, United States
Authors with affiliations: Coe, James Q., California Dep of Water Resources, United States; Rankin, Arthur W., California Dep of Water Resources, United States
Abstract: Operations of the California Aqueduct, a 440-mile-long feature of the State Water Project (SWP) consisting of canals, pipelines, reservoirs and hydroelectric plants, are planned using NEOSYS, a computerized mathematical model which employs state-of-the-art operations research techniques. NEOSYS simulates and optimizes the operation of five main SWP reservoirs on a monthly basis with detail for on-peak and off-peak periods. Optimization is performed by an incremental dynamic programming (IDP) component operating upon reservoir storages to minimize on-peak power cost. Feasible starting solutions are found for the IDP by a network flow programming (NFP) formulation. Simulation procedures are specific to the California Aqueduct facilities. For eight years, the California Department of Water Resources (CDWR) has used NEOSYS to optimize power and energy purchases and to allocate costs of operation to water contractors. Additional aspects of the subjects are discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Hydroelectric Power Plants; Operations Research--Applications; Water Resources--Management; Water Supply--California; California Aqueduct; Incremental Dynamic Programming; Network Flow Programming; Operations Planning; Software Package NEOSYS; State Water Project; Water Distribution Systems

Title: Effect of LEO cycling at shallow depths of discharge on MANTECH IPV nickel-hydrogen cells
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smithrick, John J., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: An individual pressure vessel nickel-hydrogen battery is being considered as an alternate for a nickel-cadmium battery on the Hubble Space Telescope. The space telescope battery will primarily be operating at a shallow depth of discharge (10 percent DOD) with an occasional 40 percent DOD. This shallow DOD raises several issues: (a) What is the cycle life? It is projected to be acceptable; however, there is no reported real time data base for validation. (b) The state of charge of the nickel electrode at the beginning of charge is 90 percent. Will this cause an acceleration of divergence in the battery individual cell voltages? (c) After prolonged cycling at 10 percent DOD, will there be enough capacity remaining to support the 40 percent DOD? (d) Is the state of charge really 90 percent during cycling? There is no reported real time data base at shallow depths of discharge. The purpose of this investigation was to initiate a data base to address the above issues.
Index Keywords: Database Systems; Energy Storage; Pressure Vessels; Spacecraft--Observatories; Telescopes--Aerospace Applications; Depth of Discharge; Hubble Space Telescope; Nickel-Cadmium Batteries; Nickel-Hydrogen Batteries; Electric Batteries

Authors: Hiew Kim L., Labadie John W., Scott John F.
Title: Optimal operational analysis of the Colorado-Big Thompson Project
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hiew, Kim L., Colorado State Univ, United States; Labadie, John W., Colorado State Univ, United States; Scott, John F., Colorado State Univ, United States
Abstract: The Northern Colorado Water Conservancy District is currently investigating the feasibility of constructing a major water storage project on the mainstem of the Poudre River for water supply and power generation purposes. With the addition of the Windy Gap Project for augmenting supplies to the Colorado-Big Thompson (C-BT) Project has come the need to reevaluate operating strategies for the C-BT system. This has focused attention on the possibility of operationally integrating the C-BT system and the proposed Poudre Project for thier mutual enhancement. In particular, the C-BT system could provide additional water for the proposed Poudre Project during periods of spill when available flows exceed C-BT demands. This study combines simulation and optimization techniques for determining how much water could reliably be made available for transfer to the proposed Poudre Project, while satisfying all C-BT water and energy requirements. Multiple regression techniques are applied to the results for determining optimal feedback decision policies for the C-BT system.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Hydroelectric Power Plants; Optimization; Rivers--Colorado; Water Resources--Management; Colorado-Big Thompson Project; Feedback Operating Policies; Multireservoir Systems; Northern Colorado Water Conservancy District; Operational Analysis; Reservoir Operation; Reservoirs

Authors: Bennett Timothy J., Lacy Dovie E.
Title: Advanced sensible heat solar receiver for space power
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, Timothy J., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States; Lacy, Dovie E., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: NASA Lewis through in-house efforts has begun a study to generate a conceptual design of a sensible heat solar receiver and to determine the feasibility of such a system for space power applications. The sensible heat solar receiver generated in this study uses pure lithium as the thermal storage media and was designed for a 7 kWe Brayton (PCS) operating at 1100 K. By nature of design, the sensible heat receiver generated in this study is comparable in both size and mass to a latent heat system of similar thermal capacitance. The heat receiver design and thermal analysis was conducted through the combined use of PATRAN, SINDA, TRASYS, and NASTRAN software packages.
Index Keywords: Computer Aided Design; Lithium and Alloys; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Heat Solar Receiver; Space Power; Thermal Storage; Solar Energy

Title: Thyristor generators for pulse excitation of electromagnets with direct supply from AC line
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Baginskii, B.A., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Braslavskii, G.D., Tomsk Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: Generators are described that produce unipolar current pulses in the windings of electromagnets. The generators are connected to a single-phase ac line without an intermediate rectifier or filter. The specifications are given for a generator for excitation of the electromagnet of a 35-MeV betatron. The energy stored in the electromagnet is 5.5 kJ; the degree of energy control is 10-100%. The maximum voltage and current of the electromagnet are 9.2 kV and 400 A; the current-pulse repetition frequency is 100 Hz.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Betatron - Magnets; Capacitors; Control, Electric Variables - Current; Electromagnets - Electric Power Supplies; Thyristors - Applications; Active Power Consumption; Circuit Analysis; Pulsed Energy Storage; Pulsed Excitation; Thyristor Current Pulse Generators; Unipolar Current Pulses; Pulse Generators

Title: Asymmetry in the charge injection of SIMOX interfaces.
Affiliations: Middlesex Polytechnic,, Microelectronics Cent, London, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Patel, C.J., Middlesex Polytechnic,, Microelectronics Cent, London, Engl; Butcher, J.B., Middlesex Polytechnic,, Microelectronics Cent, London, Engl
Abstract: The charge transport in the synthesized buried oxide of a SIMOX (separation by implantation of oxygen) structure shows deviation from the ideal Fowler-Nordheim dependence. An observed asymmetry of the injecting layers associated with the top and bottom Si/SiO2 interfaces is reported. This observation is compatible with optical measurements which reveal the presence of an intermediate layer (10-40-nm thick) at the interface between the buried oxide and the bulk silicon substrate. Sequential ramp I-V measurements show a large reservoir of positive charge trapping centers. Little is known about the spatial distribution of the centers and their dependence on the high-energy oxygen implantation parameters. The sequential ramping measurements demonstrate maximum charge storage capacity of the buried oxide. The electron injection from the cathode is enhanced at a relatively low average field, and the current levels are higher by several orders than those of thermal SiO2. This observation is compatible with silicon-rich-SiO2 injectors. The effective barrier heights are considerably lower than the thermal SiO2 barrier height. Also observed is a difference in the effective barrier heights at the top and bottom Si/SiO2 interfaces, which leads to asymmetry in charge injection.
Index Keywords: Semiconductor Devices, Charge Transfer; Charge Transport; Fowler-Nordheim Dependence; SIMOX (Separation by Implantation of Oxygen); SIMOX Interfaces; Summary Only; Semiconducting Silicon

Title: Charge storage and relaxation SrTiO3 and KTaO3 crystals
Affiliations: Moscow Inst of Electronics, Engineering, Moscow, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Gorokhovatsky, Y., Moscow Inst of Electronics, Engineering, Moscow, USSR; Sezonov, Y., Moscow Inst of Electronics, Engineering, Moscow, USSR
Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. Charge relaxation in SrTiO3 and KTaO3 single crystals was studied by the thermally stimulated depolarization (TSD) technique. TSD current measurements of the photo- and thermoelectret state in crystals showed the close relationship of high-temperature peaks to volume charge storage at hole capture centers. The energies of these centers were determined by fractional TSD techniques. The authors obtained three quasi-discrete levels with energies of 0.22, 0.25, and 0.43 eV, respectively, in KTaO3. In the case of SrTiO3 only one quasi-discrete level with energy of 0.56 eV was determined, but a number of levels with continuous energy distribution in the rage of 0.15-0.22 eV were found.
Index Keywords: Crystals--Physical Properties; Abstract Only; Charge Relaxation; Charge Storage; Single Crystals; Thermally Stimulated Depolarization; Electrets

Authors: McDonald K.F., Mayerchak M.A., DeHart T.E., Hedeen P.F., Kimball W.S., Hoffman A.L.
Title: Design verification of the ignitron-switched energy storage modules for the LSX FRC device
Affiliations: Spectra Technology Inc, Bellevue,, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: McDonald, K.F., Spectra Technology Inc, Bellevue,, WA, USA; Mayerchak, M.A., Spectra Technology Inc, Bellevue,, WA, USA; DeHart, T.E., Spectra Technology Inc, Bellevue,, WA, USA; Hedeen, P.F., Spectra Technology Inc, Bellevue,, WA, USA; Kimball, W.S., Spectra Technology Inc, Bellevue,, WA, USA; Hoffman, A.L., Spectra Technology Inc, Bellevue,, WA, USA
Abstract: LSX is a field-reversed-configuration (FRC) theta-pinch device designed to use a modular ±25-kV energy storage system and switched by 380 ignitrons. Each energy storage module will utilize four series type-D start switches and four series type-D crowbar switches. In all, 38 such energy storage modules will deliver 1.7 MJ of stored energy to a single-turn magnet load at a peak current of 3.4 MA. A design verification test (DVT) has been conducted on a single module of the 38-module energy storage system, documenting the feasibility of using ignitron switching. Subjects addressed include coulomb-lifetime data, voltage holdoff, turn-on delay and jitter, and some factors affecting these topics such as triggering, conditioning, and ignitron thermal control. Both type-A and type-D switches were tested, using samples from both known sources. In addition, testing was done to confirm the module configuration, buswork, connectors, cabling, components, and characteristic waveforms.
Index Keywords: Electric Switches; Magnetic Fields; Abstract Only; Crowbar Switches; Energy Storage Modules; Field Reversed Configuration; Theta Pinch Devices; Plasmas

Authors: Buchenkov V.A., Vinokurov G.H., Malinin B.G., Fromzel V.A., Shumilin V.V.
Title: Energy storage and release in a multielement laser
Source title: Bulletin of the Academy of Sciences of the U.S.S.R. Physical series
Authors with affiliations: Buchenkov, V.A.; Vinokurov, G.H.; Malinin, B.G.; Fromzel, V.A.; Shumilin, V.V.
Abstract: We have examined pumping performance in a laser having several active elements; we determined the performance on the stored energy from the small-signal gain and the stored-energy recovery in the amplifying stage with the single or double path, which we compared with numerical calculations, where neodymium phosphate glasses were used. Calculations were performed for two-pass and four-pass amplification and for various losses in the amplifier in order to elucidate the reasons for the low stored-energy efficiency. Successive approximation was used.
Index Keywords: Glass; Mathematical Techniques--Numerical Analysis; Neodymium Compounds; Energy Storage; Multielement Systems; Neodymium Phosphate; Lasers, Solid State

Authors: Klein Ronald J., Heimburger Stanley A.
Title: Hydrogen peroxide optimization in short sequence bleaching
Source title: Pulping Conference, Proceedings of the Technical Association of the Pulp and Paper Industry
Affiliations: FMC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klein, Ronald J., FMC, United States; Heimburger, Stanley A., FMC, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen peroxide in combination with other oxidizing chemicals in the E1 stage can have an additive effect on delignification. This can be used to decrease the number of bleaching stages and lower capital and energy requirements. Alternatively hydrogen peroxide can be used in a terminal stage or high density storage to achieve brightness and brightness stability. A comparison of costs and pulp quality is presented. Studies were conducted to optimize pulp brightness, brightness stability, viscosity, and chemical efficiency in each peroxide stage as well as the overall bleach plant. Four stages, brightness values of 91% ISO were obtained, brightness reversion was reduced from four to two points, and final pulp viscosity was 0.5 points higher. In addition the use of H2O2 to reduce bleach plant effluent color by over 50% is also examined. A process is proposed for recycle of residual peroxide. Recycle to the E1 stage can achieve the benefits of an (EOP) stage without additional chemical cost.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen Peroxide--Recycling; Paper and Pulp Mills--Costs; Pulp--Kraft; Wastewater--Color Removal; Bleach Plant Effluent Color; Bleaching Optimization; Brightness Stability; Peroxide Use Optimization; Pulp Brightness Optimization; Short Sequence Bleaching; Pulp Manufacture

Abstract: The volume contains ten papers presented at the meeting. Subjects covered include packed bed energy storage systems, exergy and surface requirements for heat transfer processes involving binary mixtures, performance evaluation of combustion gas turbine cogeneration systems, entropy generation in heat exchanger networks, solar radiation conversion thermodynamics, and others.

Authors: Sasagawa Teruo, Kawahara Akihiro, Obara Minoru
Title: Diffuse discharge interruption induced by ArF/KrF lasers in pure N2 gas
Affiliations: Keio Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Yokohama, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Sasagawa, Teruo, Keio Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Yokohama, Jpn; Kawahara, Akihiro, Keio Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Yokohama, Jpn; Obara, Minoru, Keio Univ, Dep of Electrical, Engineering, Yokohama, Jpn
Abstract: A laser-controlled diffuse discharge opening switch will be useful for inductive energy storage (IES) systems at high repetition rates in the future. The authors have observed the complete discharge interruption induced by an excimer laser in pure N2 of a few torr, using a discharge tube with cylindrical electrodes. With an ArF laser of 27 mJ/cm2 (10 ns, FWHM) and an N2 pressure of 1.0 torr, a sustaining discharge current of 1.1 mA (0.156 mA/cm2) was interrupted completely, and the maximum current delay rate of 770 A/s was observed at a discharge current of 0.75 mA. The discharge interruption depended on the laser wavelength. A discharge current over 0.27 mA could not be interrupted by 27 mJ/cm2 (20 ns, FWHM) of KrF laser irradiation, and the discharge current was not affected at all by an XeF laser irradiation. The discharge interruption strongly depended on the laser fluence, the N2 pressure, and the discharge current.
Index Keywords: Electric Switches; Lasers, Excimer; Nitrogen--Electric Breakdown; Abstract Only; Cylindrical Electrodes; Inductive Energy Storage; Electric Discharges

Title: Tuned energy storage for solid state transmitters
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electr Corp, Baltimore,, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Morse, Alfred W., Westinghouse Electr Corp, Baltimore,, MD, USA
Abstract: The author outlines the theory and application of tuned energy storage, which provides a substantial weight saving for solid-state transmitters by greatly reducing the energy storage requirements. A reactive network is used for energy storage and operates in conjunction with the RF amplifier to produce the proper effective operating voltage while also compensating for capacitor droop. Computer analysis and optimization are used to obtain a maximally flat pulse plateau, with minimum capacitor weight. Several hardware implementations show excellent agreement between theory and results, such as a pair of 600-A networks operating inside an ultralightweight 18-kW solid-state UHF power module. This circuit achieves a 7:1 reduction in capacitance and a 5:1 reduction in weight compared with previous capacitive storage equipment.
Index Keywords: Radio Transmitters; Solid State Devices; Capacitive Storage Equipment; Solid State Transmitters; Tuned Energy Storage; UHF Power Module; Weight Saving; Radar Transmitters

Authors: Liu K.V., Choi U.S., Kasza K.E.
Title: Pressure drop and heat transfer characteristics of nearly neutrally buoyant particulate slurry for advanced energy transmission fluids
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Fluids Engineering Division (Publication) FED
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, K.V., Argonne Natl Lab, United States; Choi, U.S., Argonne Natl Lab, United States; Kasza, K.E., Argonne Natl Lab, United States
Abstract: Under sponsorship of the U.S. Department of Energy, Argonne National Laboratory is developing high-performance energy transmission fluids that have the potential to substantially reduce frictional losses and improve heat transfer in a variety of thermal systems, and thus to allow the use of smaller piping, pumps, heat exchangers, and storage tanks. This paper presents experimental results and discusses the pressure drop and heat transfer characteristics of non-melting slurry flows. The experimental data obtained in this study improve the fundamental understanding of slurry fluid mechanics and heat transfer, and provide support for the use of slurries as advanced energy transmission fluids in thermal system applications.

Title: Optical processing applications of the photorefractive effect
Affiliations: Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Klein, M.B., Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA
Abstract: Photorefractive materials have been used for a wide variety of optical processing applications based on degenerate four-wave mixing (DFWM). In this talk we review recent applications, as well as advances in materials technology. In addition, we compare the performance of devices based on DFWM in photorefractive materials with bistable etalons and MQW devices which can perform similar functions. Performance parameters to be considered include resolution, response time and writing/switching energy.

Affiliations: Univ of Southern California, Los, Angeles, CA, USA

Abstract: The frequency response function of various magneto-optic materials has been measured. Write frequency and incident laser energy were varied parametrically. The envelope (upper bound) of these frequency response functions is monotonically increasing with incident energy. However, the response function at fixed frequency may be convex with increasing incident energy.

Authors with affiliations: Bruesselbach, H., Hughes Research Lab, Malibu, CA, USA
Abstract: Transverse depumping limits the gain and stored energy for neodymium-doped materials in pump cavities employing samarium-doped filters. Formerly, approx. 75% filter transmission, limiting longitudinal gain to approx. 10 dB for 1/4 ″×3″ Nd:YAG rods, was thought adequate. We report increased samarium filter thickness allowed 23 dB gain, 982 mJ stored energy, for this size rod.

Authors: Bordovsky James P., Lyle William M.
Title: Cotton Response to high frequency irrigation
Affiliations: Texas Agricultural Experiment, Station, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bordovsky, James P., Texas Agricultural Experiment, Station, United States; Lyle, William M., Texas Agricultural Experiment, Station, United States
Abstract: Three cotton production tests irrigated with the Low Energy Precision Application (LEPA) system were conducted from 1985 through 1987 on the Texas High Plains. Cotton treatments were irrigated at intervals ranging from 2 to 18 days. Irrigation amounts varied from 0.4 to 1.4 times estimated evapotranspiration (ET) at each irrigated frequency. Lint yields varied from 412 to 1769 kg/ha per year over the three-year period. Irrigation intervals of 2 to 4 days at 0.4 to 0.7 times estimated ET produced the highest yields under normal High Plains conditions. High frequency irrigation promoted early development of cotton plants as indicated by leaf area, total dry matter and storage organ weight data.
Index Keywords: Agronomy; Irrigation; Cotton Plant Development; Evapotranspiration; High Frequency Irrigation; Lint Yields; Low Energy Precision Application System; Cotton

Title: Quasi-resonant Cuk DC-to-DC converter employs integrated magnetics. Part I
Affiliations: California Inst of Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cuk, Slobodan, California Inst of Technology, United States; Maksimovic, Dragan, California Inst of Technology, United States
Abstract: A high frequency, integrated magnetics, quasi-resonant Cuk converter is described. It reduces the size and weight of energy storage components and exhibits extremely low input and output voltage ripple. The theory behind this technology is outlined in this part.
Index Keywords: Magnetic Devices; Cuk Converter; DC-To-DC Converter; High-Efficiency Converters; Integrated Magnetics; Voltage Ripple; Electric Converters, Static

Title: IEEE conference record of the 1988 eighteenth power modulator symposium
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The following topics are dealt with: solid-state modulators; megavolt modulators; thyratron modulators; magnetic modulators; regulation/power supplies; high-current ignitrons; thyratron testing; hollow-cathode crossatrons; solid-state switches; transformers and magnetics; and capacitive energy storage.
