Title: Fast-opening vacuum switches for high-power inductive energy storage
Affiliations: US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cooperstein, Gerald, US Naval Research Lab, Washington,, DC, USA
Abstract: Opening switch technology, which generally involves the use of plasmas as the switching medium, is discussed. Results of research efforts in this area are outlined. The role of theoretical research, coupled with recent plasma diagnostic measurements, in providing breakthroughs in opening switch operation is underscored.
Index Keywords: Electric Switches; Plasmas--Diagnostics; Abstract Only; Inductive Energy Storage; Opening Switch Technology; Plasma Devices

Title: Use of a modified finite element method for CFD applications
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Fluids Engineering Division (Publication) FED
Affiliations: Marquardt Company, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pepper, D.W., Marquardt Company, United States; Russell, P.K., Marquardt Company, United States
Abstract: A modified finite element method is used to solve the governing equations for incompressible fluid motion and energy. The time-dependent primitive equations are solved sequentially using explicit time marching. Equal order basis functions are used for velocity, temperature, and pressure. The pressure distribution is calculated from the discretized momentum equations. Velocities are adjusted via a simple Poisson equation to ensure mass consistency. Mass lumping of the time-dependent matrix and one-point quadrature are used to reduce computational storage and enhance speed. In high Reynolds number flows, the Balancing Tensor Diffusivity technique is utilized. The method appears applicable for small computers; problems requiring several thousand nodes can be solved on (enhanced) personal computers.
Index Keywords: Flow of Fluids; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method; Temperature Distribution; Balancing Tensor Diffusivity Technique; Computational Fluid Dynamics; Fluid Flow; Modified Finite Element Methods; Pressure Distribution; Fluid Dynamics

Title: Development of a component sizing optimization model for wind diesel system design
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: AeroVironment Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zambrano, T., AeroVironment Inc, United States; Lindberg, D., AeroVironment Inc, United States
Abstract: A computer code has been developed that determines for a site's wind energy resources, load requirements and economic constraints, the components and sizes for a wind/diesel system that results in the lowest cost of energy. In the context of this code, wind/diesel systems are defined as electricity generation stations in the 50 kilowatt (kW) to one megawatt (MW) range that (a) are not connected to another electricity network, (b) use wind energy as the first source of supply to meet demand, and (c) contain sufficient energy storage and/or backup diesel electric generators to compensate for lapses in wind energy. This computer code also determines for the same input load requirements and economics the best number and size for an isolated diesel-only system so that comparisons of wind/diesel systems and diesel-only systems can be made.
Index Keywords: Computer Software; Diesel Engines; Power Generation--Equipment; Component Sizing Optimization Model; Software Package SOLSTOR; Wind Diesel System Design; Wind Turbines

Authors: Verkhovskii S.Ya., Egorov V.P., Tolstenev A.G., Flat F.A.
Title: Regulated pump-lamp supply for pulsed solid-state laser
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Verkhovskii, S.Ya., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Egorov, V.P., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Tolstenev, A.G., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Flat, F.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: A pump-lamp supply is described that ensures a spread of laser radiation energy on the order of tenths of a percent from pulse to pulse. The supply contains a capacitive storage device, a charging device, a thyristor commutator, and radiofrequency keep-alive supplies. The energy of a laser-radiation pulse is ≈3 J, and the pulse repetition frequency is ≈1 Hz.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Signal; Lasers, Solid State - Optical Pumping; Optical Pumping - Electric Power Supplies; Thyristors; Charging Devices; Laser Beam Deposition; Pulse Repetition Frequency; Pulsed Laser Radiation; Regulated Pump Lamp Supplies; Electronic Circuits, Power Supply

Title: Aerospace methodology applied to development of an advanced powered mobility system
Source title: IEEE/Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society Annual Conference
Affiliations: NASA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Fedor, Otto H., NASA, USA
Abstract: NASA investigated the use of an advanced power train for use in a powered wheel chair and patient support systems to accommodate a wide range of patient trauma. The author discusses how the use of aerospace technology to replace the automotive electric storage battery with a small, lightweight and rugged power unit resulted in a design concept which has surplus hydraulic power to erect the occupant to an upright position, to climb stairs or ramps, operate a small robotic arm and energize a lumbar massage and ripple cushion. The approach differs from conventional engineering in that it emphasizes the full use of material and component capabilities by pushing the state of the art to the limit. A system approach is used to satisfy the operational requirements. There is emphasis on systems assurance, including reliability, safety, maintainability and life-cycle costs. Human engineering aspects are integrated in the design.
Index Keywords: Human Rehabilitation Engineering; Propulsion--Hydraulic Energy; Robotics; Advanced Powered Mobility System; Lumbar Massage; Robotic Arm; Biomedical Equipment

Authors: Rix W., Thompson J., Shannon J., Davis P., Ware K.
Title: Operation and empirical modeling of the plasma erosion switch
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rix, W., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Thompson, J., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Shannon, J., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Davis, P., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA; Ware, K., Maxwell Lab Inc, San Diego, CA, USA
Abstract: Plasma erosion opening switch (PEOS) experiments have been conducted on both the DNA Blackjack 5 and ACE accelerators. On Blackjack 5 one of the switch geometries tested increased the value of dI/dt delivered to a ring e-beam load by a factor of five to a value of 2 × 1014 A/s. Bremsstrahlung radiation pulse shapes indicate a power pulse compression of greater than a factor of two. Work on the ACE accelerator has demonstrated the capability of the PEOS to perform as a final opening switch in an inductive energy storage system. Both experiments allow comparison of switch operation over three distinct switch-conduction-time regimes: 50 to 100 ns for Blackjack 5, 200 to 400 ns for a fuse-driven configuration on ACE, and 500 to 2000 ns for a capacitor-bank-driven configuration on ACE. The data have been compared with the predictions of a plasma erosion and an ion piston switch model.
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Capacitors; Electric Switches; Erosion; Abstract Only; Bremsstrahlung Radiation; Plasma Erosion Opening Switches; Plasma Devices

Authors: Ivanov A.M., Vyboishikov F.P., Misevich B.S., Tsvetkova L.V.
Title: Heat accumulator for electric car heating
Authors with affiliations: Ivanov, A.M.; Vyboishikov, F.P.; Misevich, B.S.; Tsvetkova, L.V.
Abstract: The operation of thermal accumulators is based on the effect of liberation of heat during crystallization of substances. The thermal accumulators are ecologically clean, devoid of thermal inertia, require no servicing, and are not expensive to produce or operate. They can provide heat while the vehicle is stopped. A mixture containing 98% lithium nitrate and 2% lithium carbonate most fully meets the requirements. This mixture was used in the experiments. The experimental setup contained 9 kg of heat-storage substance. The thermal energy stored (in terms of the latent heat of fusion) came to about 3340 kJ. Energy reserves comes to about 3.5 h.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heating--Heat Storage; Lithium Compounds; Storage Battery Vehicles--Heating; Vehicles--Heating; Crystallization; Electric Vehicles; Electromobiles; Lithium Carbonate; Lithium Nitrate; Thermal Accumulators; Automobiles

Authors: McDonald D.J., Dollinger R., Sarjeant W.J.
Title: Method of characterizing high energy density capacitors for power conditioning systems
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: State Univ of New York, Dep of, Electr & Comput Eng, Buffalo,, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: McDonald, D.J., State Univ of New York, Dep of, Electr & Comput Eng, Buffalo,, NY, USA; Dollinger, R., State Univ of New York, Dep of, Electr & Comput Eng, Buffalo,, NY, USA; Sarjeant, W.J., State Univ of New York, Dep of, Electr & Comput Eng, Buffalo,, NY, USA
Abstract: An effort was made to develop methods for characterizing CDL (chemical double layer) capacitors in terms of percent energy transfer to a resistive load as well as energy density packaging capabilities. A novel soft charging method, in contrast to constant-voltage charging, was developed to increase the energy density by approximately 1600% of the CDL capacitors' rated value. This method consists of slowly increasing the terminal voltage to approximately four times its rated value, achieving energy densities on the order of 4.5 kJ/kg (with case) and 6.5 kJ/kg (without case) for a life of several days. The capacitor studied showed promise in DC storage applications where high energy densities are required for relatively long discharge times.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Electric Equipment; CDL (Chemical Double Layer) Capacitors; Energy Transfer; High Energy Density Capacitors; Power Conditioning; Soft Charging Method; Capacitors

Title: Power conditioning system for a electromagnetic launcher
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Jasper Jr., Louis J., LABCOM, Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA
Abstract: A power conditioning system for a electromagnetic (EM) launcher is described that uses both low-voltage (100 V) and high-voltage (3000 V) capacitive storage and semiconductor opening/closing switches. The operating voltage is 3 kV with 500-kA peak current available for the load. The energy per pulse delivered to the EM launcher is 600 kJ per pulse for a three-round burst with 20-s downtime between bursts. Weight and volume estimates are given for the various components of the system that are available today or would be available in a 1-3 yr time frame having a low-to-medium risk developmental effort. Midterm (3-5 yr) and far-term (5-10 yr) weight/volume projections are given for the components. A system that weighs less 1.0 ton and has a volume of about 60 ft3 is considered feasible. This includes rough estimates of the peripheral equipment such as safety, diagnostic, and cooling equipment, as well as cable, pipes, and connectors.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic Pulse; Electromagnetism; Semiconductor Devices--Switching; Capacitive Storage; Electromagnetic Launcher; Power Conditioning; Semiconductor Opening; Weight/Volume Projections; Electric Equipment

Title: Microwave power beaming from earth-to-space
Affiliations: Lockheed Research Lab, Palo Alto,, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gregorwich, Walt S., Lockheed Research Lab, Palo Alto,, CA, USA
Abstract: The author presents an overview of the potential and limitations of microwave power transfer. In addition, he reviews state-of-the-art technology and the required hardware to implement such a system. Tradeoffs among frequency selection, atmospheric effects, orbital geometry and energy storage are discussed. Present hardware capabilities of ground station antennas, microwave power sources, and spacecraft receiving antennas such as large unfurlable and space erectable dishes, deployable rectennas, and tethered systems are also reviewed. It is concluded that on the basis of present technology, the efficient transfer of microwave power from earth to a low-orbiting satellite is feasible.
Index Keywords: Antennas; Microwave Generation; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Technological Forecasting; Deployable Rectennas; Earth/Space Microwave Power Beaming; Microwave Frequency Selection; Spacecraft Receiving Antennas; Tethered Systems; Electric Power Transmission

Title: Low Temperature Biotechnology: Emerging Applications and Engineering Contributions
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Bioengineering Division (Publication) BED
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 19 papers, grouped under three sections: the introduction, emerging applications; and engineering contributions. Some of the topics discussed are the following: the nature of cryobiological problems; cryopreservation of islets of Langerhans for transplantation; plant cryobiology: cellular and molecular aspects of freezing injury and cold acclimation; cryosurgery: new developments in understanding and technique; freeze tolerance and adaptation to low temperature in insects and frogs; cryopreserved tissues for transplant; storage in the undercooled state; vitrification; low temperature molecular distillation drying of cryofixed biological samples; cryofixation methods for electron microscopy; osmotic behavior of cells during freezing and thawing; the equations for modelling heat and mass transfer during freezing of biological tissue; energy-based network modelling for cryobiology; and osmotic dehydration in food science: review and future directions.
Index Keywords: Biomedical Engineering--Cryosurgery; Biotechnology; Glycerol; Osmosis; Physical Chemistry; Cryobiology; Cryopreservation; Cryoprobe; Cryoprotectants; Dimethyl Sulfoxide; EIREV; Biological Materials

Title: Alkaline fuel cell performance investigation
Affiliations: Int Fuel Cells Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Martin, R.E., Int Fuel Cells Corp, United States; Manzo, M.A., Int Fuel Cells Corp, United States
Abstract: An exploratory experimental fuel cell test program was conducted to investigate the performance characteristics of alkaline laboratory research electrodes. The objective of the work was to establish the effect of temperature, pressure, and concentration upon performance and evaluate candidate cathode configurations having the potential for improved performance. The performance characterization tests provided data to empirically establish the effect of temperature, pressure, and concentration upon performance for cell temperatures up to 300°F and reactant pressures up to 200 psia. Evaluation of five gold alloy cathode catalysts revealed that three doped gold alloys had more than two times the surface area of reference cathodes and therefore offered the best potential for improved performance.
Index Keywords: Catalysts; Cathodes; Gold and Alloys; Satellites--Energy Storage; Spacecraft--Power Supply; Alkaline Fuel Cells; Doped Gold Alloys; Gold Platinum Cathode Catalysts; Orbiter-Type Fuel Cells; Fuel Cells

Authors: Friedman S., Limpaecher R., Sirchis M.
Title: Compact energy storage using a modified-spiral PFL
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Avco Research Lab Inc, Everett, MA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Friedman, S., Avco Research Lab Inc, Everett, MA,, USA; Limpaecher, R., Avco Research Lab Inc, Everett, MA,, USA; Sirchis, M., Avco Research Lab Inc, Everett, MA,, USA
Abstract: The pulse length available from a coaxial PFL (pulse-forming line) of given length and dielectric constant has been doubled using a modified spiral technique. The modified spiral consists of a cylinder formed from a large number of insulated cables which are first laid parallel to the PFL axis and then given a moderate twist. The PFL is essentially a helical delay line in a form which accomplishes substantial pulse stretching without introducing significant turn-to-turn voltage gradients or distortion of the pulse shape. The technique can be used to increase the energy stored per unit length for a PFL of fixed impedance and pulse duration.
Index Keywords: Dielectric Devices; Electric Cables; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Shaping; Pulse Generators; Dielectric Constant; Helical Delay Line; Modified Spiral Technique; PFL (Pulse-Forming Line); Pulse Stretching; Electric Delay Lines

Title: 1 mv repetition-rated modulator
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rust, Ken, Los Alamos Natl Lab, NM, USA
Abstract: The design of a 1-MV, repetition-rated modulator capable of switching 20 kJ into an 80-Ω load is presented. The design utilizes two recently developed 100-kV hollow-anode thyratrons to discharge four parallel lumped-constant Blumleins composed of two 1.0-2.0-Ω, 6-stage, type E pulse-forming networks (PFNs). The Blumleins are to be command-resonantly charged from a capacitive energy storage bank to 100 kV and then discharged through a 10:1 step-up iron core transformer to 1 MV. The primary switch thyratrons in the modulator must be able to hold off 100 kV and conduct currents up to 200 kA with a di/dt approaching 1012 A/s total. Preliminary work has shown that the main switch tube, with PFNs, and the command charge circuits perform satisfactorily at half their rated values (50 kV).
Index Keywords: Electron Tubes, Thyratron; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Shaping; Blumleins; Capacitive Energy Storage Bank; Hollow-Anode Thyratrons; Repetition-Rated Modulator; Type E Pulse-Forming Networks; Modulators

Authors: Bugaev S.P., Volkov A.M., Iskoldsky A.M., Kim A.A., Kovalchuk B.M., Kokshenev V.A., Mesyats G.A., Novikov A.A., Yakovlev V.P.
Title: Terawatt pulsed power generator with plasma opening switch
Affiliations: USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Bugaev, S.P., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Volkov, A.M., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Iskoldsky, A.M., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Kim, A.A., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Kovalchuk, B.M., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Kokshenev, V.A., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Mesyats, G.A., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Novikov, A.A., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR; Yakovlev, V.P., USSR Acad of Science, High Current, Electronics Inst, Tomsk, USSR
Abstract: GIT-4 (SNOP4) has been developed using pulsed-power generators with intermediate energy storage and the plasma opening switch. GIT-4 has a primary capacitive energy storage with thirty-six parallel Marx generators located in four oil-filled tanks containing nine generators each. The energy from the Marx generators is transferred to the vacuum insulator through four oil-insulated lines. The intermediate inductive energy storage as well as the plasma opening switch and the load are located in a vacuum chamber of the generator. The discharge circuit has a 4.8-μF capacitance in the primary store and a 0.2-μH inductance in the intermediate store. At 40-80-kV charging voltage the energy in the primary store is 0.54-2.16 MJ, the output voltage is 480-960 kV, and the current rises to 2.35-4.7 MA in 1.54 μs. GIT-4 is being tested with current levels up to 2 MA. The output power of approximately 1.6 TW and voltage of approximately 1.2 MV are achieved at a charging voltage of 40 kV.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Generation; Electric Switches; Pulse Generators; Abstract Only; Marx Generators; Plasma Opening Switches; Pulsed Power Generators; Plasma Devices

Title: Withdrawal of wasted energy from engine by adsorption (part 1)
Source title: Memoirs of the Faculty of Engineering, Osaka City University
Affiliations: Osaka City Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Akiyama, Sadao, Osaka City Univ, Japan
Abstract: The withdrawal of wasted thermal energy from an engine is one of the better methods to heighten total thermal efficiency. In the small size engine for automobile use, withdrawal energy from exhaust gas is not enough to heighten the output power. The storage of withdrawal energy is most suitable for small size engines. The adopted method is the desorption of silica gel. Experimental research was done to inspect the effect of heat capacity versus desorption temperature and time. As this adsorption is completed in a few minutes, this method of wasted energy withdrawal is expected to be realized.
Index Keywords: Gases--Adsorption; Heat Sinks; Silica Gel--Applications; Desorption; Heat Storage; Thermal Efficiency; Wasted Energy; Automobile Engines

Authors: Tattersall J.Matthew, Mingrone Joseph A., King Peter C.
Title: VCR based digital data recorder for underwater acoustics multipath measurements
Affiliations: US Naval Underwater Syst Cent, New, London, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tattersall, J.Matthew, US Naval Underwater Syst Cent, New, London, CT, USA; Mingrone, Joseph A., US Naval Underwater Syst Cent, New, London, CT, USA; King, Peter C., US Naval Underwater Syst Cent, New, London, CT, USA
Abstract: Summary form only given. A family of multichannel underwater acoustic data acquisition systems which were deployed to the ocean floor and which utilize video cassette recorders (VCRs) as a digital data storage medium have been developed. One of these systems, the Acoustic Transient Recording Buoy (ATRB), was used recently as part of an ocean boundary interaction acoustic measurement program. Explosive SUS charges were used as a source of transient high-energy wideband acoustic signals and the direct, surface, and bottom-interacting multipath arrivals from the detonation of these charges were recorded by the bottom-moored ATRB system. Acoustic data obtained from the first two deployments of ATRB are of very high quality, with wider bandwidth and dynamic range than data sets acquired during earlier experiments using analog recording methods.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Data Acquisition; Data Storage, Digital; Acoustic Data Acquisition; Digital Data Recorder; Multipath Measurement; Summary Form Only; Video Cassette Recorders; Acoustics, Underwater

Title: Storage requirements in the design of hybrid, wind/PV, systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States
Authors with affiliations: Swift, A., Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States; Dominquez, H., Univ of Texas at El Paso, United States
Abstract: Previous simulation work has shown that the addition of wind turbine capacity to a remote photovoltaic power system can, in most cases, lower the cost of delivered energy. This is due to both the decreased PV capacity required, and also the reduced storage requirements in a hybrid system. A discussion is presented of the effects of storage requirements on system design using both TMY and actual site date from El Paso, Texas.
Index Keywords: Power Generation--Solar Energy; Abstract Form Only; Hybrid Systems; Storage Requirements; Wind Turbines

Title: Charge storage and charge decay in silicon dioxide
Source title: Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena (CEIDP), Annual Report
Affiliations: Inst for Electroacoustics, Tech Univ of Darmstadt, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Gunther, P., Inst for Electroacoustics, Tech Univ of Darmstadt, West Ger; Sessler, G.M., Inst for Electroacoustics, Tech Univ of Darmstadt, West Ger
Abstract: SiO2 layers with thicknesses between 150 nm and 2.5 μm were either thermally grown or made by chemical vapor deposition on 2-inch p-type silicon wafers. Positive or negative charging of the samples was performed by means of liquid-contact, corona, and electron-beam methods. The decay of the surface potential was observed isothermally at room temperature and at 350°C or by a thermally stimulated discharge (TSD) method linearly increasing temperature. In the isothermal measurements, positively charged samples showed a somewhat faster decay than negatively charged ones. The decays can be interpreted with a simple theory based on carrier drift and compensation by conductivity. TSD peaks of negatively charged material occur at higher temperatures than those of positively charged samples. Activation energies of 1.0 and 1.4 eV for positively charged oxides and 1.9 eV for negatively-charged oxides were found.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Semiconductor Device Manufacture; Charge Decay; Charged Oxides; Silicon Dioxide; Silicon Wafers; Thermally Stimulated Discharege; Semiconducting Silicon Compounds

Title: Transformation from bond-graphs to system-graphs
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Dynamic Systems and Control Division (Publication) DSC
Affiliations: CEN, France
Authors with affiliations: Maschke, B.M., CEN, France
Abstract: A purely graphical transformation is presented of a Bond Graph, an energy-based network model used in Physical System Theory, into the associated System-Graph, an algebraic representation used in Nonlinear Control Theory. Based on a generalization of the concept of direct causal connection, the transformation extracts first the Causal Walk Graph associated with the generalized causal walk between storage elements. In a second step, the System-Graph is deduced by edge transitivity from the Causal Walk Graph. Using this transformation and some existing results of Control Theory provide one with a very fast procedure for determining graphically the generic nonlinear input-output characteristics of physical systems.
Index Keywords: Control Systems; Mathematical Transformations; Bond Graphs; Causal Walk Graph; Control Theory; Mathematical Techniques

Authors: Cals M.P., Marque J.P., Alquie C.
Title: Determination of the charge distribution within an e-irradiated dielectric using the pressure wave propagation method
Affiliations: Natl d'Etudes et de Recherches, Aerospatiales, Chatillon, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Cals, M.P., Natl d'Etudes et de Recherches, Aerospatiales, Chatillon, Fr; Marque, J.P., Natl d'Etudes et de Recherches, Aerospatiales, Chatillon, Fr; Alquie, C., Natl d'Etudes et de Recherches, Aerospatiales, Chatillon, Fr
Abstract: The pressure wave propagation (PWP) method is used to investigate charge storage in Teflon FEP films irradiated with a monoenergetic electron beam in a vacuum. Signals obtained at different time intervals during charging of the material up to -7 kV are presented and analyzed. The PWP method clearly shows the incident electrons trapped near the surface and positive charges injected at the opposite metal-polymer interface. These charges remain trapped after a surface discharge. However, the buried electrons disappear. A numerical treatment leads to an improved determination of the charge distribution throughout the sample and gives the value of the mean depth of penetration versus the beam energy.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Electromagnetic Waves--Propagation; Electrons; Plastics--Films; Pressure Effects; Charge Distribution; Metal-Polymer Interface; Monoenergetic Electron Beams; Pressure Wave Propagation; Teflon FEP Films; Dielectric Materials

Authors: Thullen P., Schoenberg K.F., DiMarco J.N.
Title: Status of the design and construction of the CPRF and the ZTH reversed field pinch experiment
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thullen, P., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; Schoenberg, K.F., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA; DiMarco, J.N., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Abstract: The Confinement Physics Research Facility (CPRF) and the first experimental device to be tested in it, the ZTH reversed field pinch, are being designed and constructed by the Los Alamos National Laboratory. The CPRF and ZTH will be completed in the last quarter of 1992, with a capability for operation of ZTH at 2-MA plasma current. The CPRF is designed to allow operation of ATH at 4-MA plasma current following alteration of the ZTH structure and torus and installation of additional power supplies. At this time, site preparation is under way, the energy storage generator has been procured and delivered to the site, the power conversion equipment has been defined, magnet coils are being procured, and detailed design of the ZTH torus and structure is under way.
Index Keywords: Electric Coils; Magnetic Devices; Abstract Only; Power Supplies; Reversed Field Pinch; ZTH Torus; Plasmas

Title: 10 mw GTO converter for battery peaking service
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Gen Electr Co, Salem, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Walker, Loren H., Gen Electr Co, Salem, VA, USA
Abstract: The description is given of a bidirectional 18-pulse voltage source converter utilizing gate turn-off thyristors (GTOs). The converter, which is rated at 10 MVA, has been placed in service to connect an energy storage battery to a utility grid. The converter is rated and controlled to operate in all four quadrants, (discharge, charge, leading vars, or lagging vars) at the full 10-MVA rating. It is capable of independent, rapid control of real and reactive power with a transient response of 16 ms to changes in commanded value of real or reactive power. Thus it is usable as a reactive power controller (static var control), voltage control, frequency control, power system stabilizer, or as a real power peaking station. The author describes the design, construction, control, and application of the converter, and gives performance data taken at the installation.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Electric Converters, Power Type; Electric Power Systems; Thyristors; Battery Peaking Service; GTO Converter; Reactive Power Controller; Utility Grid; Voltage Source Converter; Electric Converters, Static

Authors: Nakahara Nobuo, Sagara Kazunobu, Tsujimoto Makoto, Okumiya Masaya
Title: Study on the performance of water thermal storage
Source title: Memoirs of the Faculty of Engineering, Nagoya University
Affiliations: Mie Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakahara, Nobuo, Mie Univ, Japan; Sagara, Kazunobu, Mie Univ, Japan; Tsujimoto, Makoto, Mie Univ, Japan; Okumiya, Masaya, Mie Univ, Japan
Abstract: Theoretical development and a practical design process, accompanied by easy to apply data, are presented for some practical types of water thermal storage tanks. The first part describes basic design concepts, system composition and controls, characteristics of the most popular multi-connected complete mixing tanks, and an estimation table of storage efficiencies of this type. In part 2, a theoretical mixing model is developed for the temperature-stratified type of thermal storage water tank. Empirical equations consisting of the model parameter and input conditions were derived from experiments under the stepwise temperature input. The effects of various design parameters on storage efficiency were examined statistically with experimental designs through numerical simulations. In part 3, it is revealed that a self-balanced type of stratified tank composed of main tank and subheaders that accept returned chilled/heated water maintains stable stratification regardless of the type of imposed inlet condition. Performance was tested by experiment and compared with numerical simulation results.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Storage Efficiency; Water Storage Tanks; Water Thermal Storage; Tanks

Title: First and second law studies on packed bed energy storage systems utilizing phase-change materials
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Mississippi State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adebiyi, G.A., Mississippi State Univ, United States
Abstract: Thermal modeling of Packed Bed Thermal Energy Storage Systems has traditionally been for sensible heat storage and generally limited to first-law considerations. Second-law studies on packed bed thermal energy storage systems normally treat the thermal energy storage and removal processes essentially as 'batch' heating and cooling. This approximation effectively ignores finite temperature gradients. This paper presents results of numerically-based first-law and second-law studies on packed bed thermal energy storage systems utilizing encapsulated phase-change materials. The studies take cognizance of the finite temperature gradients in the storage material and along the bed length in the storage and fluid media employed.
Index Keywords: Fluids; Materials--Phase Transitions; Temperature Distribution; Thermodynamics--Mathematical Models; Bed Length; Finite Temperature Gradients; Packed Bed Energy Storage; Phase-Change Materials; Thermal Energy; Energy Storage

Authors: O'Donnell Patricia M., Cataldo Robert L., Gonzalez-Sanabria Olga D.
Title: Energy storage considerations for a robotic Mars surface sampler
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: O'Donnell, Patricia M., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States; Cataldo, Robert L., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States; Gonzalez-Sanabria, Olga D., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: A Mars Rover capable of obtaining surface samples will need a power system for motive power and to power scientific instrumentation. Several different power systems are considered in this paper along with a discussion of the location options. The weight and volume advantages of the different systems are described for a particular power profile. The conclusions are that a Mars Rover Sample Return Mission and Extended Mission can be accomplished utilizing photovoltaics and electrochemical storage.

Authors: Cook Lawrence P., Plante Ernest R., Bonnell David W., Hastie John W.
Title: Reaction of liquid aluminum with gaseous ClO3F
Affiliations: Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cook, Lawrence P., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Plante, Ernest R., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Bonnell, David W., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States; Hastie, John W., Natl Inst of Standards and, Technology, Gaithersburg, United States
Abstract: The reaction of liquid Al with gaseous perchloryl fluoride, ClO3F, is highly exothermic and has potential for stored chemical energy applications. We have established the mode of thermal decomposition of ClO3F mass spectrometrically using the low pressure Knudsen effusion method and, also, using a transpiration method in which a high pressure cell is directly sampled through a differentially pumped vacuum system. The results show that ClO3F begins decomposition at approximately 500°C and that by 700°C, decomposition to Cl2, F2, and O2 is nearly complete. We have also studied the reaction of dissociated ClO3F with liquid Al by Knudsen and transpiration mass spectrometry and by direct thermogravimetric analysis at 700-800°C. The experimental data indicate that reaction occurs primarily with the F2 component of the gas, resulting in formation of a passivating film of AlF3. Analysis of the kinetic data suggests that film growth progresses as follows: (1) nucleation and growth of AlF3 precipitation sites; (2) edge growth of AlF3 islands on the metal surface; (3) island coalescence; and (4) complete film coverage with diffusion-controlled thickening, according to a parabolic rate law. The reactant gas flow geometry is important since there is evidence for kinetically-favored gas phase reactions that can, under certain circumstances, interfere with formation of the AlF3 product layer. We conclude that under the experimental conditions studied, equilibrium is achieved only in an interfacial sense. In order to completely react the ClO3F and form chloride and oxide products, it may be necessary to first deplete the fluorine component of the gas, followed by disruption of any passivationg film to expose fresh aluminum.
Index Keywords: Aluminum and Alloys--Molten; Fluorine Compounds--Chemical Reactions; Liquid Metals--Chemical Reactions; Chemical Reactions - High Temperature; Chlorine Compounds - Chemical Reactions; Fluorine Compounds - Chemical Reactions; Liquid Metals - Chemical Reactions; Mass Spectrometry; Aluminum Fluoride; Perchloryl Fluoride; Stored Chemical Energy; Knudsen Mass Spectrometry; Liquid Aluminum; Thermogravimetry; Transpiration Mass Spectrometry; Energy Storage; Aluminum and Alloys

Title: Evaluation of a model of long-term memory based on the properties of the Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Brandeis University, Waltham, MA 02254, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lisman, J., Department of Biology, Brandeis University, Waltham, MA 02254, United States; Goldring, M., Department of Biology, Brandeis University, Waltham, MA 02254, United States
Abstract: 1) This paper further explores the feasibility of a model for long-term memory (Lisman, 1985; Lisman and Golring, 1988). According to this model, the value of synaptic efficacy of individual synapses is stored locally by the group of Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II molecules contained within the post-synaptic density. 2) Calculations presented in a previous paper indicate that it is feasible for these kinase molecules to encode information with the stability required for long-term memory. These calculations were based on the assumption that the 30 phosphorylation sites on the enzyme are phosphorylated in a serial fashion, i.e. that the sites are not independent. This paper presents similar calculations based on the alternative assumption that the sites are phosphorylated independently. 3) Kinase molecules that have been switched 'on' undergo a continuous process of dephosphorylation and rephosphorylation. Estimates of the energy consumed by this cycle indicate that the energy required would not make unreasonable demands on neuronal metabolism. The necessity of energy consumption by molecular switches is discussed. 4) The rate of intramolecular autophosphorylation of the Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent kinase implies that the cytoplasmic free Ca2+ concentration must stay elevated for several seconds in order for kinase molecules to switch 'on'. How such a sustained rise in Ca2+ might be achieved is discussed. 5) An alternative view is that long-term memory storage involves a change in gene expression. The principal evidence supporting this view is the effect of protein synthesis inhibitors on memory. A model is presented showing that the observed effect of protein synthesis inhibitors does not necessarily imply that information storage is at the level of gene expression. 6) The distinction between 'presynaptic' and 'postsynaptic' associative learning mechanisms is discussed. It is concluded that this distinction can be misleading and that the possibility that the underlying mechanisms are similar should not be excluded.
Index Keywords: calmodulin; protein kinase; controlled study; learning; mathematical analysis; memory; methodology; molecular biology; nonbiological model; nonhuman; plasticity; priority journal; protein synthesis; Ca(2+)-Calmodulin Dependent Protein Kinase; Calcium; Calmodulin; Memory; Models, Neurological; Protein Kinases

Title: State of the art materials recovery systems options and economics
Affiliations: Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vasuki, N.C., Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States; Canzano, Pasquale S., Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States
Abstract: The four components of a long range solid waste disposal system, viz. materials recovery, organic stabilization, energy recovery, and long-term storage, are considered. The state of the art materials recovery system set up by the State of Delaware is described. The Delaware Reclamation Plant (DRP) was completed in 1983. It is capable of processing daily 1,000 tons of municipal solid wastes and up to 350 tons of municipal sewage sludge (20% solids). This Plant is an integral portion of a comprehensive waste disposal program for New Castle County, Delaware (population 420,000). The facilities for refuse derived fuel (RDF) recovery, glass recovery, nonferrous recovery, the composting system, and energy generation are described. The lessons learned are summed up.
Index Keywords: Fuels--Refuse Derived Fuels; Glass--Recovery; Nonferrous Metals--Recovery; Power Generation--Waste Utilization; Waste Disposal; Aluminum Recovery; Composting; Delaware Reclamation Plant; Landfills; Sewage Sludge; Solid Waste Disposal; Materials

Authors: Nakhamkin M., Howard J., Hoffman P., Schainker R.B.
Title: Reheat 110 MW gas turbine with intercooling for Alabama Electric Cooperative CAES Plant
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Gibbs & Hill Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nakhamkin, M., Gibbs & Hill Inc, United States; Howard, J., Gibbs & Hill Inc, United States; Hoffman, P., Gibbs & Hill Inc, United States; Schainker, R.B., Gibbs & Hill Inc, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a description of the 110 MW turbomachinery train optimized for the specific requirements of Alabama Electric Cooperative. Presented are a) results of AEC's load management study, justifying the addition of Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) to existing power generation capacities, b) overall CAES plant integration, c) detail description of turbomachinery train major components, parameters, performance data and operating characteristics.

Authors: Henderson D.M.S., Steele W.A., Fyvie J., Sharp E.F.
Title: Refurbishment of generator/motor units and main transformers at Cruachan pumped storage power station
Affiliations: NEI Peebles Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Henderson, D.M.S., NEI Peebles Ltd; Steele, W.A., NEI Peebles Ltd; Fyvie, J., NEI Peebles Ltd; Sharp, E.F., NEI Peebles Ltd
Abstract: The North of Scotland Hydro Electric Board's Cruachan Power Station is situated on the shores of Loch Awe in the Scottish Highlands. The underground 400Mw pumped storage station was conceived in the 1950s at a time when commercial nuclear power was in its early days of development. Pumped storage was introduced to store energy by pumping at night for generation during the day to meet the system load peaks. The load regime foreseen was a simple one of a single pumping period and two periods of generation to meet the morning and early evening peaks with an average of 4/5 load changes per day for each of the machines. The station was built in 1965. Since then the flexibility of the plant, and its ability to pick up full load from spinning reserve in less than 1 min, has allowed a change to system running conditions requiring the machines to perform 2 or 3 times that number of daily mode changes. The station has been in service for more than 20 years. The paper examines the refurbishment of two of the most critical areas of electrical plant - two of the four generator/motor units, and the two generator/motor transformers. It demonstrates that refurbishment is not just a matter of new parts for old. Problem areas have been analysed, redesign carried out, and solutions incorporated during the refurbishment with the aim of achieving an extended plant life.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Scotland; Electric Transformers; Hydroelectric Power Plants--Pumped Storage; Extended Plant Life; Generator/Motor Transformers; Refurbishment; Scotland Hydro Electric Board; Electric Generator Motors, AC

Authors: Okada Hidehiko, Ezaki Tadao, Ogawa Kokichi, Koba Hiromi, Takeo Masakatu, Funaki Kazuo, Sato Seiki, Irie Fujio, Chikaba Jituo, Terazono Kanichi, Takamatsu Masahiro, Kawakami Noriko, Hirano Masaru
Title: Experimental study of SMES system with DC intertie for power line stabilization.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Oita Univ, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Okada, Hidehiko, Oita Univ, Jpn; Ezaki, Tadao, Oita Univ, Jpn; Ogawa, Kokichi, Oita Univ, Jpn; Koba, Hiromi, Oita Univ, Jpn; Takeo, Masakatu, Oita Univ, Jpn; Funaki, Kazuo, Oita Univ, Jpn; Sato, Seiki, Oita Univ, Jpn; Irie, Fujio, Oita Univ, Jpn; Chikaba, Jituo, Oita Univ, Jpn; Terazono, Kanichi, Oita Univ, Jpn; Takamatsu, Masahiro, Oita Univ, Jpn; Kawakami, Noriko, Oita Univ, Jpn; Hirano, Masaru, Oita Univ, Jpn
Abstract: A superconducting magnet energy storage (SMES) system for power-transmission-line stabilization is studied using an experimental model system. It has a DC intertie section using convertors in an AC transmission line, with SMES used in series in the DC section. The distinctive characteristics of this sytem are that independent stabilization can be made for each AC line and that the power flow through the DC section can be controlled. The model system has pulsewidth-modulated GTO (gate-turn-off) converters, a superconducting pulse magnet, and a simulated power line system with generators. Measured characteristics of the system are discussed. Results of some simple line-fault experiments are shown.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS; ELECTRIC LINES -- Stability; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PULSE WIDTH MODULATION; GATE-TURN-OFF (GTO) CONVERTERS; LINE-FAULT EXPERIMENTS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET ENERGY STORAGE (SMES); SUPERCONDUCTING PULSE MAGNET; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Authors: Dubovitskii V.V., Sokolov Yu.N., Strebkov D.S.
Title: Classification of solar energy stations

Abstract: An SES represents a new class of energy and architectural-construction facilities, consisting of interrelated solar-technology units and devices (the station's solar collector), various equipment and apparatus, and also the necessary buildings and structures intended for production of heat and/or electricity through the use and conversion of the sun's radiant energy. The basic functional features characterizing various types of SES are defined, and a classification of SES is developed on the basis of them.
Index Keywords: Solar Energy--Storage; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Electricity Production; SES Architecture; SES Classification; Solar Collectors; Solar Energy Stations (SES); Solar Heat Production; Solar Power Plants

Authors: Nakaoka M., Yu G., Chibani A., Yonemori H., Ueda H., Ogino Y.
Title: Resonant flyback switched-mode DC-DC converters using static induction power devices
Affiliations: Kobe Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakaoka, M., Kobe Univ, Japan; Yu, G., Kobe Univ, Japan; Chibani, A., Kobe Univ, Japan; Yonemori, H., Kobe Univ, Japan; Ueda, H., Kobe Univ, Japan; Ogino, Y., Kobe Univ, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the state-of-the art series resonant dc-dc converters using static induction-transistors and -thyristors, which are capable of operating in the switching frequency ranges from 50kHz to 400kHz. Described are the circuit topologies of the two-switch quasi-resonant current-mode flyback converter and the single-switch quasi-resonant voltage-mode flyback converter as compared with thyristorized circuits. Their modified configurations are also presented. The new quasi-resonant flyback power converters developed on the basis of quasi-resonant forward converters include more efficient switching processing at higher frequencies, low acoustic noise and reduced EMI, reduction of size and weight of energy-storage and resonant components and filter components, and effective utilization of parasitic LC components. The operating principles of both types of proposed flyback converters circuits using static induction power devices are explained, and the voltage regulation characteristics of the PFM or PWM time ratio control-based resonant flyback converters are discussed in terms of computer aided simulation results.
Index Keywords: Electronic Circuits; Thyristors; Current-Mode Flyback Converter; DC-DC Converters; Flyback Power Converters; Resonant Flyback Converters; Static Induction Power Devices; Voltage-Mode Flyback Converter; Electric Converters, Static

Title: Parametric study of phase change thermal energy storage systems for space applications
Affiliations: Univ of Kansas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yimer, B., Univ of Kansas, United States; Adami, M., Univ of Kansas, United States
Abstract: A two-dimensional transient analytical model was developed to study and evaluate the high-temperature phase-change thermal energy storage systems for space applications. Parametric studies were performed in order to assess the effects of various thermal and geometric parameters on the heat transfer process and on the performance of the energy storage system. The analytical model was developed for the two dimensional tube and shell configuration with internal longitudinal fins included inside the phase-change material. In the study liquid phase thermal conductivity was taken to be different from that of the solid phase. The effects of convective currents in the liquid phase were also accounted for. The enthalpy approach (where both enthalpy and temperature are the dependent variables) was used to develop the describing equations. The Gauss-Seidel iterative scheme with successive over-relaxation was used to numerically solve the resulting non-linear simultaneous finite-difference equations.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Thermal Conductivity; Gauss-Seidel Iterative Scheme; Phase-change; Phase-change Material; Thermal Energy Storage Systems; Energy Storage

Authors: Arkley K.I., Halstead J.M., Pinto A.
Title: Modernization of ammonia industry by small economic plants
Affiliations: Imperial Chemical Industries plc, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Arkley, K.I., Imperial Chemical Industries plc, United Kingdom; Halstead, J.M., Imperial Chemical Industries plc, United Kingdom; Pinto, A., Imperial Chemical Industries plc, United Kingdom
Abstract: Modernization of the ammonia capacity afforded opportunities and presented challenges. The opportunity to reaffirm an effective and progressive technological capability via a closely controlled in-house project on an ICI site providing comprehensive feedback of information to the design function was recognized as valuable. The challenges to be addressed in selecting the appropriate investment strategy. A discussion is presented of the economics of small plants and the effect of plant size on investment cost. The role played by reduced size and weight of main plant items is examined. It is concluded that ICI's decision to adopt a radical total engineering approach has been vindicated through the project execution phase to date. Modern engineering methods provide an increased scope for investment optimization which can in certain circumstances considerably reduce the real cost penalty of reduced scale plants; in particular by reducing storage requirements in multistream situations and allowing phased cash flow and faster return on investment, which is of considerable benefit where target returns or interest rates are high.
Index Keywords: Chemical Plants--Modification; Economics; Industrial Plants--Computer Aided Engineering; Energy Efficiency; Investment Strategy; Phased Cash Flow; Small Capacity Plants; Ammonia

Authors: Shirai Yasuyuki, Nitta Tanzo, Okada Takao
Title: Computer simulation for power system including superconducting magnetic energy storage.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Shirai, Yasuyuki, Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Jpn; Nitta, Tanzo, Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Jpn; Okada, Takao, Kyoto Univ, Kyoto, Jpn
Abstract: A computer simulation for power systems using superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is described. The simulation code takes into account mode changes due to commutations of thyristor converters of SMES. It is easy to obtain codes for changes of power-system configuration. A method for getting accurate initial values for simulations is shown. The simulation results agree well with the experimental results.

Title: Current research in heat and mass transfer (Compendium and a festschrift for professor Arcot Ramachandran)
Source title: Current Research in Heat and Mass Transfer
Abstract: This collection contains 24 papers discussing current research activities in heat transfer and mass transfer research. The effect of secondary flow on heat transfer in ducted flows, as well as, the mechanisms for enhancement of heat transfer in turbulent impinging jets are discussed. One paper discusses heat transfer and fluid flow research relevant to India's Nuclear Power Program while another analyzes results of heat transfer experiments for an under platform ventilation system. Heat transfer and thermal storage characteristics of an optically semitransparent material packed bed solar air heater and the effect that the technical utilization of solar energy has on heat transfer researach are aspects also considered. Post-Dryout heat transfer in tubes with uniform and circumferentially nonuniform heating, and an investigation on swirling vertical turbulent buoyant jets are themes included.

Authors: Shapiro M.M., Feldman D., Hawes D., Banu D.
Title: PCM wallboard tempers passive-solar temperature swings
Affiliations: Concordia Univ, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Shapiro, M.M., Concordia Univ, Canada; Feldman, D., Concordia Univ, Canada; Hawes, D., Concordia Univ, Canada; Banu, D., Concordia Univ, Canada
Abstract: The purpose of the work reported here was to develop a cost-effective heat storage that doesn't overheat room air in the early evening and does not allow overcooling in the early morning. The authors obtained an extraordinary latent heat-storage product by infusing ordinary wallboard with mixtures of organic phase-change materials (PCMs). Moreover, the product permits homes to be designed for different comfort zones by changing the ratio of organic PCM mixtures.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Transfer--Walls; Organic Compounds--Phase Transitions; Comfort Zones; Organic Phase-Change Materials; Wall Boards; Heating

Title: HYDRA-II, a computer code for hydrothermal analysis of spent fuel storage systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, United States
Authors with affiliations: McCann, R.A., Pacific Northwest Lab, United States
Abstract: HYDRA-II is a hydrothermal computer code designed to accurately predict steady-state fluid flow and temperature distributions in spent nuclear fuel storage and transportation systems. The code is capable of three-dimensional analysis of coupled conduction, convection, and thermal radiation problems. It provides a finite difference solution in cartesian coordinates to the equations governing the conservation of mass, momentum, and energy. A cylindrical coordinate system may also be used to enclose the cartesian coordinate system. This exterior coordinate system is useful for modeling cylindrical cask bodies. The basic equations and an overview of the numerics employed in their solution are presented. Selected results from an extensive code verification/validation effort are also presented. Comparisons are made between the results of simulations of a multi-assembly storage system and actual experimental data. The effects of backfill gas composition and pressure and cask orientation are illustrated.
Index Keywords: Computer Software; Flow of Fluids--Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Temperature Distribution--Mathematical Models; Backfill Gas Composition; Cylindrical Cask Bodies; Hydrothermal Analysis; Software Package HYDRA II; Spent Fuel Storage Systems; Nuclear Fuels

Authors: Aziz Rafat H., Aggarwal Mahesh C.
Title: Flat-plate solar collector with integrated storage system
Affiliations: VFT Systems Inc, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Aziz, Rafat H., VFT Systems Inc, Canada; Aggarwal, Mahesh C., VFT Systems Inc, Canada
Abstract: A proposed design of a flat plate solar collector consists of the glass cover, absorber plate, storage medium, tubing network, insulation shield, insulation, and casing. Solar energy is stored in a phase-change material (PCM), sodium diabasic phosphate. The layer of solid PCM is sandwiched between the absorber plate and the insulation shield. Thermal energy is recovered from the storage medium by passing air through copper tubes located within the storage medium. The overall system efficiency was calculated. The temperatures of the glass cover, absorber plate, and storage medium were also calculated. The analysis shows the overall system efficiency for Erie, Pennsylvania ranged from 3.01%-34.20% and for Austin, Texas from 24.71%-39.90%.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Models; Sodium Compounds; Efficiency Factor; Flat Plate Collectors; Phase Change Materials; Sodium Diabasic Phosphate; Solar Energy

Title: Energy storage/mechanical energy production based on sulfuric acid decomposition and synthesis
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Hammache, A., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Canada; Bilgen, E., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Canada
Abstract: A thermodynamic assessment was carried out of the chemical energy process based on sulfuric acid decomposition and synthesis process using hot oxygen as a vector. The purpose of the study was to evaluate the nominal mechanical energy that could be produced by the synthesis process. In the synthesis process, the raw materials SO2, H2O and O2 produced and stored by the decomposition process are used to manufacture H2SO4. The thermal energy produced within the process is converted to mechanical energy using the same equipment. The results indicate that the second law efficiency of the mechanical energy production is about 48.39%.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Synthesis; Energy Storage; Thermodynamics; Mechanical Energy; Thermal Energy Production; Sulfuric Acid

Title: State of the art materials recovery systems: Options & economics
Source title: American Institute of Chemical Engineers, National Meeting
Affiliations: Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vasuki, N.C., Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States; Canzano, Pasquale S., Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States
Abstract: Solid waste disposal systems are discussed with emphasis on materials recovery methods. The discussion shows that materials recovery on a large scale through central processing plants is quite feasible. Materials recovery prior to combustion of solid wastes offers a means of achieving two goals - recycling and reduction in the metals content of ash. If the new type of landfills equipped with liners and leachate collection systems are used for ash disposal, the perceived threat of groundwater pollution is minimized. Further improvements in materials recovery are possible and attention should be paid to recovery of certain plastics.
Index Keywords: Plastics--Recovery; Waste Disposal--Incineration; Waste Utilization--Economics; Central Waste Processing Plants; Energy Recovery; Long-Term Storage; Materials Recovery; Organic Stabilization; Solid Waste Disposal; Fuels

Title: Space station photovoltaic power modules
Affiliations: NASA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tatro, Charles A., NASA, United States
Abstract: Silicon cell Photovoltaic (PV) power modules are key components of the Space Station Electrical Power System (EPS) scheduled to begin deployment in 1994. Four PV power modules, providing 75 kWe of user ac power, form the cornerstone of the EPS. The PV modules are located on rotating outboard sections of the Space Station (SS) structure and each module incorporates its own nickel-hydrogen energy storage batteries, its own thermal control system, and some autonomous control features. The PV modules are a cost-effective and technologically mature approach for providing reliable SS electrical power and are a solid base for EPS growth, which is expected to reach 300 kWe by the end of the Space Station's 30 year design lifetime.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - Reliability; Photovoltaic Cells - Space Applications; Solar Cells - Arrays; Power Modules; Space Station; Space Platforms

Title: Laser-induced state changes in reversible optical memory materials.
Affiliations: Univ of Southern California, Los, Angeles, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mendez, Antonio J., Univ of Southern California, Los, Angeles, CA, USA; Wang, Chin-Lin, Univ of Southern California, Los, Angeles, CA, USA
Abstract: A mathematical model of the sensitivity (laser marking efficiency) function of reversible optical memories has been developed from empirical data. Excellent agreement between the experimental data and the theoretical values has been found. The model shows that all reversible optical memories behave as two state systems, with switching between states induced by the incident write or erase laser pulse. The mathematical model permits detailed analysis of the writing phenomena or the intercomparison of optical memory types. With this sensitivity function, one can model a system or further explore the characteristics of the materials such as the threshold energy and the switching speed.
Index Keywords: LASER BEAMS -- Effects; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; DIGEST OF PAPER; LASER MARKING EFFICIENCY; LASER-INDUCED STATE CHANGES; REVERSIBLE OPTICAL MEMORY MATERIALS; SENSITIVITY FUNCTION; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: State of the art materials recovery systems: Options and economics
Affiliations: Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vasuki, N.C., Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States; Canzano, Pasquale S., Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States
Abstract: The United States occupies the premier position in solid waste production. This is understandable because of the high standard of living and the enormous choice of goods and services available. Solid waste disposal methods have been hampered by political indecision, not by technical limitation. A long-range solid waste disposal system has four main components. They are: 1. Materials recovery, 2. Organic stabilization, 3. Energy recovery, and 4. Long-term storage. These components are examined in this paper.
Index Keywords: Materials Handling; Energy Recovery; Materials Recovery; Organic Stabilization; Source Separation Systems; Waste Storage; Waste Disposal

Title: Industrial superconductivity - practical applications

Abstract: Some possibilities of application of superconductivity in industrial processes and industrial measurements are considered. In particular, electrical applications, such as in power transmission, energy storage, and electric motors; industrial applications of magnetism such as for magnetic separation, or of very small magnetic fields, e.g. in SQUID detectors of corrosion current; applications to process control and manufacturing processes are discussed.
