Authors: Hasatani Masanobu, Itaya Yoshinori, Adachi Kouji
Title: Heat transfer and thermal storage characteristics of optically semitransparent materials packed bed solar air heater
Source title: Current Research in Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Nagoya Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hasatani, Masanobu, Nagoya Univ, Japan; Itaya, Yoshinori, Nagoya Univ, Japan; Adachi, Kouji, Nagoya Univ, Japan
Abstract: In this work, an optically semitransparent materials-packed-bed solar air heater, which may have two advantages to the flat plate solar air heaters, was proposed: (1) it has accelerative effects of heat transfer rate due to increases in the optical depth of the air layer and the heat transfer area; and (2) the packed material itself can be used as a heat storage material. As one of basic steps of the R&D on the solar air heater of the proposed type, the effects of the thermal and optical properties of packed materials and the air flow rate on the overall efficiency of the energy collection and thermal storage were investigated theoretically and experimentally. Then the applicability of this type of solar air heater to a practical solar system was discussed comparing with the flat plate type.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage--Materials; Heat Transfer--Radiation; Heat-Trap Characteristics; Optically Semitransparent Materials; Packed Bed Solar Air Heater; Radiative Heat Transfer; Thermal Storage Characteristics; Heating

Title: Technical utilization of solar energy-its effects on heat transfer research
Source title: Current Research in Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Univ Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hahne, E.W.P., Univ Stuttgart, Germany; Fisch, N.M., Univ Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: From the heat transfer point of view, the utilisation of solar energy means the solution of transient problems, comprising all three modes of heat transfer: radiation, convection and conduction and as boundary condition an intermittingly acting, uncontrollable heat source of a low heat flow density (compared to electrical or fossil fuel heating). So far, such conditions were unmet in heating technology. They called for a number of components to be combined in a system: a collector, a storage device, an auxiliary heat source and control- and regulating installations. Because of the restrictive boundary condition, the best components have to be found to interact optimally in the system. The paper presents analysis of thermal energy storage in solar collectors and discusses, some solar heating projects.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Research; Heating--Solar; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Solar Energy

Title: Variable rate adaptive transform coder for the digital storage of audio signals.
Affiliations: Bell Canada Switching Systems, Research, Toronto, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Tansony, R.W., Bell Canada Switching Systems, Research, Toronto, Ont, Can; Kabal, P., Bell Canada Switching Systems, Research, Toronto, Ont, Can
Abstract: A transform-coding algorithm, designed for the mass storage of variable-quality audio signals, is presented. The storage of both speech and music is considered. Automatic silence deletion and signal order, energy, and bandwidth estimation are employed to provide a continuously variable bit rate, adaptively matched to the characteristics of the input signal. Test results show that the algorithm offers storage savings of more than 75% over linear-PCM (pulse-code-modulation) coders, and more than 63% over equivalent quality log-PCM coders. Results also show improved performance over the CCITT standard wideband coder. The complexity of the algorithm is such that it can be implemented in real time on existing digital signal processors.
Index Keywords: AUDIO SYSTEMS; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING -- Algorithms; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL; SIGNAL PROCESSING -- Digital Techniques; SPEECH -- Coding; AUTOMATIC SILENCE DELETION; MASS STORAGE; MUSIC; TRANSFORM-CODING ALGORITHM; VARIABLE RATE ADAPTIVE TRANSFORM CODER; VARIABLE-QUALITY AUDIO SIGNALS; CODES, SYMBOLIC

Title: Molecular view of bulk deformation
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cook, Robert, Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, United States
Abstract: During the deformation the chain conformational motion will be partially suppressed by neighboring chains, and those motions necessary to relax the chain will be blocked. Since the chain is still being elongated, a good deal of the deformation energy may be taken up in the backbone bond angles and bond lengths. The author explores this area of energy storage during deformation by modeling a polyethylene-like chain imbedded in a bulk medium which is mechanically strained. Experimental data indicate that the energy stored in a deformed material below Tg can generally be quantitatively recovered by heating the sample above Tg, which allows for conformational relaxations by effectively reducing the constraining forces.
Index Keywords: Plastics--Deformation; Bulk Deformation; Chain Conformational Motion; Conformational Transitions; Polymers

Title: High temperature thermal energy storage for space power systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Gannon Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Torab, H., Gannon Univ, United States; Chang, W.S., Gannon Univ, United States
Abstract: Encapsulated Phase Change Material (PCM) Thermal Energy Storage (TES) Systems may be used to reduce the total volume and mass of the heat rejection system in pulsed space power supplies. The storage system receives waste heat generated during high power sprint operation. The stored energy will then be dissipated into space using a radiator during the non-operational period of the orbit. Since the non-operational period is much longer than the operational period, the use of a storage system allows the size of the radiator to be made significantly smaller. This study is concerned with the dynamic behavior of a high temperature energy storage system using encapsulated PCM. The PCM considered in this study is lithium hydride, one of the best PCM candidates for this particular application. The heat transport fluid is assumed to be lithium. A model representing the performance of the storage system can then be used in an optimization study to minimize the weight and volume of the TES or a given operation conditions.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer; Encapsulated Phase Change Material (PCM); High Temperature Thermal Energy Storage; Space Power Systems; Energy Storage

Authors: Masada Eisuke, Tamura Minoru, Nakajima Tatsuhito
Title: Compensation of industrial load variation with superconducting magnetic energy storage.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Masada, Eisuke, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Tamura, Minoru, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Nakajima, Tatsuhito, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: A compensation system for the power-flow variation in utility networks caused by superconducting magnet energy storage (SMES) is studied. The daily pattern of the load variation in typical industrial systems is investigated to obtain basic requirements for the compensating system. A storage capacity of 0.3-2 MWh is found to be enough to regulate short-term load variation. An integrated compensation system is proposed, and its control scheme is studied. The system consists of the SMES, a synchronous phase modifier, and an active power filter. Its conceptual design is carried out. Simulation results show the effectiveness of the approach.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES -- Phase; ELECTRIC FILTERS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS -- Energy Storage; INDUSTRIAL LOAD VARIATION COMPENSATION; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNET ENERGY STORAGE (SMES); SYNCHRONOUS PHASE MODIFIER; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Rewriteable dye-polymer optical storage media
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Optical Data Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Iwamoto, N.E., Optical Data Inc, United States; Halter, J.M., Optical Data Inc, United States
Abstract: A unique rewriteable dye-polymer, bump forming media has been developed for high density optical data storage. The media structure consists of two active layers, an elastomeric layer and a thermoplastic layer, which are dyed to selectively absorb at different wavelengths. Writing and erasing is accomplished through the viscoelastic response of the heated layer. The marks are created mechanically by thermal expansion of response of the heated layer. The marks are created mechanically by thermal expansion of the elastomeric layer. The subsequent deformation of the surface is captured by the thermoplastic layer upon cooling. Erasure of the mark is caused when the thermoplastic layer is relaxed with heat. Material requirement trends have been identified which change media performance and lead to structures which create marks with higher read contrast and which write and erase with lower energy. The selection of materials is based upon modulus, glass transition temperature and relative crosslink density.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Optical--Plastics Applications; Surfaces--Deformation; Thermal Effects; Thermoplastics--Dyeing; Viscoelasticity; Abstract Form Only; Bump Forming Media; Dye-Polymer; Rewritable Dye Polymer Storage Media; Polymers

Title: Power conditioning system for the +/-8,5/17 MW - energy storage plant of BEWAG
Affiliations: Berliner Kraft-und-Licht (BEWAG) AG, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Saupe, R., Berliner Kraft-und-Licht (BEWAG) AG, Germany
Abstract: For an orderly electricity supply, balancing of frequency and voltage is a primary consideration. The frequency stands in direct dependence to the real power. In a superimposed grid the flywheel effect of all generators and machines damps erratic influences. Compared to this effect, a small insular supply system is sensitive to, and interactive with, load variations. All questions of load frequency control and instantaneous reserve become matters of chief concern. The electricity supply of Berlin (West) is operated by the Berliner Kraft- und Licht (BEWAG)-Aktiengesell-schaft and has been running as an insular system since 1952. Due to the political situation, there is no connection to any of the European grid systems. To solve the aforementioned problems, the utility company was taking a fresh look at using large-scale storage batteries as a part of the BEWAG modernising program in order to reduce cost for load frequency control and instantaneous reserve. This paper shows the conceptual design and some considerations integrating a battery with an electric system. Some constructional considerations are discussed.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary--Energy Storage; Electric Converters, Power Type; Large-Scale Storage Batteries; Power Conditioning; Superimposed Grid; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Cnobloch Herbert, Nischik Herbert, Pantel Kurt, Ledjeff Konstantin, Heinzel Angelika, Reiner Andreas
Title: 250 W/1 kWh iron-chromium redox flow storage battery
Source title: Siemens Forschungs- und Entwicklungsberichte/Siemens Research and Development Reports
Affiliations: Siemens AG, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Cnobloch, Herbert, Siemens AG, Germany; Nischik, Herbert, Siemens AG, Germany; Pantel, Kurt, Siemens AG, Germany; Ledjeff, Konstantin, Siemens AG, Germany; Heinzel, Angelika, Siemens AG, Germany; Reiner, Andreas, Siemens AG, Germany
Abstract: The energy is stored in solutions of metal ion couples at different states of oxidation. The construction and testing of a 250 W/1 kwh storage unit is described. It consists of the battery, the supply tanks, pumps for electrolyte circulation, a charge rebalancing system, a charge indicator and a controlling device. The technical cell consists of a polysulfone frame to incorporate the ion exchange membrane and of a plastic bonded natural graphite as electrode and bipolar plate. Cell voltages of 0.7 v to 0.75 v have been measured at 50 mA/cm2. The charge is rebalanced by the reduction of Fe(III) ions formed in excess. Th charging state of the system is measured on a charge indicator, which is a cell containing three eletrodes. Cost aspects of the flow battery are stated.
Index Keywords: Electrodes; Electrolytes; Electrolytic Cells; Energy Storage; Solutions; Accumulators; Charge Rebalancing System; Iron Chromium Redox Flow Batteries; Redox Flow Batteries; Storage Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Testing of an autonomous wind energy conversion system for domestic space heating
Affiliations: Univ of Strathclyde, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stepek, Andrew, Univ of Strathclyde, United Kingdom
Abstract: A wind powered space heating system was installed in a low-energy house on North Ronaldsay, Orkney, using electrical heating of a hot water store. This installation was assisted by occasional passive solar heating. Tests were carried out from March to October 1988, yielding an overall system efficiency of 64%, and readings were taken to investigate the correlation of windspeed data with those obtained at Kirkwall Airport.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heating - Hot Water Systems; Hot Water Supply Systems; Houses - Space Heating; Wind Turbines; Energy Conversion; Low Energy Houses; Wind Powered Space Heating Systems; Wind Power

Title: A large, high-speed memory buffer for high energy physics data
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Physics FM-15, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195, United States
Authors with affiliations: Plaag, R.E., Physics FM-15, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195, United States; Rutherfoord, J.P., Physics FM-15, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195, United States
Abstract: Many high-data-rate experiments in elementary particle physics suffer large dead-times due to the slow speeds with which the on-line computer can read in data from each event. To eliminate this bottle-neck, we have designed, constructed, and made extensive use in a physics experiment of a 4 megabyte memory buffer which employs ordinary dynamic RAM memory chips and which accepts all of our event data generated during a beam spill at Fermilab at a rate of 14 Mbyte per second. © 1988.
Index Keywords: Computer Systems, Digital--Fast Response Capability; Data Processing--Natural Sciences Applications; Physics--High Energy; Mega Memory; Memories; Particle Physics; Data Storage, Digital

Title: Thermal analysis of a cool storage system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Georgia Inst of Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lyons, D.P., Georgia Inst of Technology, United States; Wepfer, W.J., Georgia Inst of Technology, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a simplified model to analyze an operating strategy for a cool storage system also known as commercial off-peak air conditioning. Many comfort and process cooling loads exist for only a few hours each day. Because conventional cooling systems produce cooling as it is needed, the maximum energy consumption occurs during peak utility demand, when electrical charges are a maximum. Significant savings may be achieved with a commercial off-peak air conditioning system, utilizing low cost, off-peak energy to supply on-peak cooling. In this paper a partial storage, chiller priority, closed ice bank system was studied for application to a commercial office building in the Altlanta area. A six-mode heuristic chiller/ice storage model was developed for use with a simplified building load model based on actual operating data.
Index Keywords: Ice--Storage; Chiller Priority Systems; Closed Ice Bank System; Cool Storage System; Refrigerant Based Systems; Thermal Storage; Air Conditioning

Authors: Lightstone M.F., Raithby G.D., Hollands K.G.T.
Title: Numerical study of thermal stratification in tanks of liquid water
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Waterloo, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Lightstone, M.F., Univ of Waterloo, Canada; Raithby, G.D., Univ of Waterloo, Canada; Hollands, K.G.T., Univ of Waterloo, Canada
Abstract: Thermally stratified storage has been shown to significantly improve the energy delivered by a solar energy hot water system. This paper presents a finite volume model for the analysis of storage tanks which have axisymmetric flow and heat transfer. The model, which solves the conservation equations for mass, momentum, and energy, was extensively validated using benchmark problems. The accuracy of the model for thermal storage tank predictions was examined by comparing predictions to experimental data. Good agreement was found, as reported herein.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--Numerical Analysis; Reservoirs--Thermal Stratification; Solar Energy--Storage; Water Tanks and Towers; Finite Volume Model; Thermal Storage Systems; Heat Transfer

Title: Aerospace energy systems laboratory: requirements and design approach
Source title: Instrumentation in the Aerospace Industry, Proceedings of the ISAAerospace Instrumentation Symposium
Affiliations: NASA, Ames Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Glover, Richard D., NASA, Ames Research Cent, United States
Abstract: The NASA Ames-Dryden Flight Research Facility at Edwards, California operates a mixed fleet of research aircraft employing nickel-cadmium batteries in a variety of flight-critical applications. Dryden's Battery Systems Laboratory (BSL), a computerized facility for battery maintenance servicing, has evolved over two decades into one of the most advanced facilities of its kind in the world. Recently a major BSL upgrade was initiated with the goal of modernization to provide flexibility in meeting the needs of future advanced projects. The new facility will be called the Aerospace Energy Systems Laboratory (AESL) and will employ distributed processing linked to a centralized data base. AESL will be both a multistation servicing facility and a research laboratory for the advancement of energy storage system maintenance techniques. This paper describes the baseline requirements for AESL and the design approach taken for its mechanization.
Index Keywords: Aircraft, Research--Electric Equipment; Cadmium and Alloys; Database Systems; Nickel and Alloys; Battery Maintenance Servicing; Centralized Data Base; Flight-Critical Applications; NASA; Nickel-Cadmium Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Heat transfer - Houston 1988, papers presented at the 25th national heat transfer conference
Abstract: This conference contains 32 papers. The topics of the papers include heat transfer in gas-solid suspensions, self-propagating high temperature synthesis of ceramics, heat and mass transfer in chemical vapor deposition, solar heat transfer and energy storage. Multiphase flow is applied to reservoir engineering, and heat transfer under microgravity conditions is reviewed.
Index Keywords: Chemical Equipment--Reactors; Flow of Fluids; Heat Exchangers--Tubes; Mathematical Techniques--Finite Difference Method; Semiconducting Films--Chemical Vapor Deposition; Combustion Turbine; EIREV; Mass Velocity Effect; Microgravity Conditions; Thermal Energy Storage; Transition Boundaries; Heat Transfer

Authors: Nomura Hiroshi, Fujiwara Kenichiro, Kawakami Hisaaki
Title: Power factor compensator using a force-commutated cycloconverter.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Kochi Natl Coll of Technology, Nangoku, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Nomura, Hiroshi, Kochi Natl Coll of Technology, Nangoku, Jpn; Fujiwara, Kenichiro, Kochi Natl Coll of Technology, Nangoku, Jpn; Kawakami, Hisaaki, Kochi Natl Coll of Technology, Nangoku, Jpn
Abstract: A power-factor compensator using a force-commutated cycloconverter (FCC) is proposed that keeps the displacement factor of the AC system at unity regardless of the load power factor. No energy storage elements or feedback controls are required. An FCC with half of the load capacity can provide fast and complete compensation of the reactive power in the load. An extension of the basic concept results in a power-factor compensator with output-voltage control that retains most of the merits of the original system and extends the areas of application.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES -- Voltage; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, FREQUENCY; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE -- Switching; ELECTRIC REACTORS; FORCE-COMMUTATED CYCLOCONVERTER (FCC); INTERPHASE REACTOR; OUTPUT-VOLTAGE CONTROL; PARALLEL COMPENSATOR; SERIES COMPENSATOR; ELECTRIC POWER FACTOR

Title: Topological constraints on basic PWM converters.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: ITT, Tucson, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Kwang-Hwa, ITT, Tucson, AZ, USA; Lee, Fred C., ITT, Tucson, AZ, USA
Abstract: A modeling and synthesis technique is introduced for single-ended, ladder-structured, DC-DC converter topologies. Topological constraints are derived that enhance the understanding of structural properties of converter circuits and clarify the roles of inductors and capacitors in various converters using magnetic or capacitive energy storage/transfer mechanism. The exact duality relationships among the basic converter topologies are established.
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS; ELECTRIC INDUCTORS; ELECTRIC NETWORKS -- Topology; ENERGY STORAGE; PULSE WIDTH MODULATION; MAGNETIC OR CAPACITIVE ENERGY STORAGE/TRANSFER MECHANISM; SINGLE-ENDED, LADDER-STRUCTURED, DC-DC CONVERTER; VOLTAGE AND CURRENT BUFFERS; VOLTAGE AND CURRENT SOURCES; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Title: High-temperature solar central receivers for electricity production
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Inst, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, John V., Solar Energy Research Inst, United States; Weaver, Norm, Solar Energy Research Inst, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a study on the technical and economic potential of high-temperature (1000°C-1400°C) central receiver systems for electricity production. The three receiver concepts analyzed, the high-temperature direct absorption receiver, the particle injection receiver, and the volumetric receiver, use an intercooled, steam-injected gas turbine engine. The energy collected by the receivers is transferred to the engine by one of two heat exchange systems: a conventional ceramic air-to-air unit and a direct-contact heat exchange system. The systems were configured without storage, and the engine and heat exchangers were assumed to be located on the tower top. The results show that the particle injection receiver combined with a direct-contact heat exchanger has the potential to produce a levelized energy cost that is nearly 30% lower than comparable low-temperature (550°C) central receiver systems.
Index Keywords: Gas Turbines; Heat Exchangers; Solar Energy--Costs; Direct Absorption Receivers; Particle Injection Receivers; Solar Central Receivers; Volumetric Receivers; Solar Power Plants

Title: Analysis of inductor-converter bridge by means of state-space averaging technique.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bilgic, M., Texas A&M Univ, TX, USA; Ehsani, M., Texas A&M Univ, TX, USA
Abstract: The time-averaged behavior of an inductor-converter bridge (ICB) circuit has been analyzed using a state-space averaging technique. The application of the state-space averaging technique to the ICB circuit analysis is somewhat different from the well known DC-to-DC converter cases such as buck, boost, and flyback of Cuk converter analysis in that the first-order approximation of the state transition matrix will give trivial results. The results, which were previously obtained in infinite Fourier series form, are in closed form. A comparison is also made with the Fourier result. The ICB is a two-quadrant power supply for superconductive energy storage magnets. Closed-form expressions are found for the average current, voltage, and power behavior of the ICB. This application is somewhat different from the analysis of other DC choppers such as buck, boost, flyback, and Cuk converters in that the first-order terms are identically zero and the second-order terms have to be used.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS; ELECTRIC INDUCTORS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, POWER SUPPLY; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES -- State Space Methods; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS -- Energy Storage; INDUCTOR-CONVERTER BRIDGE (ICB) CIRCUIT; STATE-SPACE AVERAGING TECHNIQUE; TWO-QUADRANT POWER SUPPLY; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, BRIDGE

Authors: Shirahama Hidefumi, Sakurai Yoshimi, Matsuda Yasuo, Ishigaki Yukio, Murai Katsuji

Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Shirahama, Hidefumi, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn; Sakurai, Yoshimi, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn; Matsuda, Yasuo, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn; Ishigaki, Yukio, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn; Murai, Katsuji, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn
Abstract: A novel GPG (gate pulse generator) for gate-turn-off converters (GTOs) is presented that provides quick-response firing-angle control and pulsewidth-modulated (PWM) control. Using the GPG, instantaneous control active and reactive powers for an SMES (superconducting magnetic energy storage) system using one GTO converter is studied.
Index Keywords: CONTROL, ELECTRIC VARIABLES -- Power; ELECTRIC NETWORKS -- Reactive Power; PULSE GENERATORS; PULSE WIDTH MODULATION -- Control; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS -- Energy Storage; GATE PULSE GENERATOR (GPG); GATE-TURN-OFF (GTO) CONVERTERS; QUICK-RESPONSE FIRING-ANGLE CONTROL; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS

Title: Processes involved in reversible optical writing in chalcogenide semiconductor films
Authors with affiliations: Shvarts, K.K.
Abstract: The present state of development of reversible optical storage materials for writing information in real time is reviewed. The physical processes involved in optical writing are analyzed. Emphasis is placed on the writing energy and writing time. An energy of 0.5-2.0 J/bit is required for direct writing in reversible storage materials when the length of the light pulse is about 100 ns. The requirements which semiconductor lasers will have to meet for optical writing are analyzed.
Index Keywords: Lasers, Semiconductor; Semiconducting Films; Optical Writing; Reversible Optical Storage; Data Storage, Optical

Authors: Turman B.N., Neau E.L., Humphreys D.R., Harjes H.C., Bloomquist D.D., Lockwood G.J., Seamen J.F.
Title: Power and energy measurements in large pulse power systems.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Turman, B.N., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Neau, E.L., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Humphreys, D.R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Harjes, H.C., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Bloomquist, D.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Lockwood, G.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Seamen, J.F., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: Some of the techniques used for voltage and current measurements for pulsed power components are discussed. The application of these techniques to a single-module accelerator prototype (Demon) is examined. Their application to the 36-module Particle Beam Fusion Accelerator II (PBFA II) is also described.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS; ENERGY STORAGE -- Measurements; ACCELERATOR II (PBFA II); LARGE PULSE POWER SYSTEMS; PARTICLE BEAM FUSION ACCELERATOR II (PFBA II); SINGLE-MODULE ACCELERATOR PROTOTYPE (DEMON); ELECTRIC MEASUREMENTS

Authors: Halbout Jean-Marc, May Paul, Jenkins Keith A., Compeau Gary
Title: SRAM access measurements using a picosecond photoelectron scanning electron microscope.
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers - IEEE International Solid-State Circuits Conference
Affiliations: IBM, Yorktown Heights, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Halbout, Jean-Marc, IBM, Yorktown Heights, NY, USA; May, Paul, IBM, Yorktown Heights, NY, USA; Jenkins, Keith A., IBM, Yorktown Heights, NY, USA; Compeau, Gary, IBM, Yorktown Heights, NY, USA
Abstract: Waveform measurements at the internal nodes of a 0.5-μm CMOS SRAM (static random-access memory) are presented. They yield detailed information on the internal operation of the circuit, and, more precisely, on the delays whose sum constitutes the access time in this high-speed memory circuit. The waveforms were measured in a noncontact and nonintrusive fashion with an ultrafast electron-beam prober. For these measurements, the primary electron-beam energy is set at 1.5 keV. The main goal is the accurate measurement of the access time from the clock input (falling edge) to the data output (rising or falling edge depending on whether a logic zero or a one is being read) and its breakdown into individual delays between logic devices (inverters, NOR and NAND gates, etc.) on the way to the cell and then similarly from the cell to the output buffer.
Index Keywords: LOGIC DEVICES; MICROSCOPIC EXAMINATION -- Scanning Electron Microscopy; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES, MOS; CMOS SRAM; DIGEST OF PAPER; HIGH-SPEED MEMORY; INTERNAL NODES; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: Simulation study on minimum prediction error controllers for power systems based on superconducting magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Oita Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sugisaka, M., Oita Univ, Japan; Veloso, E.A., Oita Univ, Japan
Abstract: This paper considers an application of the minimum prediction error controller to stabilize electric power systems using the Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) after an occurrence of fault. The nonlinear weighted one-step-ahead control laws are proposed for continuous time electric power systems as the minimum prediction error controller. The proposed control laws have an advantage that the computational time and storage are less than those in calculating optimal controllers or feedback controllers. Stability of electric power systems can be realized using the SMES because the power is absorbed in the SMES during the accelerating period of the power generation and conversely is discharged from the SMES during the decelerating period of power generation.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation--Applications; Control Systems--Applications; Energy Storage; Superconducting Magnets--Applications; Minimum Prediction Error Controllers; One-Step-Ahead Control; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES); Electric Power Systems

Title: Studying and harnessing the sun
Affiliations: Smithsonian Inst, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abbott, Charles Greeley, Smithsonian Inst, United States
Abstract: The author's early interest in astronomy led him in 1916 to experiments on Mount Wilson, California with solar cookers. In this paper, one of these parabolic cookers is described. Quite different from the box cookers discussed elsewhere in this issue, Abbot's cookers also featured a heat storage device allowing food to be cooked long after sunset.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Solar Energy--Applications; Solar Radiation--Collectors; Parabolic Solar Cookers; Solar Energy Storage; Solar Heat Collectors; Stoves

Title: Regulatory constraints on co-combustion
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Fuels and Combustion Technologies Division (Publication) FACT
Affiliations: Murtha, Cullian, Richter &, Pinney Environment, Energy &, Natural Resources Group, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sussman, M.R., Murtha, Cullian, Richter &, Pinney Environment, Energy &, Natural Resources Group, United States; McCary, P.R., Murtha, Cullian, Richter &, Pinney Environment, Energy &, Natural Resources Group, United States
Abstract: A description is given of several environmental and energy regulatory problem areas which might be overlooked in assessing the feasibility of a co-combustion project. An examination is made of various environmental regulatory programs, emphasizing the impact these programs have on co-combustion projects. The multiple fuel characteristics of co-combustion projects often lead to special problems with respect to laws regulating air and water pollution, hazardous waste disposal, and fuel handling and storage. With respect to energy regulation, an analysis is made of how fuel savings expected from a co-combustion project using natural gas can evaporate (or, with proper planning, be amplified) once the full impacts of any gas demand charges are taken into account.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution--Legislation; Environmental Protection; Legislation; Waste Disposal--Legislation; Water Pollution--Legislation; Air Toxics; Co-Combustion; Federally-Regulated Pollutants; Gas Utility Tariffs; Fuels

Title: Power reflection techniques in susceptibility tests of electronic devices.
Affiliations: Univ of Bundeswehr, Munich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Kortstock, M., Univ of Bundeswehr, Munich, West Ger; Schmeer, H., Univ of Bundeswehr, Munich, West Ger
Abstract: A setup for statistical tests of electronic devices with fast transients is described. It contains a transient generator, the test box for the device-under-test (DUT), and a delay line along with a digitizing oscilloscope and personal computer. The purpose is to find a relationship between the damage threshold and time-dependent functions of the voltage, current, and power and the total energy absorbed in the DUT. The outgoing pulse of the generator is compared with the pulse reflected by the electronic device. An evaluation method based on time-domain reflectometry (TDR) and the Fourier transform is developed, taking into account experimental uncertainties. The minimum requirements for the digitizing scope are a sample frequency of at least 500 MHz and sufficient storage depth. The results are compared to measurements with known impedances of the DUT (resistors, short circuit and open end) for voltages below 2 kV; the differences are below 5%, which is tolerable in comparison to the maximum measuring error of the digitizing scope (typically 5%).
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL TRANSFORMATIONS -- Fourier Transforms; REFLECTOMETERS; STATISTICAL METHODS; DEVICE-UNDER-TEST; POWER REFLECTION TECHNIQUES; SUSCEPTIBILITY TESTS; TIME-DOMAIN REFLECTOMETRY; ELECTRON DEVICE TESTING

Authors: Ise Toshifumi, Skiles James J., Kustom Robert L., Wang Ju
Title: Circuit configuration of the GTO converter for superconducting magnetic energy storage.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ise, Toshifumi, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Skiles, James J., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Kustom, Robert L., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Wang, Ju, Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: The authors discuss the circuit configurations and design of two AC-to-DC power converters for superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) using gate-turn-off (GTO) thyristors. The circuits are current-source rectifiers, so that suppressing the overvoltage on the GTOs during commutation is an important consideration. Moreover, to get high conversion efficiency it is necessary to handle the commutation energy properly. Two circuits are presented for this purpose, and the detailed computer simulation of these circuits is discussed. The resulting design policies and characteristics for both circuits are described, and the best choice of converter circuit for SMES is determined.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC RECTIFIERS -- Computer Simulation; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS -- Analysis; PULSE WIDTH MODULATION -- Control; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS -- Energy Storage; THYRISTORS; CONVERTER CIRCUIT CONFIGURATION; GATE-TURN-OFF (GTO) THYRISTORS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE (SMES); ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Authors: Ouano A.C., Wu A.W., Park J., Pecora R.
Title: Brillouin spectroscopy and tribological properties of some lubricants for magnetic storage media
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: IBM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ouano, A.C., IBM, United States; Wu, A.W., IBM, United States; Park, J., IBM, United States; Pecora, R., IBM, United States
Abstract: The shear rates during head take-off and landing, and in the event of a head/disk interaction (HDI) during flying is so enormous (>106Hz) that the concept of viscosity as the single most important material property to characterize lubricants for magnetic disks application becomes questionable. Other material characteristics, i.e., mechanical/thermal energy dissipation at very high frequency is perhaps more appropriate. Brillouin Spectroscopy can give information on the sound attenuation coefficient (SAC) as well as the thermal diffusivity (k) of liquids/solids at Giga Hz frequency. Using this technique, the authors have obtained the SAC and k for several (9) well known lubricants and their Pin On Disk (POD) life. A good correlation between the tribological properties and the product of SAC and k was established.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic--Materials; Spectroscopy; Tribology; Abstract Form Only; Brillouin Spectroscopy; Magnetic Disks; Magnetic Storage Media; Lubricants

Title: Polymeric side chain liquid crystals for information storage
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Haase, W., Technical Univ of Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: Polymers with mesogenic groups as side chains are new materials for information storage and recording using the laser heating technique or for holography. Also, this material is of interest for nonlinear optics. The authors focus on two main points of interest: (i) the molecular dynamics under an applied electrical field; (ii) properties of dyes needed for energy absorption in the polymer matrix. It is of great importance to know about the relaxation processes, especially of the c-process near the glass or clearing point. The switching processes will be discussed. Also the properties of the dyes in the polymer matrix will be discussed. This contribution is concerned with cell technology and the device construction. Results of some experiments with ferroelectric polymers will be reported.
Index Keywords: Crystals, Liquid; Dyes and Dyeing; Holography--Materials; Optics--Nonlinear; Polymers--Physical Properties; Abstract Form Only; Mesogenic Groups; Polymer Matrix; Polymeric Side Chain Liquid Crystals; Data Storage, Digital

Title: Power for the ground-based free electron laser
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Materials Division (Publication) MD
Affiliations: Nichols Research Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sommers Jr., W.J., Nichols Research Corp, United States; Weed, R.A., Nichols Research Corp, United States
Abstract: The ground-based free electron laser (FEL) is a leading candidate for future strategic defense systems due to its wavelength tunability, power scalability, and relatively high efficiency. Electrical power requirements, however, exceed the state of the art when the high power, fast start-up, and low cost objectives are all considered. This paper addresses the power system options potentially applicable to meeting the FEL requirements and ranks their utility. It was found that energy storage technologies, in particular secondary batteries and superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES), are the most attractive concepts.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Superconducting Magnets--Energy Storage; Figure of Merit; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Lasers, Free Electron

Authors: Pai D.M., Ratterman E., Shaw M.C.
Title: Grinding forces and energy for brittle materials
Affiliations: North Carolina Agricultural &, Technical State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pai, D.M., North Carolina Agricultural &, Technical State Univ, United States; Ratterman, E., North Carolina Agricultural &, Technical State Univ, United States; Shaw, M.C., North Carolina Agricultural &, Technical State Univ, United States
Abstract: Grinding forces and energy are important to any grinding operation. For brittle materials, the specific grinding energy is much lower and the ratio of radial to tangential forces is much higher than for ductile materials. As in the case of metals, the specific grinding energy varies inversely with the mean undeformed chip thickness as long as the volume between wheel and work is sufficient to accommodate the chips produced. Otherwise, there is an increase in specific grinding energy due to a lack of chip storage space. The particular influence of the lack of chip storage space on grinding energy per unit volume depends upon the details of the chip storage problem pertaining. A specific example is presented in the form of a 2n factorial experimental design and the results used to discuss the general nature of the chip storage problem.
Index Keywords: Abrasives; Granite--Grinding; Rock--Grinding; Brittle Materials; Chip Storage; Grinding Forces; Materials

Title: High-pressure CO2 laser preionized by a new type of X-ray source using helium discharge.
Affiliations: CGT Cent for Research, Marcoussis, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Collier, F., CGT Cent for Research, Marcoussis, Fr; Vosluisant, Y., CGT Cent for Research, Marcoussis, Fr
Abstract: The author reports on a multiatmosphere CO2:N2He (1:1:8) laser operating in the self-sustained transverse discharge mode using X-ray preionization obtained from a novel source. The source is very similar to a classical X-ray cold-cathode gun. X-rays in the 10-40-keV range are produced from runaway electrons in a helium fast discharge with an overvoltage pulse of 60 kV driven by a Marx generator and applied on a 6-mm gap. X-ray generation has been optimized by action on parameters such as helium pressure, discharge gap width, cathode materials and cathode shape, applied voltage, and discharge current density. For helium pressure in the 0.1-0.5-mbar range and a discharge gap of 6 mm, 80% of the X-ray intensity measured in vacuum was obtained. X-ray photoelectron density in a CO2:N2:He (1:1:8) mixture and in argon has been determined from the conduction current measured into the laser chamber transformed in the ionization chamber. At 5 bars an electron density of 5 × 1073/cm-3 in the CO2 mixture and 4 × 109 in argon were found. Output laser energy of 80 mJ has been obtained at Vc = 35 kV under these conditions with a laser efficiency of 2%. The X-ray gun storage energy was only 1 J.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTRONS; HELIUM; IONIZATION; X-RAY AND GAMMA-RAY PRODUCTION; DIGEST OF PAPER; ELECTRON DENSITY; PREIONIZATION; SELF-SUSTAINED TRANSVERSE DISCHARGE MODE; X-RAY PHOTOELECTRON DENSITY; LASERS, CARBON DIOXIDE

Authors: Baldi R.W., Johnson R.A., Leung E.M., Kimmy E.R.
Title: Experience with large superconducting magnets and foreseeable future applications
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Materials Division (Publication) MD
Affiliations: General Dynamics, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baldi, R.W., General Dynamics, United States; Johnson, R.A., General Dynamics, United States; Leung, E.M., General Dynamics, United States; Kimmy, E.R., General Dynamics, United States
Abstract: General Dynamics is the largest producer of large superconducting magnets for U.S. Government applications. The Energy Programs group of the Space Systems Division has won over 65% of the superconducting magnet application contracts awarded by the U.S. Department of Energy over the past 12 years. These applications include thermonuclear fusion, magnetohydrodynamics, isotope separation, and accelerator magnets. Overall, General Dynamics has built 29 large superconducting magnets with a total contract value of over $83 million. At present, we have contracts involving space-based and ground-based magnetohydrodynamics, superconducting magnetic energy storage, and thermodynamic aspects of accelerator magnets. Potential near-term production of large-scale application includes superconducting magnets for the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC) and the Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES). Potential far-term production programs may include thermonuclear fusion, magnetohydrodynamics, and possibly electromagnetic launch.
Index Keywords: Accelerators; Magnetohydrodynamics; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Superconducting Super Collider; Superconducting Magnets

Title: Investigation of triboelectric effects in nonwoven fabric/floppy disk dynamic contact
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: MIT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tse, M.K., MIT, United States; Federspiel, C., MIT, United States
Abstract: When two surfaces are in dynamic contact, the materials may react simultaneously in a variety of ways: friction and wear (tribomechanical effects), increase in the interfacial temperature (tribothermal effects), photon-emission (triboluminescence), and electric charge redistribution (triboelectric effects). The author's previous work demonstrated that the energy of triboacoustic emission can be related to the nature of the diskette (nonwoven) liner fabric/ magnetic media dynamic contact in a floppy disk. This work involves a phenomenological study of the complex interactions between charge build-up and decay with materials, sliding conditions, and environment. Preliminary results indicate that much can be learned about the fabric/media contact through transient and steady-state triboelectric responses.
Index Keywords: Magnetic Materials--Friction; Textiles--Friction; Triboelectricity; Abstract Form Only; Charge Redistribution; Floppy Disk; Nonwoven Fabric; Triboacoustic Emission; Data Storage, Magnetic

Authors: Wang J., Skiles J., Kustom R., Ise T., Tsang F., Cleary J.
Title: Studies of power conditioning circuits for superconductive magnetic energy storage.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wang, J., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Skiles, J., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Kustom, R., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Ise, T., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Tsang, F., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA; Cleary, J., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: The superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) approach to utility-load leveling has the potential for very high energy conversion efficiency and fast response to changes in load demands. It can be used to improve utility system operation economics and system stabilities. The power-conditioning circuit interfacing an SMES and a utility network consists of thyristor or gate-turn-off (GTO) device bridges or the combinations of thyristor bridges and GTO bridges. The special requirements for power-conditioning circuits are discussed, and an experimental model system for testing the performance of the proposed circuits is described. The experimental studies concern power transfer of the model system, current balance control, independent real (P) and reactive (Q) power control, online numeric P-Q measurement, and protection of the SMES system. The proposed GTO circuit topology appears to satisfactorily provide independent real and reactive power control and maintain the high efficiency and fast response properties of the SMES system.
Index Keywords: DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; ELECTRIC LOADS -- Economics; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS -- Energy Storage; SYSTEM STABILITY; THYRISTORS; GATE-TURN-OFF (GTO) DEVICE BRIDGES; POWER CONDITIONING CIRCUITS; POWER TRANSFER; SUPERCONDUCTIVE MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE (SMES); UTILITY-LOAD LEVELING; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Authors: Ishigaki Yukio, Shirahama Hidefumi, Kuroda Kunishige
Title: Power control experiments using a 5 MJ superconducting magnetic energy storage system.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ishigaki, Yukio, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn; Shirahama, Hidefumi, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn; Kuroda, Kunishige, Hitachi Ltd, Hitachi, Jpn
Abstract: A theoretical approach to the simultaneous control of active power and reactive power that is based on decoupling control theory is proposed. The idea has been applied to a 5-MJ superconducting magnetic energy storage system connected to a 6600-V power line. The control performance was confirmed by a simulator test, a dummy test, and a real machine test. This system did use a dumping resistor for protection, but the stored energy in the magnet was successfully transferred back to the power line by the phase control operation of the thyristor converter in the dummy quenching test. Operation in the permanent-current mode was also verified, and the decay time of the permanent current was consistent with loss due to the forward voltage drop of the thyristor switch.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CONVERTERS; ELECTRIC LINES -- Protection; RESISTORS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS -- Energy Storage; THYRISTORS -- Switching; DUMPING RESISTOR; FORWARD VOLTAGE DROP; PERMANENT-CURRENT MODE OPERATION; PHASE CONTROL OPERATION; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Authors: Simmes Stephen D., Turner Charles J.
Title: Associative memories on the connection machine
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Parallel Processing
Affiliations: Science Applications Int Corp,, Tucson, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Simmes, Stephen D., Science Applications Int Corp,, Tucson, AZ, USA; Turner, Charles J., Science Applications Int Corp,, Tucson, AZ, USA
Abstract: The Hopfield associative memory on a Connection Machine (CM) is examined and a synchronous algorithm is derived that allows up to 1600 memory patterns, each 16K in size, on a 16K processor machine. The memory-recall time for such a setup is estimated to be approximately eight minutes on a CM-1. An expression for the asynchronous energy change during an interaction is derived, showing that the diagonal terms in the synaptic coupling matrix have an effect on the memory-recall process. These terms are generally set to zero in studies of associative memory. It is shown that this might not be the best strategy.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING -- Algorithms; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL -- Associative; CONNECTION MACHINE; HOPFIELD ASSOCIATIVE MEMORY; SYNAPTIC COUPLING MATRIX; COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL

Title: Integrated energy system
Affiliations: Windlight Workshop, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dankoff, Windy, Windlight Workshop, United States
Abstract: The integrated energy system works as a whole, which is greater than the sum of its parts. It contains subsystems that optimally work with each other and with the needs as they change through the seasons and the years. The integrated system is an attempt to combine multiple energy sources, storage and usage systems, for optimum economy. The paper shows how a well-planned 'whole system' can temper the feast or famine extremes of alternative energy, and reduce or eliminate the need for a backup mechanical generator.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Solar Cells; Solar Energy--Applications; Water Heaters; Integrated Energy System; Electric Power Systems

Title: American College of Greece solar heating and cooling project
Affiliations: Nuclear Research Cent 'Democritos', Greece
Authors with affiliations: Korres, C.J., Nuclear Research Cent 'Democritos', Greece; Bardakas, E.E., Nuclear Research Cent 'Democritos', Greece
Abstract: The construction of the American College of Greece (A.C.G.) solar project began in 1982 and was completed in 1986. This project, combines different applications of solar energy use, i.e. space heating and cooling and domestic hot water (DHW) production. The technical design of both installations was based upon the following assumptions: a) The collected solar energy, in the form of heat, should be used directly in meeting the instant requirements or the most probable peak energy demand of the building, both in space heating or cooling increased by the DHW production load. b) No heat storage was considered or used. However, for the sake of demonstrating the negative effect of the storage tank in the overall efficiency of the installation, a comparatively small storage tank was connected (12 lt of storage per m2 net aperture area of collector). c) The installation has to be as little automated as possible. On the crucial part of energy conservation, it has been estimated that a total saving of approximately 35 tons of oil equivalent (TOE) was surpassed.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning--Solar Energy Systems; School Buildings--Solar, Active; Water Heaters--Solar; Domestic Hot Water; Solartron Evacuated Tube Solar Collectors; Heating

Authors: Aleksandrov K.S., Seredkin V.A., Frolov G.I., Yakovchuk V.Yu.
Title: Optical storage in amorphous ferrimagnetic films
Authors with affiliations: Aleksandrov, K.S.; Seredkin, V.A.; Frolov, G.I.; Yakovchuk, V.Yu.
Abstract: A mechanism for thermomagnetic writing in amorphous films of alloys of rare-earth and transition metals is described. It is shown that data in analog form can be written in these materials. The interaction of short light pulses with a thin magnetic film is analyzed. It is found that significant internal pressures develop in the film during the exposure. Consequently, writing with a higher light sensitivity in terms of energy can be carried out in magnetostructure metal magnetic thin films than during thermomagnetic writing.
Index Keywords: Films--Amorphous; Magnetic Materials--Thin Films; Magnetism--Ferrimagnetism; Transition Metals; Perpendicular Anisotropy; Thermomagnetic Writing; Data Storage, Optical

Authors: Lockwood G.J., Muron D.J., Ruggles L.E., Chang J., Bloomquist D.D., Babcock S.R.
Title: Fiber-optic diagnostic for energy measurements.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lockwood, G.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Muron, D.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Ruggles, L.E., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Chang, J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Bloomquist, D.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA; Babcock, S.R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA
Abstract: A fiber-optic diagnostic based on calorimetry, which was developed to measure the total energy deposited in a liquid-filled load resistor, is presented. Thermodynamic calculations show that the fluid temperature comes to equilibrium in about two seconds and remains there for several tens of seconds. Thus, fluid temperature can determine the energy deposited. Using a fluoroptic thermometer, the change in temperature of a copper-sulfate-solution-load resistor was measured as a function of the energy stored in a capacitor bank. A comparison of these results with the calculated temperature rise shows agreement to ±3% over the energy range from 1.4 kJ to 5.9 kJ. Measurements were then made of the energy deposited in a sodium-chloride-solution-load resistor on the ripple accelerator. These were made as a function of energy stored in the Marx generator from 7.4 kJ to 21.2 kJ. Electrical measurements of the energy deposited made at the same time were high by an average of 8%.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS -- Testing; CALORIMETRY; CAPACITORS; ENERGY STORAGE -- Measurements; THERMODYNAMICS -- Calculations; FIBER-OPTIC DIAGNOSTIC; LIQUID-FILLED LOAD RESISTOR; MARX GENERATOR; RIPPLE ACCELERATOR; FIBER OPTICS

Authors: Bien A., Jodlowski W., Khafagy A.Z., Wolczko P.
Title: Fixed structure production optimization at limited energy supply
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Mining &, Metallurgy imu ontro C, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Bien, A., Technical Univ of Mining &, Metallurgy imu ontro C, Poland; Jodlowski, W., Technical Univ of Mining &, Metallurgy imu ontro C, Poland; Khafagy, A.Z., Technical Univ of Mining &, Metallurgy imu ontro C, Poland; Wolczko, P., Technical Univ of Mining &, Metallurgy imu ontro C, Poland
Abstract: A procedure is presented for determining a suboptimal strategy of switching off production plants when the power supply to them is periodically reduced. The problem is considered from the aspect of production of a fixed final product structure. Account is taken of: production facilities, work in process, storage facilities, relations between them, materials flow and waste management.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Utilization; Industrial Management; Industrial Plants--Electric Power; Inventory Control; Optimization; Energy Supply; Power Supply; Storage Facilities; Production Engineering

Authors: Ishikawa Tadao, Akita Shirabe, Taniguchi Haruhito, Kohso Seiichi, Tanaka Toshikatsu
Title: Power system stabilization by SMES using current-fed PWM power conditioner.
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Ind, Komae, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Ishikawa, Tadao, Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Ind, Komae, Jpn; Akita, Shirabe, Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Ind, Komae, Jpn; Taniguchi, Haruhito, Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Ind, Komae, Jpn; Kohso, Seiichi, Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Ind, Komae, Jpn; Tanaka, Toshikatsu, Central Research Inst of Electric, Power Ind, Komae, Jpn
Abstract: The power-system-stabilizing ability of a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit consisting of a superconducting coil and an AC/DC power conditioner has been examined experimentally using a model power system and a small SMES unit. A current-fed pulsewidth-modulated power conditioner was used to obtain maximum stabilizing effect by controlling active and reactive power simultaneously and independently. The power conditioner configuration, operating characteristics, and control scheme for power system stabilization are described. Experimental results showing the effectiveness of the approach are reported.
Index Keywords: PULSE WIDTH MODULATION; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS -- Energy Storage; SYSTEM STABILITY -- Control; ACTIVE AND REACTIVE POWER CONTROL; CURRENT-FED PULSEWIDTH-MODULATED POWER CONDITIONER; SMES SPINNING RESERVE; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE (SMES); ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Latent energy storage with salt and metal mixtures for solar dynamic applications
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of South Florida, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crane, R.A., Univ of South Florida, United States; Konstantinou, K.S., Univ of South Florida, United States
Abstract: This paper examines three design alternatives for the development of a solar dynamic heat receiver as applied to power systems operating in low earth orbit. These include a base line design used for comparison in ongoing NASA studies, a system incorporating a salt energy storage system with the salt dispersed within a metal mesh and a hybrid system incorporating both a molten salt and molten metal for energy storage. Based on a typical low earth orbit condition, designs are developed and compared to determine the effect of resultant conductivity, heat capacity and heat of fusion on system size, weight, temperature gradients, cycle turbine inlet temperature and material utilization.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Generation; Solar Power Plants--Orbiting; Temperature Distribution; Latent Energy Storage; Salt Energy Storage System; Solar Dynamic Heat Receiver; Solar Receiver Design; Thermal Storage Material; Solar Energy

Title: Learning internal representations in the Coulomb energy network
Affiliations: Nestor Inc, Providence, RI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Scofield, Christopher L., Nestor Inc, Providence, RI, USA
Abstract: The authors introduce a learning algorithm for the N-dimensional Coulomb network which is applicable to multilayer networks. The central idea is to define a potential energy of a collection of memory sites. Then each memory site is an attractor (or repeller) of other memory sites. With the proper definition of attractive and repulsive potentials between various memory sites, it is possible to minimize the energy of the collection of memories. The authors illustrate this procedure with the Coulomb potential and discuss a supervised learning algorithm using this method. This procedure may be applied to each layer of a multi-layer network. The method does not depend on the propagation of error through all layers; thus the system is modular, with each layer trainable independently. Finally, this system is applied to a network which learns the binary mapping for XOR.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Data Storage, Digital; Coulomb Energy Network; Energy Minimization; Independently Trainable Layers; N-Dimensional Coulomb Network; Supervised Learning Algorithm; Systems Science and Cybernetics

Title: Proceedings of the 23rd intersociety energy conversion engineering conference
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Abstract: This four-volume Conference Proceedings contains over 400 technical papers dealing with advanced energy conversion technology. The topics of the sessions include almost every area of space and terrestrial power generation methods. The volumes contain papers by topical areas for the convenience of the readers. Volume one includes papers on advanced air and heat engines, nuclear power sources, thermionic power generation and nuclear reactors for both space and terrestrial applications. Volume two deals with energy storage systems, fuel cells, electric power sources and storage, and superconductivity research work. Volume three contains papers on space power sources while volume four has papers on wind energy, solar energy, alternative fuels and magnetohydrodynamics.
Index Keywords: Air Engines--Design; Nuclear Power Plants--Space Applications; Solar Energy; Superconductivity--Research; Thermionic Power Generation--Research; Aerospace Power; EIREV; Energy Conversion; Space Power Sources; Stirling Engines; Thermal Energy Storage; Power Generation

Authors: Goodwin James M., Rosen Bruce, Vidal Jacques J.
Title: Exploration of learning in an associative magnetic processor
Affiliations: Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Goodwin, James M., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA; Rosen, Bruce, Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA; Vidal, Jacques J., Univ of California, Los Angeles, CA,, USA
Abstract: The authors previously proposed a physical implementation of an amorphous magnetic processor functioning as a fast associative memory with massive information storage. An amorphous magnetic material, such as a spun glass film, is used. Magnetic particles, which orient along or against the direction of local magnetic fields (called spins) in a film, play the role of neurons or units in a neural net. Magnetic interactions in the film serve the role of weights in a connectionist neural net model. The film is taught a series of pattern vectors imposed by local laser heating in a magnetic field by allowing the magnetic spins of the system to move and seek a self-consistent energy minimum. The energy landscape created effectively stores a set of pattern vectors and permits their subsequent retrieval. The authors explore two training procedures (learning rules) and discuss computer simulations by which the effectiveness of learning in this machine can be studied. In addition to its use as associative memory, its use for data compression and unsupervised feature direction is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Data Storage, Digital--Associative; Data Storage, Magnetic--Film; Magnetic Fields; Associative Magnetic Processor; Magnetic Spins; Pattern Vectors; Systems Science and Cybernetics

Authors: Samant M.G., Robinson C.J., Marinero E.E., Cargill III G.S.
Title: EXAFS study of atomic structure and relaxation phenomena in amorphous Tb20Fe80
Affiliations: IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Rd, San Jose, CA 95120-6099, United States; IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Samant, M.G., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Rd, San Jose, CA 95120-6099, United States; Robinson, C.J., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Rd, San Jose, CA 95120-6099, United States; Marinero, E.E., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Rd, San Jose, CA 95120-6099, United States; Cargill III, G.S., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: We have used EXAFS to investigate the local atomic structure and its change with annealing for amorphous, sputtered Tb20Fe80 alloy films. The structural and magnetic properties of these materials are of particular current interest because of applications for magneto-optic storage which require well controlled magnetic anisotropy. The major result from the Tb LIII and Fe K EXAFS measurements on Tb20Fe80 alloy films is that the distribution of TbFe nearest neighbor distances is significantly broader than the distribution of FeFe nearest neighbor distances. Annealing at 200C for 20h, which reduces magnetic anisotropy by about 50%, slightly alters both Tb and Fe environments. Annealing at 400C for 2h causes much more drastic structural changes: precipitation of crystalline, bcc Fe; major change of the near neighbor environment of Tb; and increase of the Tb LIII edge energy by about 1 eV. © 1988.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic; Data Storage, Optical--Materials; Heat Treatment--Annealing; Magnetic Properties; Mathematical Transformations--Fourier Transforms; Atomic Structure; Extended X-Ray Absorption Fine Structure; Magnetic Anisotropy; Terbium Iron Alloys

Title: Thermodynamic analysis of chemically reactive systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 11 papers discussing innovative techniques and case studies involving the analysis, design, and optimization of the effective use of chemical energy/exergy including combustion and controlled chemical reactors. Thermodynamic objective functions in distillation sequence synthesis are presented. One paper presents a thermoeconomic study of a sugar factory, and another presents an analytical determination of the specific heat of electrolyte solutions. Energy and exergy analysis of production processes, and thermodynamic analysis of indirect injection diesel engines are aspects also discussed.
Index Keywords: Diesel Engines--Combustion; Economics; Electrolytes--Specific Heat; Energy Storage; Sugar Factories--Thermodynamics; Chemical Process Exergy Analysis; Combustion Two Zone Modeling; EIREV; Energy Storage/Mechanical Energy; Fossil Fuel Combustion; Gibbs Free Energy Formulation; Thermodynamics

Title: Use of phase change chemicals for reserve cooling and energy conserving cooling systems in telecommunication equipment buildings
Affiliations: Telecom Australia, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Prudhoe, Robert K., Telecom Australia, Aust; Longland, David, Telecom Australia, Aust
Abstract: The authors outline Telecom Australia's development work and achievements in the use of the relatively high latent heat of fusion and thermal storage of phase change chemicals (PCC). Novel PCC applications, which have been successfully implemented into the Australian telecommunications network, relate to the use of PCC encapsulated in 1-m-long plastic tubes to provide room temperature control after failure of the normal cooling plant. Experience has shown that the use of PCC in suitable installations can provide a simple, low-cost, maintenance-free solution to protect temperature-sensitive electronic equipment from excessive temperature rise during times of loss of normal cooling. The authors introduce a novel type of energy-conserving cooling system currently under testing and evaluation. This system combines the use of a variable-volume fresh-air cycle for normal operation on cool days, with refrigeration-type cooling on hot days, coupled with a PCC thermal storage to provide reserve cooling, for enhanced reliability.
Index Keywords: Air Conditioning; Refrigerants; Telephone Exchanges--Cooling; Phase Change Chemicals (PCC); Telecommunication Equipment Buildings; Telecommunication Equipment

Authors: Kawakami S., Maeda K., Yoshida S., Matsumoto K., Imaizumi H., Kato T.
Title: Application of heat pipes to a thermal storage cooling system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Kohnoike Gumi Co, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kawakami, S., Kohnoike Gumi Co, Japan; Maeda, K., Kohnoike Gumi Co, Japan; Yoshida, S., Kohnoike Gumi Co, Japan; Matsumoto, K., Kohnoike Gumi Co, Japan; Imaizumi, H., Kohnoike Gumi Co, Japan; Kato, T., Kohnoike Gumi Co, Japan
Abstract: In previous work, an innovative thermal storage cooling system was proposed by the authors. It was shown at that time that the unique properties of heat pipes proved to be very effective in the production of ice and as a result a very compact thermal storage system based on ice as the storage media was designed. This paper presents the advantages of the Heat Pipe-Ice Storage System over ordinary coil systems which utilize either a refrigerant or brine solution as the transfer media. The operating performance characteristics of a 260 U.S. REFRIGERATION TON (USRT) heat pipe based air conditioning system incorporating 50 mm. (2 in.) diameter heat pipes for a 3000 square meters (10,000 square feet) building are reported.
Index Keywords: Ice--Storage; Energy Release Cycle; Heat Pipe-Ice Storage System; Ice Production Rates; Thermal Storage Cooling System; Thermal Storage Performance; Heat Pipes

Title: Analysis of single flying capacitor converter by the state-space averaging technique
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bilgic, M.O., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA; Ehsani, M., Texas A&M Univ, College Station,, TX, USA
Abstract: The single flying capacitor converter (SFCC) is a two-quadrant power supply for energy storage and transfer system. It has applications in nuclear research and pulsed power systems in which superconductive coils are used in superconductive magnets. The authors derive analytical expressions for the time-averaged behavior of the SFCC by using the state-space averaging technique. Useful expressions are found for the average behavior of the SFCC. The results can be used in the design, control, and optimum operation of the system.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--State Space Methods; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion; Superconducting Magnets--Electric Power Supplies; DC-DC Current Chopper; Single Flying Capacitor Converter (SFCC); State Space Averaging Technique; Electric Converters, Power Type

Title: Proceedings of the fourth European symposium on thermal analysis and calorimetry
Abstract: This issue contains 68 papers from the symposium, dealing generally with thermal analysis and calorimetry in relation to inorganic chemistry, glass, and ceramics. Some papers typical of the areas of interest are cited as examples: TG study on the reduction kinetics of hematite and iron oxide-containing water; temperature-dependence of interfacial energies between solid oxide ceramics and liquid metals; use of EGD for the characterization of fining processes of glass melt; estimation of specific heats of metallic foils by the pulse method; thermoanalytical investigation of sodium acetate trihydrate for application as a latent heat thermal energy storage system; zeolite content determination in kaolinic clays via thermal effects; heat capacity of neutron-irradiated silica glass; DTA of water-salt glasses; thermal stabilities of new complexes of magnesium nitrate, acetate, phosphate with amide ligands; and DTA and chemical characteristics of YBa2Cu3O6.5+y superconductor processing from different raw materials. All papers are abstracted separately.
Index Keywords: Calorimetry--Applications; Ceramic Materials--Phase Transitions; Glass--Thermal Effects; Organometallics--Decomposition; Superconducting Materials--Thermoanalysis; Dehydration Kinetics; EIREV; Hydration Kinetics; Rare Earth Oxides; Thermal Decomposition; Transition Metal Complexes; Thermoanalysis

Title: Analysis of time-dependent thermal systems (Presented at the winter annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers)
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 9 papers discussing recent innovation in the analysis, design and optimization of thermal systems. The papers discuss a ramp wave analysis of heat pump systems, and present a model for a refrigerant condenser. An analysis is presented of the transient operation of solar-driven absorption units, and a simple transient heating coil model is also provided. High temperature thermal energy storage for space power systems in a topic also discussed.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Heat Pump Systems; Refrigerating Machinery--Condensers; Refrigeration--Solar; Thermodynamics; Cool Storage System Thermal Analysis; EIREV; High Temperature Energy Storage; Solid-Vapor Heat Pump Analysis; Thermal Systems Modeling; Transient Heating Coil Model; Energy Management

Authors: Nair P.K., Campos J., Nair M.T.S.
Title: Opto-electronic characteristics of chemically deposited cadmium sulphide thin films
Affiliations: Lab. de Energia Solar, IIM, Univ. Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Nair, P.K., Lab. de Energia Solar, IIM, Univ. Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico; Campos, J., Lab. de Energia Solar, IIM, Univ. Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico; Nair, M.T.S., Lab. de Energia Solar, IIM, Univ. Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico
Abstract: Cadmium sulphide thin films showing photo-to-dark conductivity ratio up to 109 and photoconductivity up to 3 Omega -1 cm-1 for white illumination approximately 300 W m-2 can be prepared from chemical baths containing thiourea and triethanolamine complex of cadmium ions. The photocurrent decay time depends on the bath temperature and the duration of storage and it ranges from a few seconds to 104 s per decade. The optical transmission of the films also varies significantly: from about 10% to 70-80% (above the band-gap absorption), depending on the deposition conditions. The high activation energy approximately=1 eV for dark conductivity as well as the high photosensitivity suggest the nearly stoichiometric nature of the films. The implications of these characteristics in various opto-electronic applications are discussed.
Index Keywords: OPTOELECTRONIC DEVICES; PHOTOCONDUCTIVITY; CADMIUM SULFIDE; STOICHIOMETRY; THIOUREA; TRIETHANOLAMINE; SEMICONDUCTING CADMIUM COMPOUNDS

Title: Autonomous wind-diesel systems for remote applications
Affiliations: Rutherford Appleton Lab, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lipman, N.H., Rutherford Appleton Lab, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper is made up of three main elements: 1) A look at the main design questions for wind/diesel systems. The criteria affecting design choices for the diesel sets, wind turbines and energy stores are briefly surveyed. 2) Examples of current Research and Development and Demonstration projects are given, ranging from small supplies of a few kW to large systems up to 1MW. 3) There is a separate discussion of the largest systems (multi-megawatt) which include a number of diesel sets on an isolated grid, and which permit 'multiple-diesel strategies' to be operated.
Index Keywords: Diesel Engines--Design; Flywheels--Energy Storage; Autonomous Wind-Diesel Systems; Load Control Schemes; Multiple Diesel Grids; Wind Turbine Sizing; Wind Turbines

Title: The effect of Frenkel defect formation on spherical SiO2 precipitate growth in silicon wafers
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tiller, W.A., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Oh, S., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: A general analytic solution is given to the sphere-growth problem which includes (1) oxygen and point defect transport, (2) interface reaction kinetics, (3) surface energy, and (4) strain energy storage. Short, intermediate, and long time behaviors are given. In the long time domain, where the Peclet number for oxygen is constant provided the far field conditions are constant, the growth rate is dominated at low and intermediate temperatures primarily by silicon interstitial formation and somewhat by strain energy storage. At high temperatures (≳1150 °C), these effects become small and the interface begins to approach the thermodynamic equilibrium state. However, at all lower temperatures, the supersaturation of silicon interstitials at the SiO 2/Si interface is very large and the interface is far from the thermodynamic equilibrium. Extension of the mathematical approach to precipitates of other shapes is also given.

Authors: Maeda Y., Andoh H., Ikuta I., Minemura H.
Title: Reversible phase-change optical data storage in InSbTe alloy films
Affiliations: Hitachi Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd., Hitachi 319-12, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Maeda, Y., Hitachi Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd., Hitachi 319-12, Japan; Andoh, H., Hitachi Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd., Hitachi 319-12, Japan; Ikuta, I., Hitachi Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd., Hitachi 319-12, Japan; Minemura, H., Hitachi Research Laboratory, Hitachi Ltd., Hitachi 319-12, Japan
Abstract: Some characteristics of reversible phase-change optical data storage based on an amorphous-crystalline transformation in InSbTe alloys are given. The reversible phase change was observed in a wide region of composition. The laser amorphized spot of a ternary compound In3SbTe2 film could be crystallized using a diode laser pulse of less than 100 ns with an incident laser power of more than 10 mW. The crystallization temperature of the amorphized spot was 280°C and the activation energy was about 1.8 eV which shows that long-term data retention at room temperature is possible. The repetition number of static write and erase using the pulse of 50 ns reached above 105.
