These data show that the ternary compound film has potential for reversible optical data storage media with high-speed erasing and long-term data retention.

Authors: Read M.E., Dudas A.J., Oettinger P.E.
Title: High current density cathodes for microwave tubes
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Physical Sciences, Incorporated, 635 Slaters Lane, Suite G-101, Alexandria, VA, 22314, United States; Thermo Electron Technologies Corporation, 74 West Street, Waltham, MA, 02254-9046, United States
Authors with affiliations: Read, M.E., Physical Sciences, Incorporated, 635 Slaters Lane, Suite G-101, Alexandria, VA, 22314, United States; Dudas, A.J., Physical Sciences, Incorporated, 635 Slaters Lane, Suite G-101, Alexandria, VA, 22314, United States; Oettinger, P.E., Thermo Electron Technologies Corporation, 74 West Street, Waltham, MA, 02254-9046, United States
Abstract: There has been a recent resurgence in the research and development of high power microwave sources, spurred by the growth of pulse power technology, wherein advances in energy storage and pulse forming have made possible the generation of electron beams with peak powers over 4 Terawatts. These beams can generate microwaves and millimeter waves with impressive intensity over a wide frequency range. Unfortunately, these high peak powers have been achieved, with few exceptions, with pulse lengths less than 100 ns, and, therefore low energy content. Moreover, the pulse repetition rate has been very low, with a measured peak of approximately 50 Hz. Such limitations in pulse length and repetition rate have been due to the characteristics of the accelerators and the nature of the cathode sources of the electron beams. However, lately, significant advances have been made in accelerator technology allowing the generation of pulses with microsecond pulse lengths and peak powers of 10 GW. © 1988 SPIE.

Title: Development of energy efficient sodium sulphur battery aided with 'smart' control devices
Affiliations: Powerplex Technologies Inc, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Spek, Erik, Powerplex Technologies Inc, Canada
Abstract: Microprocessor-based controllers are holding temperature to within 1% of target, ending product-destroying temperature overshoots in a critical bonding operation in the production of sodium sulphur (NaS) batteries. The NaS batteries produced at the company store about three times more energy and produce twice the horsepower of comparable lead-acid batteries. At 570 lb., they measure 56-in. long, 19-in. wide and 14-in. in height. The NaS battery requires 360 cells-each cylindrical in shape, about 10-in. long. Cell components include an exterior aluminum casing, which contains a beta alumina ceramic tube filled with sodium metal. Molten sulphur is placed in the area between the casing and the ceramic. When the sodium and sulphur chemically interact, they produce a high-density energy electrochemical cell.
Index Keywords: Process Control; Sodium and Alloys; Storage Battery Vehicles; Sulfur; Temperature Control - Computer Applications; Beta Alumina Ceramic Tubes; Energy Efficiency; Sodium Sulfur Cells; Thermal Compression Bonding; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Adaptations of the reed frog Hyperolius viridiflavus (Amphibia, Anura, Hyperoliidae) to its arid environment - IV. Ecological significance of water economy with comments on thermoregulation and energy allocation
Affiliations: Zoologisches Institut der Universität, Röntgenring 10, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Geise, W., Zoologisches Institut der Universität, Röntgenring 10, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany; Linsenmair, K.E., Zoologisches Institut der Universität, Röntgenring 10, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany
Abstract: After breeding African savanna dwelling reed-frogs of the "superspecies" Hyperolius viridiflavus face a severe dry season. The frogs withstand the adverse abiotic conditions in exposed positions, clinging to dry vegetation. Only juveniles (300-700 mg) are able to adjust water economy and metabolism to a prolonged dry season. Wet season frogs attain low levels of evaporative water loss (EWL) within 6-8 days after incipient water shortage. This time course is mainly determined by the animal's ability to lower metabolism and activity level to the minimum demands of a dry season. Barriers against diffusion of water which most probably are built up by the stratum corneum and/or the overlying film of dried mucus seem not to be essentially modified during adjustment to dry season conditions. Changeover to dry season physiology is greatly accelerated through preconditioning frogs to water shortage. Adult Hyperoliusare unable to reduce activity and metabolism as fast and effectively as juveniles. Most probably these are the main reasons for their very restricted survival capability under dry season conditions; the generally poor energy reserves after the breeding period may further shorten their survival time. At the critical thermal maximum (CTM) Hyperolius uses skin gland secretions for evaporative cooling. Acclimation effects and regulation of evaporative cooling within some 1/10° C help to employ limited water reserves very economically. Dry adapted, dehydrated frogs take up water, whenever available, via specialized skin areas. Rate of uptake is high and is mainly determined by the actual stage of dehydration. The onset of the water-balance-response is also affected by preconditioning. Survival time of small (<500 mg) estivating Hyperolius is limited by their water reserves.Due to their unfavourable surface to volume ratio they loserelatively more water by evaporation than larger conspecifics. Therefore, smaller specimens should allocate energy preferably to growth, until reducing EWL so far to survive the average periods between the rare precipitations. In larger frogs (>500 mg) the amount of stored energy determines maximal survival time. When a critical size is reached in postmetamorphic growth, a change in energy allocation from body growth to energy storage would improve prospects of survival and should therefore be expected. Species specific differences in regard to EWL and CTM indicate a strong correlation between physiological properties and ecological demands. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Estivation; Hyperolius; Thermoregulation; Water-balance
Index Keywords: Anura; arid; frog; reed frog; thermoregulation; water use; Amphibia; Anura; Hyperoliidae; Hyperolius; Hyperolius viridiflavus; Phragmites

Authors: Witkowski Francis X., Penkoske Patricia A.
Title: New system design for transmural directly coupled (DC) cardiac mapping in vivo
Source title: IEEE/Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society Annual Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Alberta, Pediatrics &, Surgery, Dep of Internal Medicine,, Edmonton, Alberta, Can
Authors with affiliations: Witkowski, Francis X., Univ of Alberta, Pediatrics &, Surgery, Dep of Internal Medicine,, Edmonton, Alberta, Can; Penkoske, Patricia A., Univ of Alberta, Pediatrics &, Surgery, Dep of Internal Medicine,, Edmonton, Alberta, Can
Abstract: Improved methods for assessing three-dimensional distributions and rapid temporal changes of activation, repolarization, and systolic and diastolic potentials in extracellular unipolar electrogram recordings would enhance studies of arrhythmogenesis. To assess all these parameters requires directly coupled (DC) mapping techniques. DC coupling offers further advantages in its rapid response characteristics to high-energy defibrillatory impulses. A system has been developed that utilizes DC unipolar transmural recording electrodes coupled to appropriate processing, analog-to-digital conversion, and digital storage of 384 channels simultaneously for up to 60 minutes. This 3.5-Gbyte data stream is then rapidly processed using high-resolution digital displays and interactive graphics software with three-dimensional data presentation.
Index Keywords: Computer Graphics--Interactive; Data Conversion, Analog to Digital; Data Processing--Data Acquisition; Signal Processing--Digital Techniques; Arrhythmogenesis; Directly Coupled Cardiac Mapping; Extracellular Unipolar Electrogram Recordings; In Vivo Cardiac Mapping; Biomedical Engineering

Authors: Akhmatova T.G., Kichaeva G.S., Shkuropat P.I.
Title: Initiation of pulse discharge on dielectric surface in highcurrent vacuum commutators
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Leningrad Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Akhmatova, T.G., Leningrad Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Kichaeva, G.S., Leningrad Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Shkuropat, P.I., Leningrad Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: An effective method for the high-speed formation of sparktriggered pulse discharge in the form of a plasma layer on a dielectric surface in a ″technical″ vacuum of 10-210-1 Pa for low-inductance high-current commutators of high-energy capacitive storage devices for controlled thermonuclear fusion research is developed and studied. The results of an experimental study of the delay of controlled actuation of the commutator at voltages that are considerably lower than the static breakdown voltage and the commutation times with variation of the current in the control circuit and the initial pressure with control of the trigger spark at the cathode far from the dielectric wall and immediately at the wall are compared. The development of high-current discharge initiated at a dielectric surface is governed mainly by electron-avalanche processes in the layer of gas desorbed from the surface.
Index Keywords: Dielectric Materials - Electric Breakdown; Electric Sparks; Nuclear Reactors, Fusion - Electric Equipment; Plasmas - Production; Pulse Generators - Performance; Controlled Actuation; Electron Avalanche Processes; High Current Vacuum Commutators; High Energy Capacitive Storage Devices; Pulse Discharge Initiation; Spark Triggered Pulse Discharges; Electric Switches

Authors: Kunin V.N., Konopasov N.G., Pleshivtsev V.S.
Title: Inductive storage device
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Vladimir Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kunin, V.N., Vladimir Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Konopasov, N.G., Vladimir Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation; Pleshivtsev, V.S., Vladimir Polytechnic Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: An inductive storage device used to generate electrical pulses in experiments on the formation of plasmoids at atmospheric pressure is described. The stored energy is approximately 0.5 MJ and the discharge produces current pulses with a duration of 0.1 sec. The device is based on a U-shaped open core of transformer iron with a weight of 22 tons wound with fifteen parallel turns of copper wire. The ratio of stored energy to mass makes the device inferior to capacitive and impact type storage devices due to the fact that the inductance of the device was selected in accordance with the resistance of the load (plasmoid) to obtain an optimum discharge time constant for gas-dynamic formation of a plasma eddy. The advantages of the device, however, include matching to the load, simplicity, convenience, short pulse-production preparation time, safety, and comparatively low cost per unit of stored energy.
Index Keywords: Electric Discharges; Electric Inductors - Energy Storage; Electronic Circuits, Switching; Magnetic Cores; Plasmas - Production; Electric Loads; Inductive Storage Devices; Open Cores; Plasma Eddy Formation; Plasmoid Production; Transformer Iron Cores; Pulse Generators

Title: Advanced batteries pegged for load levelling
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Zinc-bromine and sodium-sulfur batteries present an attractive approach to meeting peak-demand requirements by supplying energy which is stored during off-peak periods. Battery energy storage conserves fossil fuels, is environmentally clean, and offers the additional capability of supplying reserve power during unplanned outages.
Index Keywords: Bromine Compounds--Applications; Electric Utilities; Sodium Compounds--Applications; Sulfur Compounds--Applications; Zinc Compounds--Applications; Cost Considerations; Load Levelling; Peak-Clipping Ability; Sodium Sulfur System; Zinc-Bromine Systems; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: New lead-acid battery storage facility aids utility load leveling
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This article describes the first modern-day Load-Leveling lead acid battery energy storage plant in the U.S. The 10 MW, 4 hour facility is sited at Chino, California. Plant benefits include siting flexibility, short lead times, and the ability to be put on line in milliseconds.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Electric Power Plants--Standby Service; Electric Utilities; Industrial Plants--Design; Battery Demonstration Plant; Lead-Acid Battery Storage Facility; Plant Performance Parameters; Utility Load Leveling; Energy Storage

Title: Space station energy storage system development
Authors with affiliations: Price, Robert O.
Abstract: Low earth orbit (LEO) space stations and dedicated platforms, which utilize electric power generated by solar photovoltaic or solar thermal dynamic technology, require some type of energy storage system to supply electrical power when the spacecraft is eclipsed by the earth's shadow. At the 330-460 kilometer orbital altitude of the proposed NASA Space Station, this eclipse period will be approximately 36 minutes. Energy storage capability is also required to provide power under contingency conditions should, for example, the electric power system (EPS) fail due to loss of station orientation. Consequently, a portion of the energy converted by the station's photovoltaic solar array assemblies (SAAs) must be diverted to an energy storage assembly (ESA). This paper explores the characteristics of the alternative energy storage system candidates evaluated for deployment aboard the Space Station, as well as the storage technology finally selected.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary; Electric Power Systems; Fuel Cells; Low Earth Orbit Space Stations; NASA Space Station; Nickel Cadmium Batteries; Nickel Hydrogen Batteries; Photovoltaic Solar Array Assemblies; Space Platforms

Title: Why not recycle the landfill
Affiliations: Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vasuki, N.C., Delaware Solid Waste Authority, United States
Abstract: A holistic approach to solid waste disposal usually includes four main components: materials recovery, composting, energy recovery (usually through combustion), and long-term storage (landfilling). Although all four components must be carefully integrated for successful system design and operation, it is the last one, landfilling, that is most critical. This article describes the method used for site selection and a site that the Delaware Solid Waste Authority plans to experiment with in its approach of in-the-landfill recycling.
Index Keywords: Waste Disposal--Recycling; Capital Cost Estimates; Delaware Solid Waste Authority; Landfill Liners; Refuse Disposal

Title: Flash drying and milling techniques for high moisture brown rice
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Hirosaki Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bekki, Eiji, Hirosaki Univ, Japan; Kunze, Otto R., Hirosaki Univ, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes experiments that utilized heated air to flash-dry bran layers on high-moisture brown rice while the grains were being milled. Temperature of the drying air was 55°C. A 40-s million period was used along with 810, 1020, 1310 and 1500 rpm abrasive mill speeds with brown rice of 16, 18 and 20% moisture content. Recovery rates (wt. of milled rice to brown rice) between 86 and 98% were observed. With a recovery rate of 91%, the broken ratio (wt. of broken grains to total milled rice) was 0.1% or less. Energy consumption to mill the high-moisture brown rice was significantly reduced when compared to control experiments in which brown rice was milled at storage moisture. However, the control samples showed more whiteness and had a higher bulk density that the high-moisture milled rice.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Products--Crushing and Grinding; Biological Materials--Moisture; Grinding Mills--Energy Conservation; Brown Rice; Crushing Strength; Dry Milling; Energy Consumption; Flash Drying; Milling Techniques; Grain

Authors: Ehmke A., von Borstel K., Hartmann T.
Title: Alkaloid N-oxides as transport and vacuolar storage compounds of pyrrolizidine alkaloids in Senecio vulgaris L
Affiliations: Institut für Pharmazeutische Biologie der Technischen Universität Braunschweig, Mendelssohnstrasse 1, Braunschweig, D-3300, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ehmke, A., Institut für Pharmazeutische Biologie der Technischen Universität Braunschweig, Mendelssohnstrasse 1, Braunschweig, D-3300, Germany; von Borstel, K., Institut für Pharmazeutische Biologie der Technischen Universität Braunschweig, Mendelssohnstrasse 1, Braunschweig, D-3300, Germany; Hartmann, T., Institut für Pharmazeutische Biologie der Technischen Universität Braunschweig, Mendelssohnstrasse 1, Braunschweig, D-3300, Germany
Abstract: Cell-suspension cultures of pyrrolizidinealkaloid-producing species selectively take up and accumulate senecionine (sen) and its N-oxide (sen-Nox). Cultures established from non-alkaloid-producing species are unable to accumulate the alkaloids. The uptake and accumulation of 14C-labelled alkaloids was studied using a Senecio vulgaris cell-suspension culture as well as protoplasts and vacuoles derived from it. The alkaloid uptake exhibits all characteristics of a carrier-mediated transport. The uptake of sen-Nox follows a multiphasic saturation kinetics. The Km-values for sen Nox of 53 μM and 310 μM are evaluated. Senecionine competitively inhibits sen-Nox uptake, indicating that the tertiary alkaloid and its N-oxide share the same membrane carrier. The N-oxide of sen shows a pH optimum below 5.5, whereas sen is taken up over a range from pH 4 to 8. Activation energies of 90 and 53 kJ·mol-1 are calculated for sen-Nox and sen transport, respectively. At concentrations of 10 to 100 μM, sen-Nox is rapidly taken up by cells and protoplasts; within 2 h >90% of total N-oxide is within the cells. By contrast the uptake of sen is less efficient. Vacuoles isolated from protoplasts preloaded with sen-Nox totally retained the alkaloid N-oxide, whereas sen is rapidly lost during the procedure of vacuole preparation. N-oxidation converts the weak lipophilic tertiary base into a charged polar molecule which is excellently adapted to serve as the cellular transport and storage form of pyrrolizidine alkaloids. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Alkaloid N-oxide (transport, accumulation); Cell culture (alkaloids); Protoplast; Pyrrolizidine alkaloid; Senecio; Vacuole (alkaloid storage)

Authors: Siegmund O.H.W., Everman E., Hull J., Vallerga J.V., Lampton M.
Title: Soft x-ray and extreme ultraviolet quantum detection efficiency of potassium chloride photocathode layers on microchannel plates
Affiliations: University of California-Berkeley, Space Sciences Laboratory, CA, 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siegmund, O.H.W., University of California-Berkeley, Space Sciences Laboratory, CA, 94720, United States; Everman, E., University of California-Berkeley, Space Sciences Laboratory, CA, 94720, United States; Hull, J., University of California-Berkeley, Space Sciences Laboratory, CA, 94720, United States; Vallerga, J.V., University of California-Berkeley, Space Sciences Laboratory, CA, 94720, United States; Lampton, M., University of California-Berkeley, Space Sciences Laboratory, CA, 94720, United States
Abstract: We present measurements of the quantum detection efficiency (QDE) of potassium chloride, applied directly to the surface of a microchannel plate (MCP), over the 44-1460-Å wavelength range. The contributions of the photocathode material in the channels, and on the interchannel web, to the QDE have been determined.Two broad peaks in the QDE centered at λ ≅ 500 A and λ ≅ 900 Å are apparent, the former with −40% peak QDE and the latter with −30% peak QDE. The photoelectric threshold is observedat λ∼ 1400 Å, and there is a narrow QDE minimum at λ∼670 Å, which correlates with 2× the band gap energy for KC1. The angular variation of the QDE from 0 to 35° to the channel axis has also been examined. We describe a simple QDE model and show that its predictions are in accord with our QDE measurements. Assessment of the stability of KC1 shows that therewas no significant degradation of the QDE at wavelengths of ≤ 1066 Å during a 4-month storage period in dry nitrogen with a limited exposure to air. © 1988 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Nicolaides C.A., Valtazanos P., Bacalis N.C.
Title: Excited molecules and clusters in solid media. Hydrogen and tetrahydrogen in ionic crystals
Affiliations: Theoretical and Physical Chemistry Institute, National Hellenic Research Foundation, 48, Vas. Constantinou Ave, Athens, 116 35, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Nicolaides, C.A., Theoretical and Physical Chemistry Institute, National Hellenic Research Foundation, 48, Vas. Constantinou Ave, Athens, 116 35, Greece; Valtazanos, P., Theoretical and Physical Chemistry Institute, National Hellenic Research Foundation, 48, Vas. Constantinou Ave, Athens, 116 35, Greece; Bacalis, N.C., Theoretical and Physical Chemistry Institute, National Hellenic Research Foundation, 48, Vas. Constantinou Ave, Athens, 116 35, Greece
Abstract: We present accurate results from full CI calculations on ground and excited states of H2 and (H2)2 embedded in AgF and RbI solids. It is found that the effect of these crystals on the spectra and on the energy surface characteristics is considerable. This finding suggests that, with a suitable selection of solid media, it may become possible to manipulate substantially the electronic spectroscopy and the energy storage and dissipation of certain classes of molecules and clusters. © 1988.

Title: The effect of rejuvenation of aged erythrocytes on biochemical parameters in the perfused hind limb muscle preparation
Affiliations: Clinical Nutrition and Metabolism Unit, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London, United Kingdom; Division of Clinical Cell Biology, MRC Clinical Research Centre, Harrow, Middlesex, United Kingdom; Rowett Research Institute, Bucksburn, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Preedy, V.R., Clinical Nutrition and Metabolism Unit, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London, United Kingdom, Division of Clinical Cell Biology, MRC Clinical Research Centre, Harrow, Middlesex, United Kingdom; Garlick, P.J., Clinical Nutrition and Metabolism Unit, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, London, United Kingdom, Rowett Research Institute, Bucksburn, Aberdeen, United Kingdom
Abstract: (1) A systematic investigation was carried out into the use of time-expired erythrocytes in an isolated perfused skeletal muscle preparation. Comparisons were made between erythrocytes subjected to a process of 'rejuvenation' (Rennie and Holloszy (1977), Biochem. J. 168, 161-170) and untreated erythrocytes (controls). (2) The use of rejuvenated erythrocytes had no significant effect on concentrations of muscle ATP, phosphocreatine and lactate, nor fractional rates of muscle protein synthesis. However, muscle water concentrations were reduced when compared to controls. (3) There was an influx of K+ from the plasma into rejuvenated erythrocytes. This was accompanied by a substantial loss (17%) of intramuscular K+. There was also loss of K+ from control preparations but this amounted to approx. 1% of muscle content. (4) Erythrocyte fragility was greater in the control perfusate (6%, haemolysis) when compared to the medium with rejuvenated cells (1%, haemolysis). As a consequence of either erythrocyte storage, rejuvenation or haemolysis, plasma concentrations of phosphate, magnesium, calcium and potassium were significantly different from starting values, by as much as 300% in both groups, and varied throughout the study. (5) It is concluded that the use of rejuvenated erythrocytes does not confer any advantage in unexercised perfused skeletal muscle preparations. However, both types of erythrocytes induce changes in perfusate composition relative to starting or in vivo profiles. © 1988.
Author Keywords: (Skeletal muscle); Erythrocyte; Muscle perfusion; Oxygen uptake; Potassium transport; Protein synthesis
Index Keywords: animal cell; energy metabolism; erythrocyte; erythrocyte fragility; muscle perfusion; nonhuman; oxygen consumption; priority journal; protein synthesis; rat; Animal; Electrolytes; Erythrocyte Aging; Erythrocytes; Hemoglobins; Hemolysis; Male; Muscles; Perfusion; Potassium; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains

Title: Signs of a high q2 "electric dipole moment"
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Institut für Physik, Astrophysik - Werner-Heisenberg-Institut für Physik, P.O. Box 40 12 12, D-8000 Munich 40, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hoogeveen, F., Max-Planck-Institut für Physik, Astrophysik - Werner-Heisenberg-Institut für Physik, P.O. Box 40 12 12, D-8000 Munich 40, Germany; Stodolsky, L., Max-Planck-Institut für Physik, Astrophysik - Werner-Heisenberg-Institut für Physik, P.O. Box 40 12 12, D-8000 Munich 40, Germany
Abstract: We note that there are effects sensitive to F3, the "electric dipole moment" of the electron and other fermions in high energy e+e- reactions. These use the naturally occuring transverse polarization in electron storage rings and include an "up-down" and "left-right" asymmetry relative to this polarization. Interference with the Z resonance is necessary and maximal effects occur near the Z or narrow high energy resonances. We show for the example of the tau lepton how it is possible to look for "the electric dipole moment" of other particles than the electron. Although the possible sensitivity is much less than in searches for a static electric dipole moment, this proposal would permit investigations at high energy and in principle of different particles. © 1988.

Title: On the measurement of the hadronic contribution to the muon anomalous magnetic moment
Affiliations: INFN, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, P. O. Box 13, Frascati, 00044
Authors with affiliations: Greco, M., INFN, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, P. O. Box 13, Frascati, 00044
Abstract: A new precise measurement of σ (e+e-→ hadrons) at low energy is suggested, of particular relevance for the theoretical prediction of aμ. The method proposed consists in colliding o((10÷100) MeV) electrons from a superconducting linac with o((1÷2) GeV) positrons of a conventional storage ring. © 1988 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: Experimental tests of quantum electrodynamics; Handron production by electron-positron collisions

Title: Direct and indirect estimates of sperm precedence and displacement in the dragonfly Sympetrum danae (Odonata: Libellulidae)
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of Antwerp, U.I.A. Universiteitsplein 1, Wilrijk, B-2610, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Michiels, N.K., Department of Biology, University of Antwerp, U.I.A. Universiteitsplein 1, Wilrijk, B-2610, Belgium; Dhondt, A.A., Department of Biology, University of Antwerp, U.I.A. Universiteitsplein 1, Wilrijk, B-2610, Belgium
Abstract: The non-territorial dragonfly Sympetrum danae shows a high degree of post-copulatory mate-guarding, which suggests precedence of the last male's sperm. Irradiated male techniques revealed that the last male that mates with a female fertilizes an average of 95% (100% in 28% of the cases) of the clutch laid immediately after copulation, irrespective of any previous matings. Sperm volume estimates in both sexes and sperm opacity changes in females at 7 stages of copulation and oviposition indicated that males remove 41-87% of previously deposited sperm from the female's storage organs during the first 5 min of the copulation. Ejaculation takes place during the remaining 10-15 min. We maintain that indirect estimates of precedence in libellulids, based on sperm volume changes, always understimate reality because of the supplementing effect of a "first-in, last out" mechanism. Because males are skilled at achieving sperm precedence, they are forced to be good guards as well, since a risk of take-overs exists. Females are believed to benefit from contact guarding because it results in a lowered risk of male harassment and predation as well as a lower energy expenditure during oviposition. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: dragonfly; mate guarding; Odonata; sperm competition; Libellulidae; Sympetrum danae

Title: COGENERATION PLANT COUPLED WITH THERMAL STORAGE SERVES MEDICAL CENTER ENERGY NEEDS.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Hospitals having a high rate of occupancy find that energy constitutes a major portion of their operation expense. This makes them prime candidates for cogeneration for all or part of their energy needs. The Crozer-Chester Medical Center, in Chester, Pennsylvania, has all the characteristics necessary to justify cogeneration - high electrical demand, high to moderately high electric rates, high heat load and a requirement for absolute reliability. Earlier this year, CCMC's cogneration plant, with its two Ajax-Superior 12-cylinder, 1170 kW Model 40GDX12 dual-fuel engines driving 1170 kW Kato generators, was placed in operation and is expected to save the institution some U. S. 200,000 dollars annually.
Index Keywords: HOSPITALS - Energy Conservation; THERMAL STORAGE; COGENERATION PLANTS

Title: Separation and concentration of Kr and Xe from hydrogen using TiFe0.86Mn0.1 alloy
Source title: Acta Metallurgica Sinica Series B, Process Metallurgy & Miscellaneous
Affiliations: Academia Sinica, China
Authors with affiliations: Yang, Minjie, Academia Sinica, China; Chen, Bingzhao, Academia Sinica, China
Abstract: When TiFe0.86Mn0.1 alloy is used as the separating material, the concentration of Kr and Xe in initial hydrogen desorption can be raised more than two orders of magnitude than the initial concentration below the separating temperature 300 K. The concentration descends to below 1 ppm when the hydrogen desorption quantity becomes 5% of the total hydrogen storage quantity. Concentrations of Kr and Xe in hydrogen decrease as the temperature is raised. The lower temperature is advantageous for separating and concentrating. At T = 300 K, the relationship between the concentration of Kr, Xe and hydrogen desorption quantity satisfies the equation N = ae-bV.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Krypton - Separation; Titanium Iron Manganese Alloys - Gases; Xenon - Separation; Hydrogen Storage; Hydrogen

Authors: Batten J.J., McDonald I.G., Moore B.T., Silva V.M.
Title: Corrosion of high-density sintered tungsten alloys. Part 1. Immersion testing
Affiliations: Materials Research Lab
Authors with affiliations: Batten, J.J., Materials Research Lab; McDonald, I.G., Materials Research Lab; Moore, B.T., Materials Research Lab; Silva, V.M., Materials Research Lab
Abstract: Sintered tungsten alloys are candidate materials for certain Australian ammunition components, namely kinetic energy penetrators, because of their high density (about 19 g/cm3). It is probable that a storage life of twenty years in an uncontrolled environment will be a requirement for this ammunition. Thus there is a need to determine the long-term storage capability of these alloys, in particular their capability to remain uncorroded during this period. The corrosion behaviour of four candidate alloys has therefore been evaluated through weight loss measurements after total immersion in both distilled water and 5% sodium chloride solutions. The propensity of these alloys to corrode in a crevice situation was assessed in the sodium chloride solution. Some insight into the mechanism of corrosion was afforded by an examination of the surfaces after the tests using the SEM and through an analysis of the corrosion products.
Index Keywords: Corrosion Protection; Corrosion--Testing; Ordnance--Australia; Powder Metallurgy--Tungsten; Tungsten Nickel Iron Alloys--Corrosion; Ammunition Components; Corrosion Prevention; Immersion Testing; Kinetic Energy Penetrators; Sintered Tungsten Alloys; Sodium Chloride Solutions; Tungsten and Alloys

Authors: Zhou Daming, Hou Lei, Jin Qinghua, Guo Zhenya, Ding Datong
Title: NMR study of hydrogen motion in LaNi5, LaNi4Cu and LaNi4Fe lattices
Source title: Acta Metallurgica Sinica Series B, Process Metallurgy & Miscellaneous
Affiliations: Nankai Univ, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, Daming, Nankai Univ, China; Hou, Lei, Nankai Univ, China; Jin, Qinghua, Nankai Univ, China; Guo, Zhenya, Nankai Univ, China; Ding, Datong, Nankai Univ, China
Abstract: The continuous wave NMR (nuclear magnetic resonance) results of 1H in LaNi5 · H6, LaNi4Cu · Hx and LaNi4Fe · Hx are reported. The Line shape at both higher and lower temperatures, activation energy of diffusion, self correlation time and diffusion coefficient calculated according to a model are discussed. It is concluded that the partial substitution of Cu and Fe for Ni increases the stability of hydrogen in the host alloy.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Gases; Hydrogen - Diffusion; Nuclear Magnetic Resonance; Activation Energy; Hydrogen Motion; Hydrogen Storage; Lanthanum Nickel Alloys

Authors: Thompson Murray A., DeClute Gary, Kehres John, Lackey Joe
Title: Operation and use of a 2 terabyte optical archival store
Source title: Digest of Papers - IEEE Symposium on Mass Storage Systems
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Physics Science, Lab, Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, Murray A., Univ of Wisconsin, Physics Science, Lab, Madison, WI, USA; DeClute, Gary, Univ of Wisconsin, Physics Science, Lab, Madison, WI, USA; Kehres, John, Univ of Wisconsin, Physics Science, Lab, Madison, WI, USA; Lackey, Joe, Univ of Wisconsin, Physics Science, Lab, Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: The authors report on the operation and use of the Optical Archival Store (OAS), a very large archival storage system. The system uses a robot which moves optical disk cassettes to and from three read/write units. The software was designed to make the system very easy to use. The users or clients see the system as a large file server, and see the system as a single 2 terabyte (16 Tb) volume with a 1 gigabyte file-length limitation. Thus the users concern themselves only with filenames and not with cassette numbers or track numbers. The system is automatic and available 24 h/day, seven days a week to a community of scientists in many university departments. The users pay for their use and can choose between the OAS, centralized magnetic disk systems, their own magnetic disks, and various magnetic tape systems. Use is voluntary, and the users make their choice in terms of the perceived values and perceived costs.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Natural Sciences Applications; Data Storage, Optical; Information Retrieval Systems; Physics--High Energy; Robotics; Archival Storage System; Optical Archival Store (OAS); Data Storage, Digital

Title: Department of Energy Nuclear Weapons Complex network
Source title: Digest of Papers - IEEE Symposium on Mass Storage Systems
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Elliott, Raymond L., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA
Abstract: The Nuclear Weapons Complex (NWC) of the US Department of Energy (DOE) is a collection of 11 government-owned, contractor-operated facilities operated by nine different contractors and the US DOE Albuquerque Operations Office. An effort is under way to automate the exchange of product-definition data between members of the Nuclear Weapons Complex (NWC). A description is presented of network components, their interaction and some of the efforts to ensure security. The NWC network is a computer network that will allow the facilities to exchange, store, and manage shared information. The networking and storage capabilities are enhancements of systems available from commercial sources and from specific systems in use at Los Alamos National Laboratory.
Index Keywords: Data Processing--Security of Data; Information Retrieval Systems; Ordnance; Los Alamos National Laboratory; Nuclear Weapons Complex (NWC); NWCNET Architecture; Computer Networks

Authors: McLaughlin B.R., Russell P.R., Carroll Don J.
Title: Cogen plant includes 12-acre greenhouse, oyster farm
Affiliations: United Engineers & Constructors, United States
Authors with affiliations: McLaughlin, B.R., United Engineers & Constructors, United States; Russell, P.R., United Engineers & Constructors, United States; Carroll, Don J., United Engineers & Constructors, United States
Abstract: The American Atlas combined cycle cogeneration plant recently started up in Rifle, Colo. has some interesting and unique features, such as an oyster farm and a greenhouse and an associated thermal storage system. The plant's power cycle consists of three natural-gas-fired combustion turbine-generators and one condensing steam turbine-generator which together produce 75 MW (net) of electricity. Exhaust gases from the gas turbines are also used to produce hot water for year-round heating of a 12-acre greenhouse for growing tomatoes. A thermal storage system allows the greenhouse to operate when the gas turbines are not operating. Since start-up of the unit, an oyster farm has been added. Oysters are shipped from the Gulf Coast, grown in brine tanks heated by hot water from the power plant, harvested, and shipped to distributors.
Index Keywords: Gas Turbines - Waste Heat Utilization; Power Plants - Gas and Steam Turbine Combined; Waste Heat Utilization - Energy Storage; Combined Cycle Cogeneration Plants; Thermal Storage Systems; Waste Heat Recovery; Cogeneration Plants

Title: Multi-source hydronic heat pump application study and analysis
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Meckler Group, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, Milton, Meckler Group, United States
Abstract: A multi-source hydronic heat pump (MSHHP) system was recently evaluated for a proposed Valley Oaks Village senior housing project containing 258 units arranged within two- and three-story buildings, which with a two-story Recreation Building, comprise approximately 200,000 gross square feet. The project was planned for construction in Southern California in 1988. The project involved determination of the engineering-economic feasibility of incorporating a cost-effective off-peak cooling system. The serving utility, Southern California Edison (SCE) Company, offered an attractive cool storage inducement program. It was decided to evaluate the use of a MSHHP system integrated with an ice builder thermal energy storage (TES) so that the water source heat pump (WSHP) unit compressors could all be shut down during on-peak hours.
Index Keywords: Apartment Houses--Energy Utilization; Energy Storage; Hydronic Heat Pump; Ice Storage Units; Heat Pump Systems

Title: Overview of European research and development of electric vehicles
Affiliations: Fiat Research Cent, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Brusaglino, G., Fiat Research Cent, Italy; Mazzon, L., Fiat Research Cent, Italy
Abstract: Means are already available for the use of electric, hybrid and dual-mode vehicles for a variety of purposes. Within the European action, COST 302, an analysis has been made of the various factors concerning electric vehicle introduction, namely: energy conservation, environmental benefits, operational adequacy, industrial production, technological development, standardization and economics. The main results are summarized and recommended follow-up actions are reported. The technological achievements and continuing developments are presented in the field of energy supply and propulsion systems; their applications to electrically propelled vehicles of various types are discussed. The experience of dual-mode vehicles within a program of the finalized Projects-Transport CNR, under coordination of A.T.M. of Milan, is reported.
Index Keywords: Automobiles; COST 302; Dual-Mode Vehicles; Electric Propulsion; Electric Vehicles; European Research/Development; Hybrid Vehicles; Storage Battery Vehicles

Authors: Matsuda M., Lee S.K., Ishizu T., Hasatani M.
Title: Heat-release characteristics of a packed bed of CaO during its exothermic hydration
Affiliations: Nagoya Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuda, M., Nagoya Univ, Japan; Lee, S.K., Nagoya Univ, Japan; Ishizu, T., Nagoya Univ, Japan; Hasatani, M., Nagoya Univ, Japan
Abstract: As a step in the application of the thermochemical reaction cycle of Ca(OH)2 and CaO for chemical storage of heat, the heat-release characteristics of a packed bed of CaO during exothermic hydration were studied experimentally and theoretically. The hydration of CaO began as soon as the steam entered the bed, with the bed temperature rising to an equilibrium temperature for reaction, which depended on the partial pressure of the steam, and remaining almost constant at this level throughout the reaction.
Index Keywords: Calcium Compounds; Chemical Equipment--Packed Beds; Chemical Reactions--Hydration; Energy Storage; Calcium Hydroxide; Exothermic Hydration; Heat-Release Characteristics; Packed Bed; Heat Transfer

Authors: Epp J., Bricelj V.M., Malouf R.E.
Title: Seasonal partitioning and utilization of energy reserves in two age classes of the bay scallop Argopecten irradians irradians (Lamarck)
Source title: Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology
Affiliations: Marine Sciences Research Center, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Epp, J., Marine Sciences Research Center, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY, United States; Bricelj, V.M., Marine Sciences Research Center, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY, United States; Malouf, R.E., Marine Sciences Research Center, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, NY, United States
Abstract: Seasonal cycles in body component indices, reproductive condition (determined histologically), and storage and utilization of protein, lipid and carbohydrate reserves in various tissue pools, were investigated in two cohorts of the bay scallop Argopecten irradians irradians (Lamarck). Scallops were held in cages at two contrasting localities in Long Island, New York, U.S.A. Gametogenesis occurred mainly at the expense of adductor muscle protein and lipid reserves. Energy loss in the adductor muscle could potentially account for 63 to 99% of the gonadal buildup in the spring. In contrast to prior studies, digestive gland lipid and muscle carbohydrate made an insignificant contribution to the energy demand during reproduction. In first-year, pre-reproductive scallops, adductor muscle protein also contributed 63-66% of the total energy loss during overwintering stress. Senescence of older scallops was evidenced by a more rapid decline in mantle protein reserves than in young individuals. Twenty percent of the older population showed signs of anomalous, advanced oogenesis in March, coincident with the period of highest natural mortality. Results of this study suggest a possible association between senescence and protein metabolism. Contrary to studies showing glycogen to be the main storage product in bivalves such as oysters and mytilids, this study serves to stress the importance of protein as an energy substrate in pectinids. © 1988.
Author Keywords: Argopecten; Biochemical composition; Energy metabolism; Scallop
Index Keywords: bay scallop; energy reserves; scallop; USA, New York, Long Island; Argopecten irradians

Stanco, L., Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università di Padova, e INFN, Sezione di Padova, I-35131 Padua, Italy
Abstract: The e+e-→ηπ+π- reaction has been measured in the center of mass energy interval 1350-2400 MeV by the magnetic detector DM2 at the Orsay storage ring DCI. Under the hypothesis of only one large resonance the cross section is not fit in a satisfactory way. The branching ratio τ-→η-π0ντ=(0.13 ± 0.02)% is deduced via CVC from the above measurement. © 1988.

Title: Analysis of Unconventional Powertrain Systems
Authors with affiliations: Weber, T.R.
Abstract: A system optimization approach has been developed to configure and analyze hydraulic energy-storage based propulsion systems. The powertrain synthesis problem is formulated as an optimization problem of minimizing the engine fuel rate over a finite time interval. The solution process is driven by energy management and control strategies, which determine the transmission ratio and the hydrostatic pump/motor unit displacement such that the engine can be operated at its minimum fuel rate. This approach has identified a powertrain consisting of an automatic four-speed transmission plus a hydrostatic pump/motor unit and accumulator used to regenerate and store vehicle kinetic energy. Within the limitations of our analysis, the hydraulic hybrid system has shown potential for significant improvement in fuel economy over a conventional system. These limitations are: the use of an optimum energy management strategy which may be difficult to capture in a real-time controller; the practicality and transient effects of turning the engine on and off; the packaging of all the subsystems into a vehicle; and the lack of hydraulic noise assessment. Using the approach in this paper, optimal energy management and control strategies have been developed and their effects on fuel economy have been quantified. The analysis has shown that the fuel economy gains are due to turning the engine on and off and to using stored energy to power the accessories and/or launch the vehicle. This research effort has assessed the potential of a hydraulic hybrid powertrain vehicle system. Bounds on the predicted fuel economy gain were determined as a function of sensitivities to subsystem parameters.
Index Keywords: Energy management; Engines; Fuels; Hybrid systems; Hydraulics; Kinetic energy; Kinetics; Powertrains; Propulsion; Vehicle transmissions; Conventional systems; Finite time intervals; Hydraulic energy storage; Management and controls; Optimization problems; Real time controllers; System optimizations; Transmission ratios; Fuel economy

Title: Reservoir operation policies for optimizing energy generation at the Shiroro Dam
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Ilorin, Ilorin, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Sule, B.F., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Ilorin, Ilorin, Nigeria
Abstract: Reservoir water release policies are computed for the Shiroro Dam hydroelectric power scheme in Northern Nigeria, using a probabilistic dynamic programming model. The state variable is the reservoir storage volume, while the uncertain nature of the inflow process is accounted for in the model by considering different possible inflow volumes and their inflow probabilities. Simulation of the reservoir operations with the derived policies show that on the average the hydrosystem has acceptable reliability when two units are in use, at 45% design power plant factor. At 70% power plant factor, which is the desired optimum for the power system in Nigeria, system failures are frequent and, in most cases, severe. For normal operation of the Shiroro Dam hydroelectric power system, two or three generating units, running at 40-50% power plant factor is recommended. © 1988 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: Hydroelectric power; operating policy; optimization; probabilistic dynamic programming; Shiroro Dam

Title: Minimum norm approach to optimal long-term operation of multireservoir power systems with specified monthly generation
Source title: Journal of Optimization Theory and Applications
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Soliman, S.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt; Christensen, G.S., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada
Abstract: The aim of this paper is to present a new algorithm to maximize the value of the energy produced from a multireservoir power system, plus the estimated value of water remaining in storage at the end of the 12-month planning period. The systems described here are characterized by having a specified monthly generation, and this generation is equal to a certain percentage of the total generation at the end of the year. The problem is formulated as a minimum norm problem in the framework of analytic optimization. Numerical results are reported for a real system in operation consisting of three rivers; each river has two series reservoirs. The proposed algorithm is efficient in computing time and in calculating the total expected benefits from the system. © 1988 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Author Keywords: long-term operations of power systems; Minimum-norm problems; nonlinear optimal control; specified monthly generation

Authors: Borchardt I., Karantzoulis E., Mais H., Ripken G.
Title: Calculation of beam envelopes in storage rings and transport systems in the presence of transverse space charge effects and coupling
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik C Particles and Fields
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, Hamburg 52, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Borchardt, I., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, Hamburg 52, Germany; Karantzoulis, E., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, Hamburg 52, Germany; Mais, H., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, Hamburg 52, Germany; Ripken, G., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, Hamburg 52, Germany
Abstract: In the following report we describe a method for calculating the envelopes of coasting beams in linear coupled storage rings and transport systems in the presence of transverse space charge forces. This work is an extension of earlier calculations [2, 3] to include coupled beam optics and energy deviations. The extension is achieved by defining a 5-dimensional ellipsoid in the x-px-z-pz-Δp/p space. The motion of this ellipsoid under the influence of the external fields and the instantaneous space charge forces can be described by five generating orbit vectors which can be combined into a 5-dimensional matrix {Mathematical expression}. This "bunch-shape matrix", {Mathematical expression}, contains complete information about the configuration of the bunch. The solution of the equations of motion is carried through in the thin lens approximation. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Naumann R., Fanghänel Th., Emons H.-H.
Title: Thermoanalytical investigation of sodium acetate trihydrate for application as a latent heat thermal energy storage material
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Mining Academy Freiberg, Freiberg, 9200, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Naumann, R., Department of Chemistry, Mining Academy Freiberg, Freiberg, 9200, Germany; Fanghänel, Th., Department of Chemistry, Mining Academy Freiberg, Freiberg, 9200, Germany; Emons, H.-H., Department of Chemistry, Mining Academy Freiberg, Freiberg, 9200, Germany
Abstract: The thermal behaviour of sodium acetate trihydrate (NaAc · 3H2O) was investigated by DTA, Q-TG and measurements of the solubility properties. The nucleation efficiency of Na4P2O7 · 10H2O for the crystallization of NaAc · 3H2O melts is not stable over long periods. Stratification can be ascribed to the formation of anhydrous sodium acetate in the supercooled melts. Under static heat storage conditions, NaAc · 3H2O and Na4P2O7 · 10H2O do not exhibit stable behaviour. © 1988 Wiley Heyden Ltd., Chichester and Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest.
Index Keywords: Heating--Heat Storage; Salts--Melting; Heat Storage Stratification; Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage Material; Melting Solidification Behavior; Sodium Acetate Trihydrate; Sodium Phosphates Melting; Static Heat Storage Conditions; Sodium Compounds

Authors: Starick D., Lange W., Herzog G.
Title: Investigations on the thermoluminescence of LaOBr:Tb3+ phosphors - I. Experimental results
Affiliations: Leuchtstofftechnikum, Department of Chemistry, E.-M.-Arndt-University, Greifswald, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Starick, D., Leuchtstofftechnikum, Department of Chemistry, E.-M.-Arndt-University, Greifswald, Germany; Lange, W., Leuchtstofftechnikum, Department of Chemistry, E.-M.-Arndt-University, Greifswald, Germany; Herzog, G., Leuchtstofftechnikum, Department of Chemistry, E.-M.-Arndt-University, Greifswald, Germany
Abstract: Thermoluminescence measurements are thermoanalytical techniques that allow study of the thermally stimulated relaxation processes in solids, yielding qualitative information on the mechanism of energy storage and permitting calculation of quantitative trap-spectroscopic parameters, too. The thermoluminescence of undoped and Tb3+-activated LaOBr materials was investigated. The experimental results are summarized and some factors influencing the thermoluminescence of this system are discussed. © 1988 Wiley Heyden Ltd., Chichester and Akadémiai Kiadó, Budapest.
Index Keywords: Bromine Compounds--Doping; Lanthanum Compounds--Doping; Luminescence--Inorganic Solids; Terbium--Effects; Thermoluminescence--Measurements; Electronic Trap Levels; Excitation Spectra; Lanthanum Oxybromide Phosphors; Terbium Doped Lanthanum Oxybromides; X-Ray Phosphors; Phosphors

Title: CHALLENGE OF PACKAGED COGENERATION.
Authors with affiliations: Douglas, John
Abstract: A battle is shaping up in the commercial sector, with packaged cogeneration units and high-efficiency electric technologies competing head to head as cost-saving energy options. Such technologies include integrated heat pump systems for space conditioning and water heating, thermal storage systems for inexpensive off-peak heating and cooling, high-efficiency chillers for air conditioning applications, and multiplex refrigeration equipment designed specifically for the needs of supermarkets. Which of these alternatives better suits a particular facility depends on several factors, including electricity and gas rates, daily hours of operation, the need for cooling or refrigeration, the availability of maintenance personnel, and a variety of financial considerations. It is often difficult for the customer to assess these factors, particularly because of the limited availability of performance data on the relatively new 'packaged' cogeneration systems. This paper tries to provide the information which can help the customer to make the decision in favor of one of these two alternatives.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC EQUIPMENT; HIGH-EFFICIENCY ELECTRIC TECHNOLOGY; INTEGRATED HEAT PUMPS; PACKAGED COGENERATION; THERMAL STORAGE; COGENERATION PLANTS

Title: Theory of static stability for cylindrical magnetic domains in multilayer films
Affiliations: Donets State Univ, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Gerasimchuk, V.S., Donets State Univ, Russian Federation
Abstract: Cylindrical magnetic domain (CMD) materials have great promise for the creation of memory systems for storing and processing data. A theory was developed for the static properties of CMD's in multilayer materials that have different structural characteristics. Conditions were determined for the static stability of CMD's in a film for which the layers containing domains are separated by a nonmagnetic layer. The results indicate the possibilities of stable existence of a CMD in magnetically nonuniform materials as well as the possibilities of utilizing the interaction between CMD's in proximate magnetic layers to create various kinds of switching and functional units in circuits.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic - Film; Magnetic Fields - Mathematical Models; Magnetic Properties - Mathematical Models; Magnetism - Theory; Magnetostatics - Calculations; Cylindrical Magnetic Domains; Magnetically Nonuniform Materials; Magnetostatic Energy; Multilayer Films; Nonmagnetic Layer Effects; Static Stability; Magnetic Materials

Title: Oxygen electrode bifunctional electrocatalyst NiCo2O4 spinel
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fielder, William L., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States; Singer, Joseph, NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: A significant increase in energy density may be possible if a two-unit alkaline regenerative H2-O2 fuel cell is replaced with a single-unit system that uses passive means for H2O transfer and thermal control. For this single-unit system, new electrocatalysts for the O2 electrode will be required which are not only bifunctionally active but also chemically and electrochemically stable between the voltage range of about 0.7 and 1.5 V. NiCo2O4 spinel is reported to have certain characteristics that make it useful for a study of electrode fabrication techniques. High surface area NiCo2O4 powder was fabricated into unsupported, bifunctional, PTFE-bonded, porous gas fuel cell electrodes by commercial sources using varying PTFE contents and sintering temperatures. The object of the present study was to measure the bifunctional activities of these electrodes and to observe what performance differences might result from different commercial electrode fabricators. O2 evolution and O2 reduction data were obtained at 80°C (31 percent KOH). An irreversible reaction (i.e., aging) occurred during O2 evolution at potentials greater than about 1.5 V. Within the range of 15 to 25 percent, the PTFE content was not a critical parameter for optimizing the electrode for O2 evolution activity. Sintering temperatures between 300 and 340°C may be adequate but heating at 275°C may not be sufficient to properly sinter the PTFE-NiCo2O4 mixture. Electrode disintegration was observed during O2 reduction. Transport of O2 to the NiCo2O4 surface became prohibitive at greater than about -0.02 A/cm2. A PTFE content of 25 percent (or greater) appears to be preferable for sintering the PTFE-NiCo2O4 mixture.
Index Keywords: Catalysts--Activity; Chemical Reactions--Redox; Electrodes, Electrochemical--Materials; Oxides--Electrochemistry; Space Flight--Energy Storage; Bifunctional Electrocatalysts; Energy Storage Devices; Fuel Cell Oxygen Electrodes; Nickel Cobalt Spinels; Fuel Cells

Authors: Siebenmorgen T.J., Schulte D.D., Ballard J.L.
Title: Integration of a cogeneration system into a swine operation: I. Model development and system description
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Univ of Arkansas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siebenmorgen, T.J., Univ of Arkansas, United States; Schulte, D.D., Univ of Arkansas, United States; Ballard, J.L., Univ of Arkansas, United States
Abstract: The development of a mathematical model simulating the operation of a biogas-fueled, engine-generator cogeneration system, a thermal energy storage and utilization system, an anaerobic digester, and the electrical and hot water demands on a farrow-to-finish swine farm is presented. The components of the model were validated with data collected on the University of Nebraska Energy Integrated Farm. The model was written and presented in context of integrating cogenerator operation into a swine operation. This is the first in a series of two papers detailing the integration of a biogas-fueled cogeneration system into a farmstead.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Wastes--Processing; Biogas--Production; Cogeneration Plants--Applications; Energy Storage; Waste Heat Utilization; Swine Operation; Agricultural Engineering

Title: Developments in integrated computer control lead to energy savings in production
Affiliations: BNF Metals Technology Cent, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Clarke, Phil, BNF Metals Technology Cent, United Kingdom
Abstract: In the metals industry environment, the total integration of production control information with directly-recorded information has hitherto been difficult to achieve. Until recently, production control data has been presented manually to data processing computers. The use of computers for process control has been limited to those processes where critical control is required, regardless of cost, and to clean environmental conditions - or has been restricted to microcomputers with limited capacity for data storage, analysis, and processing. This article outlines some recent advances in the field.
Index Keywords: Energy Conservation; Process Control - Computer Applications; Furnaces, Metallurgical

Title: Dynamic mechanical study of narrow molecular weight amorphous polypropylenes
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: Univ of Southern Mississippi, United States
Authors with affiliations: McLaughlin, K.W., Univ of Southern Mississippi, United States; Latham, D.D., Univ of Southern Mississippi, United States
Abstract: The dynamic mechanical properties of amorphous polypropylene above the glass transition temperature have been used to determine the activation energy for the deformation kinetics. The polymers studied all exist in a simple, single phase, and possess the same dyad and triad distributions. The narrow molecular weight distributions for the polymers allow the influence of molecular weight to be clearly identified. Even though the storage modulus between the two higher molecular weight polymers differs considerably in their frequency dependence, they both give the same activation energy of approximately 28 kcal/mol. However, the lowest molecular weight sample is clearly behaving differently from the other two.
Index Keywords: Plastics--Deformation; Polymers--Amorphous; Activation Energy; Deformation Kinetics; Poly-1-Alkenes; Polypropylene

Title: Reduction Theorem for Phase Equilibrium Problems
Affiliations: Koninklijke/Shell Laboratorium, Amsterdam (Shell Research B.V.), P.O. Box 3003, 1003 AA Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Hendriks, E.M., Koninklijke/Shell Laboratorium, Amsterdam (Shell Research B.V.), P.O. Box 3003, 1003 AA Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: If the excess Gibbs free-energy function for re-component mixtures depends on composition only through a limited number, K, of linear functions (scalar products), then the set of two-phase equilibrium equations and the equations of the stability test can be reduced to a set of only K + 1 equations; the Newton-Raphson correction equations can be reduced from a system of re linear equations to one of size, K + 1, and the spinodal curve can be evaluated from the criterion of positive semidefiniteness for a (K + 1)-dimensional quadratic form. Applications include examples ranging from mixtures of hydrocarbons with L non-hydrocarbons (K = 2L + 2) to polymer mixtures. In a number of special cases, the simplications have been exploited by other authors, among other things to save computer time and storage. The present work shows the mathematical structure behind these examples and generalizes these to a well-defined class of models. © 1988, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Equations of state; Fluids--Phase Equilibria; Hydrocarbons; Mixtures; Reduction Theorem; Thermodynamics

Authors: Esaulenko V.A., Ivanov E.N., Orlov A.I., Terekhov E.P.
Title: Generator of current pulses with slow rise and fast fall
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: All-Union Electrical Engineering, Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Esaulenko, V.A., All-Union Electrical Engineering, Inst, Russian Federation; Ivanov, E.N., All-Union Electrical Engineering, Inst, Russian Federation; Orlov, A.I., All-Union Electrical Engineering, Inst, Russian Federation; Terekhov, E.P., All-Union Electrical Engineering, Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: A generator of current pulses of variable shape and duration is described that is based on two capacitive storage devices of different voltages: 5 (10) kV with a stored energy of 125 kJ and 25 kV with a stored energy of 75 kJ. With an inductive load, the generator provides asymmetrical current pulses with durations of 20-2000 μsec, fall times to 10 μsec, and amplitudes to 200 kA.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Discharges; Electronic Circuits, Switching; Electronic Circuits, Trigger; Pulse Time Modulation; Current Pulse Generators; Inductance Coils; Inductive Loads; Pulse Amplitude Modulation; Pulse Fall Time; Pulse Rise Time; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Shaping

Title: Heat transfer of latent thermal energy storage capsules arranged in alignment with the fluid flow (part 1, experiments on heat transfer characteristics)
Affiliations: Shinshu Univ
Authors with affiliations: Hirata, Tetsuo, Shinshu Univ; Ueda, Hideki, Shinshu Univ
Abstract: Experiments were performed to obtain data for the heat transfer characteristics of latent thermal energy storage capsules. The arrangement of the capsules was in alignment with the flow direction. During the melting of the phase change material (n-Octadecane), there is less difference in the phase change rate of each capsule than for the solidification case because of the effect of natural convection in the liquid phase on heat transfer. It was also shown that the non-dimensional time required to complete the solidification of each capsule can be arranged without distinction of the rows in the flow direction.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Melting; Paraffins; Latent Thermal Energy Storage Capsules; Phase Change Materials; Energy Storage

Title: Photo-induced polymerization and isomerization
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nagaosa, N., Univ of Tokyo, Japan; Hanamura, E., Univ of Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The authors present a simplified model to understand, from a unified viewpoint, of photo-induced polymerization and isomerization phenomena. The authors stress the following points. (1) The temperature dependence. (2) The characteristic time scales of the processes, and the factors which determine them. (3) The dependence of the dynamics on the excitation intensity and its duration time of the laser light as well as lattice temperature. (4) Dimensionality of the system. (5) The respective role of optical and thermal processes. As an example, the authors discuss here the photoisomerization (A-B transition) of polydiacetylene crystals.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Isomerization; Crystals; Data Storage, Optical--Materials; Photochromism; Erasable Photo-Memory Systems; Frank-Condon Excitation Energy; Polydiacetylene Crystals; Polymerization

Title: Solder mask materials and equipment specification summary
Affiliations: Electronic Manufacturing, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ott, Mary, Electronic Manufacturing, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the criteria for selecting solder masks which are applied to printed circuit boards (PCB) prior to component insertion and soldering. The criteria for mask selection include shelf life, ease of application, solubility of the mask deposit after storage, and the ability to protect the underlying circuits. Solder masks must provide a sharp print definition, and the cured masks must exhibit good mechanical and electrical properties. They also must withstand various chemical and heat treatments employed in board processing steps such as roll-tinning, hot-air leveling, and wave soldering. Solder masks are available in three types: screen printable, dry film, and photoimageable liquids. They may be formulated as dual- or single-component polymer systems, curable by ultraviolet (UV) or thermal energy, and developed by aqueous or solvent chemistry. The list of equipment and materials for solder masking is presented.
Index Keywords: Electronic Circuits--Manufacture; Dry Film Solder Masks; Photoimageable Liquids; Printed Circuit Boards; Screen-Printable Masks; Solder Masking; Printed Circuits

Authors: Ouano A.C., Wu A.W., Park J., Pecora R.
Title: Brillouin spectroscopy and tribological properties of some fluids
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: IBM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ouano, A.C., IBM, United States; Wu, A.W., IBM, United States; Park, J., IBM, United States; Pecora, R., IBM, United States
Abstract: A correlation between the POD life and the energy dissipation (SAC) (Sound Attenuation Coefficient) and k (Thermal Diffusion Coefficient) appears to exist at least qualitatively. Although the (SAC) can be measured with some precision with current spectrometers, the thermal diffusion coefficient (k) could not be obtained with the same precision because the width of the Rayleigh Peak is close to the instrumental line width, thus a much higher resolution spectrometer with narrower line width is needed to obtain more reliable data on (k). Furthermore, the quality and precision of the results obtained also depend on removal of particulate contaminants from the sample. The results thus far obtained show some promise that Brillouin spectroscopy may offer additional insight into the tribological properties of lubricants.
Index Keywords: Lubricants--Spectroscopic Analysis; Spectroscopy; Tribology; Brillouin Spectroscopy; Sound Attenuation Coefficient(SAC); Thermal Energy Dissipation; Data Storage, Magnetic

Title: Solid state ionics-87: Proceedings of the 6th international conference on solid state ionics
Abstract: This conference proceedings consists of two parts and contains 323 papers on solid state ionics. The conference has been set up to take care of the interdisciplinary character of this field in materials science. The papers present the recent developments in scientific areas alongside the more common areas of solid state ionics. Special emphasis has been given to recent practical developments and theoretical work since both have shown major progress and need to be further strengthened. The main topics of the conference include: inorganic cationic and anionic conductors; beta-alumina; NASICON ceramics; protonic and hydroxide-ion conductors; glasses; energy storage and conversion; polymers; composite electrolytes; mixed conductors and semiconductor ionics; high-temperature and solid-state chemistry; surfaces and interfaces; microionics and thin films; heterogeneous catalysis; sensors; new materials; and biological membranes.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries--Materials; Electric Conductivity; Electrodes, Electrochemical; Electrolytes, Solid; Ions--Diffusion; EIREV; Fast Ion Condcution; Inorganic Ionic Conductors; NASICON; solid State Batteries; Solid State Ionics; Solids

Authors: Phadke Ratna S., Sonawat H.M., Govil Girjesh
Title: Biomolecular electronics using coenzymes immobilized on solid supports
Affiliations: Tata Inst of Fundamental Research, India
Authors with affiliations: Phadke, Ratna S., Tata Inst of Fundamental Research, India; Sonawat, H.M., Tata Inst of Fundamental Research, India; Govil, Girjesh, Tata Inst of Fundamental Research, India
Abstract: By attaching biological molecules to solid supports through conducting bridges, one can establish an electron transport chain between the biomolecules and solid surfaces, prevent them from diffusing into aqueous environment, improve their stability and efficacy and, more important, utilize them gainfully. We have been successful in chaining to graphite surfaces two important coenzymes involved in the energy transduction in living cells, viz. FAD and cyt-c. In both cases, the electrons can be transported either from or to the coenzymes by application of an electric potential to the solid support. Since each of these molecules lies in two states (oxidized and reduced) and can be switched reversibly by applied voltage, they can form the basis of molecular storage of information. Other perceptual applications are biobatteries, biosensors and the synthesis of value-added compounds. The concepts being developed may play an important role in bioengineering in the future.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Redox; Data Storage, Digital--Materials; Electric Batteries--Materials; Sensors--Materials; Solid State Devices--Materials; Biobatteries; Biomolecular Electronics; Biosensors; Energy Transduction; Immobilized Enzyme Systems; Molecular Storage of Information; Coenzymes

Title: Energy loss and storage in RC-transmission lines
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Levine, H., Department of Mathematics, Stanford University, United States
Abstract: The distribution of energy supplied by a step-voltage generator to a semi-infinite transmission line with uniform series resistance and shunt capacitance is investigated; and explicit (simple integral) representations for both line and generator losses as well as the line storage during an arbitrary time interval are given. A relatively greater loss due to internal resistance of the generator obtains in the initial phase of excitation while that due to resistance of the line predominates in the long run. A larger proportion of energy is stored in the line at the outset and, ultimately, the output of the generator is equally divided between line loss and storage in its internal capacitance. © 1988 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Differential Equations; ENERGY LOSS; RC-TRANSMISSION LINES; SEMI-INFINITE TRANSMISSION LINE; ELECTRIC NETWORKS

Title: Use of radiations for the modification of polymers
Source title: American Chemical Society, Polymer Preprints, Division of Polymer Chemistry
Affiliations: CNRS, France
Authors with affiliations: Chapiro, Adolphe, CNRS, France
Abstract: The purpose of this review is to describe some of the techniques which are commonly used today in radiation processing, with special emphasis on those aspects which may be attractive to information storage technology. The following processes are considered: (1) Radiation curing; (2) Radiation cross-linking; (3) Radiation grafting.
Index Keywords: Plastics--Radiation Effects; High Energy Radiation; Radiation Crosslinking; Radiation Grafting; Polymers

Authors: Kalem C.B., Blanco J.R., Champetier R.J.
Title: UV/Ozone removal of contaminants in spacecraft environments
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Hughes Aircraft Company, P.O. Box 902, El Segundo, CA, 90245, United States; California State University Northridge, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Northridge, CA, 91330, United States; TRW Inc., MS 01/1251, One Space Park, Redondo Beach, CA, 90278, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kalem, C.B., Hughes Aircraft Company, P.O. Box 902, El Segundo, CA, 90245, United States; Blanco, J.R., California State University Northridge, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Northridge, CA, 91330, United States; Champetier, R.J., TRW Inc., MS 01/1251, One Space Park, Redondo Beach, CA, 90278, United States
Abstract: The UV/Ozone cleaning process has been studied as both a method for preventing contaminant films from forming on optical surfaces of a space sensor during storage, and for removing them from these surfaces after formation. Using mercury resonance lines at 253.7 and 184.9 nm and O2 pressures in the range of 8 × 10−5 to 4 × 10−4 torr, removal efficiencies from 1.8 × 10−26 to 4.4 × 10−26 cm3/photon were measured. The UV/Ozone process has been shown to be an effective method for preventing contaminant buildup during the storage of a sensor. If the removal efficiencies can be improved, as expected, by using higher energy photons, the UV/Ozone process should also prove to be a viable method for cleaning contaminant films from optical surfaces in space. © 1988, SPIE.
Index Keywords: Cleaning; Cleaning contaminants; Cleaning process; Contaminant films; Higher energy photons; Optical surfaces; Removal efficiencies; Resonance line; Space sensors; Contamination

Authors: Johnson C.B., Bonney L., Floryan R.F.
Title: Some ultraviolet spectral sensitivity characteristics of broadband multialkali photocathodes
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: ITT Electro-Optical Products Division, 3700 E. Pontiac Street, Fort Wayne, IN, 46081, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, C.B., ITT Electro-Optical Products Division, 3700 E. Pontiac Street, Fort Wayne, IN, 46081, United States; Bonney, L., ITT Electro-Optical Products Division, 3700 E. Pontiac Street, Fort Wayne, IN, 46081, United States; Floryan, R.F., ITT Electro-Optical Products Division, 3700 E. Pontiac Street, Fort Wayne, IN, 46081, United States
Abstract: Window and photocathode combinations are used to produce detectors having broadband spectral sensitivities. Using synthetic fused silica input windows and multialkali photocathodes, useful sensitivities are produced in the 160-900 nm spectral range. Interesting and strongly wavelength dependent sensitivity and photoelectron emission energy effects are observed in the uv and near-uv spectral regions. A physical model is proposed to describe the observations, based upon wavelength dependent photon absorption, single and multiple photoelectron emission, and thin-film interference effects. These window/photocathode combinations are used in microchannel plate (MCP) photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), MCP image tubes, and position-sensing-PMTs. A near-uv transmissive fiberoptic window/cathode assembly is used on a streak-tube, and its characteristics are also discussed. © 1988 SPIE.
