Title: Measurement of low energy neutrino absorption probability in thallium 205
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Freedman, M.S., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Abstract: A major aspect of the P-P solar neutrino flux determination using 205Tl is the very difficult problem of experimentally demonstrating the neutrino reaction cross section with about 10% accuracy. Based on an idea of P. Kienle, such measurements now become possible. Moreover, the proposed measurements of weak interaction rates are in the isotopic states of interest; hence they will be much more readily acceptable than would indirect measurements via strong or electromagnetic interactions or theoretical calculations. One will soon be able to completely strip the electrons from atomic 205Tl and to maintain the bare nucleus in this state in the heavy ion storage ring to be built at GSI Darmstadt. This nucleus can decay by emitting a beta-minus particle into the bound K-level of the daughter 82205Pb1 2-81+ ion as the only energetically open decay channel (plus, of course, an antineut This single channel beta decay explores the same nuclear wave functions of initial and final states as does the neutrino capture in atomic 205Tl, and thus its probability or rate is governed by the same nuclear matrix elements that affect both weak interactions: 81205Tl1 2+81+→ 82205Pb1 2-81++ νν81205Tl1 2+0→ 82205Pb1 2-1++e- Measuring the rate of accumulation of 205Pb81+ ions in the circulating beam of 205Tl81+ ions gives directly the cross section of reaction (b). The calculations of the expected rates under realistic experimental conditions will be shown to be very favorable for the measurement, e.g., ∼104 ions per hour in a 100 mA beam. The great sensitivity of the rate to the 205Pb-205Tl mass difference will appear (12%/keV), showing the need to materially improve the uncertainty in this value, and several experiments will be proposed. A special calibration experiment to verify the method and check the theoretical calculations will be suggested. Finally the neutrino cross section calculation based on the observed rate of reaction (a) will be shown. Demonstrating bound state beta decay may be the first verification of the theory of this very important process that influences beta decay rates of several isotopes in stellar interiors, e.g., 187Re, that play important roles in geologic and cosmologic dating and nucleosynthesis. © 1988.
Index Keywords: Lead and Alloys; Particle Detectors; Thallium and Alloys; Neutrino Absorption; Solar Neutrinos; Solar Radiation

Title: Studies of radioactive decays of completely ionized nuclei in a heavy ion storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: GSI, D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kienle, P., GSI, D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: With a heavy ion synchrotron and a storage ring currently under construction at GSI in Darmstadt it will be possible to look for the still undiscovered mode of β- decay to bound electron states. This mode has played a key role in nuclear synthesis at high temperatures. Possible detection techniques and the decay of 163Dy as a test case as well as the decays of 187Re and 205Tl, which are of astrophysical interest, are discussed. © 1988.
Index Keywords: Accelerators--Storage Rings; Dysprosium; Physics--High Energy; Thallium and Alloys; Beta Decay; Heavy Ion Storage Ring; Isotopes

Authors: Bartz R., Richard W., Kitchen J.C., Spinrad R.W.
Title: A low power, high resolution, in situ fluorometer for profiling and moored applications in water
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Sea Tech Inc., Corvallis, OR, 97339, United States; Naval Research, 800 N. Quincy St, Arlington, VA, 22217, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bartz, R., Sea Tech Inc., Corvallis, OR, 97339, United States; Richard, W., Sea Tech Inc., Corvallis, OR, 97339, United States; Kitchen, J.C., Sea Tech Inc., Corvallis, OR, 97339, United States; Spinrad, R.W., Naval Research, 800 N. Quincy St, Arlington, VA, 22217, Germany
Abstract: Sea Tech Inc. has developed an in situ fluorometer to measure chlorophyll a fluorescence in aquatic environments. The instrument has been developed within stringent constraints of size, weight and power consumption. The use of custom-designed components, including the flashlamp, excitation and emission filters, and energy storage capacitor for the light source has permitted optimal mechanical, optical and electrical design of the instrument. This new design results in efficient stimulation and detection of chlorophyll a fluorescence. The instrument is not sensitive to ambient light and has excellent stability over time and temperature. Chlorophyll a concentration is measurable on three selectable ranges of approximately 3, 10 or 30 μg/1 full scale with a minimum detectable signal of <0.02 gg/1. Time constants of 0.1, 1, 3 and 10 seconds are selectable to smooth the output data. Power requirements are nominally 12 VDC at 150 mA, and output signal is 0 to 5 VDC. These power requirements and signal levels make the fluorometer compatible with most oceanographic moored and profiling data acquisition systems. Operating depth for the instrument is rated at 500 meters with a plastic housing or 3000 meters with a stainless steel pressure housing. © 1988 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Chlorophyll; Data acquisition; Digital storage; Fluorescence; Fluorometers; Housing; Light sources; Aquatic environments; Chlorophyll a fluorescence; Chlorophyll-a concentration; Data acquisition system; Electrical design; Energy storage capacitor; Power requirement; Stringent constraints; Light

Authors: Elegant L., Salman M., Schwob Y.
Title: Calorimetric study of some carboxylic acids lewis-bases complexes in view of thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Expérimentale, Institut Polytechnique Méditerranéen, Parc Vairose 06034, NiceFrance
Authors with affiliations: Elegant, L., Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Expérimentale, Institut Polytechnique Méditerranéen, Parc Vairose 06034, NiceFrance; Salman, M., Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Expérimentale, Institut Polytechnique Méditerranéen, Parc Vairose 06034, NiceFrance; Schwob, Y., Laboratoire de Thermodynamique Expérimentale, Institut Polytechnique Méditerranéen, Parc Vairose 06034, NiceFrance
Abstract: This paper studies the equilibrium reaction between acetic acid and triethylamine induced by the formation of an H-bonded complex. These compounds were used as bulk reagents to form a complex in the liquid state. This type of reaction can be used in thermochemical energy storage at low temperature (from ambient temperature up to 423 K) and atmospheric pressure. Only one storage tank is required: the formation of the H-bond is an exothermic process, and this bond can be broken by heat absorption. Physical and thermodynamic parameters were determined by means of a Calvet calorimeter and a DSC 111 differential scanning calorimeter. © 1988.

Authors: Strauss C.H., BlAnkenhorn P.R., Bowersox T.W., Grado S.C.
Title: Financial and energy costs of supplying woody biomass to conversion sites
Affiliations: School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, 16802, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strauss, C.H., School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, 16802, PA, United States; BlAnkenhorn, P.R., School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, 16802, PA, United States; Bowersox, T.W., School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, 16802, PA, United States; Grado, S.C., School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, 16802, PA, United States
Abstract: A series of short rotation Populus plantations involving four management strategies were evaluated in tandem with alternate harvest and storage strategies to determine the least cost method for supplying biomass to conversion sites. All inputs were itemized on both a financial and energy basis to establish the unit output costs for commercial-scale systems. The control strategy had the lowest production costs, at $28.74 Mg-1 (ovendry), and 5,455 MJ Mg-1(OD). The addition of harvest and storage costs, based on existing and proposed technologies within the forest product industries, increased the total supply cost for biomass to $59.61 Mg-1(OD) and 7,233.1 MJ Mg-1(OD). On a financial basis, the proposed cost was 17% more expensive than a projected price for biomass from an ethanol plant and was also higher than the general prices for aspen from domestic markets. However, on an energy basis, the gross heat of combustion for the Populus biomass was 2.7 times greater than its total energy costs. © 1988 Humana Press Inc.
Author Keywords: economics; energy costs; financial costs; Woody biomass

Title: Temperature determinants of plant-soil-air mercury relationships
Affiliations: Department of Botany, College of Natural Sciences, Honolulu, 96822, HI, United States; Department of Environmental Health Sciences, School of Public Health, United States; University of Hawaii at Manoa Honolulu, 96822, HI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siegel, S.M., Department of Botany, College of Natural Sciences, Honolulu, 96822, HI, United States; Siegel, B.Z., Department of Environmental Health Sciences, School of Public Health, United States, University of Hawaii at Manoa Honolulu, 96822, HI, United States
Abstract: Using the Arrhenius thermodynamic equation, which relates rates of processes to temperature through the quantity Ea, the 'Heat (or Energy) of Activation', we have evaluated the thermal relationships for several parameters of Hg cycling. It is shown that release from isolated leaves (shoots) of Hg0 is a two-step process with a higher Ea value below 21 °C than above (28 vs 14 kcal mol-1). Open field air Hg measurements over a mixed stand of grasses and other plants in volcanic soil show strikingly similar behavior to detached organs. Mercury release from volcanic soil was uniform over a wide temperature range, resembling plant and open field emissions above 18 to 21°C with an Ea value of 13 kcal · mol-1. We conclude that Hg release below 18 to 21 °C is limited by a physiological process, whereas above that range, release is controlled by the physical process of vaporization itself. Plant concentration of total Hg from 5 to 33 °C (air temperature), is a more complex function involving direct accumulation and re-release of Hg0 from the atmosphere, release from tissue storage, and root uptake with reduction. © 1988 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Index Keywords: air; Hg; plant; soil; temperature; mercury; air analysis; higher plant; nonhuman; plant; soil; temperature

Title: DEEP BOREHOLE SPECIAL CABLE.
Authors with affiliations: Knox, R.
Abstract: The Earth's internal heat offers one of the most promising sources of renewable energy. Unlike other sources such as wind and solar power, geothermal energy has the major advantage of being constant, so the need for expensive energy storage or back-up systems is avoided. However, a detailed geological study on the site, requiring test boreholes, must first be undertaken. A special version of the established mineral insulated cable, developed in the United Kingdom for use in geothermal and oil recovery borehole applications is supplied in unbroken lengths of up to 10 kilometres.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC CABLES - Heat Resisting; ELECTRIC INSULATING MATERIALS; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; THERMOCOUPLES; BICC PYROTENAX, HEPBURN, UK; GEOTHERMAL BOREHOLES; MINERAL INSULATED THERMOCOUPLE CABLES; NICKEL ALUMINUM CONDUCTORS; NICKEL CHROMIUM CONDUCTORS; OIL RECOVERY BOREHOLES; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY

Authors: Prairie M.R., Cho B.K., Oh S.H., Shinouskis E.J., Bailey J.E., Prairie M.R.
Title: Steady-State and Transient Studies of Carbon Monoxide Oxidation on Alumina-Supported Rhodium via Transmission Infrared Spectroscopy
Affiliations: Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research Laboratories, Warren, Michigan 48090, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California 91125, United States
Authors with affiliations: Prairie, M.R., Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research Laboratories, Warren, Michigan 48090, United States, Department of Chemical Engineering, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California 91125, United States; Cho, B.K., Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research Laboratories, Warren, Michigan 48090, United States; Oh, S.H., Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research Laboratories, Warren, Michigan 48090, United States; Shinouskis, E.J., Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research Laboratories, Warren, Michigan 48090, United States; Bailey, J.E., Department of Chemical Engineering, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California 91125, United States; Prairie, M.R., Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research Laboratories, Warren, Michigan 48090, United States, Department of Chemical Engineering, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California 91125, United States
Abstract: Transmission infrared (TIR) spectroscopy was used to examine the behavior of adsorbed CO on a Rh/Al2O3 catalyst during transient CO chemisorption experiments and during steady-state, step-response, and forced-cycling oxidation experiments at 900 Torr. At 300 °C, the catalyst initially supported primarily a dicarbonyl CO species but after use exhibited spectra characteristic of a surface mostly covered by linearly bound CO. A model that describes transient, diffusion-influenced CO adsorption and desorption for the supported catalyst is presented. It suggests that the CO desorption energy depends linearly on coverage and that the magnitude of this dependence is a function of temperature. Observed rate dependence on bulk CO concentration for O2 effluent levels of 0.5% and 0.25% is interpreted considering the effects of internal and external mass transport at 300 °C. Step-response and forced-cycling oxidation experiments across stoichiometric conditions exhibit oxygen and CO storage effects characteristic of CO oxidation catalysts. Data indicating autonomous oscillation of CO coverage and CO2 production are also presented. © 1988, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: ADSORPTION - Transients; Catalysts; Desorption; Spectroscopy; ALUMINA-SUPPORTED RHODIUM; TRANSIENT ADSORPTION; TRANSMISSION INFRARED SPECTROSCOPY; Carbon monoxide

Title: How Will Superconductivity Change Your Workplace?
Authors with affiliations: Minetos, Peter
Abstract: The author examines the impact of superconductivity on industry. He reports on the search for the 'right' superconducting material, i.e., a material that is capable of transporting energy without resistance at room temperature or close to it. Superconductors, once perfected, are likely to have uses ranging from cable and electrical wiring to full-scale power generation and energy storage coils. Improvements will be seen in virtually all electronic devices. Most notably, the computer will be greatly enhanced. Computer transmission lines, thin-film computer interconnects, and Josephson junctions (superconducting on-off switches) are expected to be the first elements for commercialization of this technology.
Index Keywords: High Temperature Superconductivity; Potential Risks; Room Temperature Superconductivity; Work Procedures; Superconductivity

Title: Thermal storage: will it be ice or water
Affiliations: Engineering Interface Ltd, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Tamblyn, Robert T., Engineering Interface Ltd, Canada
Abstract: Manufacturers of thermal storage equipment are competing today for the allegiance of HVAC designers. Spurred by utilities with an interest in reversing their declining load factors, some 30 manufacturers are offering a selection of cool storage hardware. The competition is slightly one sided. Only three of the 30 are marketing water tanks while the rest are manufacturing a variety of ice modules. Further, the water tanks present an unsuitable silhouette for modern buildings; however, they are likely to be more acceptable for industrial complexes. The debate now narrows to ice versus concrete water tanks that can be buried and out of sight. Fortunately, concrete can be used under buildings or on roofs when no other space on the site is available. This paper discusses cost considerations for different types of water storage.
Index Keywords: Water--Energy Storage; Chilled Water Storage Systems; Ice Storage; Thermal Storage; Ice

Title: Effect of switching surges on series compensated EHV transmission lines
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers (India): Electrical Engineering Division
Affiliations: Bengal Engineering Coll, India
Authors with affiliations: Pal, J., Bengal Engineering Coll, India; Purkayastha, G.P., Bengal Engineering Coll, India
Abstract: The effects of series capacitor compensation on switching surges in transmission lines have been studied. The lines have been considered as three phase and fully transposed. The voltage response at the receiving-end with different degrees of compensation has been analyzed. For this purpose, the sending-end is excited with a voltage of unit step function. The voltage response without series compensation has also been analyzed to make a comparison between the two system. The effects of frequency dependent line parameters on transient over-voltages at the receiving-end with and without series compensation has been studied. A suitable example of a transmission system has been given, the results tabulated and the curves plotted.
Index Keywords: Capacitors--Energy Storage; Electric Lines--Surges; Surge Protection; EHV Transmission Lines; Series Capacitor Compensation; Switching Surges; Electric Power Transmission, EHV

Title: Polymerization of micelle-forming surfactants
Source title: Journal of Macromolecular Science - Reviews in Macromolecular Chemistry and Physics
Affiliations: NRC Demokritos, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Paleos, C.M., NRC Demokritos, Greece; Malliaris, Angelos, NRC Demokritos, Greece
Abstract: In this review we discuss the principal aspects of the polymerization of micelle-forming surfactants in the aggregated state. Micellar polymerization means that the micelle is not merely the medium in which polymerization takes place, as is the case in emulsion polymerization, but instead the micelle-forming surfactant monomers themselves undergo polymerization. Interest in micellar polymerization arises primarily from the expectation that stable micelles, appropriate for technological applications, will be produced. Thus, in problems of conversion and storage of solar energy, chemical catalysis and inhibition drug carriers, adjuvants in immunology, etc., micelles can play an important role. Furthermore, polymerized micelles, owing to their covalent intermolecular bonds, have a closer physicochemical resemblance to biopolymers than their nonpolymerized counterparts. Also, the ion-containing polymers obtained from polymerization in the micellar state are closely related to interesting classes of polyelectrolytes and ionomers. Finally, micellar polymerization can sometimes offer an easy path to the synthesis of polymeric products difficult to obtain by conventional methods.
Index Keywords: Miscellar Polymerization; Surface Active Agents

Title: Thermal storage systems slash on-peak demand
Affiliations: Christian Broadcasting Network, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fiedler, Bob, Christian Broadcasting Network, United States
Abstract: The Christian Broadcasting Network, located in Virginia Beach, Va., developed an energy management program with two ice storage systems to reduce on-peak demand by 31 percent. CBN, a television ministry and graduate university, is a complex of five buildings totaling 710, 000 sq ft. The unique energy requirements for television production and a graduate university have created tremendous challenges for CBN to be energy efficient. This paper discusses two different ice storage systems which were created and installed under different circumstances. They are the R22 liquid recirculation system and a glycol ice storage system.
Index Keywords: Energy Management; Energy Management Program; Glycol Ice Storage System; R22 Ice Storage System; Thermal Storage Systems; Ice

Title: Compact plasma source of soft x-rays
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Baksht, R.B., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: A pulsed source of soft x-radiation at a wavelength of ≈ 1 nm with a pulse energy of 1-2 J is described. The radiator is a dense high-temperature plasma produced by compression of a cylindrical liner. The liner is formed by jets of ionized vapors emitted by electrodes in the operation of a vacuum arc.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Arcs; Electrodes - Ionization; Plasmas; X-Ray Apparatus - Design; Ionized Vapor Deposition; Liner Compression; Plasma Sources; Pulsed X Ray Sources; Soft X Radiation; Soft X Ray Sources; X-Ray and Gamma Ray Production

Title: Time average neutralized migma: A colliding beam/plasma hybrid physical state as aneutronic energy source - A review
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Aneutronic Energy Laboratory, United Sciences, Inc., P.O. Box 3037, Princeton, NJ 08543, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maglich, B.C., Aneutronic Energy Laboratory, United Sciences, Inc., P.O. Box 3037, Princeton, NJ 08543, United States
Abstract: A D+ beam of kinetic energy Ti = 0.7 MeV was stored in a "simple mirror" magnetic field as self-colliding orbits or migma and neutralized by ambient, oscillating electrons whose bounce frequencies were externally controlled. Space charge density was exceeded by an order of magnitude without instabilities. Three nondestructive diagnostic methods allowed measurements of ion orbit distribution, ion storage times, ion energy distribution, nuclear reaction rate, and reaction product spectrum. Migma formed a disc 20 cm in diameter and 0.5 cm thick. Its ion density was sharply peaked in the center; the ion-to-electron temperature ratio was TiTe ∼ 103; ion-electron temperature equilibrium was never reached. The volume average and central D+ density were n = 3.2 × 109 cm-3 and nc = 3 × 1010 cm-3 respectively, compared to the space charge limit density nsc = 4 × 108 cm-3. The energy confinement time was τc = 20-30 s, limited by the change exchange reactions with the residual gas in the vacuum (5 × 10-9 Torr). The ion energy loss rate was 1.4 keV/s. None of the instabilities that were observed in mirrors at several orders of magnitude lower density occurred. The proton energy spectrum for dd + d → T + p + 4 MeV shows that dd collided at an average crossing angle of 160°. Evidence for exponential density buildup has also been observed. Relative to Migma III results and measured in terms of the product of ion energy E, density n, and confinement time τ, device performance was improved by a factor of 500. Using the central fast ion density, we obtained the triple product: Tnτ ≅ 4 × 1014 keV s cm-3, which is greater than that of the best fusion devices. The luminosity (collision rate per unit cross section) was ∼ 1029 cm-2s-1, with o.7 A ion current through the migma center. The stabilizing features of migma are: (1) large Larmor radius; (2) small canonical angular momentum; (3) short axial length z (disc shape); (4) nonadiabatic motions in r and z; (5) precession and enegy spread; (6) ambipolar potential; (7) radial density gradient;(8) large ion-to-electron temperature ratio; (9) metal walls in z; (10) suitability for external stabilization techniques (small volume, recurrent surfacing of ions); and particularly (11) diamagnetic well. Extrapolition of the results to reactor densities led to a D + 3He reactor "basic migma disc" 0.5 m in diameter and 0.25 m thick, suspended in a 10 T field, generating 1.5 MW(th). A 2-MW(e) power plant would consist of 3 such discs in a common volume. referred to as a triplet migmacell. Its specific power is projected to be 1 MW(e)/ton. A large power plant of any size would consist of a large number of migma discs in a common volume. The advantages f such modular systems are: (1) economy of mass production: capital cost per kW will be 25% that of fission and 10% that of DT fusion; (2) plants will be economical for all sizes above 10 kW(e); (3) minimal heat pollution, thanks to direct conversion of the changed ion kinetic energy into electricity; (4) no proliferative potential; and (5) large power-to-weight ratio due to absence of shielding. Anticipated physics problems in density increase are discussed. © 1988.
Index Keywords: Ion Beams--Measurements; Plasmas; Aneutronic Energy Source; Hadrons; Migma 4 Experiment; Physics

Title: Infrared Beam Induced Contrast With Double Illumination
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: University of Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Castaldini, A., University of Bologna, Italy; Cavallini, A., University of Bologna, Italy
Abstract: Over the last few years scanning optical microscopy (SOM) has been largely developed as a tool to explore the physical properties of materials. In particular the optical beam induced current (OBIC) mode of the SOM has been used to map the electronic properties of semiconducting devices. A new type of scanning microscopy method, as well as some results obtained by it, will be reported in this paper. Though similar, to a certain extent, to the standard scanning optical microscopy, this new investigation technique, from now on refered to as infrared beam induced contrast (IRBIC), differs from it in substance. The chopped light from a quartz halogen lamp is focused by a conventional microscope rearranged on the specimen surface, and a pin-hole is positioned so as to reduce the probe size (not the resolving power) to 1.5μm. The resulting beam power density is of the order of 1mW*cm-2. Such a low power density presents some disadvantages in comparison with the traditional laser sources, but, on the other hand, it allows a very high sensitivity in the investigation of the defect electrical activity. With this experimental set-up the specimen front surface is probed with band-gap radiation. Its back surface is illuminated by continuous light in the infrared, coming through a monochromator from a glow-bar. The radiation wavelength can be selected continuously so as the photon energy ranges over the whole valence-to-conduction energy gap. When the specimen is probed, the photoinduced carriers are separated by the built-in field due to the depletion zone of a p-n junction or a Schottky barrier, and the photocurrent is amplified by the lock-in technique. The application of a back-surface radiation of less than the band-gap energy modifies, in some way, the photoconductive response to the band-gap probe since the secondary illumination changes the occupancy of the traps in the forbidden gap active in the photoconductive process. This phenomenon, known as “quenching” of extrinsic photoconductivity, when applied to scanning optical microscopy allows localized investigations on energy levels. As a matter of fact, the beam induced contrast at a defect depends on the secondary illumination wavelength, that is on the trap level excited, as we observed in defective Si. © 1988 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Electronic properties; Optical data storage; Optical microscopy; Photoconductivity; Probes; Schottky barrier diodes; Semiconductor junctions; Electrical activities; Illumination changes; Optical beam induced currents; Photoconductive response; Physical properties of materials; Quartz halogen lamps; Radiation wavelength; Scanning optical microscopy; Energy gap

Title: Three-jet events at the CERN intersecting storage rings

Yelton, J.M., Dept. of Physics, Oxford University, Oxford, United Kingdom
Abstract: Three-jet events have been observed in pp collisions at s = 62.3 GeV. The data were collected using a total neutral energy trigger with a threshold at 25 GeV. These events appear predominantly as two jets, with some appearing as three jets. A novel analysis for the extraction of 2-jet and 3-jet events is described, and some of the event properties are discussed. The relative numbers of two- and three-jet events are studied within the framework of leading-order QCD, and yield a value of αs(K3/K2) = 0.19 ± 0.02 (stat.) ± 0.04 (syst.). © 1988.

Authors: Nitsch C., Braslavsky S.E., Schatz G.H.
Title: Laser-induced optoacoustic calorimetry of primary processes in isolated Photosystem I and Photosystem II particles
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Institut für Strahlenchemie, Mülheim an der Ruhr, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Nitsch, C., Max-Planck-Institut für Strahlenchemie, Mülheim an der Ruhr, Germany; Braslavsky, S.E., Max-Planck-Institut für Strahlenchemie, Mülheim an der Ruhr, Germany; Schatz, G.H., Max-Planck-Institut für Strahlenchemie, Mülheim an der Ruhr, Germany
Abstract: The heat released by all primary processes occurring within the first few microseconds after a laser flash of 677 nm was measured by optoacoustic spectroscopy of Photosystem I and II particles isolated from the cyanobacterium Synechococcus sp. The heat production was calibrated either 'internally' by inhibiting photochemistry, i.e., closing the reaction centers, or by using solutions of CuCl2 as calorimetric standard. By this method detailed information on the energy partitioning between fluorescence, photochemistry and heat dissipation is obtained for each photosystem. The photoproducts formed within 1.4 ± 0.1 μs in the Photosystem I and II particles, i.e., the states P+-700 A-1 and Z+ P-680 IQ-A, were found to be associated with a relative energy storage of 0.83 (±0.08) and 0.65 (±0.07), respectively. From these data a difference of midpoint potentials (ΔEm) between P+-700 P-700 and A-1 A1 of 1520 ± 150 meV was calculated, which implies an Em( A-1 A1) of -(1040 ± 160) meV. The midpoint potential difference between Z+ Z and Q-A QA was 1190 ± 100 meV. The consequences for the value of Em( Z+ Z) are discussed on the basis of the variability of Em values reported for the quinone acceptors in the literature. In the case of Photosystem II particles with closed reaction centers a fraction of 5% of the absorbed energy stored for a time longer than 1.4 μs is attributed to the formation of triplet P-680. Data from intact Synechococcus cells, excited at 628 and 677 nm, is explained in terms of the results obtained from the isolated particles and the coupling of the antenna pigments in the phycobilisomes to Photosystem II. © 1988.
Author Keywords: (Cyanobacterium); Electron transport; Energy storage; Optoacoustics; Photosynthesis

Title: Energy conversions and storage caused by an unsteady poloidal flow in active solar regions
Affiliations: Dr Remeis-Sternwarte, Astronomical Institute, Erlangen-Nürnberg University, Bamberg, Germany; Dept. of Earth and Space Science, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, Anhui, China; Institute of Mechanics, Academia Sinica, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, Z., Dr Remeis-Sternwarte, Astronomical Institute, Erlangen-Nürnberg University, Bamberg, Germany, Dept. of Earth and Space Science, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, Anhui, China; Hu, W.R., Institute of Mechanics, Academia Sinica, Beijing, China
Abstract: In this paper we discuss coupling processes between a magnetic field and an unsteady plasma motion, and analyze the features of energy storage and conversions in active region. It is pointed out that the static force-free field is insufficient for a discussion of storage processes, and also the pure unsteady plasma rotation is not a perfect approach. In order to analyze the energy storage, we must consider the addition of poloidal plasma motion. The paper shows that because the unsteady poloidal flow is added and coupling occurs between the magnetic field and both the toroidal and the poloidal plasma flows, an unsteady process is maintained which changes the force-free factor with time. Hence, the energy in the lower levels can be transferred to the upper levels, and a considerable energy can be stored in the active region. Finally, another storage process is given which is due to the pure poloidal flow. The article shows that even if there is no twisted magnetic line of force, the energy in the lower levels may still be transferred to the upper levels and stored there. © 1988 Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Title: EXPLORATORY BATTERY DEVELOPMENT AND TESTING.
Affiliations: Sandia National Lab, USA, Sandia National Lab, USA
Authors with affiliations: Clark, Robert P., Sandia National Lab, USA, Sandia National Lab, USA
Abstract: The exploratory battery development project encompasses core technology development and engineering of advanced battery systems. The end use of the battery technologies include electric and hybrid vehicles, utility load-levelling, dispersed energy storage, photovoltaic systems and windbased electric generating systems. Battery technologies currently under development include the sodium/sulphur, zinc/bromine, nickel/hydrogen and aluminium/air systems. The battery technology evaluation element seeks to characterize the performance of developmental units; the resulting data is used to help guide the work of developers.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; BATTERY TECHNOLOGY; EXPLORATORY BATTERY DEVELOPMENT; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: BATTERY LIFE-cYCLE COST ANALYSIS.
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, USA
Authors with affiliations: Brown, D.R., Pacific Northwest Lab, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, USA; Humphreys, K.K., Pacific Northwest Lab, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, USA
Abstract: Life-cycle cost (LCC) estimates have been prepared for 17 combinations of battery or fuel-cell technologies and load-levelling, stand-alone power system, or electric vehicle applications. In addition, LCCs for gas-fired turbine, compressed-air energy storage, pumped hydro energy storage, and internal combustion engine technologies were estimated for comparative purposes. The objectives in preparing the estimates were to determine the relative economics among alternative battery systems and to compare battery systems economics with competing energy technologies.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE - Costs; FUEL CELLS - Costs; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; BATTERY LIFE-CYCLE COST; ENERGY STORAGE LOAD-LEVELLING; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: INTEGRATING WATER SOURCE HEAT PUMPS WITH THERMAL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Meckler Group, Encino, CA, USA, Meckler Group, Encino, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, Milton, Meckler Group, Encino, CA, USA, Meckler Group, Encino, CA, USA
Abstract: The main differences between the patented multi-source hydronic heat pump (MSHHP) system developed by Design Build Systems and a conventionally designed water source heat pump (WSHP) system involve the use of a separate chilled water, or diversity, cooling loop interconnecting the air-to-water coils of two or more WSHP units with a central chilled water thermal energy storage (TES) tank. The operational features are listed in the paper.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Hydronic Systems; ENERGY STORAGE; COLD AIR DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS; MULTI-SOURCE HYDRONIC HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; PEAK DAY OPERATING PROFILE; REDUCED ENERGY COSTS; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: COOL STORAGE SYSTEM DESIGN.
Affiliations: Henry Adams Inc, Baltimore, MD, USA, Henry Adams Inc, Baltimore, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pearson, Frederick J., Henry Adams Inc, Baltimore, MD, USA, Henry Adams Inc, Baltimore, MD, USA
Abstract: The progress of the design, construction and operation of the HVAC systems for a building in Baltimore is discussed. This includes the central-station air handling; system cooling cycle; system heating cycle; thermal storage system; heating/cooling loads; system costs and energy use; and design problems. Recorded data indicate a usable storage capacity of approximately 95 percent, which is in excess of that anticipated. Additionally, the system has continued to cool the building with outside air temperature higher than design, while space thermostats were set at 75 F instead of 78 F.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Costs; ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEATING - Heat Storage; CENTRAL-STATION AIR HANDLING; SYSTEM COOLING/HEATING CYCLE; SYSTEM DESIGN; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM; BUILDINGS

Title: ELECTRICAL ENERGY CONSUMPTION IN REFRIGERATED PRODUCE STORAGES.
Affiliations: Agriculture Canada, Agassiz, BC, Can, Agriculture Canada, Agassiz, BC, Can
Authors with affiliations: Perrin, Peter W., Agriculture Canada, Agassiz, BC, Can, Agriculture Canada, Agassiz, BC, Can
Abstract: Electrical energy consumption by three different refrigerated produce storage systems was monitored over two storage seasons (22 mo. ). The jacketed storage was the lowest energy user with a mean consumption between 0. 8 and 0. 9 kW. The Humi-fresh storage had the highest mean consumption of about 2 kW. Monitoring proved effective in detecting a fault in the fan speed controller of a modified conventional storage which otherwise had a mean energy consumption of 1. 1-1. 2 kW. Energy consumption in all storages did not appear to vary markedly with load. However, the Humi-fresh storage showed a significant correlation of energy use in response to outside temperatures. Although satisfactory produce storage was achieved with both the Humi-fresh and jacketed storage systems, economy of operation would favor the latter, especially if controlled atmosphere storage were desirable.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS - Analysis; ELECTRIC MEASUREMENTS; FOOD PRODUCTS - Storage; REFRIGERATORS - Electric Power; ELECTRICAL ENERGY CONSUMPTION; REFRIGERATED PRODUCE STORAGES; AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

Title: DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF AN ICE-IN-TANK DIURNAL ICE STORAGE COOLING SYSTEM FOR THE PX BUILDING AT FORT STEWART, GA.
Source title: Technical Report - United States Army Corps of Engineers, Construction Engineering Research Laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Sohn, Chang W.; Tomlinson, John
Abstract: Ice, water, or eutectic salts can be used to store refrigeration produced during offpeak hours. Then during peak load periods, the stored cold can be used to cool a facility. Such a reduction in the peak electrical demand can result in substantial savings in utility bills throughout the year. However, there is a lack of standard design guidance on these systems for Army engineers. As a first step forward system was designed and installed - using standard engineering practices - at Fort Stewart, Ga. This report documents the design and installation of the ice-in-tank system.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER UTILIZATION; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ICE; REFRIGERATION - Energy Storage; DIURNAL ICE STORAGE; ICE-IN-TANK SYSTEM; BUILDINGS

Title: AIR POWER BOOSTS UTILITY ENERGY SUPPLIES.
Affiliations: Longardner & Associates Inc,, Indianapolis, IN, USA, Longardner & Associates Inc, Indianapolis, IN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Longardner, Robert L., Longardner & Associates Inc,, Indianapolis, IN, USA, Longardner & Associates Inc, Indianapolis, IN, USA; Visnesky, Anthony, Longardner & Associates Inc,, Indianapolis, IN, USA, Longardner & Associates Inc, Indianapolis, IN, USA
Abstract: The Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) facility, proposed for Pittsfield, Ill. , could consist of up to four 50MW units. It will use a sandstone aquifer underlying the site to store some 650 million cu ft of air injected under about 360 psi pressure (per 50MW unit). The system can be built for a capital cost of less than 600/kW using off-the-shelf machinery, which has a turnaround efficiency common to fossil-fuel based, load steam plants. The Pittsfield project was derived in part from the successful findings of air storage tests that the Electric Power Research Institute, Palo Alto, Calif. conducted at the site in St. Peter sandstone - one of the principal geologic formations in Illinois. The proposed facility would be the first system in the U. S. to store compressed air in an aquifer for future energy production.
Index Keywords: AQUIFERS; COMPRESSED AIR - Storage; GEOLOGY; STRUCTURAL DESIGN - Underground; AIR POWER; PEAK-POWER DEMANDS; PUMPED-AIR STORAGE SYSTEM; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: ALTERNATIVE PROPULSION CONCEPTS USING HIGH-ENERGY BATTERIES AND HYDROGEN.
Affiliations: BMW AG, Bonn, West Ger, BMW AG, Bonn, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Braess, Hans-Hermann, BMW AG, Bonn, West Ger, BMW AG, Bonn, West Ger
Abstract: The role of electricity and hydrogen in vehicle propulsion, whether in a purely solar energy system or in a mixed nuclear/solar system, but at any rate in an extremely low pollution energy economy, could be outlined as follows. Advanced systems such as the sodium-sulphur battery offer the possibility of providing urban and short range transport (up to a range of 200 km). Larger distances of 200-500 km would have to be covered by using liquid hydrogen fuelled cars with internal combustion engines.

Title: QUALITY-THE CRITICAL ELEMENT IN LIQUID FUEL HANDLING.
Affiliations: Power Engineering, Tulsa, OK, USA, Power Engineering, Tulsa, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rittenhouse, R.C., Power Engineering, Tulsa, OK, USA, Power Engineering, Tulsa, OK, USA
Abstract: Utilities traditionally have had long-term contracts with oil companies who knew exactly what they shipped and made sure that the delivered fuel did not cause problems in use or storage. But now there are few long-term fuel oil contracts. Most utilities must buy fuel in odd lots and the origin (or lineage) may not be known, because today's oil jobber may simply buy it from someone else. Consequently, the EPRI is presently carrying out programs designed to provide utilities with improved means of specifying and assessing boiler fuel quality and to help them prevent complications from occurring when heavy fuel oils from different sources are mixed together. In addition, the US Department of Energy has programs underway on the handling and firing of coal-oil fuel mixtures and coal-water slurries. It is noted that coal-water slurries can be stored for periods of time even in normal oil tanks and handled with oil piping, valves and other common equipment.
Index Keywords: COAL SLURRIES - Applications; OIL FUEL - Residual; COAL-WATER SLURRIES; EPRI; HEAVY FUEL OILS; LIQUID FUEL HANDLING; LIQUID FUELS

Authors: Wilkins Ebtisam S., Ramachandran Ram S.
Title: GELLED SOLAR PONDS.
Affiliations: Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wilkins, Ebtisam S., Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Ramachandran, Ram S., Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Univ of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: In this overview the authors compare different concepts in solar pond technology and then cite examples of their practical application. Although the conventional solar pond uses a salt gradient, many other types, such as the gel pond, the viscosity-stabilized pond, the membrane-stratified pond, the saturated pond, and the honeycomb-covered pond, have also been suggested. The authors present the advantages and disadvantages of each type. A discussion is also presented of the gel pond in which the nonconvective zone is modified chemically or replaced by a chemically formed gel. Preliminary studies on gel ponds indicate that polymer gels that have good optical and thermal insulating properties might be able to replace the nonconvective zone. Because gels are semisolid, convective currents are inhibited and hence the gel acts as a good insulator. Further, the gel material could be used inside a bag made of Du Pont's Tedlar material, and gel 1 or 2 ft thick is enough to achieve a high storage zone temperature. 32 Refs.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES; ENERGY STORAGE; FALLING POND CONCEPT; GEL POND; HONEYCOMB SOLAR POND; PARTITIONED SOLAR POND; SATURATED SOLAR POND; VISCOSITY-STABILIZED POND; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Pollution comparison between diesel and electric powered vehicles
Affiliations: Electric Vehicle Association of Canada, Ottawa, Ont. K1P 5H9, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sporckmann, B., Electric Vehicle Association of Canada, Ottawa, Ont. K1P 5H9, Canada
Abstract: The increasing prominence of environmental issues gives rise to questions on the environmental effect of some industrial processes. For internal transport in particular, electric traction brings marked reduction in harmful emissions by comparison with internal combustion (IC) powered transport sytems. Since IC powered systems do not offer any economic advantages either, the use of electric powered industrial trucks to relieve the environment of pollution does not involve any additional expense. Taking an example of a 2.5 t fork-lift model to represent the wide range of industrial trucks, a comparison is made between the annual pollutant emissions of both power systems, which may be attributed to their energy consumption. The pollutants examined are dust, sulphur dioxide, nitric oxide, carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon. These substances are shown to have the greatest relevance in the public discussions on pollution.

Title: Heat transfer of latent thermal energy storage capsules arranged in alignment with the fluid flow (part II. Analysis of solidification process)
Affiliations: Shinshu Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirata, Tetsuo, Shinshu Univ, Japan; Ueda, Hideki, Shinshu Univ, Japan; Fujiwara, Masanori, Shinshu Univ, Japan
Abstract: Analytical considerations are presented for the solidification process of latent thermal energy storage capsules. The arrangement of the capsules was in alignment with the flow direction. It was shown that good agreement between the predicted and the experimental results can be obtained by application of the quasi-steady assumption on the solidification process. Numerical calculations for fifty rows of capsules showed that there is a certain location in the rows where the heat transfer rate between the capsules and the flow shows a maximum value, and the location moves to the downstream rows as time proceeds.

Abstract: Semiconductor generators of bell-shaped pulses of two types are examined. The first type of generator produces in a 50-Ohm resistive load a pulse with an amplitude of 1300 V and rise and fall times of 2 nsec and 5 nsec; the pulse repetition frequency is 20 kHz and the efficiency is better than 20%. The second type of generator produces in a 10-Ohm resistive load a pulse with an amplitude of 4 kV and a half-width of 5 nsec; the pulse repetition frequency is 100Hz and the efficiency is better than 30%.

Authors: Rink R.E., Gourishankar V., Zaheeruddin M.
Title: Optimal control of heat-pump/heat-storage systems with time-of-day energy price incentive
Source title: Journal of Optimization Theory and Applications
Affiliations: University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Rink, R.E., University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada; Gourishankar, V., University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada; Zaheeruddin, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada
Abstract: The maximum principle of optimal control theory is applied to the problem of optimizing the operation of a heat pump, when a storage capability is available and the electrical utility offers time-of-day price incentives in order to help level its diurnal load profile. The cost functional for optimal control is the monetary cost of purchased electrical energy. A bilinear model for the heat pump is assumed. When the ambient temperature is cyclic over the 24-hour period of the price pattern, periodic boundary conditions apply and the closed extremal trajectories are found to be unique and easily determined with a one-dimensional numerical search. These extremals have simple characteristics and reveal plausible strategies for minimizing the cost of purchased energy. They are potentially implementable with a simple, micro-processor-based controller. © 1988 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Abstract: The fluidized bed performance is predicted when it is coupled to a solar parabolic concentrator. The prediction method uses the one dimensional fluidized bed model in connection to a solar concentrator-receiver model. An analytical study of the different design parameters such as the concentration ratio, concentrator aperture area and the size of the fluidized bed is presented. The results are then used to obtain a correlation between some performance and design parameters, which can be used to optimize the design of the fluidized bed-concentrator storage system. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Jee Y., Becker M.F., Walser R.M.
Title: Multiple-pulse laser-induced damage to metal mirror surfaces
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Materials Science and Engineering, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Austin, TX, 78712-1084, United States; Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corp., (MCC), Austin, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jee, Y., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Materials Science and Engineering, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Austin, TX, 78712-1084, United States, Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corp., (MCC), Austin, TX, United States; Becker, M.F., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Materials Science and Engineering, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Austin, TX, 78712-1084, United States; Walser, R.M., The University of Texas at Austin, Center for Materials Science and Engineering, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Austin, TX, 78712-1084, United States
Abstract: The accumulation dependence of damage and laser induced damage morphologies on single crystal metal surfaces have been observed under Q-switched 1064 nm Nd:YAG laser irradiation at 10 nsec pulses at a 10 Hz rate. Several different damage morphologies were observed: Slip-line formation, ripple patterns, flat-melting, and boiling. Damage probability versus fluence curves and accumulation curves are plotted to investigate damage behavior as it correlates with morphology. Accumulation curves showed different damage behavior for crystals of different orientation. Threshold decrease due to accumulation was the largest on (111) Cu and Al surfaces, whidh also had the lowest single shot damage threshold. The threshold reduction in accumulation follows the equation FN = F1 NS-1 where FN is the N-pulse damage threshold, N the pulse number, and S the slope of the accumulation curve. Accumulation appears to be the result of the storage cycle of thermal stress-strain energy induced by each laser pulse, and multi-pulse damage results from plastic slip and fatigue. © 1988 SPIE.

Title: Global computational techniques
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: University of Tennessee, Department of Physics, Molecular Biophysics Laboratory, Knoxville, TN, 37996-1200, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weidner, R., University of Tennessee, Department of Physics, Molecular Biophysics Laboratory, Knoxville, TN, 37996-1200, United States; Georghiou, S., University of Tennessee, Department of Physics, Molecular Biophysics Laboratory, Knoxville, TN, 37996-1200, United States
Abstract: The remarkable success of global methods for analyzing time-resolved spectroscopic data has led to their extension in recent years to larger, more complex and more difficult analyses. Because of the increased complexity and difficulty, it has become even more important to use least-squares statistics to judge the accuracy of parameter estimates and the goodness of fit of the model under consideration. But the increased size of analyses has resulted in computational times so large that a complete least-squares analysis is frequently infeasible. To resolve this difficulty and to provide an adequate computational base for the further growth of global methods, we have developed a comprehensive, efficient methodology, based on separation techniques, for global least-squares analysis of time-resolved data from time- and frequency-domain measurements. We have formulated these techniques so as to exploit the special form of fluorescence spectral models. In particular, we have been able to reduce the cubic rate of growth in the number of computations per data curve of previous methodologies to essentially a linear growth rate. For excited-state kinetics described by time-independent rates and for data that adequately determine the corresponding model, computational times suitable for interactive computing can thereby be obtained, regardless of the magnitude and complexity of the analysis. For example, we have simulated data for energy transfer between the two chromophores of the a subunit of phycoerythrin at 99 consecutive emission wavelengths, each with 500 channels. Parameter estimation required less than 0.4 seconds per iteration on an IBM 3081, a reduction of more than three orders of magnitude over previous methods. Computational storage requirements undergo a similar reduction. These techniques are equally applicable to error estimation. We have derived a separated form of the equations for standard deviations and algorithms for computing nonlinear joint confidence limits that are analogous to those for parameter estimation (requiring, therefore, essentially the same amount of time per iteration). Standard deviations and linear estimates of confidence limits are all computed in a single iteration. Two types of confidence limits, support-plane and principal axis, can be calculated. The latter allow the limits for strongly correlated parameters to be estimated simultaneously by means of more stable algorithms. If only linear joint confidence limits are computed for the emission intensities, which is standard practice in the literature, then a complete analysis of the above system, which includes parameter and error estimates for the two decay rates, the energy transfer rate and approximately 200 emission intensities, can be obtained in less than 10 seconds. Equations are still expressed in normal form, which is simpler and more familiar to most users than singular-value decompositions and allows a wider range of algorithms to be employed in their solution. In particular, this approach facilitates the use of a variety of algorithms of higher order (i.e., with stronger convergence properties) than those customarily available. We have found their use in more difficult analyses to be crucial for achieving rapid convergence to parameter estimates. © 1988 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Biochemistry; Chromophores; Decay (organic); Digital storage; Energy transfer; Excited states; Frequency domain analysis; Iterative methods; Laser spectroscopy; Least squares approximations; Nonlinear equations; Singular value decomposition; Statistics; Accuracy of parameters; Computational technique; Convergence properties; Excited state kinetics; Global least squares analysis; Least squares analysis; Three orders of magnitude; Time and frequency domains; Parameter estimation

Title: Air formed concrete dome structures
Source title: American Concrete Institute, ACI Special Publication
Affiliations: McCarty Engineering, Longmont, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zimmerman, J., McCarty Engineering, Longmont, CO, United States
Abstract: Air supported forming represents a rapid and cost-effective technique for buiiding long span, thin shell, monolithic concrete structures. This construction method consists of inflating an air form, designed to the required building size and shape, after attachment to a foundation ring. Once inflated, the inside skin of the air form is sprayed with polyurethane foam. Steel reinforcement is fastened to the inside surface of the foam. Concrete is sprayed over the steel reinforcement, again from the inside. Steel is not placed, and concrete is not sprayed where shell openings are required. The air form can be color coated and textured, or removed for reuse when protective coatinps are applied over the exposed foam. This technology is appropriate for trea-soun architectural applications, bulk storage of granulated solids and liauids. © 1988 American Concrete Institute. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Photoionisation efficiency (PIE)-spectra are measured for small (N2O)n-clusters, n=2...8, using synchrotron radiation from the electron storage ring BESSY at Berlin. Ionisation thresholds are reported. Resonances in the wavelength-range 97...100 nm for n>2 are attributed to exciton absorption with N2O-Rydberg levels, series I and II parentage. This interpretation is supported by measurements of the PIE of mixed benzonitrile · (N2O)n clusters where benzonitrile serves as a monitor for photon absorption in N2O at energies above the ionisation limit of benzonitrile. © 1989 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Martingale approach to neural networks with hierarchically structured information
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik B Condensed Matter
Affiliations: Sonderforschungsbereich 123 der Universität Heidelberg, Im Neuenheimer Feld 294, Heidelberg 1, D-6900, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bös, S., Sonderforschungsbereich 123 der Universität Heidelberg, Im Neuenheimer Feld 294, Heidelberg 1, D-6900, Germany; Kühn, R., Sonderforschungsbereich 123 der Universität Heidelberg, Im Neuenheimer Feld 294, Heidelberg 1, D-6900, Germany; van Hemmen, J.L., Sonderforschungsbereich 123 der Universität Heidelberg, Im Neuenheimer Feld 294, Heidelberg 1, D-6900, Germany
Abstract: A modified version of a model with hierarchically structured information, originally proposed by Parga and Virasoro, is studied in the context of martingale theory. The number of generations is allowed to be arbitrary but fixed. In the calculation of the storage capacity both the patterns and all their ancestors have to be taken into account as retrieval states. Due to the martingale property, the free energy greatly simplifies and for the retrieval states is shown to reduce to the one of the Hopfield model. So the storage capacity and retrieval quality of both models are identical. Numerical stimulations confirm the theoretical predictions. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.

Abstract: Mechanical energy can be stored in a variety of ways - including a coiled spring or a stretched rubber band - but the most effective devices, especially for energy conservation applications, are considered to be the flywheel and the accumulator. Title: MAGNETIC FIELD EFFECTS ON HUMANS.
Authors with affiliations: Allison, William W.
Abstract: Man lives in a weak (0. 5 Gauss) magnetic field that apparently is not harmful and probably is beneficial. More intense magnetic fields occur at the time of the solar flares. The use of high magnetic fields is growing. Magnetic fields have been put to use for energy storage magnets, superconducting motors, generators, weapons detection, cyclotrons, levitated trains, and are encountered in high voltage transmission lines, fusion, space travel, bubble chamber and other advanced technologies. This article presents an overview of the effects of magnetic fields on humans since the use of high magnetic fields presents problems not commonly encountered in the past.

Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering, Brooklyn,, NY, USA, Mechanical Engineering, Brooklyn, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rosen, Jerome, Mechanical Engineering, Brooklyn,, NY, USA, Mechanical Engineering, Brooklyn, NY, USA
Abstract: Superconducting materials can conduct dc electricity - sometimes in enormous currents - with no resistance. They can cause a locomotive to levitate. They have been tested in noteworthy projects, but must still overcome several economic as well as technical constraints. Almost all the applications contemplated for high-temperature superconductors are extrapolations of applications that have already been suggested or explored for the low-temperature superconductors. Thus, the prerequisite of applications for the new materials, when they become available, is progress in developing the older materials.

Abstract: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream's plant expansion at their existing leased facility in Commerce, California, required a complete new refrigeration system to provide for added ice cream production and storage capacity. This created an opportunity to optimize the existing refrigeration load distribution as well as to upgrade the two-stage ammonia refrigeration system by utilizing the state-of-art equipment with significant energy-saving features and computer-based controls. The decision by Dreyers to build their own new refrigeration system meant construction of an entire new machine room facility, and then connecting back into the existing plant production and storage loads. This paper describes the new refrigeration system design.

Title: Kinetics of hydrogen absorption in alpha titanium
Affiliations: IBM Research, Tower 1, 1701 Golf Road, Rolling Meadows, 60008, IL, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, 48824-1226, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, C.C., IBM Research, Tower 1, 1701 Golf Road, Rolling Meadows, 60008, IL, United States; Buxbaum, R.E., Department of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, 48824-1226, MI, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen absorption and desorption often limits a material's application. For titanium, hydrogen absorption kinetics determine its suitability for tritium storage, tritium gettering, and vacuum pump applications. This study examines the absolute rate theory energy surface which molecular hydrogen gas encounters as it is absorbed into alpha-phase titanium. This results in useful new predictions for hydrogen absorption rates, desorption rates, and surface coverages on titanium. The only energy surface which is consistent with observed activation and absorption enthalpies, while predicting all absorption/desorption rate data, is found to contain a new activation barrier. Accuracy is within a factor of 3.6 for two surface preparations and temperatures between 250 and 500 °C. © 1988 The Metallurgical Society of AIME.

Abstract: The conference materials contain 41 papers dealing with amorphous magnetic materials, magnetic anisotropy studies, magnetic recording equipment, magnetic films, magnetic thermal factors, rare-earth materials, magnetostriction, magnetoelasticity, perpendicular magnetic recording, magnetooptic materials, photovoltaic power systems, magnetic materials in electric motors, Bloch line memories, and superconducting materials and films.
