Title: Operating performance of the new waste calcining facility
Affiliations: Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Company, P.O. Box 4000, Idaho Falls, ID 83403, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bingham, G.E., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Company, P.O. Box 4000, Idaho Falls, ID 83403, United States
Abstract: Reprocessing nuclear fuels at the Idaho Chemical Processing Plant (ICPP) to recover the unspent fissile material results in the generation of significant quantities of radioactive liquid wastes. Handling, treatment, and storage of these wastes are areas that have received considerable attention from the entire nuclear industry. Although no decision concerning 'permanent' disposition of these wastes has yet been reached, a new facility built by the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) at the ICPP near Idaho Falls, Idaho, is providing the capability to solidify the liquid wastes and safely store them in underground bins. This article discusses the facility and design requirements, remote requirements, and operating reasults.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR FUELS - Reprocessing; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; REMOTE CONTROL; OPERATING PERFORMANCE; WASTE CALCINING FACILITY; RADIOACTIVE WASTES; nuclear fuel reprocessing; radioactive waste storage; solidification; waste water management

Authors: Macleod M.G., Whitehead C.C., Griffin H.D., Jewitt T.R.
Title: Energy and Nitrogen Retention and Loss in Broiler Chickens Genetically Selected for Leanness and Fatness
Affiliations: AFRC Institute for Grassland and Animal Production, Poultry Department, EH25 9PS, Roslin Midlothian, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Macleod, M.G., AFRC Institute for Grassland and Animal Production, Poultry Department, EH25 9PS, Roslin Midlothian, United Kingdom; Whitehead, C.C., AFRC Institute for Grassland and Animal Production, Poultry Department, EH25 9PS, Roslin Midlothian, United Kingdom; Griffin, H.D., AFRC Institute for Grassland and Animal Production, Poultry Department, EH25 9PS, Roslin Midlothian, United Kingdom; Jewitt, T.R., AFRC Institute for Grassland and Animal Production, Poultry Department, EH25 9PS, Roslin Midlothian, United Kingdom
Abstract: 1. A breeding programme based on the assessment of the body fat content of broilers by measurement of plasma very low density lipoprotein concentration has resulted in 2 lines with significantly different body fat contents. 2. Energy and nitrogen intake and retention were measured in 63- to 70-d-old females from each line during 5-d periods of indirect chamber calorimetry. Results obtained by this technique were compared with results from a previously published growth trial incorporating carcase analysis at 49 d. 3. Body weight, metabolisable energy intake, heat production, energy retention and efficiency of energy retention did not differ significantly between the fat and lean lines. 4. The proportion of energy retained as crude protein and the efficiency of crude protein retention were significantly greater in the lean line. 5. In terms of whole-body energy and nitrogen exchanges, the essential difference between the lines was therefore in the partition of the same quantity of retained energy between fat and protein deposition. 6. The results were consistent with a higher rate of breakdown of amino acids in the fat line; because heat production did not also increase, a greater proportion of retained energy therefore became available for storage as fat. © 1988, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: nitrogen; adipose tissue; animal; article; body composition; body weight; chicken; energy metabolism; female; genetic selection; genetics; male; metabolism; Adipose Tissue; Animal; Body Composition; Body Weight; Chickens; Energy Metabolism; Female; Male; Nitrogen; Selection (Genetics)

Authors: Leenders K.L., Frackowiak R.S.J., Lees A.J.
Title: Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome: Brain energy metabolism, blood flow and fluorodopa uptake measured by positron emission tomography
Affiliations: MRC Cyclotron Unit, Department of Neurology, Hammersmith Hospital, Queen Square, London, United Kingdom; National Hospital for Nervous Diseases, Queen Square, London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Leenders, K.L., MRC Cyclotron Unit, Department of Neurology, Hammersmith Hospital, Queen Square, London, United Kingdom; Frackowiak, R.S.J., MRC Cyclotron Unit, Department of Neurology, Hammersmith Hospital, Queen Square, London, United Kingdom, National Hospital for Nervous Diseases, Queen Square, London, United Kingdom; Lees, A.J., National Hospital for Nervous Diseases, Queen Square, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Brain function was measured in 5 patients with clinically diagnosed Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome using positron emission tomography and tracers of dopamine metabolism, blood flow and oxygen metabolism. A global decrease in blood flow and oxygen utilization compared with normal values was found but the decrease was more marked in the frontal regions. The degree of impairment in oxygen utilization in the frontal region paralleled roughly the duration of the disease. Blood flow was impaired to a greater extent than oxygen utilization, resulting in raised oxygen extraction. This can partially be explained by a lower pCO2 in the patients. Alternatively it may imply involvement of brain vasculature in the pathophysiology of the disease in addition to neuronal degeneration. Striatal dopamine formation and storage, as indicated by L-(18F)fluorodopa uptake, was significantly decreased compared with control values. The severity of this decrease paralleled the degree of reduction in frontal cerebral blood flow. The results suggest that the impairment of cerebral function in Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome is determined to a large extent by brainstem pathology. © 1988 Oxford University Press.
Index Keywords: dopamine; radioisotope; brain blood flow; brain stem; clinical article; corpus striatum; fluorodopa f 18; human; oxygen consumption; positron emission tomography; priority journal; progressive ophthalmoplegia; Adult; Brain; Cerebrovascular Circulation; Dihydroxyphenylalanine; Energy Metabolism; Fluorine Radioisotopes; Human; Middle Age; Oxygen Consumption; Supranuclear Palsy, Progressive; Tomography, Emission-Computed

Title: Microwave fixation provides excellent preservation of tissue, cells and antigens for light and electron microscopy
Affiliations: Department of Pathology, Beth Israel Hospital, Harvard School of Dental Medicine, and Harvard Medical School, Boston, 02215, Massachusetts, United States; Charles A. Dana Research Institute, Beth Israel Hospital, Boston, 02215, Massachusctts, United States
Authors with affiliations: Login, G.R., Department of Pathology, Beth Israel Hospital, Harvard School of Dental Medicine, and Harvard Medical School, Boston, 02215, Massachusetts, United States, Charles A. Dana Research Institute, Beth Israel Hospital, Boston, 02215, Massachusctts, United States; Dvorak, A.M., Department of Pathology, Beth Israel Hospital, Harvard School of Dental Medicine, and Harvard Medical School, Boston, 02215, Massachusetts, United States, Charles A. Dana Research Institute, Beth Israel Hospital, Boston, 02215, Massachusctts, United States
Abstract: It was demonstrated that microwave energy used simultaneously in combination with low concentrations of glutaraldehyde (0.05%) and formaldehyde (2.0%) rapidly preserved light microscopic histology and excellent fine structural details, as well as a variety of cytoplasmic and membrane-bound antigens. Specimen blocks up to 1 cm3 can be fixed in as brief a time as 26 ms using a specially designed microwave device (ultrafast microwave fixation method). The fast microwave fixation method, using a commercially available device, was successfully used to preserve granule-bound rat mast cell chymase which was subsequently detected by a postembedding immunogold procedure. Control of the following parameters is important to the microwave fixation method: (1) specimens with one dimension less than 1 cm; (2) irradiation temperatures lower than 50°C; (3) irradiation times less than 50 s; (4) immediate replacement of the postirradiation solution with cold storage buffer; (5) fixing the specimen within 15 min after it is removed from its blood supply. © 1988 Chapman and Hall Ltd.
Index Keywords: animal cell; histochemistry; histology; microwave radiation; nonhuman; tissue preservation; ultrastructure; Animal; Antigens; Comparative Study; Female; Histological Techniques; Human; Immunoenzyme Techniques; Liver; Male; Mast Cells; Microscopy, Electron; Microwaves; Myocardium; Skin; Staining and Labeling; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.; Tissue Preservation

Authors: Hoffert M.I., Miller G., Heilweil B., Ziegler W., Kadiramangalam M.
Title: Earth-to-satellite microwave beams: Innovative approach to space power
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Applied Science, New York University, New York, NY  10003, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoffert, M.I., Department of Applied Science, New York University, New York, NY  10003, United States; Miller, G., Department of Applied Science, New York University, New York, NY  10003, United States; Heilweil, B., Department of Applied Science, New York University, New York, NY  10003, United States; Ziegler, W., Department of Applied Science, New York University, New York, NY  10003, United States; Kadiramangalam, M., Department of Applied Science, New York University, New York, NY  10003, United States
Abstract: A new space power concept incorporating earth-to-satellite microwave power beams coupled to onboard regenerative electrochemical energy storage is proposed for energizing defensive satellite constellations. The system addresses housekeeping, orbital maneuvering and burst mode power requirements, and offers an attractive alternative to the nuclear and solar space power systems currently envisioned for this application. This energy-conversion system incorporates six steps: (1) generate primary DC power at surface stations along the satellite ground-track, (2) convert to microwave (RF) frequencies, (3) transmit in a narrow beam to spacecraft using phased-array antennas which track and lock-on to satellite receivers as they pass in range during a fraction of their orbit, (4) receive the energy and convert to DC in space using lightweight and inexpensive rectennas; (5) store the energy onboard as chemical energy by electrolysis of water to oxygen and hydrogen and (6) recover free energy onboard the spacecraft during the balance of the orbit continuously or on demand as pulsed power with a high power-density fuel cell. Component and overall systems considerations of this scheme are discussed in comparison with alternatives, outstanding research problems are defined and preliminary analyses are described. These include orbital mechanics and ground tracks of satellites, accessibility of orbiters to microwave beams, transmission efficiencies, electronic and mechanical designs of the transmitter and rectenna, regenerative fuel cell energy storage, power conditioning and thermal management. The development of readily space-deployable rectennae, their supporting structures, and high specific power solid oxide monolithic fuels cells are the main pacing technologies leading to a wholly non-nuclear space power system capable of supporting all defensive satellite power requirements. © 1988 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Antenna phased arrays; Chemical oxygen demand; Earth (planet); Energy conversion; Energy storage; Free energy; Fuel storage; Microwaves; Particle beams; Rectennas; Regenerative fuel cells; Satellites; Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC); Spacecraft power supplies; Electrochemical energy storage; Electrolysis of waters; Energy conversion systems; Innovative approaches; Nuclear space power systems; Phased array antennas; Satellite constellations; Transmission efficiency; Orbits

Title: Recycling containers of liquids for human consumption
Affiliations: Gateway Foodmarkets Ltd and Sheffield City Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ridge, S.R., Gateway Foodmarkets Ltd and Sheffield City Polytechnic, United Kingdom; Cull, C., Gateway Foodmarkets Ltd and Sheffield City Polytechnic, United Kingdom
Abstract: The packaging of food is vital to ensure that the product reaches the consumer in good condition. Modern retailing methods require packaging for self-service operation. Food manufacturers use more and more packaging to protect the product during distribution and storage — costs paid for by the consumer. After consuming the food the packaging is disposed of via the refuse collection and disposal system and again the consumer pays for this cost via a charge on the rates. As the awareness of conservation grows, are there opportunities to market food packaging as being recyclable and so causing less damage to the environment? Should those manufacturers and retailers who require additional packaging be forced to pay towards the disposal costs? Should we bother with recycling any material? What materials can be recycled? If we agree that it is desirable to recycle materials, who should be responsible for initiating and promoting recycling schemes? How can recycling be made to work? These are questions which this paper has addressed. By means of a literature search and personal contact, the implementation of the EEC Directive is investigated. The energy savings associated with recycling are highlighted and recycling schemes for glass, metals and plastics have been described. We have investigated the basic advantages and disadvantages of recycling for waste collection and disposal authorities, and for retail organisations. Our conclusion is that if recycling of waste materials in the UK is to be effective then firm government action is vital, but until greater public awareness of the issues involved develop government action is unlikely. © 1988, MCB UP Limited

Title: An electric-current description of solar flares
Affiliations: Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, Alaska, United States
Authors with affiliations: Akasofu, S.-I., Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, Alaska, United States
Abstract: The presently prevailing theories of solar flares rely on the hypothetical presence of magnetic flux tubes beneath the photosphere and the two subsequent hypotheses, their emergence above the photosphere and explosive magnetic reconnection, converting magnetic energy carried by the flux tubes to solar flare energy. In this paper, we discuss solar flares from an entirely different point of view, namely in terms of power supply by a dynamo process in the photosphere. By this process, electric currents flowing along the magnetic field lines are generated and the familiar 'force-free' fields or the 'sheared' magnetic fields are produced. Upward field-aligned currents thus generated are carried by downward streaming electrons; these electrons can excite hydrogen atoms in the chromosphere, causing the optical Hα flares or 'low temperature flares'. It is thus argued that as the 'force-free' fields are being built up for the magnetic energy storage, a flare must already be in progress. © 1988 Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Authors: Bickford D.F., Congdon J.W., Oblath S.B.
Title: Corrosion of radioactive waste tanks containing washed sludge and precipitates
Affiliations: E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, Savanna River Laboratory, Aiken, SC 29808, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bickford, D.F., E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, Savanna River Laboratory, Aiken, SC 29808, United States; Congdon, J.W., E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, Savanna River Laboratory, Aiken, SC 29808, United States; Oblath, S.B., E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company, Savanna River Laboratory, Aiken, SC 29808, United States
Abstract: At the US Department of Energy's (DOE) Savannah River Plant, the corrosion of carbon steel storage tanks containing alkaline, high-level radioactive waste is controlled by specification of limits on waste composition and temperature. Laboratory tests, conducted to determine minimum corrosion inhibitor levels, indicated pitting of carbon steel near the waterline for proposed storage conditions. In situ electrochemical measurements of full-scale radioactive process demonstrations were conducted to assess the validity of laboratory tests. The in situ results are compared to those of laboratory tests, with particular regard given to simulated solution composition. Transition metal hydroxide sludge contains strong passivating species for carbon steel. Washed precipitate contains organic species that lower solution pH and tend to reduce passivating films, requiring higher inhibitor concentrations than the 0.01 M nitrite required for reactor fuel reprocessing wastes.At the US Department of Energy's (DOE) Savannah River Plant, the corrosion of carbon steel storage tanks containing alkaline high-level radioactive waste is controlled by limits on waste composition and temperature. Laboratory tests to determine minimum corrosion inhibitor levels indicated pitting of carbon steel near the waterline for proposed storage conditions. In situ electrochemical measurements of full-scale radioactive process demonstrations were conducted to assess the validity of laboratory tests. Transition metal hydroxide sludge contains strong passivating species for carbon steel. Washed precipitate contains organic species that lower solution pH and tend to reduce passivating films, requiring higher inhibitor concentrations than the 0. 01 M nitrite required for reactor fuel reprocessing wastes.

Title: THERMAL STORAGE WITH EMS CONTROL.
Authors with affiliations: Herro, Michael; Roach, Robert
Abstract: An in-house application of ice thermal storage controlled by a centralized energy management system is described in detail. The combined system is installed and operating in the newly remodeled Trane Technology Center in La Crosse, Wisconsin, near the east bank of the Mississippi River. This northern location has an average of 7,540 heating degree days and 683 cooling degree days. For this region, the design dry-bulb cooling temperature is 91 F and wet-bulb is 75 F. An energy management system (EMS) equipped with equation processing is used to control and monitor the thermal storage system components. Equation processing is a user definable control program within the software of the EMS. The routines are written in a language similar to elementary Fortran statements.
Index Keywords: ENERGY MANAGEMENT - Computer Applications; ICE; DIRECT DIGITAL CONTROL (DDC); ICE TANK SYSTEM; ICE THERMAL STORAGE; PARTIAL STORAGE SYSTEM; TECHNOLOGY CENTER; RESEARCH LABORATORIES

Title: EFFECTS OF SUBCOOLING ON MELTING ON A VERTICAL WALL.
Affiliations: Aoyama Gakuin Univ, Aoyama Gakuin Univ
Authors with affiliations: Okada, Masashi, Aoyama Gakuin Univ, Aoyama Gakuin Univ; Koyanagi, Yutaka, Aoyama Gakuin Univ, Aoyama Gakuin Univ
Abstract: One of the vertical boundaries of a phase change material (PCM) which was initially subcooled below its fusion temperature in a rectangular enclosure was subjected to a step-wise temperature increase. Other boundaries were insulated. The melting process with natural convection in the time-dependent melt region and with heat conduction in the solid region was analyzed by both two-dimensional finite-difference method and one-dimensional approximate analysis in which the melting front was in parallel with the heated wall. The analytical results of the shape of the melting front and the temperature distribution in the PCM were compared with the results of the experiments which were carried out by using n-octadecane as a PCM.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; PHASE CHANGE MATERIAL; SOLIDIFICATION; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS.
Affiliations: Alsthom Intermagnetics SA, Fr, Alsthom Intermagnetics SA, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Grunblatt, G., Alsthom Intermagnetics SA, Fr, Alsthom Intermagnetics SA, Fr; Phillips, D., Alsthom Intermagnetics SA, Fr, Alsthom Intermagnetics SA, Fr
Abstract: Experience gained in the maturing medical imaging industry has demonstrated that superconducting magnets, even at liquid helium temperatures, can today be regarded as industrial pieces of electrical machinery. It is pointed out that advances in magnetic stability, cryogenic engineering and refrigeration technology make it feasible for superconductivity to be considered seriously for other electrical engineering applications such as energy storage, levitation and magnetic separation of ores and minerals. Whereas the impact of the new high temperature superconductors on electrical engineering can at present only be imagined, it is argued that ambient temperature superconducting electrical machinery will not be generally available for at least another decade.
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTIVITY; EARLY SUPERCONDUCTORS; ROOM TEMPERATURE; TYPE-II SUPERCONDUCTORS; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS

Title: On pinch technology based procedures for the design of batch processes
Affiliations: Linnhoff March, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Obeng, E.D.A., Linnhoff March, United Kingdom; Ashton, G.J., Linnhoff March, United Kingdom
Abstract: Batch Plant design makes use of a wide range of procedures to achieve good performance in flexibility, yields, capital cost, capacity, energy, etc. Energy is often one of the less significant factors. However, two recent papers have presented procedures which make use of pinch technology - i.e. energy-based techniques in batch plant. One paper uses an analysis of energy flows as a tool for debottlenecking and reducing plant-wide operating costs. It develops energy performance targets, subject to scheduling which provide opportunities for general cost reduction. The second paper also sets energy performance targets but restricts use of the targets to heat recovery. An analytical procedure is used to quantify the minimum energy required by a batch plant using direct heat transfer and energy storage within a given overall schedule. Unfortunately the proposed energy storage 'targets' are not rigorous and can lead to missed design opportunities. This severely limits the practical usefulness of the procedure. The present paper discusses both previous publications in depth and attempts to clarify what there is by way of workable techniques. It concludes that future developments of energy based analysis for batch plant integration should not consider energy in isolation. Cost structure and the interaction between capital, energy, scheduling, yields, and other aspects, mean that it is necessary to address the wider problem in context.
Index Keywords: Chemical Plants--Design; Energy Conservation; Batch Plant Design; Batch Plant Integration; Energy Based Analysis; Energy Performance; Overall Plant Bottleneck; Pinch Technology; Chemical Engineering

Authors: Buckley L.P., Philipose K.E., Torok J.
Title: Engineered barriers and their influence on source behaviour
Source title: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, AECL (Report)
Affiliations: Chalk River Nuclear Lab, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Buckley, L.P., Chalk River Nuclear Lab, Canada; Philipose, K.E., Chalk River Nuclear Lab, Canada; Torok, J., Chalk River Nuclear Lab, Canada
Abstract: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited has an on-going comprehensive program in low level waste management. It involves the characterization, processing and storage of low and intermediate level waste streams. Transition from storage to disposal of low level waste is currently being pursued. Plans are underway for the construction of IRUS Intrusion Resistant Underground Structure, a concrete facility with a permeable bottom placed underground in a sand aquifer, but above the water table. Engineered barriers, including the waste form, containers, buffer and backfill materials and the concrete vault and roof are being evaluated as an integral system to minimize radionuclide release. The research and development programs are establishing the confidence limits for performance so that even if there are potential failures from one or more of the barriers, the radiological consequences to the public of escaping radionuclides from the waste source placed within the repository will be acceptable.
Index Keywords: Concrete Construction; Industrial Wastes--Radioactive Materials; Backfills; Buffers; Engineered Barriers; Intrusion Resistant Underground Structure; IRUS Facility; Radioactive Wastes

Title: Parallel discharge-gap switching in an Arkad'ev-Marks generator
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Rukin, S.N., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: A triggering circuit was tested for three-electrode discharge gaps employing field distortion in an Arkad'ev-Marks generator, where the control electrodes are connected together by resistors and semiconductor diodes. Parameter optimization provided for parallel gap connection, where the triggering time is reduced by a factor 2-3 by comparison with series connection. The triggering time for a 10-stage generator working at 500 kV with stored energy up to 7 kJ is 30 plus or minus 2 nanoseconds for an undervoltage coefficient of 0.9. The triggering time for one gap under state conditions is 23 plus or minus 2 nanoseconds.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Spark Gaps - Optimization; Electrodes; Electronic Circuits, Switching; Electronic Circuits, Trigger; Arkad'ev-Marks Generators; Semiconductor Diodes; Three-Electrode Field-Distortion Gaps; Pulse Generators

Authors: Vasil'ev V.V., Lukonin E.I., Furman E.G.
Title: Fast pulsed system for charging the shaping lines of an accelerator
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnical Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Vasil'ev, V.V., Tomsk Polytechnical Inst, Russian Federation; Lukonin, E.I., Tomsk Polytechnical Inst, Russian Federation; Furman, E.G., Tomsk Polytechnical Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: A circuit is described for charging the shaping lines of an accelerator through a step-up pulse transformer from an energy storage unit. The circuit has the feature that the voltage switching the capacitor is unipolar, which makes it possible to use the capacitor as part of the storage unit. The circuit is used for charging the shaping lines of a linear induction accelerator. The charging voltage of the lines equals up to 60 kV; the capacitance of the lines is 0.4 microF; the frequency of the charging cycles equals up to 100 Hz; and the degree of voltage regulation is 60-100%
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Transformers, Pulse; Electronic Circuits, Power Supply; Pulse Generators; Voltage Regulators; Beam Shaping Lines; Charging Chokes; Voltage Stabilizing Circuits; Accelerators, Linear

Title: Switching a capacitor bank at stored energies up to 100kJ
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Tomsk Polytechnical Inst, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kapishnikov, N.K., Tomsk Polytechnical Inst, Russian Federation; Muratov, V.M., Tomsk Polytechnical Inst, Russian Federation
Abstract: Two types of high-current switches are described for operating up to 5 kV: a multi-channel spark gap with local breakdown initiators and a system consisting of several parallel singlechannel trigatron gaps. Single-channel switching in a multichannel device showed that there was a substantial contribution to reducing the erosion from the main gap configuration. The working life can be extended to over 1000 operations. The capacitor bank containing about 100 kJ stored energy can best be switched with a multichannel device having a simple design. The gap has been switched over 300 times with a mean energy of about 80 kJ; uncontrolled breakdown did not occur.
Index Keywords: Electric Breakdown; Electric Spark Gaps - Erosion; Electric Switches - Service Life; Energy Storage; Breakdown Initiators; High-Current Switches; Multi-Channel Spark Gaps; Parallel Single-Channel Trigatron Gaps; Capacitors

Authors: Kovsharov N.F., Luchinskii A.V., Mesyats G.A., Ratakhin N.A., Sorokin S.A., Fedushchak V.F.
Title: Snop-3 pulse generator
Source title: Instruments and experimental techniques New York
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kovsharov, N.F., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Luchinskii, A.V., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Mesyats, G.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Ratakhin, N.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Sorokin, S.A., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Fedushchak, V.F., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: The Snop-3 pulse generator provides a current rise time of approximately 4 to 103 A/sec in an inductive lead (30 nH) with a current amplitude of up to 2 MA. The generator has a power equal to or greater than TW for loads of the multiwire liner type. The generator consists of primary energy storage (capacitor bank), a pulse transformer, intermediate storage, a shaping line, and a transmission line. Energy is transmitted sequentially from low-frequency to high-frequency resonant LC circuits in order to increase the power. Commutation between the intermediate storage and the shaping line is performed with a water-filled discharger in both a controlled and uncontrolled fashion. Commutation between the shaping and transmission lines is not controlled.
Index Keywords: Capacitors - Energy Storage; Electric Insulation; Electric Transformers, Pulse; Electrodes; Electronic Circuits, Pulse Shaping; Electronic Circuits, Switching; Current Transducers; Pulse Rise Time; Shaping Lines; Snop-3 Pulse Generator; Voltage Transducers; Water-Filled Dischargers; Pulse Generators

Title: Biochemical composition of the blue crab Callinectes sapidus exposed to the water-soluble fraction of crude oil
Affiliations: Department of Zoology and Physiology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, 70803, Louisiana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, S.Y., Department of Zoology and Physiology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, 70803, Louisiana, United States; Stickle, W.B., Department of Zoology and Physiology, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, 70803, Louisiana, United States
Abstract: The biochemical composition of juvenile blue crabs, Callinectes sapidus, exposed to sublethal concentrations of the water-soluble fraction of South Louisiana crude oil (0 to 2 504 ppb) for 21 d were examined. Although growth took place in all crabs, tissue content varied inversely with exposure concentration while percentage tissue water varied directly with exposure concentration. Total protein, lipid and RNA content of crabs exposed to crude oil were significantly less than that of control crabs by Day 21. DNA content was not significantly different from that of control crabs, suggesting that the difference in tissue content was due to differences in cell volume and not cell number. There were no consistent differences in the concentration of the major biochemical components, indicating that the relative contribution of each of the components remained stable during the period of sublethal stress. Ratios of RNA:DNA and protein:DNA decreased in exposed crabs and were positively correlated with scope for growth and observed growth. The ratios may be useful as indirect indicators of physiological condition. Analysis of lipid classes indicated that structural lipids in stressed crabs were less affected than were lipids used for energy storage. The changes in biochemical composition suggest that the pattern of energy utilization was altered in crabs exposed to crude oil. Growth in size without comparable growth in tissue resulted in decreased tissue content. Available energy was used for growth, with little being stored in lipid reserves. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: petroleum; animal experiment; arthropod; body burden; callinectes sapidus; methodology; nonhuman; toxicity testing

Authors: Vermaak W.J.H., Barnard H.C., Van Dalen E.M.S.P., Potgieter G.M., Van Jaarsveld H., Myburgh S.J.S.
Title: Compartmentalization of pyridoxal-5′-phosphate during the acute phase of myocardial infarction
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University of the Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Vermaak, W.J.H., Department of Chemical Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University of the Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa; Barnard, H.C., Department of Chemical Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University of the Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa; Van Dalen, E.M.S.P., Department of Chemical Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University of the Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa; Potgieter, G.M., Department of Chemical Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University of the Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa; Van Jaarsveld, H., Department of Chemical Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University of the Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa; Myburgh, S.J.S., Department of Chemical Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University of the Orange Free State, Bloemfontein, South Africa
Abstract: Vitamin B6 nutritional status is assessed by measuring the plasma concentration of one of its vitamers, pyridoxal-phosphate (PLP). Several conditions, e.g., myocardial infarction (MI), can disturb the dynamic equilibrium between the different vitamers resulting in transiently low plasma PLP levels. An important question is whether these low plasma PLP levels observed during MI represent a transient state of deficiency and what the possible clinical consequences of such a fall in plasma PLP could be. Since the main metabolic function of PLP is to act as an intracellular coenzyme, it was decided to monitor the changes not only of PLP but also of PL (transport form of vitamin B6) in both the plasma and red blood cells (RBCs) in patients with myocardial infarctions (MI): 16 patients with proven MI were investigated measuring the aforementioned parameters at regular intervals. It was found that the approximately 40% fall in plasma PLP levels was accompanied by an equivalent increase in RBC PLP levels. Subsequently plasma PLP concentrations returned to normal but RBC PLP values were maintained at the newly elevated steady state (without any vitamin supplementation). Since membranes are impermeable to PLP, the only way in which PLP could have been redistributed to the intracellular compartment was through hydrolysis to PL and rephosphorylation once inside the RBCs. This compartmentalization could be an important adaptive response since it has been shown that PLP reduces O2 affinity of deoxygenated hemoglobin, thereby facilitating O2 delivery to the tissues. In addition it would also enhance the proposed storage function of RBCs for PLP and PL which is said to be an important source for muscle vitamin B6 which again is essential for energy production by the muscle cells during ischemia. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Peterson H.R., Rothschild M., Weinberg C.R., Fell R.D., McLeish K.R., Pfeifer M.A.
Title: Body Fat and the Activity of the Autonomic Nervous System
Affiliations: Departments of Medicine and Exercise Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Louisville, Louisville, Ky., United States
Authors with affiliations: Peterson, H.R., Departments of Medicine and Exercise Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Louisville, Louisville, Ky., United States; Rothschild, M., Departments of Medicine and Exercise Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Louisville, Louisville, Ky., United States; Weinberg, C.R., Departments of Medicine and Exercise Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Louisville, Louisville, Ky., United States; Fell, R.D., Departments of Medicine and Exercise Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Louisville, Louisville, Ky., United States; McLeish, K.R., Departments of Medicine and Exercise Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Louisville, Louisville, Ky., United States; Pfeifer, M.A., Departments of Medicine and Exercise Physiology, School of Medicine, University of Louisville, Louisville, Ky., United States
Abstract: The cause of most cases of human obesity is unknown. Specific alterations in the activity of the autonomic nervous system may mediate and perhaps cause obesity in animal models. We therefore looked for alterations in autonomic activity in human obesity. Fifty-six healthy men with various percentages of body fat underwent autonomic testing while at rest. Significant correlations were found between the percentage of body fat and the variation in the R–R interval after beta-adrenergic blockade (r = -0.30, P<0.03), the heart rate (r = 0.30, P<0.03), the plasma norepinephrine concentration (r = -0.30, P<0.05), the plasma epinephrine concentration (r = -0.49, P<0.001), and the pupillary latency period (r = 0.39, P<0.01). Each of these variables reflects the activity of the sympathetic nervous system or parasympathetic nervous system or both. Depressions in sympathetic and parasympathetic activity were significantly but weakly associated with increasing percentages of body fat. These associations indicate that in obese persons, autonomic changes, though not necessarily causal, involve several organ systems. We suggest that autonomic alterations are important in human obesity, as they are in animal obesity. A disordered homeostatic mechanism may promote excessive storage of energy by decreasing sympathetic activity, while defending against weight gain by decreasing parasympathetic activity. The use of autonomic profiles holds promise for classifying human obesity and identifying obese patients at increased risk for various disorders. (N Engl J Med 1988; 318: 1077–83.) © 1988, Massachusetts Medical Society. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Three Dimension Nuclear Hartree-Fock calculations have been performed for isotopes of Osmium, Mercury, and Tungsten. Authors: Siegmund O.H.W., Everman E., Vallerga J.V., Lampton M.
Title: Extreme Ultraviolet Quantum Efficiency of Opaque Alkali Halide Photocathodes on Microchannel Plates
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Siegmund, O.H.W., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States; Everman, E., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States; Vallerga, J.V., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States; Lampton, M., Space Sciences Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States
Abstract: In recent years there has been considerable interest in the use of optically opaque layers of alkali halides on microchannel plates (MCP’s) to improve quantum detection efficiency (QDE). However, only a few materials have been studied, in particular CsI and MgF2 in the soft X-ray regime (< 200Å). We present comprehensive measurements of the quantum detec-tion efficiency for a number of materials, CsI, KBr, KC1, and MgF2, over a wide wavelength range (44Å to ˜1800Å). These results show that high (>40%) quantum detection efficiency may be achieved for many materials, at certain wavelength regions in the extreme ultraviolet (EUV). We also observe structure in the wavelength dependence of the quantum detection efficiency that is directly related to the valence band to conduction band gap energy, and the onset of atomic-like resonant transitions. We show that a simple photocathode model allows interpretation of these features, and the variation of the quantum detection efficiency as a function of illumination angle. The structure of photocathode layers has been examined with an electron microscope, and shows that typical cathodes are granular. We also demonstrate that the cathode layer structure changes when degradation of the QDE occurs for hygroscopic materials. © 1988 SPIE.

Title: Fluoroptic™ Velocity Sensor
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Luxtron Coiporation, 1060 Terra Bella Avenue, Mountain View, CA, 94043, United States; Alamo Instruments, P.O. Box 848, Alamo, CA, 94507, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ikeda, M.H., Luxtron Coiporation, 1060 Terra Bella Avenue, Mountain View, CA, 94043, United States, Alamo Instruments, P.O. Box 848, Alamo, CA, 94507, United States; Sun, M.H., Luxtron Coiporation, 1060 Terra Bella Avenue, Mountain View, CA, 94043, United States
Abstract: A fiber optic velocity sensor was developed based on optical heating of a fluoroptic™ temperature sensor. Infrared radiation is pumped into the temperature sensor, thereby raising its equilibrium temperature. When the heated sensor is placed in thermal contact with a flowing fluid, heat is carried away by the fluid, lowering the sensor temperature. This energy loss is correlated to local flow rate or velocity. This approach to flow measurement is the optical analogy of the hot wire/hot film anemometer. The velocity probe consists of a single multimode optical fiber with temperature sensitive phosphor and heat absorber material attached to the tip. A short pulse of blue excitation light pumped into the fiber causes the phosphor to fluoresce. After the exitation has terminated, the exponential decay time of the fluorescent radiation intensity is measured and correlated with temperature. The optical heating energy is provided by a continuous wave (CW) infrared laser diode. The infrared light pumped into the fiber impinges on the absorber material, heating the phosphor sensor. The temperature measurement is utilized in a feedback control loop to modulate the CW laser diode. The sensor temperature is maintained constant utilizing pulse width modulation of laser diode drive current. The resulting duty cycle (laser input energy) is correlated to fluid flow velocity. Data are presented for volumetric flow rates in the range of 0 to 10 liters/minute in a 1.9 cm diameter tube showing very promising results. © 1988 SPIE.

Title: ELECTROMAGNETIC SUSPENSION AND LEVITATION TECHNIQUES.
Source title: Proceedings of The Royal Society of London, Series A: Mathematical and Physical Sciences

Authors with affiliations: Jayawant, B.V., Sch of Engineering & Applied, Sciences, Brighton, Engl, Sch of Engineering & Applied Sciences, Brighton, Engl
Abstract: Electromagnetic suspension and levitation, following on from aircushion vehicles, such as the Tracked Hovercraft and the Aerotrain, has been the focus of attention and research for passenger-carrying vehicles since the 1970s. Two major demonstration systems are now in operation: one in Germany and one in Japan. The applications now include high-speed machine tool spindles, ultra-centrifuges, turbo-alternators, corrosive-liquid pumps, gas compressors and high-vacuum pumps, fly wheels for energy storage, handling components for protective coating and weighing balances. New developments in superconducting materials have also aroused fresh interest in the electrodynamic levitation schemes.

Box 19380, (817), Arlington, TX, 76019, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the need for and the requirements of high voltage insulation systems that operate in the space environment. The space environment is characterized and the environmental limitations of common earth insulation systems are discussed. Several alternative high voltage insulation systems are presented and the results of space high voltage experiments discussed. A high voltage space system design approach is presented based on contained field designs using controlled vacuum insulation. The limitation of alternate insulation systems in long-lived space high voltage power systems will require the development of alternate methods of capacitive energy storage at high energy densities. © 1988, SPIE.

Title: Fast risetime impulse voltage generation facility at the university of buffalo
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, State University of New York at Buffalo, Bonner Hall, Buffalo, NY, 14260, United States; Hughes Aircraft Company, CA, United States

Abstract: An experimental facility at the new campus of the University of Buffalo, which is capable of generating impulse voltages up to 260 kV at 170 J, is described in this paper. The values of circuit components can he chosen and arranged to provide varying risetimes and pulsewidths of the output transient voltage. Depending on the circuit components, an output voltage pulse with risetime from 50 ns to 35 us and pulsewidth from 40 us to 200 us can be obtained. These parameters, which cover a wide range of voltage surges, allow actual high voltage simulation of insulating materials, used in high voltage energy storage and transport devices, being stressed under impulse voltages in a laboratory environment. This paper describes the circuitry and damping unit, the double isolated screen room, the sealtite tubings and cable connections that were all installed in this new facility to make the impulse generator operational in a noise-free and safe laboratory environment. Other facilities which can perform a variety of material characterization tests are also described. © 1988 SPIE.

Authors: Allred D.B., Benson J.D., Cohen H.A.
Title: SPEAR: Rocket flights to investigate the innovative design of high power space systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Defense Nuclear Agency, 6801 Telegraph Road, Alexandria, VA  22310, United States; Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, Pentagon, Washington, DC  20301, United States; W. J. Schafer Associates, Inc., 1901 N. Fort Myer Drive, Arlington, VA  22209, United States
Authors with affiliations: Allred, D.B., Defense Nuclear Agency, 6801 Telegraph Road, Alexandria, VA  22310, United States; Benson, J.D., Strategic Defense Initiative Organization, Pentagon, Washington, DC  20301, United States; Cohen, H.A., W. J. Schafer Associates, Inc., 1901 N. Fort Myer Drive, Arlington, VA  22209, United States
Abstract: The SPEAR I and SPEAR II sounding rocket flights, will carry the highest exposed voltage systems yet flown in space. SPEAR I was launched December 13, 1987, to investigate the electrical current drain to highly charged objects in the ionosphere. SPEAR I results, augmented with laboratory and theoretical studies, will be used to determine the ambient conditions that would cause discharging and arcing of high power systems in space. These results will then be used for the design, test and flight of high power systems. SPEAR II, scheduled for launch in early 1989, will involve the innovative operations of high voltage and high current systems in the ionosphere. These flight programs utilize theoretical research efforts of several groups, as well as vacuum and plasma chamber testing of high power systems. Innovative aspects will include the exposure of uninsulated transmission and pulse forming systems to the ambient plasma, the charging and use of high energy storage systems during flight, and the use of high voltage and high current loads not previously used in space. Unique problems include outgassing, mitigation of electrical breakdown, loading, and the use of innovative spacecraft integration techniques for commands and telemetry to high voltage systems. © 1988 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Title: Novel scheme for space power generation and energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Abstract: A self-contained, disposable cartridge serves both as prime power source and electrical energy store. The energy initially stored in chemical form is transformed into kinetic form and stored in a hydromagnetic capacitor. The capacitor discharges through a closing switch into the electrical input of the weapon system. There are no structural rotating parts and no effluent. A comparative assessment with existing systems shows that the cartridge has the potential for increasing the achievable energy density by two orders of magnitude and the power density by four orders of magnitude. © 1988 SPIE.

Title: Charge state evolution in an ion trap irradiated by VUV synchrotron radiation
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meron, M., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Johnson, B.M., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Jones, K.W., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Church, D.A., Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: The energies of photons obtainable from the VUV ring at the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS) are ideally suited for high-efficiency ionization of atomic-shell electrons. Given the high fluxes of photons available on a wiggler beam line, multiple photoionization in an ion trap can be easily achieved within times short compared to typical ion storage times in the trap. Measurements of the time evolution of ion population in such a trap can yield ionic photoionization cross sections and charge-exchange interaction rates for ion-atom or ion-ion collisions. The various processes governing this time evolution are discussed and model calculations illustrating the relative importance of these processes under different conditions are presented. © 1988.

Title: Thermal Energy Storage by Agitated Capsules of Phase Change Material. 1. Pilot Scale Experiments
Affiliations: Yasar Holding Company, Sehit Fethi Bey Caddesi No. 120, Alsancak 35210, Izmir, Turkey., Turkey; Department of Chemical Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, B.C., Canada V6T 1W5, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sozen, Z.Z., Yasar Holding Company, Sehit Fethi Bey Caddesi No. 120, Alsancak 35210, Izmir, Turkey., Turkey; Grace, J.R., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, B.C., Canada V6T 1W5, Canada; Finder, K.L., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, B.C., Canada V6T 1W5, Canada
Abstract: Segregation due to incongruent melting has severely limited application of Glauber's salt as a phase change energy storage material. A 96% Glauber's salt/4% borax mixture was encapsulated in 25-mm-diameter hollow spheres and agitated in a liquid fluidized bed of diameter 0.34 m. The heat storage efficiency was improved by increasing the superficial water velocity and by decreasing the cooling rate. Heating rate had little effect. Fluidization provided enhanced heat transfer to or from the storage medium and resulted in a steady-state heat storage efficiency of about 60% after repeated heating and cooling cycles. The heat storage efficiency decreased to 38% of the theoretical capacity in only seven cycles under fixed bed conditions, but most of the original capacity was recovered within three cycles when these capsules were refluidized. © 1988, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Minten J., Flameng W., Dyszkiewicz W.
Title: Optimal storage temperature and benefit of hypothermic cardioplegic arrest for long-term preservation of donor hearts: a study in the dog
Affiliations: Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, K. U. Leuven, Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, Leuven, B-3000, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Minten, J., Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, K. U. Leuven, Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, Leuven, B-3000, Belgium; Flameng, W., Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, K. U. Leuven, Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, Leuven, B-3000, Belgium; Dyszkiewicz, W., Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, K. U. Leuven, Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, Leuven, B-3000, Belgium
Abstract: Currently, for practical clinical purposes, the preservation of donor hearts is limited to about 4 h. Transplantation must be finished within this period to assure complete functional recovery upon reperfusion. From the clinical setting it is well known that hypothermia results in a better myocardial preservation during ischemia. During ischemia, rapid catabolism of high-energy phosphates (e.g., ATP and creatine phosphate) occurs. The purpose of this study was to investigate the influence of temperature during a 24-h preservation period on the rate of catabolism of ATP and on the rate of accumulation of breakdown products (ADP, AMP, adenosine, inosine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine). For this purpose, hearts were excised and stored for 24 h at 0.5°, 12°, or 18 °C. In addition, the effect of initial cardioplegic arrest was compared with simple normothermic excision of the heart followed by 24 h in cold storage. It was found that the higher the storage temperature, the higher the rate of catabolism of high-energy phosphates and, hence, after 24 h, the lower the final ATP level and the higher the level of breakdown products, mainly nucleosides. It was also found that the initial cardioplegic arrest strongly benefits the preservation of high-energy phosphates as a result of the ATP-sparing effect. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Cardioplegia; Donor hearts; High-energy phosphates; Hypothermia; Preservation

Abstract: A method has been developed for measuring electrical conductivity in bulk samples of glassy semiconductors, based on the procedure described by Valdes, which is used to determine the conductivity of the compositions CU0.05As0.50Te0.45 and Cu0.15As0.40Te0.45. These experimental results are justified by the structural models corresponding to each of the compositions. The estimates of the number of bonds of each of the possible types, as well as their ionization energies, are used for this purpose. This analysis is preceded by the description of an electrical conduction model for this type of semiconductor material. Finally, the results obtained in the study of the properties of electrical switching are given. © 1988 Chapman and Hall Ltd.

Title: PROTOTYPE ACOUSTIC SUBSEA WELL CONTROL INSTALLED.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A research and development project named Subsea Wells Acoustic Control System (SWACS) has been developed. The system can control and monitor up to 15 wells in water depths up to 1,000 m. No umbilicals to the surface are required, either for the electric or hydraulic lines. The system relies on a lithium battery for long-term energy storage and on acoustic telemetry for signal transmission. It also features low power consumption electronics with intrinsic well safety procedures and closed loop hydraulics. The control module can be installed without guidelines, with dedicated positioning, soft landing and orientation systems. It also features remotely operated subsea electrical and hydraulic connectors.

Authors: Bowers James D., McMann Fred C.
Title: EXPERIENCE WITH REGENERATIVE BURNERS IN INCREASING GLASS MELTER EFFICIENCY.
Affiliations: North American Manufacturing Co,, Cleveland, OH, USA, North American Manufacturing Co, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bowers, James D., North American Manufacturing Co,, Cleveland, OH, USA, North American Manufacturing Co, Cleveland, OH, USA; McMann, Fred C., North American Manufacturing Co,, Cleveland, OH, USA, North American Manufacturing Co, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: A glass melting furnace with a new heat reclamation system in operation for 18 months has achieved gas consumption reduction of 54%, while increasing production by 11%. Energy saving represents 58% fuel reduction per ton of glass produced. The existing cold air combustion system was replaced with compact regenerative burners (TwinBed developed by North American Manufacturing Co. ). These burners recover heat based on a concept similar to old style regenerators; but they are much smaller, cycles are much shorter, and long insulated ducts are not required. The heat storage bed material has surface area per unit volume several hundred times greater than a traditional regenerator's massive checkerwork.

Title: Thermal energy storage by agitated capsules of phase change material. 2. Causes of efficiency loss
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, B.C., V6T 1W5, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sozen, Z.Z., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, B.C., V6T 1W5, Canada; Grace, J.R., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, B.C., V6T 1W5, Canada; Pinder, K.L., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, B.C., V6T 1W5, Canada
Abstract: In an effort to further improve the heat storage efficiency and to determine which factors contribute most to losses in efficiency, capsules were tested in a rotating tube and in a rotating drum at different speeds. Full capsule rotation around a horizontal axis improved the storage efficiency over the efficiencies achieved in part 1. Impacts resulting from motion in the drum gave small additional improvements in the efficiencies over those realized in the rotating tube, with a maximum storage efficiency of 83% for a stoichiometric Glauber's salt mixture with 4% borax. At high rotation speeds, centrifugal forces had a negative effect. Heat storage efficiencies increased with addition of excess Na2SO4 and also with excess H2O compared to eutectic salt mixtures. On a storage per unit volume basis, 47-53% by weight Na2SO4 was found to be the optimum concentration, the corresponding optimum on a per unit mass basis being 44-47% by weight Na2SO4. Segregation was found to account for less than half of the loss in heat storage capacity, the remainder being caused by subcooling and microencapsulation. Strong agitation and the presence of borax reduced the thermal efficiency loss due to subcooling. © 1988, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS - Encapsulation; SODIUM COMPOUNDS - Concentration; AGITATED CAPSULES; BORAX; EFFICIENCY LOSS; GLAUBER'S SALT MIXTURE; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; Energy storage

Authors: Kohrs M., Strobel S., Siewert W.H.
Title: STOCK PREPARATION ENERGY-SAVING MEASURES PRODUCE RAPID PAYBACK. PUMPS AND REFINERS ARE THE LARGEST ENERGY CONSUMERS IN A TYPICAL PAPER MILL: OPERATING AT THE HIGHEST EFFICIENCIES IS IMPERATIVE.
Affiliations: Sulzer Escher Wyss GmbH, Ravensburg, West Ger, Sulzer Escher Wyss GmbH, Ravensburg, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Kohrs, M., Sulzer Escher Wyss GmbH, Ravensburg, West Ger, Sulzer Escher Wyss GmbH, Ravensburg, West Ger; Strobel, S., Sulzer Escher Wyss GmbH, Ravensburg, West Ger, Sulzer Escher Wyss GmbH, Ravensburg, West Ger; Siewert, W.H., Sulzer Escher Wyss GmbH, Ravensburg, West Ger, Sulzer Escher Wyss GmbH, Ravensburg, West Ger
Abstract: The article discusses energy savings potentials in pulping; cleaning and screening; fractionation; refining; storage and mixing; wastepaper washing and pumps. Many of the measures described require considerable investments, while others can be adopted at no significant expense. These improvements are, however, often the result of detailed engineering studies. By integrating the three aspects of technological requirements, energy-saving measures, and operational reliability and flexibility an optimum plant design concept will result. In many cases, simple measures can bring considerable savings without high investments.
Index Keywords: PAPERMAKING MACHINERY - Efficiency; PULP MANUFACTURE - Energy Utilization; ENERGY SAVING MEASURES; OPERATIONAL FLEXIBILITY; STOCK PREPARATION; PAPER AND PULP MILLS

Authors: Gorodyskii A.V., Zhuravleva V.N., Karpov I.I., Kolbasov G.Ya., Pleskov Yu.V., Kharkats Yu.I.
Title: Installation for photoelectrochemical conversion of solar energy and energy storage
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Gorodyskii, A.V., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Zhuravleva, V.N., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Karpov, I.I., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Kolbasov, G.Ya., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Pleskov, Yu.V., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation; Kharkats, Yu.I., Acad of Sciences of the USSR, Russian Federation
Abstract: An electrochemical laboratory type installation for solar energy conversion with energy storage in the form of hydrogen which consists of a photoelectrochemical solar battery of the regeneration type and an electrolyzer with a solid polymer electrolyte is described. The solar battery and the electrolyzer were mutually combined to achieve maximum efficiency in transforming the electrical energy produced by the solar battery into chemical energy of hydrogen.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions - Photochemical Reactions; Energy Storage; Hydrogen; Solar Cells; Chemical Energy; Electrolyzers; Photoelectrochemical Reactions; Solar Energy Conversion; Solar Energy

Authors: Uesaka Mitsuru, Hoshi Yuichi, Kuroki Shinichiro, Honzawa Shigeru
Title: Mechanical system of revolver type multi-pole wiggler for Institute for Solid State Physics, The University of Tokyo
Affiliations: IHI, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Uesaka, Mitsuru, IHI, Japan; Hoshi, Yuichi, IHI, Japan; Kuroki, Shinichiro, IHI, Japan; Honzawa, Shigeru, IHI, Japan
Abstract: The wiggler is a device to generate radiant light (wavelength: 10 to 103 angstrom) with an intensity of about two-order higher than ordinary synchrotron orbital radiation (SOR), by inserting it into the electron storage ring of the Photon Factory in the National Laboratory for High Energy Physics. The mechanical systems of the wiggler was required to have a positioning precision of 0.01 mm (degree), and this specification was met.
Index Keywords: Electrons--Magnetic Field Effects; Electron Beams; Radiant Light Generator; Revolver Type Multi-Pole Wiggler; Wigglers; Light

Title: Determination of the beam energy of an electron storage ring by using calibrated energy dispersive Si(Li)-detectors
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, D1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tegeler, E., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, D1000 Berlin 10, Germany; Ulm, G., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Institut Berlin, Abbestrasse 2-12, D1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Abstract: The spectral photon flux of the synchrotron radiation of the storage ring BESSY was measured with calibrated energy dispersive photon counters at photon energies E around 20Ec. From these data the characteristic photon energy Ec was determined with a uncertainty of 0.4% and the electron energy W was calculated from Ec and the magnetic induction for storage ring optics with nominal beam energy of W = 337, 756 and 854 MeV. For the high electron energies the resulting electron energy agrees with W derived from the resonant spin depolarization method, which cannot be used at W = 337 MeV. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, ELECTRON RING - Storage Rings; RADIATION DETECTORS; SEMICONDUCTING SILICON; STORAGE RING BESSY; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: Photon energy tunability of the advanced photon source undulators
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Viccaro, P.J., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Shenoy, G.K., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Abstract: At a fixed storage ring energy, the energy of the harmonics of an undulator can be shifted or "tuned" by changing the magnet gap of the device. The possible photon energy interval spanned in this way depends on the undulator period, minimum closed gap, minimum acceptable photon intensity and storage ring energy. The minimum magnet gap depends directly on the stay-clear particle beam aperture required for storage ring operation. The tunability of undulators planned for the Advanced Photon Source with first harmonic photon energies in the range of 5-20 keV is discussed. The results of an analysis used to optimize the APS ring energy is presented and tunability contours and K-values are given for two typical classes of devices. © 1988.
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC DEVICES; PHOTONS; ADVANCED PHOTON SOURCE; UNDULATORS; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: An overview of the advanced photon source
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Materials Science Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Advanced Photon Source Project, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Annandale, NJ 08801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shenoy, G.K., Materials Science Division, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Moncton, D.E., Advanced Photon Source Project, Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States, Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Annandale, NJ 08801, United States
Abstract: The need for dedicated synchrotron radiation facilities based on insertion devices and a low-emittance storage ring has been recognized for many years. A facility optimized to produce X-rays from 1 to 100 keV is expected to dramatically enhance research capabilities in the areas of condensed matter physics, material sciences, chemical sciences, and biological sciences, in addition to contributing in a major way to industrial research. This goal will be accomplished by the construction (expected to begin in 1989) of the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory. This facility will consist of a 7-GeV positron storage ring with 100 mA current and 35 straight sections to accommodate insertion devices. The ring energy has been chosen so that a single undulator will provide radiation from 4 to 40 keV (using the first and the third harmonics) with 0.2% bandwidth. The low emittance of 7 × 10-9 m rad will provide hard-X-ray undulator radiation with very high brightness (∼ 1018-1019 photons/(s 0.1% BW mm2 mrad2). This overview will mainly address the facility from the users' point of view. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ELECTROMAGNETIC WAVES; PHOTONS; X-RAYS; ADVANCED PHOTON SOURCE; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; UNDULATOR RADIATION; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Bilderback D., Moffat K., Owen J., Rubin B., Schildkamp W., Szebenyi D., Smith Temple B., Volz K., Whiting B.
Title: Protein crystallographic data acquisition and preliminary analysis using kodak storage phosphor plates
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source, Wilson Laboratory, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Section of Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology, Cornell University, Clark Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Research Laboratories, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, NY 14650, United States; School of Applied and Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Clark Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bilderback, D., Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source, Wilson Laboratory, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Moffat, K., Section of Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology, Cornell University, Clark Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Owen, J., Research Laboratories, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, NY 14650, United States; Rubin, B., Research Laboratories, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, NY 14650, United States; Schildkamp, W., Section of Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology, Cornell University, Clark Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Szebenyi, D., Section of Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology, Cornell University, Clark Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Smith Temple, B., School of Applied and Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Clark Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Volz, K., Section of Biochemistry, Molecular and Cell Biology, Cornell University, Clark Hall, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Whiting, B., Research Laboratories, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, NY 14650, United States
Abstract: X-ray diffraction data from single crystals of typical proteins are very weak, numerous, and subject to systematic errors arising from radiation damage at long exposure times. Compared with films, the Kodak storage phosphor technology described in the accompanying paper [1] offers the prospect of greatly improved signal-to-noise, increased sensitivity particularly at shorter wavelengths, and wide dynamic range, though with more modest spatial resolution. To assess the suitability of this technology for protein crystallographic data collection, we have collected both monochromatic oscillation and wide bandpass Laue data at CHESS on crystals ranging in unit cell size from ∼ 50 Å (lysozyme) to ∼ 300 Å (viruses). A direct comparison of the Kodak storage phosphor with conventional Kodak Direct Exposure Film (DEF-5) was obtained by making immediately sequential exposures on the same crystal with the two detector systems. Even with an exposure time one order of magnitude less than with the corresponding film, the storage phosphor yielded data with improved signal-to-noise. Thus, storage phosphors enable more data to be acquired per crystal, with less radiation damage, and with better precision. Such detectors appear extremely well suited to protein crystallographic applications, both static and time-resolved, with both monochromatic and polychromatic X-ray sources. © 1988.
Index Keywords: CRYSTALS; DATA PROCESSING - Data Acquisition; PHOSPHORS; PROTEINS; X-RAYS - Diffraction; CORNELL HIGH ENERGY SYNCHROTRON SOURCE; KODAK STORAGE PHOSPHOR PLATES; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: Mosaic crystal monochromators for synchrotron radiation instrumentation
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, B.P. 220, F-38043 Grenoble Cédex, France
Authors with affiliations: Freund, A.K., European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, B.P. 220, F-38043 Grenoble Cédex, France
Abstract: The diffraction properties of perfect single crystals match the properties of X-ray beams emitted by high energy storage rings in many cases. However, under certain circumstances imperfect crystals are better adapted to the experimental requirements and should therefore be considered as devices for beam definition. In particular progress has recently been made in the development of low mosaic spread beryllium and silicon single crystals. The results of calculations given in the present paper show that up to two orders of magnitude can be gained in flux on the sample when perfect crystals are replaced by mosaic crystals. © 1988.
Index Keywords: CRYSTALS; X-RAYS - Diffraction; MOSAIC CRYSTAL MONOCHROMATORS; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Title: Compact electron storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams, G.P., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: There have been many recent developments in the area of compact storage rings. Such rings would have critical wavelengths of typically 10 Å, achieved with beam energies of several hundred MeV and superconducting dipole fields of around 5 T. Although the primary motivation for progress in this area is that of commercial X-ray lithography, such sources might be attractive for college campuses to operate. They would be useful for many programs in materials science, solid state physics, X-ray microscopy and biological areas. We discuss the properties of such sources and review developments around the world, primarily in the USA, Japan and FRG. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, ELECTRON RING - Storage Rings; ELECTROMAGNETIC WAVES; LITHOGRAPHY; X-RAYS; ELECTRON STORAGE RINGS; X-RAY LITHOGRAPHY; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Kurtz R.L., Ederer D.L., Barth J., Stockbauer R.
Title: Performance of the SURF-II high-throughput toroidal grating monochromator
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kurtz, R.L., National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Ederer, D.L., National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Barth, J., National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Stockbauer, R., National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States
Abstract: The performance of the "high-flux" toroidal grating monochromator (HFTGM) at the NBS SURF-II synchrotron storage ring is assessed. Two gratings are studied: one with a ruled profile and the other having a laminar profile. The laminar profile is shown to reduce substantially the intensity of higher-order diffracted light with only a small decrease in the intensity of the first order light. The dependence of the energy resolution as a function of the area of the grating illuminated is also discussed. © 1988.
Index Keywords: LIGHT SOURCES; OPTICAL GRATINGS; PHOTOEMISSION; TOROIDAL GRATING MONOCHROMATOR; ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON

Authors: Sansone M., Hewitt R., Eberhardt W., Sondericker D.
Title: Performance tests of the ERG monochromator at NSLS-U1
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Annandale, NJ 08801, United States; Brookhaven National Laboratory, NSLS, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sansone, M., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Annandale, NJ 08801, United States; Hewitt, R., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Annandale, NJ 08801, United States; Eberhardt, W., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Annandale, NJ 08801, United States; Sondericker, D., Brookhaven National Laboratory, NSLS, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: The optical components of Exxon's U1 beamline located on the VUV storage ring at the NSLS will be described. The monochromator throughput and resolution have been measured for each grating and are compared to the theoretical values. The relative throughput was obtained from the electron yield of a gold mesh while the resolution was measured at various energies from gas phase absorption spectra. © 1988.
