Title: An analysis of temperature and moisture variations in the ground under natural climatic conditions
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Kobe University, Kobe, 657, Japan; Sekisui House Ltd., Institute of Building Science, Osaka, 567, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsumoto, M., Faculty of Engineering, Kobe University, Kobe, 657, Japan; Iwamae, A., Sekisui House Ltd., Institute of Building Science, Osaka, 567, Japan
Abstract: The earth/ground is one of the main components of the thermal environment and contains water, more or less, in liquid and gas phases. The water in the ground has a great influence on the surroundings, especially on the surface temperature. It is needed to predict the moisture content profile in the ground soil and its surface, for exact consideration of the heat transfer in and on ground soil. The moisture content in the ground soil is strongly influenced by precipitation and the depth of the water table in the ground. The heat and moisture (vapor and liquid water) transfer considerably affect each other. For prediction of the temperature and the moisture content profile in the ground, simultaneous transport of heat and moisture can be considered. This paper presents the results of transient analysis of the heat and moisture fields in the earth/ground under precipitation with non-linear simultaneous heat and moisture transfer equations using the water chemical potential as the potential of the surroundings. Using the weather data of Osaka, Japan, variations of moisture content and temperature in and on the earth/ground are numerically analyzed. An evaporation/condensation process is analyzed quantitatively. The transient process of surface moisture content and water chemical potential are shown. These values vary strongly but never reach saturation in the case of the sandy soil. Average moisture content in the earth/ground is strongly affected by the annual average precipitation but little by the depth of the water table. Using these results, thermal behavior of the thermal well and method of analysis are discussed. For analysis, approximation of the side boundary condition by uniform moisture content is applicable in two-dimensional analysis within the medium moisture content. And for practical calculation, approximation by a linear simple heat diffusion equation is applicable. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Analysis; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METEOROLOGY - Climatology; MOISTURE - Analysis; MOISTURE VARIATIONS; OSAKA, JAPAN; THERMAL WELL; TRANSIENT ANALYSIS; SOILS

Title: An analysis of the heat storage process in wet soil solved as a coupled problem
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Kobe University, Kobe, 657, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsumoto, M., Faculty of Engineering, Kobe University, Kobe, 657, Japan; Kotera, N., Faculty of Engineering, Kobe University, Kobe, 657, Japan
Abstract: It is well known that the earth or ground is a useful medium for long-term heat storage or a long-term heat source and sink. Usually, the ground contains the moisture which affects the behaviour of heat transfer. In this report, a quantitative analysis of the heat storage process is tried in wet sand, based on the simultaneous heat and moisture transfer equations. And the effects of moisture on heat transfer are calculated according to the various moisture contents and mean temperatures of the storage media. The results show that moisture contents and mean has considerable effects on heat transfer. The effects depend mainly on the direct effect on thermal conductivity. The contribution of moisture flow to heat diffusion is not so large. It is shown that governing equations can be solved with the linearized approximation except for the case of a high heating temperature or a very low moisture content. Results of analysis show that when a thermal well is to be used as the heat source and sink, the annual mean operating temperature is equal to the annual mean ambient air temperature on the ground surface. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ATMOSPHERIC TEMPERATURE; ENERGY STORAGE - Analysis; SOILS - Moisture; HEAT STORAGE; MOISTURE TRANSFER; THERMAL WELL; WET SOIL; SAND AND GRAVEL

Title: Information transfer by electromagnetic waves in cortex layers
Affiliations: College of Engineering, Theoretical Physics Division, the Arizona Research Laboratories, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Department of Mathematical Physics, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, S. Australia 5001, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Triffet, T., College of Engineering, Theoretical Physics Division, the Arizona Research Laboratories, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States; Green, H.S., Department of Mathematical Physics, University of Adelaide, Adelaide, S. Australia 5001, Australia
Abstract: Coupling coefficients are derived for the transfer of energy from an electromagnetic wave propagating in the extracellular fluid of a cortex layer, using an ion dynamical model developed earlier (Green & Triffet, 1985). With the assistance of a simple computational algorithm, these are used to document the performance of a basic neural circuit (Eccles, 1979) embedded in a columnar structure of the type described by Mountcastle (1979). Results point to a holographic model of memory, in which calcium configurations in the dendrites of cerebellar granular cells, fixed by modulated alpha-waves, constitute the basic information storage mechanism. Event-related potential waves, known to sweep over selective regions of the cortex in advance of any muscular act, are explained as a logical consequence of circuit function. © 1988 Academic Press Limited.
Index Keywords: brain cortex; cerebellum cortex; computer analysis; electromagnetic radiation; information transfer; mathematical model; nonhuman; theoretical study; Animal; Cerebral Cortex; Electromagnetics; Electrophysiology; Extracellular Space; Information Theory; Models, Neurological

Title: Possible dynamical limitations to excitation energy storage in nuclei
Affiliations: Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Laboratoire de Physique Corpusculaire, Université de Caen, 14032 Caen Cedex, France; Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Bordeaux, 33170 Gradignan, France; Variable Energy Cyclotron Centre, Calcutta, 700064, India; Laboratoire National GANIL, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory, Michigan State University, East-Lansing, MI 48824, United States
Authors with affiliations: Saint-Laurent, F., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Kyanowski, A., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Ardouin, D., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Delagrange, H., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Doubre, H., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Gregoire, C., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Mittig, W., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Peghaire, A., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Peter, J., Laboratoire National GANIL, BP 5027, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Bizard, G., Laboratoire de Physique Corpusculaire, Université de Caen, 14032 Caen Cedex, France; Lefebvres, F., Laboratoire de Physique Corpusculaire, Université de Caen, 14032 Caen Cedex, France; Tamain, B., Laboratoire de Physique Corpusculaire, Université de Caen, 14032 Caen Cedex, France; Quebert, J., Centre d'Etudes Nucléaires de Bordeaux, 33170 Gradignan, France; Viyogi, Y.P., Variable Energy Cyclotron Centre, Calcutta, 700064, India, Laboratoire National GANIL, 14021 Caen Cedex, France; Pochodzalla, J., National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory, Michigan State University, East-Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Gelbke, C.K., National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory, Michigan State University, East-Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Lynch, W., National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory, Michigan State University, East-Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Maier, M., National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory, Michigan State University, East-Lansing, MI 48824, United States
Abstract: The dependence of the relative populations of particle unbound states on the associated charged particle multiplicity and on the total kinetic energy of the two decay products was investigated for 40Ar induced reactions on 197Au at E/A = 60 MeV. The measurements indicate that the relative populations exhibit little sensitivity to the violence of the collision and to the time of emission. Implications of these results on the dynamics of the reaction are discussed. © 1988.

Title: Shock versus stochastic acceleration of impulsive solar flare protons
Affiliations: Berkeley Research Associates, and Department of Astrophysical, Planetary, and Atmospheric Sciences, University of Colorado, Boulder, 80309, CO, United States; Berkeley Research Associates, P.O. Box 241, Berkeley, 94701, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.F., Berkeley Research Associates, and Department of Astrophysical, Planetary, and Atmospheric Sciences, University of Colorado, Boulder, 80309, CO, United States; Brecht, S.H., Berkeley Research Associates, P.O. Box 241, Berkeley, 94701, CA, United States
Abstract: The two major candidates for proton acceleration in impulsive γ-ray producing flares, shock and stochastic acceleration, are considered in light of recent observations of mass motions and turbulence in flares. Starting with the basic problem of energies required, energy storage and the currents which must be involved, it is concluded that the primary energy release must occur close to the temperature minimum region. It is shown that energy can propagate upwards in the form of fast magnetosonic waves which become evanescent in the transition region, converting a large fraction of their energy to mass motions and turbulence. Present observations are mostly of rather coarse (7000 km) spatial resolution and it is quite possible that significantly higher velocities than those observed were present. Using the results of recent simulations of parallel shocks and the well tested theory of Lee (1983) for parallel shock acceleration in the interplanetary medium, it is shown that shock acceleration is a viable candidate at velocities slightly higher than present observations. It is also shown that shocks must be driven by a mass of material which would be visible in coronal lines such as Ca xix for them to be energetically important in proton acceleration. Stochastic acceleration is examined using the hypothesis that there is an equipartition of energy between observed turbulence and magnetic field fluctuations. It is shown that this is a viable acceleration mechanism within a large range of presently observed turbulence provided that the above equipartition hypothesis is valid and the turbulent elements are of small scale (1-200 km). Since turbulence is observed in many flares without any evidence of γ-rays, one of the above conditions must not be satisfied in general. It is concluded that although present observations favor stochastic acceleration, no definitive conclusion can be made without higher spatial resolution observations and additional theoretical work. © 1988 Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Authors: Surholt B., Greive H., Hommel C., Bertsch A.
Title: Fuel uptake, storage and use in male bumble bees Bombus terrestris L.
Affiliations: Lehrstuhl für Tierphysiologie, Zoologisches Institut der Westfälischen Wilhelms-Universität, Hindenburgplatz 55, Münster, D-4400, Germany; Fachbereich Biologie der Philipps Universität, Karl-von-Frisch-Strasse, Marburg, D-3550, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Surholt, B., Lehrstuhl für Tierphysiologie, Zoologisches Institut der Westfälischen Wilhelms-Universität, Hindenburgplatz 55, Münster, D-4400, Germany; Greive, H., Lehrstuhl für Tierphysiologie, Zoologisches Institut der Westfälischen Wilhelms-Universität, Hindenburgplatz 55, Münster, D-4400, Germany; Hommel, C., Lehrstuhl für Tierphysiologie, Zoologisches Institut der Westfälischen Wilhelms-Universität, Hindenburgplatz 55, Münster, D-4400, Germany; Bertsch, A., Fachbereich Biologie der Philipps Universität, Karl-von-Frisch-Strasse, Marburg, D-3550, Germany
Abstract: 1. During a period of more than ten days the flight activity of male bumble bees Bombus terrestris follows a constant daily rhythm and they exhibit a constant pattern of large daily food (sugar) intake. The fate of the sugar consumed was studied with especial regard to the following questions: Is it converted into other storage products and, if so, in which organs are they stored? 2. Individual bumble bees were examined at three different times during the daily activity pattern (just before the onset of flight, at the beginning of foraging and at the end of the light period) and the total contents of glucose, fructose, trehalose, sucrose, glycogen and lipid in the thorax, digestive tract and the abdomen (minus digestive tract) measured. 3. No storage of glycogen or lipids was found in the male bumble bees. They store the chemical energy in the form of non-polymeric carbohydrates in the digestive tract. 4. The rates of fuel utilization during the different phases of the daily activity pattern were calculated. For the first time, the sugar consumption rate in male bumble bees during flight was determined directly (7.6 μmoles hexose units/min·g body mass). 5. A 24-h energy budget for male bumble bees was constructed from measurements of daily food uptake and the rates of energy consumption (Table 3). © 1988 Springer-Verlag.

Abstract: Using the Crystal Ball detector operating at the DORIS II storage ring we have measured the leptonic partial widths G{cyrillic}ee of the Υ(1 S) and Υ(2 S) resonances. We find {Mathematical expression} and {Mathematical expression} The effect on G{cyrillic}ee of applying different prescriptions for radiative corrections is discussed. We also measure R, the ratio of non-resonant hadronic cross section to the Born cross section of μ pair production, at c.m. energy W=9.39 GeV to be R=3.48±0.04±0.16. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Cylindrical domain structure in metamagnets and its stability conditions
Affiliations: State University, Donetsk, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Gerasimchuk, V.S., State University, Donetsk, Ukraine
Abstract: The possibility of the existence of a cylindrical magnetic domain structure near the first-order phase transition line is investigated theoretically in metamagnets, compounds with anisotropy energy substantially exceeding the exchange interaction energy. The domain structure of such compounds is related to the kinetics of the transition from the paramagnetic to the antiferromagnetic state. The static properties of isolated cylindrical magnetic domains and their equilibrium lattices are studied using an energetic approach. It is shown that for a low-temperature metamagnetic phase transition domains of the existence of a cylindrical domain structure, lattices and isolated cylindrical magnetic domains, abut, on the domain of plane-parallel domain structure existence from both sides. The features of their behavior are determined as a function of the magnitude of the external magnetic fields. © 1988 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Index Keywords: Crystals - Magnetic Field Effects; Data Storage, Magnetic - Materials; Magnetic Properties - Mathematical Models; Magnetism - Antiferromagnetism; Magnetization; Cylindrical Domain Structure; First Order Phase Transitions; Metamagnetic Transitions; Paramagnetic-Antiferromagnetic Transitions; Thermodynamic Stability; Transition Kinetics; Magnetic Materials

Title: PREPARING FOR THE NEXT OIL CRISIS.
Affiliations: MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lynch, Michael C., MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Abstract: The author sketches the factors that would affect the making of policy in the event of an oil crisis in the future. It is shown that energy policy has been focused on the reasons for the most recent oil crisis, rather than on the probable causes of the next. Recent reestimates of capacity in OPEC nations suggest that, at any given time, the amount of capacity outside of Saudi Arabia is only 18 Mbbl/d (2,860 ML/d), leaving current surplus capacity at 4 Mbbl/d (636 ML/d). Since the worldwide inventory build from the end of the first quarter of 1979 to the end of the third quarter in 1980 was put at 2. 4 Mbbl/d (382 ML/d), with a quarterly peak of 4. 7 Mbbl/d (747 ML/d) in the third quarter of 1979, current levels of surplus capacity can be seen to be insufficient to prevent another series of price increases in the case of a loss of Saudi supplies due to war, sabotage, or insurrection. Reliance on capacity which is not being produced is also risky. General energy policies are discussed along with methods for coping with disruptions. Current policy is analyzed briefly.
Index Keywords: ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY POLICY; PETROLEUM INDUSTRY; NATIONAL PETROLEUM COUNCIL; OIL DEMAND REDUCTION; OIL PRICE INCREASES; OIL SUPPLY DISRUPTION; ONSHORE STORAGE CAPACITY; OPEC; ENERGY RESOURCES

Title: CHINO BATTERY FACILITY.
Authors with affiliations: Morris, Douglas
Abstract: Southern California Edison is building a 100-Mw lead-acid battery energy storage plant at a site near Los Angeles. The primary objective of this facility is to demonstrate the energy management benefits of storage batteries, and in addition, to investigate the economics of other operating modes. Although the project is a demonstration, the design, procurement, and construction were carried out by normal utility practices. With the plant nearing completion, the project has already achieved the environmental acceptability, short lead time, and capital cost targets projected for lead-acid battery energy storage systems.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; BATTTERY ENERGY STORAGE PLANT; LEAD-ACID BATTERY; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Musick J.T., Pringle F.B., Walker J.D.
Title: SPRINKLER AND FURROW IRRIGATION TRENDS - TEXAS HIGH PLAINS.
Affiliations: USDA, Bushland, TX, USA, USDA, Bushland, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Musick, J.T., USDA, Bushland, TX, USA, USDA, Bushland, TX, USA; Pringle, F.B., USDA, Bushland, TX, USA, USDA, Bushland, TX, USA; Walker, J.D., USDA, Bushland, TX, USA, USDA, Bushland, TX, USA
Abstract: Declining groundwater storage, high pumping energy costs, and low farm profits are causing major changes in irrigation in the Texas High Plains. Irrigation surveys indicated that during a 'decade of decline' starting about 1974, furrow irrigated crop area has declined by 39%, while sprinkler irrigated area continued to expand through 1979 and declined by 3% by 1984. The decline in furrow irrigation is associated with systems that have relatively low estimated application efficiencies, primarily associated with deep percolation loss on moderately permeable soils. Two expanding technologies that will continue to improve irrigation application efficiencies are Low Energy Precision Application for center pivot and lateral move systems and surge flow application in graded furrow systems.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING - Texas; SPRINKLER IRRIGATION; IRRIGATION

Authors: Matsuda Hitoki, Lee Soo Kag, Ishizu Takashi, Hasatani Masanobu
Title: HEAT-RELEASE CHARACTERISTICS OF CaO PACKED BED ACCOMPANIED BY EXOTHERMIC HYDRATION.
Affiliations: Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Matsuda, Hitoki, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn; Lee, Soo Kag, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn; Ishizu, Takashi, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn; Hasatani, Masanobu, Nagoya Univ, Jpn, Nagoya Univ, Jpn
Abstract: The heat-release characteristics of a CaO packed bed accompanied by the exothermic hydration of CaO-H//2O was studied both experimentally and theoretically. It was found that after water vapor had been introduced into the CaO packed bed, the bed temperature immediately rose to the reaction equilibrum temperature, which is determined by the partial pressure of the water vapor, and remained almost constant at this temperature during the course of the reaction. The duration of the heat-release period was found to be approximately proportional to the inlet gas temperature and inversely proportional to the gas flow rate.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Storage; SOLAR ENERGY - Heat Sinks; EXOTHERMIC REACTIONS; REACTANT GAS; RELEASE CYCLES; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: TIPS ON HOW TO SLASH ENERGY COSTS: CPPA BOOKLET TELLS HOW.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: By removing the condensate line from the felt return pan on papermaking machinery (PMs) 5 and 7 at Rolland Inc. 's Saint-Jerome, Que, paper mill and by installing a low-pressure steam coil, energy consumption on the machines could be reduced by 0. 3 MBTU/hr and 0. 5 MBTU/hr respectively. Not bad for an outlay of just 10,000. At Domtar's fine paper mill at Windsor, Que. , adding sulphur and sodium hydroxide to the white liquor, instead of sodium sulphate to the black liquor, reduced the load on the recovery boilers and increased their efficiency. To reduce the load on numbers two and three recovery boilers so that more black liquor can be burned, the direct addition of solid sodium sulphate is suspended and replaced by a 70% emulsified solution of sulphur and a 50% caustic addition in the white liquor, previous to the white liquor storage tank.
Index Keywords: PAPER AND PULP MILLS - Energy Management; PAPERMAKING MACHINERY - Energy Conservation; CONDENSATE LINE; RECOVERY BOILERS; WHITE LIQUOR; BOILERS

Title: DEVELOPMENTS IN INTEGRATED DIGITAL SIGNAL PROCESSORS, AND THE PCB 5010.
Affiliations: Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth
Authors with affiliations: van Meerbergen, J.L., Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth, Philips Research Lab, Eindhoven, Neth
Abstract: Digital signal processors have evolved from older computer concepts to become a separate class of large to very large digital integrated circuits. Modern versions have the 'Harvard architecture', which is characterized by separate arrangements for transfer and storage of data and control information. This also applies to the PCB 5010, developed primarily for applications in telecommunications, audio and speech-processing. The PCB 5010, fabricated in 1. 5- mu m CMOS technology, contains 135,000 transistors on an areas of 61 mm**2 and can execute eight million instructions per second. Each instruction takes the form of a 40-bit 'microcode' word and specifies a maximum of six different sub-operations that can be executed simultaneously. As a general rule the data words have a length of 16 bits, but for some intermediate results 40 bits are available and if required, computations can be carried out with greater precision. The PCB 5010 has three data memories (a 512 multiplied by 16-bit ROM and two 128 multiplied by 16-bit RAMs) and a program memory (1024 multiplied by 16 bits, mostly in a ROM).
Index Keywords: COMPUTER OPERATING SYSTEMS; INTEGRATED CIRCUITS; CHIPS; ENERGY CONSUMPTION; INTEGRATED DIGITAL SIGNAL PROCESSORS; SIGNAL PROCESSING

Title: THERMAL STORAGE IN DISTRICT HEATING SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: KFA, Juelich, West Ger, KFA, Juelich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Scholz, Franz, KFA, Juelich, West Ger, KFA, Juelich, West Ger
Abstract: Large hot-water reservoirs can be very attractive components of medium-sized district heating systems as they offer a good means of uncoupling timewise demand and occurrence of heat and electricity from one another. The most cost effective solution is offered by pressureless hot water tanks. In special cases batteries of cylindrical pressure vessels can also be advantageous. Stratification is very important for the reuse of the stored heat. Different load-changing devices have been developed and tested and proved successful. The design, construction, and operation of four recent hot water storage systems in Germany are discussed. At the Pforzheim reservoir a comprehensive experimental program demonstrated that existing and amended computer models can also predict the thermal behavior of large thermal stores with great confidence. Finally the economical advantages of thermal storage were studied and resulted in a very short pay-back time.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS; PRESSURE VESSELS; RESERVOIRS; TANKS; HOT WATER RESERVOIRS; HOTWATER STORAGE SYSTEMS; PFORZHEIM RESERVOIR, WEST GERMANY; STRATIFICATION; THERMAL STORAGE; HEATING

Title: Optimum design of torsion bar for a vehicle suspension
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers (India): Mechanical Engineering Division
Affiliations: Steelhacks Industries, India
Authors with affiliations: Pandya, N.C., Steelhacks Industries, India; Maru, N.A., Steelhacks Industries, India
Abstract: This paper discusses the basic function of torsion bar spring which is used as a system element to store energy in vehicle suspension. The primary objective is to maximise the storage of strain energy while gradual release of the strain energy without affecting the ride comfort is the secondary objective. The case of hollow circular torsion bar is studied by applying the technique of optimisation with a view to reduce the weight of the element. Comparison of hollow bar has been made with solid bar on the basis of main objectives. Two cases are considered to analyse torsion bar design on the basis of material and optimum energy storage for different geometry. An illustrative example has been set for performance test of design for both the cases, computer run results are presented for comparison and optimum design is pointed out.
Index Keywords: Automobiles - Springs and Suspensions; Cars - Springs and Suspensions; Shock Absorbers; Springs - Design; Strain - Energy Storage; Energy Storage--Optimization; Mathematical Techniques--Variational Techniques; Springs--Design; Torsion Bar Springs; Vehicle Suspensions; Strain Energy Storage; Vehicles; Automobiles

Authors: Roy S.K., John Manley R.S., Kyu T.
Title: Physical and Dynamic Mechanical Properties of Ultradrawn Polypropylene Films
Affiliations: Pulp and Paper Research Institute of Canada, Department of Chemistry, McGill University, Montreal, H3A 2A7, Quebec, Canada; Department of Polymer Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Akron, Ohio 44325, Akron, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roy, S.K., Pulp and Paper Research Institute of Canada, Department of Chemistry, McGill University, Montreal, H3A 2A7, Quebec, Canada; John Manley, R.S., Pulp and Paper Research Institute of Canada, Department of Chemistry, McGill University, Montreal, H3A 2A7, Quebec, Canada; Kyu, T., Department of Polymer Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Akron, Ohio 44325, Akron, United States
Abstract: Dynamic mechanical measurements were made on gel films of high molecular weight polypropylene prepared by gelation/crystallization from 1% (w/v) decalin solutions. The measurements were performed at different frequencies in the temperature range from -160 °C to the melting point of the sample. The dry gel films were uniaxially drawn at 150 °C to various draw ratios (λ) between 6.5 and 48. The morphology and orientation of the samples were characterized by density, differential scanning calorimetry, infrared dichroism, wide-angle X-ray diffraction, small-angle light scattering, scanning electron microscopy, and dynamic storage modulus. WAXS studies showed that very high degrees of orientation were achieved at the higher draw ratios. SEM of highly drawn specimens revealed that the initially random texture of crystallites transforms into fibrous form with the fiber axis parallel to the draw direction. DSC and density measurements show that the melting point and crystallinity increase with λ, reaching a maximum at » = 30. The complex elastic modulus (E*) increased with increasing λ and leveled off beyond λ = 40. In the dynamic mechanical measurements the γ peak was either weak or absent in both the loss tangent (tan δ) and loss modulus curves. At a given frequency, the β-relaxation intensity decreased and shifted to lower temperatures with increasing λ. Activation energies (ΔH) of the β dispersion process were obtained from an Arrhenius-type plot of log frequency versus the reciprocal temperature of the β-dispersion maximum. The values of ΔH ranged from 59 to 119 kcal/mol. In the crystalline α-relaxation region a sharp rise in tan δ was observed and the α-peak position shifts to higher temperature with increasing λ. The activation energy for this process is about 53 kcal/mol. On the basis of the dynamic mechanical measurements the origins of the various relaxation processes are discussed. © 1988, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: CALORIMETRY; GELS - Thin Films; PLASTICS - Microscopic Examination; POLYPROPYLENE - Film; CRYSTALLINE CORE; DRY GEL FILMS; LAMELLAR REORIENTATION; SPHERULITE POLARZONE; ULTRADRAWN FILMS; PLASTICS FILMS

Title: Test program for the ZEUS calorimeter
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-2000 Hamburg 52, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Klanner, R., DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-2000 Hamburg 52, Germany
Abstract: This talk covers some of the experimental studies which have lead to the design of the ZEUS uranium scintillator calorimeter. It is shown how, by varying the scintillator to uranium ratio, equal response for electrons and hadrons and optimum hadronic energy resolution (σE/E ∼ 35%/ E) over a wide energy range can be achieved. A similar optimisation has been done for a lead scintillator calorimeter, and almost equal response for hadrons and electrons together with a hadronic energy resolution of ∼44%/ E up to ∼ 75 GeV has been achieved. Various pratical aspects of calorimetry using scintillator as detector material will also be discussed. The work described in this talk has been done by many members of the ZEUS collaboration. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; CHARGED PARTICLES - Measurements; PARTICLE DETECTORS; ELECTRON COLLIDER HERA; ENERGY RESOLUTION; ZEUS URANIUM SCINTILLATOR; CALORIMETERS

Title: Multicell drift chambers
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A

Abstract: Vector drift chambers have recently been commissioned for use at high energy storage rings, and new ones are under development. They provide a powerful technique, with good performance features built into the geometry. Further advances can be expected. © 1988.

Abstract: Using the ARGUS detector at the e+e- storage ring DORIS II, we have observed the decay τ-→π-π-π-π+π+ντ in tau-pair events produced at center-or-mass energies between 9.4 and 10.6 GeV. From the 5π invariant mass distribution we derive an upper limit of m(ντ)<35 MeV/c2 at the 95% confidence level. The branching ratio for this decay channel is found to be (0.064±0.023±0.01)%. © 1988.

Title: Phthalocyanines and their Sulfonated Derivatives as Photosensitizers in Photodynamic Therapy
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Experimental Phototherapy Section, Radiation Oncology Branch Division of Cancer Treatment, National Cancer Institute National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, 20892, United States
Authors with affiliations: Riesz, P., Experimental Phototherapy Section, Radiation Oncology Branch Division of Cancer Treatment, National Cancer Institute National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, 20892, United States; Krishna, C.M., Experimental Phototherapy Section, Radiation Oncology Branch Division of Cancer Treatment, National Cancer Institute National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, 20892, United States
Abstract: Photodynamic therapy (PDT) of human tumors with hematoporphyrin derivative (HpD) has achieved encouraging results. However, HpD is a complex mixture whose composition varies in different preparations and with time of storage. The future promise of PDT for cancer treatment depends on the development of new chemically defined sensitizers which absorb more strongly than HpD in the 600-800 nm region. A shift to higher wavelengths is desirable since it allows increased light penetration in human tissues. In vivo, these sensitizers should be non-toxic, localize selectively in tumors and generate cytotoxic species upon illumination with a high quantum yield. These damaging species may be singlet oxygen (1O2) produced by the transfer of energy from the triplet state of the sensitizer to oxygen (Type II) or superoxide anion radicals formed by electron transfer to oxygen or substrate radicals generated by electron or hydrogen transfer directly from the sensitizer (Type I). The recent work of several groups indicating that phthalocyanines and their water soluble derivatives are promising candidates for PDT is reviewed. The photophysics, photochemistry, photosensitized killing of cultured mammalian cells and the use for in vivo photodynamic therapy of phthalocyanines is outlined. Our studies of the post-illumination photohemolysis of human red blood cells as a model system for membrane photomodification sensitized by phthalocyanine sulfonates are consistent with the predominant role of 1O2 as the damaging species. © 1988, SPIE.
Index Keywords: Blood; Energy transfer; Free radical reactions; Mammals; Oxygen; Photophysics; Photosensitizers; Tumors; Cytotoxic species; Hematoporphyrin derivatives; Human red blood cell; Hydrogen transfer; Photodynamic therapy (PDT); Sulfonated derivatives; Superoxide anion radicals; Water-soluble derivatives; Photodynamic therapy

Title: High energy electron accelerator based synchrotron radiation sources
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: AT and T Bell Laboratories, Crawfords Corner Road, Holmdel, NJ 07733, USA
Authors with affiliations: Fuoss, P.H., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Crawfords Corner Road, Holmdel, NJ 07733, USA
Abstract: This paper discusses the possibility of using electron linear accelerators as picosecond synchrotron radiation sources. Calculations presented show that the Stanford Linear Collider could exceed the spectral brilliance of existing storage rings (although at a much lower total flux) while producing 3 ps long pulses at a repitition rate of 180 pulses per second. Higher performance sources might be feasible but would require major modifications of existing linear accelerators or the development of new facilities. © 1988.

Authors: van Waeg G., Niklasson F., Ericson Å., de Verdier C.-H.
Title: Purine metabolism in normal and ITP-pyrophosphohydrolase-deficient human erythrocytes
Affiliations: Department of Clinical Chemistry, Uppsala University, Akademiska Sjukhuset, Uppsala Sweden
Authors with affiliations: van Waeg, G., Department of Clinical Chemistry, Uppsala University, Akademiska Sjukhuset, Uppsala Sweden; Niklasson, F., Department of Clinical Chemistry, Uppsala University, Akademiska Sjukhuset, Uppsala Sweden; Ericson, Å., Department of Clinical Chemistry, Uppsala University, Akademiska Sjukhuset, Uppsala Sweden; de Verdier, C.-H., Department of Clinical Chemistry, Uppsala University, Akademiska Sjukhuset, Uppsala Sweden
Abstract: Fresh and stored erythrocytes from normal and ITP-pyrophosphohydrolase (ITP-ase, EC 3.6.1.19) deficient individuals were incubated with hypoxanthine, guanine, allopurinol, and inosine. Differences in the purine metabolism between the normal and the ITP-ase deficient erythrocytes were observed only in the IMP-ITP cycle. Hypoxanthine, guanine and allopurinol were converted to nucleotides at the same rate. Hypoxanthine (2.5 μmol/l) inhibited the salvage of allopurinol (40 μmol/l). A slow decrease (0.7%/day) in salvage rate was observed in both types of cells upon storage at + 4 ° C. Erythrocyte ITP-ase activity was measured in a reference sample group of 48 healthy volunteers. Two distinct groups were found with mean activities equal to 48.3 ± 13.1 nkat/g Hb (χ ± SD, n = 38) and 11.4 ± 4.3 nkat/g Hb (n = 10). In two previously selected subjects, the ITP-ase activity was 0.2 and 2.4 nkat/g Hb. A hypothetical genetic mechanism is discussed. The maximal energy turnover in the IMP-ITP cycle during hypoxanthine incubation was found to be < 10% of the basal erythrocyte energy turnover. © 1988.
Author Keywords: Allopurinol; Human erythrocytes; ITP-pyrophosphohydrolase; Phosphoribosylpyrophosphate; Purine metabolism

Title: The halogen donor depletion instability-current pulse-shape effects
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Joint Institute for Laboratory Astrophysics, National Bureau of Standards, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Coutts, J., Joint Institute for Laboratory Astrophysics, National Bureau of Standards, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States
Abstract: The halogen donor depletion instability, which affects rare gas halide lasers, is discussed with reference to an LC discharge circuit. The derivation of a simple analytic relationship between discharge duration and discharge parameters is no longer possible for such a circuit. Indeed, disagreements between recent results and previously derived scaling laws have their origin in the reactive nature of the energy storage circuit. © 1988 IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DISCHARGES; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS; CURRENT PULSE-SHAPE EFFECTS; SCALING LAWS; LASERS, GAS

Authors: Kuhne M., Fischer J., Wende B.
Title: Laser-produced plasmas as radiometric source standards for the vuv and the soft x-ray region
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2 -12, Berlin 10, D-1000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kuhne, M., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2 -12, Berlin 10, D-1000, Germany; Fischer, J., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2 -12, Berlin 10, D-1000, Germany; Wende, B., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt Institut Berlin, Abbestr. 2 -12, Berlin 10, D-1000, Germany
Abstract: Laser-produced tungsten plasmas have been investigated in respect to their suitability as radiometric source standards covering the wavelength range from 7 nm to 100 nm. The laser system used was a Nd:YAG/Glass system working at X = 1.064 pm with a pulse duration of 17 ns (FWHM) and pulse energies ranging from 100 mJ to 800 mJ in combination with a focusing system of 85 mm focal length. The time-integrated spectral concentration of radiant intensity has been determined with an overall uncertainty of 8 % using the electron storage ring BESSY as a primary standard. Within this uncertainty reproducebility in radiation emission was demonstrated over periods of several months at specific operating conditions. The spectral radiati9p emission reached its maximum at 16.5 nm. For 800 mJ pulse energy an emission of 3.5 x 10 photons/nm/sr was found at 16.5 nm. At present the development of a low cost, single stage YAG-laser based, transportable standard is under way. © 1988 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Laser beams; Neodymium lasers; Plasma interactions; Radiometry; Storage rings; X rays; Yttrium aluminum garnet; Electron storage ring; Operating condition; Radiant intensities; Radiation emissions; Radiometric sources; Soft X-ray regions; Spectral concentrations; Spectral radiation; Laser produced plasmas

Authors: Duda T.F., Cox C.S., Deaton T.K.
Title: The Cartesian diver: A self-profiling Lagrangian velocity recorder
Source title: Journal of Atmospheric and Oceanic Technology
Affiliations: Scripps Institution of Oceanography, La Jolla, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Duda, T.F., Scripps Institution of Oceanography, La Jolla, CA, United States; Cox, C.S., Scripps Institution of Oceanography, La Jolla, CA, United States; Deaton, T.K., Scripps Institution of Oceanography, La Jolla, CA, United States
Abstract: The Cartesian diver is an autonomous velocity profiler capable of operating to 1 km depth in the ocean. It has a self-controlled buoyancy changer which is used to control the direction of profiling. The buoyancy changer has two states, full positive or full negative buoyancy. With correct ballasting the instrument has roughly equal up and down profiling speeds. A passive compressible volume appended to the pressure case is used to keep the buoyancy constant during an up or down run despite changes of density of the surrounding seawater, thus keeping the profiling speed and sampling intervals constant throughout a profile. A microcomputer system controls the buoyancy changer, data collection, and internal recording. Battery energy storage for the buoyancy changer is sufficient for 200 consecutive dives to 500 meters, thus 400 profiles. Horizontal components of velocity fluctuations with vertical wavelengths greater than 10 m are sensed using the method of geomagnetic induction. Since the instrument cannot accelerate relative to the fluid surrounding it, changes of its vertical velocity can be measured with a pressure gauge and interpreted as oceanic vertical velocity. Temperature, conductivity and microscale conductivity probes are included, in order to investigate relationships between finescale velocity structure, finescale density structure, and diffusive scale conductivity structure. © American Meteorological Society.
Index Keywords: Buoyancy; Digital storage; Geomagnetism; Battery energy storage; Conductivity probe; Conductivity structures; Density structures; Geomagnetic induction; Lagrangian velocity; Microcomputer system; Velocity fluctuations; Velocity

Title: Pyridine nucleotide oxidation by a plasma membrane fraction from red beet (Beta vulgaris L.) storage tissue
Affiliations: Department of Agronomy, University of Illinois, 1102 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Giannini, J.L., Department of Agronomy, University of Illinois, 1102 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Briskin, D.P., Department of Agronomy, University of Illinois, 1102 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: The potential role of pyridine nucleotide oxidation in the energization and/or regulation of membrane transport was examined using sealed plasma membrane vesicles isolated from red beet (Beta vulgaris L.) storage tissue. In this system, pyridine nucleotide oxidation, which was enhanced in the presence of ferricyanide, occurred. In the presence or absence of ferricyanide, the oxidation of NADH was several-fold greater than the oxidation of NADPH, indicating that it was the preferred substrate for oxidation in this system. Ferricyanide reduction coupled to NADH oxidation did not require the transmembrane movement of reducing equivalents since ferricyanide incorporated inside the vesicles could not be reduced by NADH added externally to the vesicles, unless the vesicles were made leaky by the addition of 0.05% (v/v) Triton X-100. Using fluorescent probes for the measurement of transmembrane pH gradients and membrane potentials, it was determined that NADH oxidation did not result in the production of a proton electrochemical gradient or have any effect upon the proton electrochemical gradient produced by the plasma membrane H+-ATPase. The oxidation of NADH in the presence of ferricyanide did result in the acidification of the reaction medium. This acidification was unaffected by the addition of Gramicidin D and stimulated by the addition of 0.05% (v/v) Triton X-100, suggesting a scalar (nonvectorial) production of protons in the oxidation/reduction reaction. The results of this study suggest that the oxidation of pyridine nucleotides by plasma membrane vesicles is not related to energization of transport at the plasma membrane or modulation of the activity of the plasma membrane H+-ATPase. © 1988.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; ferricyanide; nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide; nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate; Proton Translocating ATPases; proton transporting adenosine triphosphatase; article; cell membrane; cell membrane potential; density gradient centrifugation; electrochemistry; energy metabolism; metabolism; microsome; oxidation reduction reaction; pH; plant; transport at the cellular level; Adenosine Triphosphate; Biological Transport; Cell Membrane; Centrifugation, Density Gradient; Electrochemistry; Energy Metabolism; Ferricyanides; Hydrogen-Ion Concentration; Membrane Potentials; Microsomes; NAD; NADP; Oxidation-Reduction; Plants; Proton-Translocating ATPases; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.

Title: The influence of storage temperature on the transition, activation enthalpy, and activity of enzymes associated with inner mitochondrial membranes
Affiliations: Plant Physiology Group, CSIRO Division of Food Research, School of Biological Sciences, 2109 NSW, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Brown, M.A., Plant Physiology Group, CSIRO Division of Food Research, School of Biological Sciences, 2109 NSW, Australia; Raison, J.K., Plant Physiology Group, CSIRO Division of Food Research, School of Biological Sciences, 2109 NSW, Australia
Abstract: The effects of storage at low temperature on the transition in enzyme function, Tf*, and the Arrhenius activation energy, Ea, were determined for several enzymes associated with the inner membrane of rat liver mitochondria. The enzymes studied were succinate:cytochrome c reductase, cytochrome c oxidase, β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase, and oligomycin-sensitive, Mg2+-activated ATPase. For freshly isolated mitochondria the Tf*, for succinate:cytochrome c reductase and cytochrome c oxidase, occurred at approximately 23 °C and was coincident with a transition in structure, Ts*, determined as the change in temperature coefficient of motion for a spin label intercalated with the membrane lipids. This suggests that the change in thermal response of the membraneassociated enzymes is related to a change in molecular ordering of the membrane lipids. When mitochondria were stored at -12 °C, the specific activities of succinate:cytochrome c reductase and cytochrome c oxidase decreased. Concomitant with these changes the Ea, above Tf*, increased. After 100 days storage at -12 °C, Ea above Tf* approached the value for Ea below Tf* such that the transition in thermal response could no longer be detected. In contrast, for mitochondria stored at -196 °C, although the specific activity declined over the 100 days storage, no changes in either Ea or Tf* were evident. The results indicate a need for caution in evaluating comparative studies of Tf and Ea, for membrane-associated enzymes, using mitochondria which have been frozen and Stored. © 1988.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphatase (calcium magnesium); Ca(2+) Mg(2+) ATPase; cytochrome c oxidase; hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase; oligomycin; oxidoreductase; succinate dehydrogenase; animal; article; enzyme activation; enzymology; freezing; intracellular membrane; kinetics; liver mitochondrion; metabolism; rat; rat strain; thermodynamics; Animal; Ca(2+) Mg(2+)-ATPase; Cytochrome-c Oxidase; Enzyme Activation; Freezing; Hydroxybutyrate Dehydrogenase; Intracellular Membranes; Kinetics; Mitochondria, Liver; Oligomycins; Oxidoreductases; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Succinate Cytochrome c Oxidoreductase; Thermodynamics

Source title: Bulletin of the Institution of Engineers, India - Supplement
Affiliations: Univ of Madras, India
Authors with affiliations: Sundaresan, B.B., Univ of Madras, India
Abstract: The author views solid waste management as involving activities associated with generation, storage, collection, transfer and transport, processing and disposal of solid wastes which are environmentally compatible, adopting principles of economy, aesthetics, and energy conservation. He then discusses how information on management techniques developed elsewhere can be applied in India with suitable modifications. Organizational principles and their applicability to waste management are discussed along with factors relating to manpower development and community participation. Reasons for composting are presented. Incineration, the self-sustained combustion reaction and pyrolysis are examined. Legal aspects are also briefly reviewed.
Index Keywords: Energy Conservation; Organic Compounds - Combustion; Waste Disposal - Management; Benefit-Cost Analysis; Manpower Development; Self-Sustained Combustion Reaction; Solid Waste Management; Urban Solid Waste; Refuse Disposal

Title: Sodium metal chloride batteries with beta alumina electrolyte
Affiliations: Beta Research & Development Ltd, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Sudworth, Jim, Beta Research & Development Ltd, United Kingdom
Abstract: The discovery in 1962 that beta alumina was a good ionic conductor, opened up the possibility of constructing electrochemical cells with sodium as one electrode and beta alumina as the electrolyte. For many years the main interest in beta alumina was as an electrolyte in the sodium sulphur cell. This article reviews some recent research and development work that has led to sodium/metal chloride batteries with high specific energies being demonstrated in electric vehicles, and to a better understanding of the operation of those cells.
Index Keywords: Alumina--Ionic Conduction; Electrodes--Sodium; Electrolytes, Solid; Storage Battery Vehicles; Beta Alumina; Electrochemical Cells; Sodium Metal Chloride Batteries; Electric Batteries

Authors: Takahashi Y., Kamimoto M., Abe Y., Sakamoto R., Kanari K., Ozawa T.
Title: Investigation of latent heat thermal energy storage materials. V. thermoanalytical evaluation of binary eutectic mixtures and compounds of NAOH with NaNO3 OR NaNO2
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kamimoto, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Abe, Y., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Sakamoto, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kanari, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Ozawa, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura-mura, Niihari-gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: Differential scanning calorimetry was applied to the evaluation of binary eutectic mixtures and compounds of NaOH with NaNO3 or NaNO2 as latent heat thermal energy storage materials. There are two compounds and three eutectic mixtures consisting of NaOH and NaNO3 and one compound and two eutectic mixtures consisting of NaOH and NaNO2. The heats of fusion of all compounds and mixtures were more than 200 J g-1. The thermal behaviour of these materials was observed, and some compounds and mixtures show a great tendency to supercool. The specific heat capacity was also measured. Because the eutectic mixture 18.5 mol.% NaNO3-81.5 mol.% NaOH is the most promising material for use in a nuclear power plant, this mixture made from industrial products was examined further. After 1000 cycles of melting and crystallization in bench-scale equipment the material shows little change. © 1988.

Title: An integrated hydraulic drive train system for automobiles.
Authors with affiliations: Fronczak, F.J.; Beachley, N.H.
Abstract: The design concept of a hydraulic drive train for an automobile is presented. This concept incorporates many features unique to a system using fluid power including the following: free piston engine pump, hydrostatic transmission, regenerative braking, hydropneumatic accumulator energy storage, individual wheel pump/motors, and hydraulically driven accessories. The feasibility of the design was established by a combination of analytical and experimental work. Test rig experimentation was used to validate many of the control techniques and also to provide design data on the system components. Most of the fluid power components that are used in the design are based on current technology. The design employs microprocessor based control of the system to maximize efficiency. By coordination of all hydraulic system functions, and continual optimization of the system parameters to meet the drivers demands, improved fuel economy can be obtained. This improvement, along with the other benefits obtained from a continuously variable transmissison and four wheel drive make the integrated hydraulic drive train system an attractive option for automobiles.

Authors: Schilke N.A., Fruechte R.D., Rillings J.H., Rohde S.M.
Title: Systems approach to the future - Automotive style
Authors with affiliations: Schilke, N.A.; Fruechte, R.D.; Rillings, J.H.; Rohde, S.M.
Abstract: The existence of the computer coupled with the rapid development of analytical engineering techniques has made it possible to design complex systems which are different and better, and to do so in a manner that is more efficient. Examples from the aircraft industry include hypersonic airplanes in which the fuel serves as a coolant to heat sensitive frame components, and the frame serves as part of the engine. Thus, design changes to any single part have cascading effects on the entire Bystem. This leads to extreme complexity in the design process and requires extensive computational resources and sophisticated computer techniques to proceed in a rational manner. For example, large scale systems theory and multi-level optimization are some of the approaches applicable to this class of design problems. Similarly, in advanced automotive systems, new ideas, which appear at the outset to be and/or affect only subsystems, (e.g., energy storage devices, active suspension systems, etc.) cannot even be considered using other than a vehicle system design, and they also may dramatically alter the system operation. This is particularly important since automobile users are a relatively heterogeneous, unskilled group. A systems approach, which integrates all aspects of product definition, design, manufacturing and use, is required to solve the dilemma. The systems approach requires the development of top-down design tools and techniques for mission definition, functional analysis, concept development and design. All salient issues must be considered from the outset and throughout, including manufacturability, reliability, serviceability, etc. And if a systems approach is used it becomes a mechanism and stimulus for the integration and resultant synergism of previously separated technical issues and disciplines.
Index Keywords: Active suspension systems; Automobile suspensions; Fighter aircraft; Hypersonic vehicles; Large scale systems; Magnetic levitation vehicles; Product design; Aircraft industries; Automotive Systems; Computational resources; Computer techniques; Concept development; Engineering techniques; Multilevel optimization; Product definition; Suspensions (components)

Title: An electric vehicle design based on a high-power, sealed, lead-acid battery
Affiliations: University of Idaho, Moscow, ID, United States
Authors with affiliations: Edwards, D.B., University of Idaho, Moscow, ID, United States
Abstract: A passenger electric vehicle which can travel 100 miles at freeway speeds (55 mph) appears to be the most competitive, electric alternative to the conventional automobile. This paper discusses an electric vehicle design which uses a number of emerging technologies that, when taken together, provide the 100-mile range. The vehicle design takes advantage of technologies in sealed, lead-acid batteries; power electronics; aerodynamics; tires; and lightweight structures. A novel, high-power, sealed, lead-acid battery is used for energy storage and is the basis for the design. The battery is paired with a 60Kw. A.C. drive for the vehicle's power train. The A.C. drive consists of a transistorized inverter and induction motor. The batteries are thermally managed and charged with an on-board, non-isolated charger. These components, when coupled with an aerodynamically designed vehicle using low rolling resistant tires and light-weight structures, can provide the necessary power and energy for good vehicle performance. Copyright © 1988 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Aerodynamics; Electric automobiles; Induction motors; Light weight structures; Passenger cars; Vehicle performance; A.c. Drives; Emerging technologies; High power; Non-isolated; Vehicle design; Lead acid batteries

Authors: Bayes S.A., Trevino L.A., Dinsmore C.E.
Title: A nonventing cooling system for space environment extravehicular activity, using radiation and regenerable thermal storage
Affiliations: United Technologies Corporation, Hamilton Standard Division, United States; NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, United States; Rockwell International Corporation, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bayes, S.A., United Technologies Corporation, Hamilton Standard Division, United States; Trevino, L.A., NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, United States; Dinsmore, C.E., Rockwell International Corporation, United States
Abstract: This paper outlines the selection, design, and testing of a prototype nonventing regenerable astronaut cooling system for Extravehicular Activity (EVA) space suit applications, for mission durations of four hours or greater. The selected system consists of the following key elements: a radiator assembly which serves as the exterior shell of the portable life support subsystem (PLSS) backpack; a layer of phase change thermal storage material, n-hexadecane paraffin, which acts as a regenerable thermal capacitor; a thermoelectric heat pump; and an automatic temperature control system. The capability for regeneration of thermal storage capacity with and without the aid of electric power is provided. ©1988 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Heat storage; Manned space flight; Paraffins; Storage (materials); Thermoelectric equipment; Extra vehicular activities; Extravehicular activity; Mission duration; Phase-change thermal storages; Space environment; Thermal capacitors; Thermal storage; Thermoelectric heat pump; Electric energy storage

Authors: Rosso Jr. M.J., Adlhart O.J., Marmolejo J.A.
Title: A fuel cell energy storage system for space station extravehicular activity
Affiliations: Ergenics Power Systems, Inc., Wyckoff, NJ, United States; NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, Houston, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rosso Jr., M.J., Ergenics Power Systems, Inc., Wyckoff, NJ, United States; Adlhart, O.J., Ergenics Power Systems, Inc., Wyckoff, NJ, United States; Marmolejo, J.A., NASA, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, Houston, TX, United States
Abstract: A greater number of manned extravehicular activities (EVAs) are anticipated for the United States Space Station compared to the few experienced on Space Shuttle missions. This requires the design of a new generation extravehicular mobility unit (EMU). Limitations inherent in the current EMU power supply - zinc silver-oxide batteries - include dry shelf-life, active wet-life, cycle-life, and recharge time, thus making its usage impractical for the Space Station. An alternative solution, a fuel cell energy storage system (FCESS), is being explored by Ergenics Power Systems, Inc. (EPSI), Wyckoff, N.J., with funding from NASA/Johnson Space Center. The ion-exchange membrane (IEM) fuel cell under consideration utilizes hydrogen stored as a metal hydride. EPSI has demonstrated experimentally that the fuel cell/hydride technology pair should be a primary candidate EMU power supply for its high volumetric/energy density and cycle life, quick recharge, durability, EMU integration, and safety. This paper describes the EMU (IEM) hydrogen-oxygen fuel cell being developed by EPSI including its construction, hydrogen storage, hydride recharge, waste heat and water removal. © 1988 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Hydrides; Hydrogen storage; Ion exchange; Ion exchange membranes; Manned space flight; NASA; Silver oxides; Space platforms; Space shuttles; Space stations; Waste heat; Alternative solutions; Energy storage systems; Extra vehicular activities; Extravehicular mobility units; Hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells; Metal hydrides; Space shuttle missions; Water removal; Fuel cells

Authors: Longardner R.L., Visnesky A., Strother J.R.
Title: Increasing the capacity factors of base load generating facilities by storage of electrical energy in acquifers as compressed air.
Authors with affiliations: Longardner, R.L.; Visnesky, A.; Strother, J.R.
Abstract: Examines how "off the shelf" equipment may be used to produce compressed air energy systems, and compares the cost of this type of energy storage system with alternative storage systems for electrical energy. Outlines EPRI plans for the sand aquifers in the Pittsfield anticline. Turbo and ancillary machinery specifications are given in an appendix.

Title: Pumped storage and compressed air storage, a comparison.
Authors with affiliations: Makarechian, A.H.; Grinnell, G.C.K.
Abstract: Pumped storage hydroelectric power plants and compressed air energy storage plants are used for peaking and intermediate duty on electrical utility load systems. A pumped storage plant uses off peak energy from the system and generates on peak energy. It is a pure energy storage plant. The compressed air energy storage plant not only stores energy by compressing air, but it adds energy to the system during the peak hours by releasing the air through an expansion turbine which uses fuel to heat the air. It is a hybrid type plant and a net generator of electricity. For each kilowatt of energy produced by a compressed air energy storage plant approximately 60% is from on peak generation similar to a gas turbine. The compressed air energy storage gas turbine uses approximately one third the fuel of a conventional turbine of the same output rating. The rest of the input is in the form of electrical energy used to compress the air which is stored for later use in the combustion cycle. In comparing storage with compressed air energy storage, the development stage of the two technologies should be kept in mind. Compressed air energy storage is a relatively new technology compared to pumped storage and only a limited number of compressed air energy plants have been built.

Authors: Tung T.P., Clark R.H., Cole J.
Title: Research and development program on small scale and low head hydro by the Canadian Government.
Authors with affiliations: Tung, T.P.; Clark, R.H.; Cole, J.
Abstract: This paper describes the technical aspects and the status of those projects recently completed or on going, such as: syphon intake geometry and submergence laboratory tests which were carried out; research on flow through rockfill dams and spillways, now underway; a 5 kW Darrieus type vertical axis hydro turbine installed on the back of a fibre glass boat is being field tested; a 120 kW S type tubular turbine designed for a head of 30 m is being fabricated; a very small micro hydro unit with plastic runner is to be further improved; and, a prototype electronic power controller for stand alone induction generator control is being constructed for field testing. Site costing and hydrologic models, and a compressed air energy storage project for retiming tidal energy are also briefly discussed.

Title: Project alternatives to benefit endangered species.
Authors with affiliations: Velehradsky, J.E.; Taylor, J.R.
Abstract: Management measures in the Missouri River main stem reservoir system to protect two endangered bird species, the interior least tern and the piping plover, are discussed. Stabilizing flow releases during the nesting season would limit hydroelectric power capacity during peak demand periods and increase system storage. Other possible actions include recovering lost energy by installing hydropower units in spillways and providing nesting habitats by removing vegetation from higher elevation sandbars and islands downstream from dams.

Title: An integrated hydraulic drive train system for use in domestic cars.
Authors with affiliations: Bleachley, N.; Fronczak, F.
Abstract: A design concept for an integrated hydraulic drive train system for an automobile is presented. Features include a free piston engine pump, hydrostatic transmission, regenerative braking, a hydropneumatic accumulator for energy storage and individual wheel pump motors. Improvements in fuel economy have been achieved as the operation of the engine can be uncoupled from the road load requirements because of the presence of the accumulator, and the hydrostatic pump motors can be used a pump during vehicle braking and the vehicle kinetic energy can be converted and then stored in the accumulator for later use in accelerating the vehicle.

Authors: Hummel F.C., Palz W., Grassi G.
Title: Biomass forestry in Europe: a strategy for the future
Source title: Biomass forestry in Europe: a strategy for the future
Authors with affiliations: Hummel, F.C.; Palz, W.; Grassi, G.
Abstract: Short rotation (3-14 yr) forest biomass plantations for industry and, when economically feasible, energy, are grown and have potential in the EC, especially now that land is being taken out of food production. The book summarises the results of research and achievements in the EC and makes recommendations on future policy, practice and research. Part I has separately authored chapters on general technical, economic, social and environmental aspects: policy and economic aspects; scientific background; selection and breeding; treatment of site and crop; harvesting, drying, storage and transport; world perspective; future strategy. Part II deals with the subject by country: Belgium, Denmark, France, FRG, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Portugal, Spain, and the UK. -M.A.Bass
Index Keywords: biomass forestry; national studies; short-rotation plantation; (West); Europe

Title: The impact resistance of concrete weight coatings for submarine pipelines.
Authors with affiliations: Hancock, J.R.
Abstract: Results obtained over the past several years on the impact resistance of concrete weight coatings are presented for 219-914 mm OD pipe and concrete thicknesses of 38-125 mm. The tests employed a pendulum impact device and were designed to simulate trawl gear impacts with unburied coated pipelines on the seabed. The number of impact blows to expose the steel reinforcement and anticorrosion coating are given for a broad range of test conditions. The results provide a large database not available before on the impact resistance of production concrete coatings This database should be useful in the development of more impact resistant concrete weight coatings and provides a practical, quantitative guide for specifying both the impact resistance of concrete weight coatings and realistic test conditions. Nonlinear trends in the impact resistance of concrete coatings are characterized as a function of impact energy, concrete thickness, striker size and shape, and direction of impact loading. In order to better define the impact resistance of concrete coatings it is recommended that testing conditions be standardized, that specimen storage conditions be controlled, and that the effects of water absorption by the concrete be determined.

Title: Understanding nuclear power: a technical guide to the industry and its processes
Source title: Understanding nuclear power: a technical guide to the industry and its processes
Authors with affiliations: Cole, H.A.
Abstract: Aims to allay popular fears concerning nuclear power, by explaining in everyday language the science on which the industry is based and the technical aspects of its operation. Covers: Britain's present and future energy requirements; history of nuclear power; the meaning of radioactivity; a summary of the nuclear fuel cycle; uranium mining and exploration; fuel element manufacture; uranium enrichment; thermal reactors; gas breeder reactors; spent nuclear fuel - temporary storage and transportation; the reprocessing plant; radioactive waste - its nature, storage, treatment and disposal; decommissioning; nuclear fuels and cladding materials, neutron moderators and absorbers; reactor coolants; radiation detection and measuring instruments; radiological protection; nuclear safeguards and public concern. -from CEGB Abstracts
Index Keywords: energy requirement; nuclear fuel cycle; nuclear industry; nuclear power; technical guide; UK

Authors: Castro M., Peire J., Carpio J., Valcarcel M., Aldana F.
Title: Large grid solar energy integration analysis
Source title: Proceedings - IECON 1988: Power Electronics - 1988 International Conference on Industrial Electronics
Affiliations: Electric, Electronic and Control Engineering Department, E. T. S. Ingenieros Industriales, Universidad Nacional de Educacion a Distancia, Laboratorio Central Oficial de Electrotecnia, Ciudad Universitaria, s/n, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Laboratorio Central Oficial de Electrotecnia, E.T.S.I.I., Universidad Politecnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Electronic Engineering Division, E.T.S.I.I., Universidad Politecnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Castro, M., Electric, Electronic and Control Engineering Department, E. T. S. Ingenieros Industriales, Universidad Nacional de Educacion a Distancia, Laboratorio Central Oficial de Electrotecnia, Ciudad Universitaria, s/n, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Peire, J., Electric, Electronic and Control Engineering Department, E. T. S. Ingenieros Industriales, Universidad Nacional de Educacion a Distancia, Laboratorio Central Oficial de Electrotecnia, Ciudad Universitaria, s/n, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Carpio, J., Laboratorio Central Oficial de Electrotecnia, E.T.S.I.I., Universidad Politecnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Valcarcel, M., Laboratorio Central Oficial de Electrotecnia, E.T.S.I.I., Universidad Politecnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Aldana, F., Electronic Engineering Division, E.T.S.I.I., Universidad Politecnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: This paper presents the weekly planning of a large electric grid like the Spanish one with the integration of solar electric units, based on solar central receiver and photovoltaic ones. The solar electric generation value is obtained from a solar central simulation program developed. The planning model used makes the generation planning hour by hour in periods of a week or multiples (up to one year). The weekly scheduling is done using all the units presents in the Spanish power system, including hydro and pump-storage ones and analyzing the introduction of solar thermal and photovoltaic ones. The possible production of overloading in the tie lines between geographic zones is avoided both in case of the normal operation and in case of the failure of a thermal unit. In this case the operation cost associated with the failure unit is considered. The weekly planning results obtained allows to define the maximum solar central operation cost that allows to replace thermal units (mainly fuel, gas and coal ones) by solar ones. © 1988 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Economic dispatch; Electric power planning; Operating cost; Simulation; Solar energy scale production; Solar units integration; Unit commitment

Title: Optimal generation expansion planning with electric energy storage systems
Source title: Proceedings - IECON 1988: Power Electronics - 1988 International Conference on Industrial Electronics

Abstract: This paper presents an efficient method which provides the optimal generation mix and the optimal addition (development) process for hot only generators but also for electric energy storage systems. The approximations method, in which the dynamic programming and the 'gradient method are combined, is developed to determine the optimal generation mix with energy storage systems. The dynamic programming, in which the stages are time periods and the state is cumulative capacity, is applied to determine the optimal generation addition process. The feasibility of the proposed method is demonstrated on a typical power system model. © 1988 IEEE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Sawai K., Tari I., Ohzuku T., Hirai T.
Title: Cell Performance of a Diaphragm-type Fe/Cr Redox Flow Cell
Affiliations: Department of Synthetic Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama-shi 700, Japan; Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Osaka City University, Sugimoto Sumiyoshi-ku, Osaka-shi 558, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sawai, K., Department of Synthetic Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama-shi 700, Japan; Tari, I., Department of Synthetic Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama-shi 700, Japan; Ohzuku, T., Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Osaka City University, Sugimoto Sumiyoshi-ku, Osaka-shi 558, Japan; Hirai, T., Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Osaka City University, Sugimoto Sumiyoshi-ku, Osaka-shi 558, Japan
Abstract: A diaphragm-type Fe/Cr redox flow cell equipped with a rebalance cell and state of charge monitors has been developed. The electrolyte used was 1 M FeCl2-l M CrCl3-2 M HCl solution for both Fe-and Cr-compartments. A 100 cycle-life test using the single cell without catalyst loading was carried out at 30°C. The system was evaluated in terms of working voltage, discharge capacity, charge/discharge eoulombic efficiency, hydrogen gas evolution rate and cross-mixing rate. The average charge/discharge eoulombic efficiency during 100 cycles was 96.7%. The losses of electricity due to hydrogen gas evolution and cross mixing were calculated to be 1.5% and 1.8%% respectively, based on the electricity used for charging. The possibility of application to an electrical energy storage system is discussed in terms of the reliability and the cycle life of the system. © 1988, The Chemical Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Title: Experiment of Power System Stabilization by Using Superconducting Mangnet Energy Storage in Artificial Power Transmission System

Authors: Hoshino M., Kimura G., Shioya M.
Title: DC-to-DC converters and inverter for photovoltaic modules
Source title: Proceedings - IECON 1988: Power Electronics - 1988 International Conference on Industrial Electronics
Affiliations: Faculty of Technology, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 2-1-1, Fukazawa, Setagaya-ku, Tokyo, 158, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hoshino, M., Faculty of Technology, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 2-1-1, Fukazawa, Setagaya-ku, Tokyo, 158, Japan; Kimura, G., Faculty of Technology, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 2-1-1, Fukazawa, Setagaya-ku, Tokyo, 158, Japan; Shioya, M., Faculty of Technology, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 2-1-1, Fukazawa, Setagaya-ku, Tokyo, 158, Japan
Abstract: Photovoltaic modules have each maximum power point, which varies depending on the intensity of the sunlight, modules temperature and etc. Three types of DC-to-DC converters, step-down chopper, step-up chopper and Cuk converter are investigated to obtain the maximum charging power from photovoltaic modules to storage batteries. This paper offers a simple tracking control method by detecting the output current of DC-to-DC converter included in the photovoltaic power generation system, in order to operate at the maximum power point even if the sunlight and the temperature are varied. The PWM inverter with five-stepped voltage source, which is used suitably in the system and formed by the series or parallel connections of the storage battery units, is also described. © 1988 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cuk converter; DC-to-DC converter; Photovoltaic modules; Step-down chopper; Step-up chopper; Tracking control and PWM inverter
