Title: The effect of feeding human milk and adapted milk formulae on serum lipid and lipoprotein levels in young infants
Affiliations: Universitäts-Kinderklinik, Josef-Schneider-Strasse 2, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wagner, V., Universitäts-Kinderklinik, Josef-Schneider-Strasse 2, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany; von Stockhausen, H.B., Universitäts-Kinderklinik, Josef-Schneider-Strasse 2, Würzburg, D-8700, Germany
Abstract: The effect of feeding with human milk and commercially available milk substitutes was studied in a group of 154 healthy infants during the first 3 months of life by assessment of body weight, body length, head circumference, skinfold thickness, serum lipid and lipoprotein concentrations. Human milk and the different milk formulae have the same energy content (kcal/100 ml) and total fat, total protein and total carbohydrate contents are comparable but they differ in respect of their fatty acid compositions. The various diets were chosen freely by the parents and the newborns were exclusively fed either human milk (n=56), Multival 1 (n=31), Humana 1 (n=33), or Pre Aptamil (n=34). No significant differences in body, weight, body length or head circumference were observed between any of the different dietary groups. Fat storage, as assessed by measurements of skinfold thickness, was significantly less in breast-fed children compared to those on the formula diets. Breast-fed and Pre Aptamil-fed infants had the highest levels of total serum cholesterol, low density lipoprotein (LDL)-cholesterol and LDL. No differences were observed in the levels of total serum triglycerides, very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)- and high density lipoproteins (HDL)-cholesterol, VLDL and HDL. There were no strong correlations between the physical and the biochemical parameters. No indication of an increased risk of developing atherosclerosis was associated with any of the dietary treatments for the duration of this study. However, these investigations support the hypothesis that subtle early nutritional variation can influence mechanisms that regulate lipoprotein and cholesterol levels in later life. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Adapted milk; Cholesterol; Human milk; Lipoproteins; Serum lipids

Authors: Maessen J.G., Van der Vusse G.J., Vork M., Kootstra G.
Title: Nucleotides, nucleosides, and oxypurines in human kidneys measured by use of reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, University of Limburg, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Maessen, J.G., Department of Physiology, University of Limburg, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands; Van der Vusse, G.J., Department of Physiology, University of Limburg, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands; Vork, M., Department of Physiology, University of Limburg, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands; Kootstra, G., Department of Physiology, University of Limburg, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands
Abstract: An HPLC technique is presented for determining adenine nucleotides and related substances in renal cortical tissue. Nineteen metabolic substances can be resolved in a single 25-min run, with use of a gradient-elution system. The mean intra-assay CV is 24%, the interassay CV 5%. The lower detection limit for substances commonly present in kidney tissue - such as ATP, ADP, AMP, GTP, GDP, GMP, IMP, inosine, adenosine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine - ranges from 0.6 to 3.6 μmol/L, corresponding to 18 and 107 pmol applied to the column. For reliable analysis, a specimen of renal cortex weighing at least 5 mg (wet weight), taken during donor nephrectomy, during cold storage of the kidney, and 1 h after the onset of reperfusion, can be used. The method presented provides a rapid, reproducible diagnostic tool for assessing the chemical energy status of human kidneys in renal surgery and transplantation.

Authors: Takami H., Matsuda H., Hirose H., Kaneko M., Ohtani M., Tagawa K., Kawashima Y.
Title: Myocardial energy metabolism in preserved heart: Comparison of simple storage and hypothermic perfusion
Affiliations: The First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-ku, Osaka 553, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takami, H., The First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-ku, Osaka 553, Japan; Matsuda, H., The First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-ku, Osaka 553, Japan; Hirose, H., The First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-ku, Osaka 553, Japan; Kaneko, M., The First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-ku, Osaka 553, Japan; Ohtani, M., The First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-ku, Osaka 553, Japan; Tagawa, K., The First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-ku, Osaka 553, Japan; Kawashima, Y., The First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-ku, Osaka 553, Japan
Abstract: Isolated canine hearts were preserved for 24 hours by either simple hypothermic storage in Collins' M solution (group 1, n = 7) or hypothermic perfusion with oxygenated modified Krebs solution (group 2, n = 7), followed in both cases by reperfusion with cross circulation. Myocardial biopsies taken consecutively during preservation and after reperfusion were analyzed for high energy phosphates (adenosine triphosphate [ATP], adenosine diphosphate [ADP], adenosine monophosphate [AMP], and creatine phosphate), their catabolites (inosine), and lactate. In group 1, ATP decreased from 23.7 ± 2.8 μmol/gm dry weight (mean ± standard deviation) at 0 hours to 5.6 ± 2.8 μmol/gm dry weight at the end of preservation. Creatine phosphate decreased and lactate increased significantly during 24 hours of preservation. The consumption rate of ATP appeared to have decreased after 18 hours of preservation. In group 2, ATP, creatine phosphate, and lactate remained at control levels during preservation. Coronary vascular resistance, however, increased significantly. After reperfusion functional measurements of the hearts in both groups did not vary significantly, despite the difference in myocardial ATP content (11.2 ± 4.9 μmol/gm dry weight in group 1 and 17.9 ± 3.9 μmol/gm dry weight in group 2; p < 0.05). Simple hypothermic storage manifested a limitation in terms of energy store compared with hypothermic perfusion, whereas the latter appeared to have a risk of possible myocardial damage caused by the perfusion itself.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate; animal experiment; coronary vascular resistance; dog; heart preservation; metabolism; methodology; nonhuman; organ culture; reperfusion; Animal; Comparative Study; Dogs; Energy Metabolism; Heart; Heart Function Tests; Heart Transplantation; Hypothermia, Induced; Lactates; Lactic Acid; Myocardium; Oxygen Consumption; Perfusion; Phosphates; Purines; Tissue Preservation; Vascular Resistance

Title: The self-generation mechanism of a laboratory scale saturated solar pond
Affiliations: Casali Institute of Applied Chemistry, School of Applied Science and Technology, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, 91904 Jerusalem, Israel; Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, 91904 Jerusalem, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Vitner, A., Casali Institute of Applied Chemistry, School of Applied Science and Technology, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, 91904 Jerusalem, Israel; Sarig, S., Casali Institute of Applied Chemistry, School of Applied Science and Technology, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, 91904 Jerusalem, Israel; Reisfeld, R., Department of Inorganic and Analytical Chemistry, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, 91904 Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: Laboratory simulation systems of saturated solar ponds using potash alum solutions were operated; the insulated columns 100 cm deep were heated at the bottom by heat exchangers with varying energy output. Self-generation of layered structure from homogeneous solution was observed. The temperature, density and supersaturation gradients, and the disappearance of convective waves indicated the relative stability of the layered structure. Attaining supersaturation of the surface zone, massive crystallization, and buildup of density gradient, which follows the temperature gradient, are the necessary conditions for the self-generation and self-maintenance of the laboratory pond. © 1988.

Title: HELIUM RESOURCES OF THE UNITED STATES, L987.
Source title: Information Circular - United States, Bureau of Mines
Affiliations: US Dep of the Interior, Washington,, DC, USA, US Dep of the Interior, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Miller, Richard, US Dep of the Interior, Washington,, DC, USA, US Dep of the Interior, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The helium resources base of the United States was estimated by the Bureau of Mines to be 1,040 Bcf as of January 1, 1987. These resources are divided into four categories in decreasing degree of assurance of their existence: (1) helium in storage and in proven natural gas reserves, 265 Bcf, (2) helium in probable natural gas resources, estimated at 228 Bcf, (3) helium in possible natural gas resources, estimated to be 320 Bcf, and (4) helium in speculative natural gas resources, 227 Bcf. These helium resources are further divided into depleting and nondepleting resources. The depleting resources are those associated with natural gasfields that are, or will be, produced for the natural gas they contain. Almost all of the helium in potential (probable, possible, and speculative) natural gas resources is included in this classification. These depleting resources are estimated to contain 951 Bcf of the total helium resource base. Helium resources contained in nondepleting natural gas resources, i. e. , those in shut-in, abandoned, or otherwise nonproducing natural gasfields, are estimated to total 53 Bcf.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES - United States; NATURAL GAS - Impurities; HELIUM RESOURCE ESTIMATES; HELIUM-BEARING NATURAL GAS; U. S. HELIUM RESERVES; HELIUM

Title: Carbohydrates for exercise: Dietary demands for optimal performance
Affiliations: Human Performance Laboratory, Ball State University, Muncie, IN 47306, United States
Authors with affiliations: Costill, D.L., Human Performance Laboratory, Ball State University, Muncie, IN 47306, United States
Abstract: Aside from the limits imposed by heredity and the physical improvements associated with training, no factor plays a bigger role in exercise performance than does nutrition. Since the mid-1930s, dietary carbohydrate (CHO) has been known to enhance performance, particularly during prolonged exercise. In these early studies, respiratory gas exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide exchange was first used to demonstrate that during intense exercise CHO serves as the primary fuel for the muscles. It was also observed that when subjects were fed diets rich in CHO they tended to have greater endurance and to derive more of their energy from CHO during steady-state exercise. The mechanisms underlying this shift toward CHO oxidation and enhanced performance have only recently been examined using the invasive measurements of muscle and liver glycogen and the employment of isotopes. The following review will attempt to show the important role played by endogenous and ingested CHO during muscle performance. Specific attention will be given to the influence of dietary sugar on muscle and liver glycogen storage.
Index Keywords: carbohydrate; glycogen; human; nutrition; performance; review; training

Title: Production and characterization of Mg-10 wt% Ni alloys for hydrogen storage

Abstract: Due to their relevance for hydrogen storage in metal hydrides, Mg-10 wt%Ni alloys were prepared and characterized from the point of view of their hydriding and dehydriding properties. The alloys were melted in a resistive heating furnace, under an inert gas atmosphere. For their characterization, a measuring equipment consisting of a high pressure reactor and a manifold, together with a computerized data acquisition system were used. Dehydriding isotherms-which are of high interest for the design of hydrogen storage systems-were obtained. The heat of dissociation of MgH2 was also accurately measured. © 1988.

Authors: Naman S.A., Said S.A., Hussein F.M.
Title: Photochemically assisted solar energy storage using eriochrome black-T in solar flat collector
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Center, Jadiriyah, P.O. Box 13026, Baghdad, Iraq, Iraq

Abstract: The criteria for cis-trans photoisomerization of eriochrome black-T (EBT) in the flat-plate collector system, which consists of endoergic photochemical reaction, has been investigated. The efficiencies of this collector in both summer and winter have been compared with blank (distilled water only) and colored liquid (non-isomer-dye-absorbing in the same wavelength range). The photochemical storage efficiency was found to be higher in winter than in summer. The optimum efficiency for this photoisomerization-thermal reversion cycle was found by varying with the pumping rate of the liquid to match the value of rate constant of cis to trans reaction. The stability of (EBT) has been studied under different environmental conditions. © 1988.
Index Keywords: COATINGS - Black Coatings; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; ERIOCHROME BLACK-T; FLAT PLATE COLLECTORS; ISOMER-COLLECTOR; SOLAR RADIATION

Abstract: Hydrogen was assumed to be produced by electrolytic water splitting at the north bank of the St Lawrence river in a port which had full access to the Atlantic Ocean throughout the year (City of Sept Isles). The energy transfer chain from production of hydroenergy in Canada over water electrolysis, ammonia formation and maritime transport to catalytic thermal cracking of ammonia in Hamburg is presented. The use of hydrogen to produce electricity in fuel cells to be used in city buses is investigated.

Title: Analytic model of a passive vapor transport heating system
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Neeper, D.A., Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: After reviewing passive systems for downward transprot of heat, this article presents an approximate mathematical model for one particular system in which refrigerant that is evaporated in a solar collector transports heat to a condenser located at some arbitrary elevation below the collector. The vapor pressure lifts the liquid from the condenser to an accumulator above the collector, from which it periodically flows into the collector. It is shown that the maximum energy delivery to the condenser can occur when the accumulator loses a specified amount of energy to the environment. Use of one of the ordinary refrigerants as the working fluid should be appropriate for passive space- or water-heating systems in which the collector can be several meters above the condenser. © 1988.
Index Keywords: REFRIGERANTS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; THERMAL STORAGE; VAPOR TRANSPORT HEATING SYSTEM; HEAT TRANSFER

Authors with affiliations: Bloom, Roger, Univ of Wisconsin, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, USA; Lotti, Robert C., Univ of Wisconsin, USA, Univ of Wisconsin, USA
Abstract: A pioneering, high-tech breakthrough in the storage of electrical energy for both utility and defense purposes is imminent with the development of a Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) systems. The Defense Nuclear Agency (DNA) of the Department of Defense (DOD) has recently contracted to develop the SMES engineering test model (ETM). Electrical utilities will be able to draw on this energy during periods of peak demand. SMES permits energy to be available instantaneously allowing utilities to regulate their systems to match load fluctuations and better control tie line flows with neighboring utilities.

Title: Performance of a solarium: An analytical study
Affiliations: Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, New Delhi, 110016, India; Physics Department, The University of Papua New Guinea, P.O. Box 320, Papua New Guinea
Authors with affiliations: Tiwari, G.N., Physics Department, The University of Papua New Guinea, P.O. Box 320, Papua New Guinea
Abstract: In this communication, a combination of phase change component material (PCCM) and water wall as a link wall in a solarium have been proposed and analysed for load levelling in the living space of the solarium. The choice of the aforesaid combination as a link wall has been made because of relatively high heat transfer coefficient of water and greater thermal energy storage potential of the combination. The relatively greater thermal storage potential of the proposed combination reduces the temperature swings in the living space and provides, thereby a comfortable living environment. Analytical expression for living space temperature as a function of climatic and system parameters as well as various heat transfer coefficients have been derived. Numerical calculations have been carried out for a typical day of North America (Boulder) for zero ventilation rate. It is concluded that the proposed combination as a link wall gives best thermal load levelling. © 1988.

Abstract: The objectives of this paper are: 1) To review the potential modes of operation of wind/diesel systems, 2) To discuss the major problem areas in typical systems, and 3) To review the current prospects for such systems. During the past several years, the development and application of wind/diesel systems has increased on a world-wide scale. This paper will also present a summary of recent international developments on the subject. A general wind diesel system consists of the following major components: 1) One or more wind turbines; 2) One or more diesel generator sets; 3) A consumer load; 4) An additional controllable load; 5) A storage system; and 6) A control unit.

Abstract: The presence and inhibitory activity of phenolic compounds in sorghum biomass were determined. Sorghum contains phenolic compounds at all stages of growth, with higher levels in leaves and glumes compared to stalks and caryopses. The phenolic compounds inhibited alpha- and gluco-amylase activity. Storage of sorghum resulted in increased levels of some phenolic acids. Levels of free phenolic compounds in ensiled sorghum leachate were sufficient to inhibit the hydrolysis of carbohydrates. The phenolic compounds from sorghum appeared to be detoxified during anaerobic digestion. © 1988.

Authors: Umemiya H., Shimawaki S., Kobayashi H.
Title: Field experiments of the thermal storage utilizing aquifer. Improvement in thermal recovery factor and payback of the investment
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Umemiya, H.; Shimawaki, S.; Kobayashi, H.
Abstract: For the thermal energy storage in an aquifer, the investigation of the structure of stratum at a moderate price is very difficult. Hence a field experiment is necessary to understand the general trend. A study of the thermal energy storage in an aquifer has been carried out on our site for 5 cycle. The experimental results showed the following. I) In the 5th cycle, the thermal recovery factor is expected to be 60%. II) IN the 5th cycle, the structure of the charge well was improved, reducing the heat losses from the casing pipe. The heat losses during charge were reduced to 2/5 of the previous one. III) The coefficient of performance of our solar system, based on the thermal storage utilizing aquifer, was 10.1. IV) The payback of the investment is 10 years when the recovery factor is 60% and the pump efficiency is 60%. © 1988, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.

Title: FUTURE ROLE OF FUEL CELLS IN TRANSPORTATION.
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: Georgetown Univ, Washington, DC, USA, Georgetown Univ, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Romano, S., Georgetown Univ, Washington, DC, USA, Georgetown Univ, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: Experiences of the past fifteen years indicate that we must ultimately replace the petroleum fueled internal combustion engines used for transportation with alternative systems. The two predominant drivers for this necessity are air quality and the finite supply of petroleum. It is obvious then, that something must be done in transportation to reverse the trend. The electric vehicle (EV) has been proposed as a means to accomplish this. But it can only succeed if we have a major replacement of the internal combustion engine (ICE) powered vehicle with the EV. To accomplish this the EV must be on a par with the ICE vehicle in terms of user acceptance. The key factor in market acceptance that has prevented the EV from competing with the ICE is its inability to provide unlimited range by rapid replenishment of the energy source. The battery electric vehicle, as presently configured cannot meet this criterion.
Index Keywords: AIR POLLUTION - Air Quality; INTERNAL COMBUSTION ENGINES; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; ELECTRIC VEHICLE; MARKET ACCEPTANCE; FUEL CELLS

Title: On the stability of calcium chloride hexahydrate in thermal storage systems
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, Institute of Advanced Studies, The Australian National University, Canberra, A.C.T., Australia, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Brandstetter, A., Department of Engineering Physics, Research School of Physical Sciences, Institute of Advanced Studies, The Australian National University, Canberra, A.C.T., Australia, Australia
Abstract: The long-term stability of calcium chloride hexahydrate phase change material, as a heat storage medium for solar and similar applications, was assessed in a 400-g nonstirred sample of formulated material. Accurate monitoring of enthalpy and temperature profiles over extended periods of daily melt/freeze cycling was achieved by a unique method of continuous thermal analysis. Results lead to the conclusion that in the presence of supercooling suppressants, such as strontium or barium salts and possibly sodium chloride, the formation of calcium chloride tetrahydrate can be inhibited totally by means of extra water above the hexahydrate composition. Heats of fusion and crystallization in excess of 200 kJ/kg have been routinely registered. © 1988.
Index Keywords: CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; SALTS; CALCIUM CHLORIDE HEXAHYDRATE; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; THERMAL STABILITY; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR PUMPED STORAGE PROJECTS.

Abstract: A variety of design, economic, power supply, and environmental factors are combining which will bring a resurgence to the interest in developing pumped storage projects in the early 1990's in certain regions of the country. This paper describes the likely suitability of pumped storage facilities in the 50 to 300 MW range to meet the capacity requirements of utilities seeking capacity additions in this range. A case study of a 120 MW pumped storage project in California scheduled for completion in the mid-1990's is presented in this paper with an explanation of how the above factors contributed to the owner's decision to pursue the project.

Authors with affiliations: Beasley, D.E., Clemson Univ, Clemson, SC, USA, Clemson Univ, Clemson, SC, USA; Torab, H., Clemson Univ, Clemson, SC, USA, Clemson Univ, Clemson, SC, USA; Kassouf, K., Clemson Univ, Clemson, SC, USA, Clemson Univ, Clemson, SC, USA
Abstract: The variation of temperature from a solar collector is a function of the sky conditions during a given day. This study examines the temperature distributions in a packed bed thermal storage unit which result from simple models of the variation in collector outlet temperature during an eight hour charging period. The temperature distribution in the storage bed is predicted as a function of time and distance along the flow direction using a finite-difference computational routine. The results of the study indicate that for a variety of possible swings in inlet temperature to the storage bed natural convective motion of the fluid phase may exist.

Abstract: The purpose of this work is to simulate the functioning of a collector-evaporator set operated during sunshine hours. This simulation covers the useful elements for the design of a solar installation. It proves the validity of the model of reconstitution of the meteorological data used as an interface. Pentane, acetone and hexane were used as the solvents to be treated. Meteorological model which utilizes meteorological data delivered each hour and sinusoidal model which approximates the instantaneous distribution of the solar flux by a sinusoidal function were employed.

Authors: Haas R.H., Breuer J., Hammen M.
Title: High-performance liquid chromatographic measurement of selected blood citric acid cycle intermediates
Source title: Journal of Chromatography B: Biomedical Sciences and Applications
Affiliations: Departments of Neurosciences and Pediatrics, University of California, San Diego, UCSD Medical Center, 225 Dickinson Street, San Diego, CA 92103, United States
Authors with affiliations: Haas, R.H., Departments of Neurosciences and Pediatrics, University of California, San Diego, UCSD Medical Center, 225 Dickinson Street, San Diego, CA 92103, United States; Breuer, J., Departments of Neurosciences and Pediatrics, University of California, San Diego, UCSD Medical Center, 225 Dickinson Street, San Diego, CA 92103, United States; Hammen, M., Departments of Neurosciences and Pediatrics, University of California, San Diego, UCSD Medical Center, 225 Dickinson Street, San Diego, CA 92103, United States
Abstract: We describe a high-performance liquid chromatographic (HPLC) method for analysis of the intermediates of the citric acid cycle. Using two Aminex HPX-87H columns in series at 36°C, the early eluting compounds cis-aconitate, oxaloacetate, α-ketoglutarate and citrate-isocitrate can be resolved. Acetonitrile is used for extraction of citric acid cycle intermediates from blood as interfering ultraviolet absorbing peaks are present with perchloric acid or trichloroacetic acid extraction. Acetonitrile extraction is compared with perchloric acid extraction of citric acid cycle intermediates from plasma. Low recovery of some organic acids from blood seems not to be due to enzymatic degradation. Storage of acetonitrile extracts in liquid nitrogen led to a small but significant decrease in pyruvate levels in human blood. However, significant changes in other organic acids were not seen. HPLC methodology allows study of the citric acid cycle in tissue samples as well as blood and promises to facilitate the investigation of human disorders of energy metabolism. © 1988.

Authors with affiliations: Jacob, K.T., Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India, Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India; Srikanth, S., Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India, Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India; Waseda, Y., Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India, Indian Inst of Science, Bangalore, India
Abstract: A knowledge of activities in liquid Ca-Al alloys is of interest in understanding the physical chemistry of aluminothermic reduction of calcium oxide in vacuum. During this process a Ca-Al alloy is formed which decreases the efficiency of utilization of Al in the reduction process. The phase diagram for the Ca-Al system shows an intermetallic phase Al//2Ca congruently melting at 1352K and Al//2Ca melting incongruently at 973 K. The intermetallic Al//2Ca has potential application as a high temperature hydrogen storage medium. Activities have been measured in this study using a combination of Knudsen effusion and distribution measurements at 1373 K.
Index Keywords: CALCIUM ALUMINUM ALLOYS - Molten; HYDROGEN - Storage; ACTIVITY; ALUMINOTHERMIC REDUCTION; CHEMICAL POTENTIAL; GIBBS ENERGY OF MIXING; INTERMETALLIC PHASES; STRUCTURE FACTOR; Liquid metals

Title: RACING WITH THE SUN.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In a race of solar-powered vehicles across Australia, the winner averaged 40 miles per hour and beat its nearest competitor by more than 600 miles. The first car to cross the finish line of the World Solar Challenge race, five and a half days later, was the General Motors Sunraycer. This paper describes the design, testing and performance of this car.
Index Keywords: FLUID DYNAMICS - Computation; SOLAR CELLS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; GENERAL MOTORS SUNRAYCER CAR; SATELLITE CELLS; SOLAR POWERED VEHICLE; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER MODULES FOR NASA's MANNED SPACE STATION.
Affiliations: NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Tatro, Charles A., NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA, NASA, Cleveland, OH, USA
Abstract: Two similar space power systems able to survive the low-earth orbit environment, are being considered for NASA's Manned Space Station (SS), scheduled to begin operation in the mid 1990's. The Space Station Electric Power System (EPS) is composed of Photovoltaic (PV) Power Modules, Solar Solar Dynamic (SD) Power Modules, and the Power Management and Distribution (PMAD) System. One EPS configuration will deliver 37. 5 kw of PV-based, utility-grade, ac power to SS users. A second 75 kwe PV-based EPS option is also being considered for SS deployment. The two EPS options utilize common modules and differ only in the total number of PV Power Modules used. Each PV Power Module supplies 18. 75 kwe of ac power and incorporates its own energy storage and thermal control. The focus of this paper is on the general requirements and the current preliminary design configuration of the Space Station PV Power Modules.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Space Applications; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Space Applications; SOLAR CELLS - Space Applications; PHOTOVOLTAIC POWER GENERATION SYSTEMS; SPACE SOLAR POWER; SPACE STATION; SATELLITES

Title: A note on microbial growth, protein and energy contents of stored goat feed pellets
Affiliations: Department of Genetics and Cellular Biology, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Institute of Advanced Studies, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Shaiful, A.A.A., Department of Genetics and Cellular Biology, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Mukherjee, T.K., Institute of Advanced Studies, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
Abstract: The effects of storing feed pellets in closed McCartney bottles, polythene bags and tin cans for 0, 10, 20 and 30 days on the growth of aerobic microorganisms and the protein and energy contents of the pellets were studied. The growth of microorganisms was not significantly affected by the storage container but was affected by the storage period (p < 0·01). A total of 39 dominant fungi, actinomycete and bacteria isolates showed that the distribution characteristic was dependent on storage period rather than storage container. Negative correlations were found between the counts of microorganisms and the protein and energy content over the storage period. Storage container and period had no significant effect on the energy content, but showed significant effect on the crude-protein content of the pellet during storage. © 1988.
Index Keywords: FUNGI; MICROORGANISMS; PROTEINS; ENERGY CONTENTS; FEEDSTUFFS; GOAT FEED PELLETS; MCCARTNEY BOTTLES; MICROBIAL GROWTH; AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

Title: Influence of Chemical Structures of Polyurethane Resins Molded by Reaction Injection Molding on Viscoelastic Properties at High Frequencies
Affiliations: Production Engineering Research Laboratory, Hitachi, Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, 244, Yokohama, Japan; Materials System Research Laboratory, Kanazawa Institute of Technology, 7-1 Ohgigaoka, Nonoichi, 921, Kanazawa, Japan; Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kouhoku-ku, 223, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Gotoh, M., Production Engineering Research Laboratory, Hitachi, Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, 244, Yokohama, Japan, Materials System Research Laboratory, Kanazawa Institute of Technology, 7-1 Ohgigaoka, Nonoichi, 921, Kanazawa, Japan, Faculty of Science and Technology, Keio University, 3-14-1 Hiyoshi, Kouhoku-ku, 223, Yokohama, Japan; Iida, M., Production Engineering Research Laboratory, Hitachi, Ltd., 292 Yoshida-cho, Totsuka-ku, 244, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: Dynamic viscoelastic properties of polyurethane resins molded by reaction injection molding (RIM) have been examined by forced oscillation method at 2~500 Hz. Polyurethane raw materials are aliphatic and aromatic polyols which have several mol numbers of PO(propylene oxide) adducts, and P-MDI (polymeric diphenyl methane diisocyanate). (1) The reciprocation law of time-temperature is useful to analyze the behavior of the dynamic storage modulus of polyurethane resins. (2) Above the glass transition temperature (Tg), activation energy derived from frequency dependency of dynamic storage modulus strongly depends on the existence of a benzene ring in the polyol and on thecrosslinking density of polyurethane resins. Below Tg these factors have little influence on the activation energy. (3) Increasing crosslinking density and adding benzene rings to polyols are effective ways to raise the Tg of polyurethane resins molded by RIM. Increasing crosslinking density would be obtained by decreasing mol numbers of PO adducts or by increasing functionalities of polyol. © 1988, The Society of Polymer Science, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Activation Energy; Crosslinking Density; Glass Transition Temperature; Isocyanate; Polyol; Polyurethane; Reaction Injection Molding; Viscoelastic Property

Title: DRY ROD CONSOLIDATION EXPERIENCE AT THE IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY.
Affiliations: Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho, Falls, ID, USA, Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hill, R.C., Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho, Falls, ID, USA, Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Mullen, C.K., Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho, Falls, ID, USA, Idaho Natl Engineering Lab, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: Research has been conducted into methods of handling and storing spent nuclear fuel from commercial reactors. Consolidating fuel can reduce the total volume of spent fuel and may reduce the cost of its handling and storage. The Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL) recently completed a U. S. Department of Energy (DOE)-sponsored project to investigate the feasibility of consolidating spent fuel in a hot cell. The consolidation operation was performed in air with the fuel in a horizontal position. The primary objective was to experimentally investigate some of the phenomena associated with dry fuel consolidation.
Index Keywords: CONTAINERS - Design; LEGISLATION; NUCLEAR REACTORS - Spent Fuels; DRY ROD CONSOLIDATION; IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY; STACKABILITY; NUCLEAR FUELS

Authors: Chaudoir D.W., Havens V.N., Heidenreich G.R.
Title: TECHNOLOGY UPDATE: SOLAR DYNAMIC ORGANIC RANKINE CYCLE POWER SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Chaudoir, D.W., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA; Havens, V.N., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA; Heidenreich, G.R., Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford,, IL, USA, Sundstrand Energy Systems, Rockford, IL, USA
Abstract: Solar dynamic power generating systems are being considered for the next generation of space platforms. NASA's Space Station, the most developed space platform concept, intends to add 50 kilowatts of solar dynamic power generation capability to the initial 75 kilowatts supplied by photovoltaics in the second phase of the program. To support the technical readiness of the solar dynamic organic Rankine cycle power system, a series of technical issues has been addressed through successful proof-of-concept demonstrations. The issues addressed and included in this presentation are: heat receiver development, thermal energy storage development, two-phase flow management, and working fluid thermal stability.

Authors with affiliations: Kolb, G.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Nikolai, U., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: Thermal performance tests have been performed on the molten salt thermal storage system located at the Central Receiver Test Facility (CRTF). The 7 MWht system is composed of a hot storage tank containing molten nitrate salt at a temperature of 566 C and a cold tank containing 288 C salt with associated valves and controls. The thermal performance of this system was evaluated and compared with three storage systems developed by the European solar community. Results of the comparison indicate that salt storage systems have higher efficiencies than a system employing an oil and iron storage medium.

Title: Bidirectional Associative Memories
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Systems, Signal, and Information Processing Institute, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kosko, B., Department of Electrical Engineering, Systems, Signal, and Information Processing Institute, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA 90089, United States
Abstract: Stability and encoding properties of two-layer nonlinear feedback neural networks are examined. Bidirectionality, forward and backward information flow, is introduced in neural nets to produce two-way associative search for stored associations (Ai, Bi). Passing information through M gives one direction; passing it through its transpose MT gives the other. A bidirectional associative memory (BAM) behaves as a heteroassociative content addressable memory (CAM), storing and recalling the vector pairs (A1, B1),-• Bm), where A ∊ {0,1}” and B ∊ {0,1}P, We prove that every n -by- p matrix M is a bidirectionally stable heteroassociative CAM for both binary/bipolar and continuous neurons ai and bj. When the BAM neurons are activated, the network quickly evolves to a stable state of two-pattern reverberation, or resonance. The stable reverberation corresponds to a system energy local minimum. Heteroassociative information is encoded in a BAM by summing correlation matrices. The BAM storage capacity for reliable recall is roughly m min (n, p). No more heteroassociative pairs can be reliably stored and recalled than the lesser of the dimensions of the pattern spaces {0,1}” and {0,1}P. The Appendix shows that it is better on average to use bipolar { -1,1} coding than binary {0,1} coding of heteroassociative pairs (Ai, Bi). BAM encoding and decoding are combined in the adaptive BAM, which extends global bidirectional stability to realtime unsupervised learning. Temporal patterns (A1,., Am) are represented as ordered lists of binary/bipolar vectors and stored in a temporal associative memory (TAM) n -by- n matrix M as a limit cycle of the dynamical system. Forward recall proceeds through M, backward recall through MT. Temporal patterns are stored by summing contiguous bipolar correlation matrices, XT1X2 +…+ XTm-1Xm, generalizing the BAM storage procedure. This temporal encoding scheme is seen to be equivalent to a form of Grossberg outstar avalanche coding for spatiotemporal patterns. The storage capacity is m = m1+…+ mk n, where mjis the length of the j th temporal pattern and n is the dimension of the spatial pattern space. Limit cycles (A1,…, Am, Al) are shown to be stored in local energy minima of the binary state space {0,1}n. © 1988 IEEE
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS, NONLINEAR; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL - Associative; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Matrix Algebra; BIDIRECTIONAL ASSOCIATIVE MEMORIES; HETEROASSOCIATIVE INFORMATION; NONLINEAR FEEDBACK NEURAL NETWORKS; REAL-TIME UNSUPERVISED LEARNING; TEMPORAL ASSOCIATIVE MEMORIES; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS

Title: High-Speed Snubberless Operation of GTOs Using a New Gate Drive Technique
Affiliations: N4768 Indian Point Road, Sullivan, WI 53178, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wirth, W.F., N4768 Indian Point Road, Sullivan, WI 53178, United States
Abstract: GTOs may be operated at currents well beyond the rated Itcsm without turn-off snubbers by use of a gate drive circuit that is capable of very high rates of rise of reverse gate current. This results in a very large, rectangular, unsnubbed, reverse-biased safe operating area (RBSOA) that extends to the Vdrxm on the voltage axis and beyond the Itcsm on the current axis. Storage time is reduced to a few tenths of a microsecond and the inductance required for paralleling is reduced by an order of magnitude. Elimination of the turn-off snubber capacitors allows protective circuit trip levels to be set closer to the device ratings and reduces the energy loss in the turn-on snubber. The size of the turn-on snubber inductor can be significantly reduced. High-frequency operation of GTOs becomes practical with this technique due to the short storage times and low external snubber losses. © 1988 IEEE
Index Keywords: CAPACITORS; ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS - Protection; GATE DRIVE CIRCUIT; GATE TURN-OFF (GTO) THYRISTOR; TURN-OFF SNUBBER CAPACITORS ELIMINATION; TURN-ON SNUBBER INDUCTOR; THYRISTORS

Abstract: The ventilation system design should take into account thermal loading; maintenance of the retrieval option and the separation of the development and emplacement ventilation circuits. An analysis was performed by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC's) contractor, Engineers International on the ventilation system design described in the Department of Energy's conceptual design for Nevada. The ventilation analysis is of a preliminary nature. The conclusions presented in this paper reflect the views of the authors and may not represent the views of the NRC. In this analysis, available Nevada Nuclear Waste Storage Investigation (NNWSI) ventilation design information was reviewed and a ventilation network analysis was performed.

Authors: Berkey Brian D., Pratt Thomas H., Williams George M.
Title: REVIEW OF LITERATURE RELATED TO HUMAN SPARK SCENARIOS.
Affiliations: Hercules Inc, Rocket Cent, WV, USA, Hercules Inc, Rocket Cent, WV, USA
Authors with affiliations: Berkey, Brian D., Hercules Inc, Rocket Cent, WV, USA, Hercules Inc, Rocket Cent, WV, USA; Pratt, Thomas H., Hercules Inc, Rocket Cent, WV, USA, Hercules Inc, Rocket Cent, WV, USA; Williams, George M., Hercules Inc, Rocket Cent, WV, USA, Hercules Inc, Rocket Cent, WV, USA
Abstract: This paper presents a summary of articles from the literature concerning human spark ignition scenarios. Two basic subjects areas are covered. These are articles related to charge generation, particularly those associated with clothing and textiles, and articles related to energy storage and discharge. The papers have been organized according to their primary subject. The key conclusions and recommendations from each of the cited articles are included, as well as a summary of conclusions drawn from the overall literature review.

Authors: Carvalho M.J., Collares-Pereira M., Cunha F.M., Vitorino C.
Title: An experimental comparison of operating strategies for solar water systems
Affiliations: LNETI-Departamento de Energias Renovaveis, Azinhaga dos Lameiros, Estrada do aco do Lumiar, 1699 Lisboa Codex, Portugal, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Carvalho, M.J., LNETI-Departamento de Energias Renovaveis, Azinhaga dos Lameiros, Estrada do aco do Lumiar, 1699 Lisboa Codex, Portugal, Portugal; Collares-Pereira, M., LNETI-Departamento de Energias Renovaveis, Azinhaga dos Lameiros, Estrada do aco do Lumiar, 1699 Lisboa Codex, Portugal, Portugal; Cunha, F.M., LNETI-Departamento de Energias Renovaveis, Azinhaga dos Lameiros, Estrada do aco do Lumiar, 1699 Lisboa Codex, Portugal, Portugal; Vitorino, C., LNETI-Departamento de Energias Renovaveis, Azinhaga dos Lameiros, Estrada do aco do Lumiar, 1699 Lisboa Codex, Portugal, Portugal
Abstract: Three identical DHW (Domestic Hot Water) solar energy systems are experimentally compared in terms of the amount of energy collected during two extended periods. The goal of the experiment is to compare three different modes of operating the systems: (1) a single-pass mode, in which the circulating fluid passes once and only once through the collector; (2) a conventional forced circulation multipass mode, in which storage contents passes many times through the collector during each day, and (3) a thermosyphon mode. It is shown that the single-pass system performs better than the other two, with the multipass system being the worst. The thermal advantage of the single-pass mode is specially significant on days with poor radiation and can be as high as 16%, in comparison with the multipass system, being on the average 7% better. The thermosyphon system is shown to perform slightly better than the multipass, although the 1.4% difference found is within the experimental errors. © 1988.
Index Keywords: TANKS - Heat Transfer; CONVENTIONAL FORCED CIRCULATION; DHW SYSTEM; DOMESTIC HOT WATER (DHW); SOLAR WATER SYSTEMS; THERMOSYPHON; WATER HEATERS

Authors with affiliations: El Osery, I.A., Nuclear Power Plants Authority, Nasr City, Egypt, Nuclear Power Plants Authority, Nasr City, Egypt
Abstract: The potential of energy electricity is increasing peak and intermediate electric demands for electricity are increasing due to the present world trend toward increased dependence on nuclear and other unconventional energy sources for electric power production. The theory of a proposed mathematical model for economic analysis of advanced energy storage application in electric utility systems is calculated. A sensitivity analysis of the effective breakeven capital cost contributing key parameters is carried out. These key parameters include the plant capacity factor, peaking unit fuel cost, peaking unit conversion efficiency, storage system charging energy cost, and storage system conversion efficiency.

Title: High pressure gas driven liquid metal mhd homopolar generator
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: Toshiba R and D Center, Toshiba Corp, Ukishima-cho, Kawasaki-ku, Kawasaki, 210, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Itoh, Y., Toshiba R and D Center, Toshiba Corp, Ukishima-cho, Kawasaki-ku, Kawasaki, 210, Japan
Abstract: A liquid metal MHD homopolar generator is proposed to be used as a high repetition rate pulsed power supply. In the generator, the thermal energy stored in a high pressure gas (He) reservoir is rapidly converted into kinetic energy of a rotating liquid metal (NaK) cylinder which is contracted by a gas driven annular free piston. The rotational kinetic energy is converted into electrical energy by making use of the homopolar generator principle. The conversion efficiency is calculated to be 47% in generating electrical energy of 20 kJ/pulse (1.7 MW peak power) at a repetition rate of 7 Hz. From the viewpoint of energy storage, the high pressure gas reservoir with a charging pressure of 15 MPa is considered to “electrically” store the energy at a density of 10 MJ/m[1]. © 1988 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Electrical energy; Energy conversion; Energy storage; High pressure gas; Homopolar generator; Liquid metals; MHD generators; Nuclear fusion; Otto cycle; Pulsed power

Abstract: The performance of fluoride salt and metallic thermal energy storage materials are compared in terms of basic performance as applied to solar dynamic power generation. Specific performance considerations include uniformity of cycle inlet temperature, peak cavity temperature, TES utilization and system weights. Also investigated were means of enhancing the thermal conductivity of the salts and its effect on the system performance.

Authors with affiliations: Vasiliev, L.L., A. V. Luikov Heat and Mass Transfer Institute, the BSSR Academy of Sciences, Minsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Different versions of heat pipe ground heating and cooling devices are considered. Solar energy, biomass, ground stored energy, recovered heat of industrial enterprises and ambient cold air are used as energy and cold sources. Heat pipe utilization of air in winter makes it possible to design accumulators of cold and ensures deep freezing of ground in order to increase its mechanical strength when building roadways through the swamps and ponds in Siberia. Long-term underground heat storage systems are considered, in which the solar and biomass energy is accumulated and then transferred to heat dwellings and greenhouse, as well as to remove snow from roadways with the help of heat pipes and solar collectors. © 1988.

Authors: Vanderborgh E., Spirio A., Huff J.R.
Title: METHANOL FUEL CELL SYSTEMS FOR TRANSPORT APPLICATIONS.
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NY,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vanderborgh, E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NY,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NY, USA; Spirio, A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NY,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NY, USA; Huff, J.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NY,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NY, USA
Abstract: The transportation fuel sector, that now accounts for significant energy usage (more than 25% in the US), will be increasingly supplied from natural gas. Natural gas reserves are large worldwide, and this fuel is now utilized to produce methanol, a liquid fuel easily transported and stored. Methanol is also synthesized from coal, and countries with abundant coal reserves (the US, for example) can move toward coal-derived methanol as a transportation fuel. Thus, during the next decades, methanol can displace quantities of petroleum used within the transportation sector. Methanol is useful in internal combustion engines, either as a neat or blended (methanol-gasoline) fuel. However, methanol can also serve to power fuel cells, either directly with anodic oxidation of methanol, or indirectly, with methanol first converted to hydrogen, and that gas fed to a hydrogen-air fuel cell device that provides electrical power for traction motors.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Energy Resources; METHANOL - Processing; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Energy Utilization; COAL-DERIVED METHANOL; HYDROGEN-AIR FUEL CELL; METHANOL FUEL CELL; FUEL CELLS

Title: INVESTIGATION OF LOW-TEMPERATURE PHASE-CHANGE MATERIALS FOR SHORT-TERM ENERGY STORAGE IN GREENHOUSES.
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Nova Scotia,, Halifax, NS, Can, Technical Univ of Nova Scotia, Halifax, NS, Can
Authors with affiliations: Mcmullin, M., Technical Univ of Nova Scotia,, Halifax, NS, Can, Technical Univ of Nova Scotia, Halifax, NS, Can; Ben-Abdallah, N., Technical Univ of Nova Scotia,, Halifax, NS, Can, Technical Univ of Nova Scotia, Halifax, NS, Can
Abstract: Several materials have been investigated to determine their suitability for use as phase-change energy storage media at low temperatures. The most feasible proved to be calcium chloride hexahydrate, and further tests were carried out on this substance to determine the effect of adding extra water on the melting point and latent heat of fusion of the mixture. The results show the melting point is lowered and the heat of fusion increased as the level of excess water increases. Benefits and limitations of 'excess water' mixture are presented and discussed.
Index Keywords: CALCIUM COMPOUNDS - Phase Transitions; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS - Phase Transitions; GREENHOUSES - Energy Storage; PHASE-CHANGE MATERIALS; SHORT-TERM ENERGY STORAGE; MATERIALS

Title: HIGH TC MATERIALS IN THE ELECTRIC NETWORK WHY OR WHY NOT? .
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: US DOE, US DOE
Authors with affiliations: Klein, Kenneth W., US DOE, US DOE
Abstract: The new high temperature superconducting ceramics could revolutionize the design of some electrical power systems if major obstacles are cleared. The obstacles include improving the critical current density with applied magnetic fields, improving mechanical properties and chemical stability. For over a decade, the Office of Energy Storage and Distribution (OESD) has supported three applications of superconducting materials: superconducting generator; superconducting transmission cable; and superconducting magnetic energy storage (SEMS). The future prospects for these and other power system applications depend, first and foremost, on the material properties of the superconductor. For most power applications, the critical current density is the crucial property. An understanding of the properties of the high temperature materials will suggest which applications may be the easiest to realize and which may have the greatest potential. This desired understanding can help formulate research goals and priorities.
Index Keywords: CERAMIC MATERIALS - Mechanical Properties; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS; HIGH TEMPERATURE ENGINEERING; SUPERCONDUCTING CABLES; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETS - Energy Storage; CHEMICAL STABILITY; CRITICAL CURRENT DENSITY; HIGH TC MATERIALS; SUPERCONDUCTING MATERIALS

Title: High K+ elevates cytosolic free Ca concentration due to mobilization from internal storage sites in rat parotid cells
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology -- Part A: Physiology
Affiliations: Department of Pharmacology, Sapporo Medical College, S. 1, W. 17, Sapporo 060, Japan. Telephone: 011-611-2111
Authors with affiliations: Haruo, T., Department of Pharmacology, Sapporo Medical College, S. 1, W. 17, Sapporo 060, Japan. Telephone: 011-611-2111; Hideyo, O., Department of Pharmacology, Sapporo Medical College, S. 1, W. 17, Sapporo 060, Japan. Telephone: 011-611-2111
Abstract: 1. 1. Effects of high K+ on cytosolic free Ca concentration ([Ca2+]i) in rat parotid cells were studied using quin2. 2. 2. High K+ elevated [Ca2+]i in a dose-dependent manner in normal and Ca-free media. The elevation of [Ca2+], induced by high K+ was less in the latter medium. 3. 3. High K+ depolarized the membrane in a dose-dependent manner in normal and Ca-free media. 4. 4. Although monensin increased [Ca2+]i, high K+ did not affect 22Na uptake into cells. 5. 5. After treatment with oligomycin, high K+ but not carbachol raised [Ca2+]i. 6. 6. We suggest that high K+ increases [Ca2+]i due to mobilizing Ca2+ from the intracellular storage site which does not need energy. © 1988.

Authors: Henry M.L., Sommer B.G., Ferguson R.M.
Title: Improved immediate function of renal allografts with belzer perfusate
Affiliations: Department of Surgery, Division of Transplantation, The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Henry, M.L., Department of Surgery, Division of Transplantation, The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States; Sommer, B.G., Department of Surgery, Division of Transplantation, The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States; Ferguson, R.M., Department of Surgery, Division of Transplantation, The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States
Abstract: The characteristics of 254 cadaveric kidneys were evaluated and the incidence of immediate function identified. The Beizer perfusate was used primarily (n=140) and secondarily (n=14) in combination with pulsatile machine perfusion. These two groups were compared with a previous group of kidneys machine-perfused with silica gel (cryoprecipitated human plasma). The incidence of immediate function of the group primarily perfused with Beizer perfusate was statistically significantly improved over that of the silica gel. The secondarily perfused Beizer group, “imported” kidneys previously preserved with simple cold storage, had notably longer periods of preservation and higher resistances on the machine. However, 100% of this group functioned immediately. Other findings in this study show that the Beizer perfusate allows for improved parenchymal function posttransplant, as noted by a more rapid clearance of serum creatinine posttransplant. When comparing the immediate function group with those suffering early dysfunction, there is a statistically significant increased resistance on the machine in the latter group. This allows for prediction of immediate function based on perfusion characteristics of the kidney. The Beizer perfusate, composed of metabolic substrates for high-energy phosphate production, improves the incidence of immediate function in machine-perfused kidneys, as well as improved qualitative function posttransplant. It also is effective as a “rescue” mechanism in previously simple cold—stored (ATP-depleted) kidneys. © 1988 by The Williams & Wilkins Co.

Abstract: This article deals with performance assessment of thermal energy collection and storage subsystem of a 100-kW solar power station in the desert area of Kuwait. An energy analysis of the solar energy collection system was made accounting for various thermal loss as in the collector field. Results have been compared with the respective design and expected values. Comparison shows a substantial reduction in mirror reflectivity and an increase in piping thermal losses. These results along with the analyses are presented and discussed here. © 1988.

Abstract: A short review is given of the high-energy physics studied at electron-positron colliders. The principles of hadronic energy measurement in experimental high-energy physics are introduced. The design and operation of the DELPHI Hadron Calorimeter are given an introductory treatment.

Abstract: The f-chart and extended f-chart design methods were used to predict the performance of 17 systems from the Solar in Federal Buildings program and the predictions were compared to the measured performance. These non-standard configurations are summarized, and methods are suggested for extending the design methods to account for some of these differences. TRNSYS simulations were used in some cases to study the effect of the configurations on system performance.

Title: Effect of some elements on oxygen reduction and hydrogen evolution at lead-acid battery negative plates
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Maja, M., Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy; Penazzi, N., Dipartimento di Scienza dei Materiali e Ingegneria Chimica, Politecnico di Torino, Turin, Italy
Abstract: The effects which the impurities As, Bi, Cd, Co, Cr, Ni, Sb, Se, Sn and Te have on the processes of hydrogen evolution and oxygen reduction on the negative plates of lead-acid batteries have been tested. This was done by measuring the gas pressure in sealed vessels containing cycled, wet, negative plates. The addition of As, Co, Ni, Sb and Te to the electrolyte used during the cycling increases the hydrogen ion discharge rate, whereas Cr, Bi and Sn have the opposite effect. In the case of oxygen, As, Bi, Ni, Sb, Se, Sn, and Te promote its reduction while Co and Cr suppress it. The effect of impurity concentration has also been considered. © 1988.

Authors with affiliations: El-Refaee, M.M., Mechanical Engeneering Department, King Abduaziz University, P.O. Box 9027, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia; Megahed, I.E., Mechanical Engeneering Department, King Abduaziz University, P.O. Box 9027, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: In the present work, the numerical model developed earlier by the same authors [5] is refined and recast in non-dimensional form. The refined model is calibrated with recent experiments at different bed air-inlet temperatures. Excellent agreement between the numerical results and experiments is obtained. The refined model is then used to conduct an extensive parametric study. The objectives of the parametric study are: (i) to determine the effect of the non-dimensional parameters (α2, α3 and α4) on the bed performance; (ii) to indicate the conditions required for favourable bed operation, and (iii) to compare the fluidized-bed performance with a small-particle packed bed performance. The numerical results are presented as time-histories of average bed temperature ( {Mathematical expression}) and bed efficiency (η). The performance histories are given for different value of each parameter (α2, α3, and α4). The study shows that the fluidized bed behaves favourably for α2 < 10, α3> 30 and α4 < 10. Moreover, it was concluded that the small particle packed bed, in general, offers better performance behaviour over a fluidized bed having the same bed size and heat input. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL EQUIPMENT - Fluidized Beds; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; FLUIDIZED BED THERMAL STORAGE; PARAMETRIC STUDY; TWO PHASE MODEL; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Effect of storage thermal behavior in seasonal storage solar heating systems
Affiliations: Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Lund, P.D., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland
Abstract: An analytical methodology has been developed to investigate the effects of storage operational strategies (or, equivalently, stratification) on the performance of a seasonal storage solar heating system with a water storage. The method is based on a relative comparison between a thermally stratified and well-mixed storage system representing probable extreme outcomes of the subsystem-to-storage loop control strategies. The effects are incorporated into a set of performance reduction factors that describe maximum changes in the solar collector yield, storage losses and solar fraction due to storage operational mode. The study indicates that the storage thermal behavior could in the worst case affect the yearly solar fraction by a factor of 2, but most likely a maximum value from 1.35 to 1.6 could be expected. © 1988.

Title: TOTAL ENERGY DEMAND IN THE ALL-ELECTRIC HOUSE OF 2010.
Affiliations: NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth, NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth
Authors with affiliations: van Wunnik, A.W.M., NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth, NV KEMA, Arnhem, Neth
Abstract: Electricity is needed in houses for lighting and appliances; heat is needed for space heating and the provision of hot tapwater. However, even the heat demand can be translated in terms of a demand for electricity. The four different types of installation dealt with in the present study are radiators, accumulation heaters, central air-heating with a heat pump for ventilation air and central air-heating with heat storage and a heat pump for ventilation air. The total energy demand for a house then follows from the sum of the electricity demand for space heating, for the preparation of hot tapwater and for lighting and appliances. The average total energy demand in an all-electric house in the year 2010 was determined, with the various combinations of different applications assumed to be in use simultaneously, to vary from less than 500 kW up to about 2200 kW.

Abstract: In this communication, a steady state analysis of a phase change component material (PCCM) collection-cum-storage walls/roof system has been presented by incorporating the effect of water flow through a parallel plate placed at the liquid and solid interface. The effect of various parameters, i.e. fraction of melted region, walls/roof thickness, flow rate and latent heat of fusion of PCCM on heat flux entering the air conditioned room has been studied in detail. Numerical calculations have been made for two typical days at Delhi (18 June 1983 and 18 January 1984). The following conclusions have been made: (i) thermal load levelling decreases with an increase of the fraction of melted region and vice versa for total thickness of walls/roof; and (ii) phase shift of 10 h is observed for 40-50% fraction of melted region for walls/roof thickness of 0.10 m. © 1988.

Title: ICE THERMAL STORAGE: SYSTEM SELECTION AND DESIGN.
Affiliations: Baltimore Aircoil Co, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Baltimore Aircoil Co, Baltimore, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: McCullough, J.M., Baltimore Aircoil Co, Baltimore, MD,, USA, Baltimore Aircoil Co, Baltimore, MD, USA
Abstract: Major changes in rate structures in the electric power industry are making ice thermal storage applications more attractive to engineers and building owners. Thermal storage systems minimize energy cost by generating cooling capacity at off-peak times and storing it for future use. Cooling load applications that can benefit from thermal storage are office buildings, schools and college buildings, religious institutions, laboratories, large retail stores, libraries, museums, and public use areas of hotels (such as meeting rooms). Thermal storage also can be used for many industrial processes, such as occur in dairies, breweries and other plants with batch cooling cycles. Another thermal storage concept involving phase change materials holds promise for the future. Ice storage has an advantage over chilled water storage since the basis for storage is the latent heat of fusion of water, which is 144 Btu/lb. 'Full storage' and 'partial storage' systems are described.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING; BUILDINGS - Cooling; CHURCHES - Air Conditioning; REFRIGERATION; THEATERS - Air Conditioning; CHILLED WATER STORAGE; FULL STORAGE SYSTEMS; ICE THERMAL STORAGE; PARTIAL STORAGE SYSTEMS; THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEMS; ICE

Title: A simplified model for the analysis of a phase-change material-based, thermal energy storage system
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kondepudi, S., Mechanical Engineering Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Somasundaram, S., Mechanical Engineering Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States; Anand, N.K., Mechanical Engineering Department, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843, United States
Abstract: The concept of a phase-change material-based, thermal energy storage system is often used for different applications. A theoretical model to determine the thermal and fluid flow characteristics of a thermal energy storage system using a phase-change material has been developed. The model can be used to predict the energy storage behavior of different phase-change materials used with different heat transfer fluids, flow geometries, flow rates and temperatures. Results have been obtained for the case where the phase-change material is Na2SO4·10H2O (Glauber's salt) and the heat transfer fluid is water. The variation of the dimensionless temperatures of the fluid and the solid, and the molten fraction of the solid during the phase change process, with dimensionless time, for different values of Biot number, Stefan number, and the flow parameter have been determined. A discussion of the results obtained and the conclusions drawn from them are also given. © 1988.

Abstract: The Foster Wheeler Energy Application (FWEA) Modular Vault Dry Store (MVDS) is a dry storage concept for the storage of all types of irradiated reactor fuel. Abstract: A thermal analysis was performed of a thermal energy storage canister of a type suggested for use in a solar receiver for an orbiting Brayton cycle power system. The chief motivation for the study is the prediction of vapor void effects on temperature profiles and the identification of possible differences between ground test data and projected behavior in microgravity.

Affiliations: Arizona Public Service Co, Phoenix,, AZ, USA, Arizona Public Service Co, Phoenix, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Weber, E.R., Arizona Public Service Co, Phoenix,, AZ, USA, Arizona Public Service Co, Phoenix, AZ, USA
Abstract: Commercialization of solar thermal central receiver (STCR) power plants have been hampered by the first plant costs. Substantial technical advances have been made in the application of molten salt technology to STCR plants, but the hurdle of high first plant cost remains. In the Utility Solar Central Receiver Study, performed by Arizona Public Service, a key issue was evaluation of technical and economic feasibility of central receiver plant modularization. Two types of modularization were considered.

Title: IMPACT OF END-USER HARDWARE OPERATIONAL SPECIFICATIONS ON WIND/DIESEL POWER SYSTEM DESIGN.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Meridian Corp, Alexandria, VA, USA, Meridian Corp, Alexandria, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Borgo, P.A., Meridian Corp, Alexandria, VA, USA, Meridian Corp, Alexandria, VA, USA
Abstract: A Hybrid Power Simulation Model (HYSIM) is discussed. The model simulates the hourly performance of a power system consisting of any combination of wind generators, diesel gensets, and batteries to satisfy constant or variable electrical loads. An example is presented for a stand-alone wind/diesel/battery-powered reverse-osmosis seawater desalination system for a small village application. The selected cost-effective combination of power system component sizes is compared with that resulting from a second analysis which considers the operating flexibility of the end-use hardware in the overall operating strategy. The final design consists of a two-stage reverse-osmosis (RO) system to reduce operating pressure and an interstage water storage to maximize the use of the wind energy component over the more expensive battery storage.

Title: Power potential from ocean currents for hydrogen production
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lodhi, M.A.K., Department of Physics, Texas Tech University, Lubbock, TX 79409, United States
Abstract: The transport energy of world ocean currents is briefly surveyed. As a case study concentration has been made on the Florida currents between Miami, Florida and Bahamas. Over a region of 60 km × 10 km × 200 m power in the range of 22 to 37 GW is predicted to be produced at about a cost of 1.1¢ per kWh. The adverse features in the ocean environment have been briefly discussed and taken in due consideration. However, a word of caution is expressed that the estimation of power production and energy cost from the Florida Current, or for that matter, from any ocean current, should not be taken any more seriously than the uncertainty factors involved in fluctuations occurring in ocean currents. The amount of power extracted from the Florida Current is well within its fluctuation limits as observed and estimated over years. Thus the power extracted is no threat to the environment. The storage, transportation and end-use of this large amount of energy is argued in favor of hydrogen. The gaseous and liquid hydrogen are both recommended. The cost of hydrogen production is comparable to conventional fuel cost. © 1988.

Abstract: The air solar heating system installed in Module 6 at the Alberta Home Heating Facility has an 11-m2 double-glazed, south-facing solar collector tilted at 68°, a 2-m3 rock storage unit, one air handling unit, motorized dampers, a two-stage electric furnace, and a system controller. The performance of the system was calculated by comparing the difference in electric power required for Module 6 and Module 5, a module of similar construction, and using the measured solar energy collected and the electric power required by Module 6. The monthly solar fraction ranged from 0 to 70%. The dynamic behavior of the solar collector was also studied. © 1988.

Authors: Birge R.R., Einterz C.M., Knapp H.M., Murray L.P.
Title: The nature of the primary photochemical events in rhodopsin and isorhodopsin
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Birge, R.R., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 15213, United States; Einterz, C.M., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 15213, United States; Knapp, H.M., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 15213, United States; Murray, L.P., Department of Chemistry, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 15213, United States
Abstract: The nature of the primary photochemical events in rhodopsin and isorhodopsin is studied by using low temperature actinometry, low temperature absorption spectroscopy, and intermediate neglect of differential overlap including partial single and double configuration interaction (INDO-PSDCI) molecular orbital theory. The principal goal is a better understanding of how the protein binding site influences the energetic, photochemical, and spectroscopic properties of the bound chromophore. Absolute quantum yields for the isorhodopsin (I) to bathorhodopsin (B) phototransformation are assigned at 77 K by using the rhodopsin (R) to bathorhodopsin phototransformation as an internal standard (phi R----B = 0.67). In contrast to rhodopsin photochemistry, isorhodopsin displays a wavelength dependent quantum yield for photochemical generation of bathorhodopsin at 77 K. Measurements at seven wavelengths yielded values ranging from a low of 0.089 +/- 0.021 at 565 nm to a high of 0.168 +/- 0.012 at 440 nm. An analysis of these data based on a variety of kinetic models suggests that the I----B phototransformation encounters a small activation barrier (approximately 0.2 kcal mol-1) associated with the 9-cis----9-trans excited-state torsional-potential surface. The 9-cis retinal chromophore in solution (EPA, 77 K) has the smallest oscillator strength relative to the other isomers: 1.17 (all-trans), 0.98 (9-cis), 1.04 (11-cis), and 1.06 (13-cis). The effect of conformation is quite different for the opsin-bound chromophores. The oscillator strength of the lambda max absorption band of I is observed to be anomalously large (1.11) relative to the lambda max absorption bands of R (0.98) and B (1.07). The wavelength-dependent photoisomerization quantum yields and the anomalous oscillator strength associated with isorhodopsin provide important information on the nature of the opsin binding site. Various models of the binding site were tested by using INDO-PSDCI molecular orbital theory to predict the oscillator strengths of R, B, and I and to calculate the barriers and energy storage associated with the photochemistry of R and I for each model. Our experimental and theoretical investigation leads to the following conclusions: (a) The counterion (abbreviated as CTN) is not intimately associated with the imine proton in R, B, or I. The counterion lies underneath the plane of the chromophore in R and I, and the primary chromophore-counterion electrostatic interactions involve C15-CTN and C13-CTN. These interactions are responsible for the anomalous oscillator strength of I relative to R and B.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 400 WORDS) © 1988, The Biophysical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: isorhodopsin; rhodopsin; unclassified drug; article; photochemistry

Title: NEW APPROACHES TO OVERCOMING KINETIC LIMITATIONS OF LATENT CATALYSTS FOR THE CURING OF HIGH SOLIDS COATINGS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Water-borne and Higher-solids Coatings Symposium
Affiliations: Ciba-Geigy Corp, Ardsley, NY, USA, Ciba-Geigy Corp, Ardsley, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gatechair, Leslie R., Ciba-Geigy Corp, Ardsley, NY, USA, Ciba-Geigy Corp, Ardsley, NY, USA
Abstract: Significant efforts continue in the development of catalysts for improved curing of higher solids coatings. Such studies are needed because energy concerns dictate that future paints and coatings will have lower emissions combined with reduced curing temperatures. Although some current technologies can be cured adequately under low temperatures, this reactivity is obtained at the expense of pot life. This paper describes recent efforts to develop a latent catalyst for acrylic-melamine high solids coatings which is unreactive under typical storage conditions, but can be thermally or photochemically deblocked to produce p-toluene sulfonic acid. Acrylic melamine coatings were formulated containing thermally deblockable acid catalysts and a development catalyst, benzoin-tosylate. Formulated coatings were stored at elevated temperatures to compare package stability, and cured at various temperatures with and without irradiation. The curing efficiency of the thermally deblocked catalyst was surprisingly high, compared to conventional acid catalysts.
Index Keywords: ACRYLICS - Curing; CATALYSTS - Acids; MELAMINE - Alkylation; ACRYLIC-MELAMINE COATINGS; COVALENTLY BLOCKED CATALYSTS; HIGH SOLIDS COATINGS; LATENT CATALYSTS; PHOTOCHEMICALLY DEBLOCKED CATALYSTS; THERMALLY DEBLOCKABLE ACID CATALYSTS; COATINGS
