Authors: Browne S.H., Neill D.R., Takahashi P.K.
Title: The Hawaii hydrogen from renewable energy program
Affiliations: Hawaii Natural Energy Institute, University of Hawaii, 2540 Dole Street, Holmes 246, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Authors with affiliations: Browne, S.H., Hawaii Natural Energy Institute, University of Hawaii, 2540 Dole Street, Holmes 246, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States; Neill, D.R., Hawaii Natural Energy Institute, University of Hawaii, 2540 Dole Street, Holmes 246, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States; Takahashi, P.K., Hawaii Natural Energy Institute, University of Hawaii, 2540 Dole Street, Holmes 246, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen and renewable energy are an ideal combination that can help satisfy mankind's future energy needs. The abundance of Hawaii's natural energy resources makes the state a model laboratory for developing strategies using hydrogen and renewable energy to achieve greater independence from imported oil. This paper discusses opportunities for hydrogen use in the near- to long-term future. Three categories of hydrogen utilization exist in Hawaii: chemical (methanol and ammonia), electrical (storage and generation), and transportational (space, aircraft, and ground). Hydrogen can be a bridge transporting energy from an energy-abundant island to an energy-deficient island. In time, it may even provide Hawaii with the means to export energy. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES - Hawaii; HYDROGEN FUELS; BALANCE OF TRADE; ENERGY EXPORTING; HAWAII NATURAL ENERGY INSTITUTE; RENEWABLE ENERGY PROGRAM; SURPLUS ENERGY; HYDROGEN

Title: ANALYSIS OF ENERGY USE AND CONTROL CHARACTERISTICS OF A LARGE VARIABLE SPEED DRIVE CHILLER SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Mitchell, John, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
Abstract: The goal of this project was to develop general methodologies useful to engineers and plant managers for designing, retrofitting, and controlling the equipment in large central chilled water systems. The methodologies are in the form of mathematical models of equipment, optimal control algorithms for systems with and without chilled water storage, and general guidelines for design and control. The performance and control characteristics of the cooling system at the Dallas/Fort Worth airport provided the base for this study. This particular system has a large data acquisition system, with a database that was invaluable in developing and validating computer simulation models of the equipment.
Index Keywords: CONTROL EQUIPMENT - Optimization; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Computer Simulation; CENTRIFUGAL CHILLER; COMPONENT BASED SIMULATION PROGRAMS; VARIABLE-SPEED CAPACITY CONTROL; WATER COOLING SYSTEMS

Authors: Malt A.P.J., Clarke G.D., Robinson P.E.
Title: COMPUTER-BASED SUPERVISORY CONTROL AND ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR THE CITY OF CAPE TOWN.
Source title: IEE Proceedings C: Generation Transmission and Distribution
Affiliations: Merz & McLellan, Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl, Merz & McLellan, Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Malt, A.P.J., Merz & McLellan, Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl, Merz & McLellan, Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl; Clarke, G.D., Merz & McLellan, Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl, Merz & McLellan, Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl; Robinson, P.E., Merz & McLellan, Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl, Merz & McLellan, Newcastle upon Tyne, Engl
Abstract: Cape Town City Council is responsible for the supply of electricity to the city area. To achieve this, the council owns and operates thermal and pumped-storage power stations and extensive hv transmission and lv distribution networks. Power is also purchased from the national supply authority. Prior to the introduction of the control system described limited supervisory control and data acquisition facilities existed to provide some degree of remote control for the network. In addition to duties associated with supervision of the hv and lv networks, the control centre operators were also responsible for energy management involving generator scheduling and control, and load-shedding when required. To assist the operators in their duties a new computer-based control centre has been developed. Because of the unusual mix of power sources special software had to be developed for energy management purposes. Descriptions are given of the functional and practical aspects of the control centre, and of associated hardware and software facilities and also some commissioning experiences.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - South Africa; Energy management; CAPE TOWN CITY; COMMISSIONING EXPERIENCES; CONTROL CENTER; GENERATOR SCHEDULING; SUPERVISORY CONTROL; Electric power distribution

Title: Low-profile solar water heaters: The mirror booster problem revisited
Affiliations: Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Faiman, D., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel; Zemel, A., Applied Solar Calculations Unit, Jacob Blaustein Institute for Desert Research, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, Sede Boqer Campus, 84993, Israel
Abstract: We discuss the use of a plane mirror, attached to the elevated storage tank of a thermosiphon solar water heater, in order to lower the total profile of the system. The discussion includes a critical review of some of the simplifying assumptions that have been made by previous authors who have proposed the use of mirror boosters in order to enhance the energy collection of flat-plate receivers. © 1988.
Index Keywords: MIRRORS; WATER HEATERS - Solar; MIRROR BOOSTER; SOLAR WATER HEATERS; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: TOOLS AND TECHNIQUES FOR EVALUATING DEMAND-SIDE MANAGEMENT OPTIONS.
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: Decision Focus Inc, Decision Focus Inc
Authors with affiliations: Barrager, Stephen M., Decision Focus Inc, Decision Focus Inc
Abstract: At the urging of regulators, stockholders and customers, electric utilities are offering a variety of new products. These products include conservation, direct load control, electric space heat, heat and cool storage, interruptible rates and real time pricing. Regulators are urging companies to sell conservation instead of building new plants. Utility stockholders also support many of these products as a way of avoiding new risky investments and improving the productivity of their assets. Customers are asking for many of these products hoping to reduce their energy costs and increase their competitiveness. Although the electric power system is unique in many ways, there is nothing new about the process of selecting and designing products. Product offerings in any industry have always faced at least two important economic tests: (1. ) The marketability test. (2. ) The profitability test. These tests are applied on a daily basis in virtually every business. We are rapidly reaching the point where they can be applied effectively in the electric power industry.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS; MANAGEMENT SCIENCE; MARKETING; DEMAND-SIDE MANAGEMENT OPTIONS; MARKETABILITY TEST; PROFITABILITY TEST; ELECTRIC UTILITIES

Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 41 papers. The following topics are dealt with: high-frequency power conversion; computer aids and simulation tools for power electronics engineers; motion control; nonlinear magnetic circuits; power system considerations; power supply design, semiconductor devices, rectification, cycloconversion and power factor compensation; and inductors, capacitors and transformers for energy storage.

Title: GENERATOR/MOTORS AND ADJUSTABLE-SPEED DRIVES FOR WADDELL PUMPED-STORAGE PLANT.
Affiliations: US Bur of Reclamation, Denver, CO,, USA, US Bur of Reclamation, Denver, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lonnecker, Bruce R., US Bur of Reclamation, Denver, CO,, USA, US Bur of Reclamation, Denver, CO, USA
Abstract: This paper describes the pumping and generating units and associated electrical equipment planned for Waddell Pumped-Storage Plant. Waddell Pumped-Storage Plant is to be located near Phoenix, Arizona, and will regulate water flowing from the Granite Reef Aqueduct towards Phoenix and Tucson. Savings in electric power costs and improved water delivery system reliability can be achieved by pumping excess water from the aqueduct into Lake Pleasant during the winter when electric power rates are lower, then using the energy of the stored water to generate electric power during the summer when electric power rates and demand for water are higher. Design problems encountered include operation over a wide speed range, converter cooling system size and reliability, system voltage dip and var limitations, high short circuit currents, space limitations, and control of harmonic distortions injected onto the electrical system.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC DRIVE - Variable Speed; ELECTRIC MOTORS - Selection; RELIABILITY; TURBOGENERATORS - Selection; ADJUSTABLE-SPEED DRIVES; GENERATOR/MOTORS; WIDE SPEED RANGE; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Authors: Invernizzi A., Manzoni G., Rivoiro A.
Title: Probabilistic simulation of generating system operation including seasonal hydro reservoirs and pumped-storage plants
Source title: International Journal of Electrical Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: ENEL, Direzione Studi e Ricerche, Centro di Ricerca Elettrica, Via A Volta 1, 1-20093 Cologno M SE - Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Invernizzi, A., ENEL, Direzione Studi e Ricerche, Centro di Ricerca Elettrica, Via A Volta 1, 1-20093 Cologno M SE - Milano, Italy; Manzoni, G., ENEL, Direzione Studi e Ricerche, Centro di Ricerca Elettrica, Via A Volta 1, 1-20093 Cologno M SE - Milano, Italy; Rivoiro, A., ENEL, Direzione Studi e Ricerche, Centro di Ricerca Elettrica, Via A Volta 1, 1-20093 Cologno M SE - Milano, Italy
Abstract: This report illustrates how, thanks to the development of a new algorithm for the probabilistic evaluation in a given period (e.g. one week) of the operating costs and risk indices (reliability) of a generation system with energy-constrained units, it has been possible to signifacantly improve the WAT program, used for many years by ENEL for generation expansion planning studies. In particular, it describes how the annual simulation of the system operation is accomplished, so as to calculate the mean expected values of the yearly operating costs (fuel) and the risk indices, at the same time optimizing the use of hydro resources and pumped-storage plants. © 1988.
Author Keywords: expansion planning; generation expansion; optimal power flows
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Costs; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS - Pumped Storage; PROBABILITY; RISK STUDIES - Assessment; OPTIMAL POWER FLOW; POWER SYSTEM EXPANSION PLANNING; SEASONAL HYDRO RESERVOIRS; WAT PROGRAM; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: DETERMINATION OF VALUES OF PROJECT STORAGE FOR HYDROPOWER SCHEDULING.
Affiliations: TVA, Chattanooga, TN, USA, TVA, Chattanooga, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Waffel, H.Dieter, TVA, Chattanooga, TN, USA, TVA, Chattanooga, TN, USA
Abstract: This paper reports on the development of optimal expected Values of Project Storage (VPS) for incremental storage at individual hydro projects using TVA's Weekly Scheduling Model (WSM) and illustrates the use of the VPS values in day-to-day scheduling of a power system with mixed generating resources. For day-to-day operations, reservoir storage is scheduled optimally when its expected future incremental value equals the current incremental cost of alternate resources. To interface operational planning with short-term decisionmaking, incremental water costs are needed for daily scheduling of available hydro energy so that long-range power production costs are minimized. These values are developed for each hydro project through repeated evaluations of the worth of an increment of storage in future weeks until that increment is used up.
Index Keywords: ECONOMICS; ENERGY STORAGE - Optimization; MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING, DYNAMIC; OPERATIONS RESEARCH - Planning; SCHEDULING - Mathematical Models; ECONOMY GUIDE; HYDROPOWER SCHEDULING; PROJECT STORAGE VALUES; WEEKLY SCHEDULING MODEL; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: LARGE-SCALE SWEDISH SOLAR HEATING TECHNOLOGY SYSTEM DESIGN AND RATING.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Dalenback, Jan-Olof
Abstract: A large number of calculations for investigation of solar heating systems with seasonal heat stores, are presented in this report. The designs and ratings proposed in the report are directly based on experience from, and research related to, the existing plants. The reasoning and analyses in this report have mainly been developed, and follow on, from the work carried out in connection with two of these plants, Ingelstad and Lambohov. However, this does not mean that the report is concentrated on these installations as such, but rather on the entire Swedish research programme for solar heating systems with seasonal heat stores. The objective of the report is to collate and summarize the results of this programme of research and to present some of the more important aspects of the technology that can be derived therefrom.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HEAT STORES; SEASONAL STORAGE; SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS; HEATING

Title: HIGH PURITY SALT FROM SOLAR PONDS.
Source title: Preprint - Society of Mining Engineers of AIME
Affiliations: Western America Ore Co, Avondale,, AZ, USA, Western America Ore Co, Avondale, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Grott, G.J., Western America Ore Co, Avondale,, AZ, USA, Western America Ore Co, Avondale, AZ, USA
Abstract: Many desert operations have been plagued by dust storms yielding salt too high in insolubles for most uses. This paper relates the history of a successful operation in a dust storm area. Saturated brine from the solution mining of LPG storage caverns is evaporated in solar ponds yielding 99. 95% sodium chloride (dry basis). Purchased energy is one-eighth that of vacuum pan operations. Production scale tests have proved it works at another desert location using a more complex brine. A new approach for refining soluble salts at ambient temperatures is demonstrated by bench scale and pilot work. Again, savings in purchased energy exceed 80%, even when temperatures are raised to reduce refining time.
Index Keywords: POTASH DEPOSITS - Recrystallization; SOLAR RADIATION - Solar Ponds; DESERTS; DUST STORMS; HIGH PURITY SOLAR SALT; SALTS

Title: DESIGN OF HYBRID ENERGY SYSTEMS.
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso,, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Swift, A.H.P., Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso,, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX, USA; Holder, M.R., Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso,, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX, USA
Abstract: Numerous small remote power systems, which presently use diesel generators, are required at various military installations for applications that include communications, radar, lighting, and navigational aids. It may be desirable to replace many of these generators with renewable energy systems. This paper describes a method using linear programming principles and monthly average resource and load data to arrive at an optimal mix of wind and photovoltaics for system design. Storage or back up requirements are estimated by a numerical simulation of several TMY ('Typical Meteorological Year') sites with hourly data that relate system reliability and storage size. These factors are then combined to give a total system cost and reliability estimate for comparison with existing systems. The linear optimization method using average monthly resource inputs for component design works was verified by the hourly simulation program, SOLSIM.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING, LINEAR; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS - Applications; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; WIND POWER - Applications; HYBRID ENERGY SYSTEMS; HYBRID WIND PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEM; LINEAR OPTIMIZATION METHOD; SOLSIM SIMULATION PROGRAM; TYPICAL METEOROLOGICAL YEAR; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Advanced power supply and distribution systems for Columbus
Affiliations: AEG Aktiengesellschaft, A472V41, 2000 Wedel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Eggers, G., AEG Aktiengesellschaft, A472V41, 2000 Wedel, Germany
Abstract: The paper describes power supply and distribution systems to be used on unmanned/man-tended Columbus elements, capable of supplying 10 kW to 30 kW to a variety of users in low earth orbits (LEO's). For the definition of the Electrical Power System (EPS) challenging requirements as the provision of high power levels under hard LEO conditions, maintainability, commonality etc. are to be taken into account. These requirements are to be seen in conjunction with the Columbus IOC (initial operational capability) scenario stipulating that EPS hardware shall be used on the Polar Platform, the Pressurized Module attached to the U.S. Space Station and the Man-Tended Free Flier. According to the availability of European technologies, the baseline in the power generation area is a photovoltaic system which provides three regulated main buses (150 V d.c.) to the users. In order to maintain power supply during eclipse phases, nickel hydrogen batteries will be used for energy storage purposes with nickel cadmium as back-up solution. The power distribution system needs special attention. Due to the elevated voltage levels mechanical switch gear cannot be used any longer. It is to be replaced by solid state power controllers (SSPC). Because these devices show a totally different behaviour with regard to conventional relay contacts, new approaches in the area of switching and protection are necessary. In view of the crucial role of this new technology for the realization of medium voltage d.c. systems, it is of great importance for Columbus and, hence will receive adequate consideration in the paper. In order to cater for effective management and control of the power supply and distribution hardware, a so called power system internal data processing assembly (PINDAP) has been introduced in the EPS. PINDAP is the key to reduced dependence on ground stations (alleviated ground support requirements); it keeps crew involvement in the EPS control process to as minimum and provides comprehensive means for EPS check-out and verification which facilitates in-orbit maintenance. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS - Space Applications; COLUMBUS PROGRAM; LOW EARTH ORBIT SATELLITES; SATELLITES

Title: Solar-assisted heat pump system and in-ground energy storage in a school building
Affiliations: Fondation Universitaire Luxembourgeoise, B-6700 Arlon, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Nicolas, J., Fondation Universitaire Luxembourgeoise, B-6700 Arlon, Belgium; Poncelet, J.-P., Fondation Universitaire Luxembourgeoise, B-6700 Arlon, Belgium
Abstract: An experimental solar-assisted heat pump system with a hybrid ground-coupled storage at the F.U.L. in Arlon, Belgium, is described. It includes a 382 m2 solar roof, two types of water storages, heat storage in earth by horizontal exchangers, and heat pumps. One operating period (1984-1985) is analyzed. The data processed has shown that each of the subsystems has apparently performed adequately: annual collector efficiency is 0.41, heat pump C.O.P. range around 4. Despite important energy losses from the underground storage, the storage efficiency reaches 0.7. This effectiveness is mainly due to heat recovery below natural soil temperature and also to the use of buried tanks for short-term storage. The main difficulties are controlling the flow between these subsystems and developing an operating strategy that matches both the building's heat requirements and a good solar fraction. © 1988.
Index Keywords: HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Storage; ANNUAL COLLECTOR EFFICIENCY; IN-GROUND ENERGY STORAGE; SOLAR ROOF; SOLAR-ASSISTED HEAT PUMP; STORAGE EFFICIENCY; SCHOOL BUILDINGS

Authors: Velehradsky John E., Taylor James R.
Title: PROJECT ALTERNATIVES TO BENEFIT ENDANGERED SPECIES.
Affiliations: US Army Corps of Engineers, Omaha,, NE, USA, US Army Corps of Engineers, Omaha, NE, USA
Authors with affiliations: Velehradsky, John E., US Army Corps of Engineers, Omaha,, NE, USA, US Army Corps of Engineers, Omaha, NE, USA; Taylor, James R., US Army Corps of Engineers, Omaha,, NE, USA, US Army Corps of Engineers, Omaha, NE, USA
Abstract: In April 1986, the Missouri River Division, U. S. Army Corps of Engineers, determined that operation of the main stem system had the potential to adversely affect the listed species. Consultation was initiated with the U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service and site specific interior least tern and piping plover studies were conducted. Preliminary data indicate that project flow releases should be stablized during the interior least tern and piping plover nesting season. Flow stabilization, however, reduces hydroelectric power capacity during peak demand periods and increases system storage. Alternatives include recouping lost energy by provision and operation of hydroelectric units in project spillways and removal of vegetation from higher elevation islands and sandbars located downstream from the main stem projects. The latter alternative creates interior least tern and piping plover nesting habitat at elevations above normal system discharge levels.
Index Keywords: LEGISLATION; RESERVOIRS; SPILLWAYS; ENDANGERED SPECIES; INTERIOR LEAST TERN; MAINSTEM RESERVOIR SYSTEM; PIPING PLOVER; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Authors: Iordache O., Isopescu R., Isopescu A., Iacobini A., Jinescu G.
Title: Non-Archimedean models of mixing-II. A nearly dispersional model for packed bed thermal storage systems
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Polytechnical Institute, Bucharest, Polizu 1, 78126, Romania, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Iordache, O., Department of Chemical Engineering, Polytechnical Institute, Bucharest, Polizu 1, 78126, Romania, Romania; Isopescu, R., Department of Chemical Engineering, Polytechnical Institute, Bucharest, Polizu 1, 78126, Romania, Romania; Isopescu, A., Department of Chemical Engineering, Polytechnical Institute, Bucharest, Polizu 1, 78126, Romania, Romania; Iacobini, A., Department of Chemical Engineering, Polytechnical Institute, Bucharest, Polizu 1, 78126, Romania, Romania; Jinescu, G., Department of Chemical Engineering, Polytechnical Institute, Bucharest, Polizu 1, 78126, Romania, Romania
Abstract: A non-Archimedean mathematical model for simulating the transient characteristics of heat transfer in a packed bed thermal storage system is presented. The use of Hermite polynomials is proposed for the analysis of systems which exhibit many scales of heat transfer. The obtained solution is an expansion in which the first term corresponds to the axial dispersion. A comparison of experimental data reported from literature with the numerical prediction shows a good correlation. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NON-ARCHIMEDEAN MODELS OF MIXING; PACKED BED THERMAL STORAGE SYSTEM; HEAT TRANSFER

Authors: Müller M.C., Jacobsen U., Michels G., Liedlke G., Reim M.
Title: Organ culture of pig cornea: Biochemical analyses of mid-term-stored corneal tissue
Affiliations: Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Rheinisch-Westfälisch Technische Hochschule Aachen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Müller, M.C., Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Rheinisch-Westfälisch Technische Hochschule Aachen, Germany; Jacobsen, U., Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Rheinisch-Westfälisch Technische Hochschule Aachen, Germany; Michels, G., Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Rheinisch-Westfälisch Technische Hochschule Aachen, Germany; Liedlke, G., Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Rheinisch-Westfälisch Technische Hochschule Aachen, Germany; Reim, M., Department of Ophthalmology, Faculty of Medicine, Rheinisch-Westfälisch Technische Hochschule Aachen, Germany
Abstract: Freshly prepared pig corneas were cultured at 22 °C in TC 199 medium supple-mented with HEPES buffer, antibiotics and 10% sterile pig blood serum. The cultures were maintained in a closed system up to 30 days. The hydration as measured by wet and dry weights increased from 80 to 94% after 2 weeks of storage. Glucose decreased slowly and continuously during the culture time by 0.32 mmol in 30 days. This was equivalent to 11 μmol/day, 0.46 μmol/h and finally 0.264 μmol/h/cm2. Lactate increased in the culture accordingly by 0.34 μmol/h/cm2. In the corneal epithelium of the cultured tissues the glucose levels -normally at about 5 μmol/g -equilibrated with those of the medium during the first 10 days; later the epithelial glucose levels incresaed up to 20-30 μmol/g. The glycogen content of the epithelium remained constant for the first 10 days of storage. The ATP/ADP ratios in the corneal epithelium initially decreased but later recovered to values of about 12. The pO2 in the culture system decreased from 156 to 120 mm Hg, which is equivalent to an oxygen consumption of 7.41 μl O2/cm2. The CO2 production initiating from a level of 16.6 mm Hg was 4.88 μl/h/cm2. The data showed that the cornea was viable in this culture system for 30 days. © 1988 S. Karger AG, Basel.
Author Keywords: ADP; ATP; Cornea; Culture; Glucose; Lactate; Metabolism; Pyruvate; TC 199

Authors: Strauss C.H., Grado S.C., Blankenhorn P.R., Bowersox T.W.
Title: Economic evaluations of multiple rotation sric biomass plantations
Affiliations: School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strauss, C.H., School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Grado, S.C., School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Blankenhorn, P.R., School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Bowersox, T.W., School of Forest Resources, The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: A series of short-rotation intensive culture (SRIC) Populus plantations involving four management strategies (control, fertilization, irrigation, and fertilization-irrigation) were evaluated in tandem with alternate harvesting and storage strategies to determine the least cost method for supplying biomass to an ethanol conversion facility. The plantations were based on Populus hydrid NE-388, a tree spacing of 0.6 m × 0.8 m, and a rotation length of four years. First rotation yields from the various strategies ranged from 33 to 42 oven-dry metric tonne per hectare (Mg(OD) ha-1). An average yield increase of 12% was realized from the second rotation coppice plantations. The control strategy had the lowest production costs for the two rotations, averaging 532 Mg-1 (OD). Harvesting and storage requirements nearly doubled the final costs, with the least cost system having an average total cost of $66 Mg-1 (OD). Over 50% of the total cost originated from equipment and material inputs, with labor costs representing nearly 30% of the total and land the final 20%. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ENERGY RESOURCES; ETHANOL - Production; POPULUS BIOMASS; SHORT-ROTATION INTENSIVE CULTURE; BIOMASS

Title: Salt hydrates used for latent heat storage: Corrosion of metals and reliability of thermal performance
Affiliations: Materials Science Division, Commission of the European Communities, Joint Research Centre- Ispra Establishment, 21020 Ispra, VA, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Porisini, F.C., Materials Science Division, Commission of the European Communities, Joint Research Centre- Ispra Establishment, 21020 Ispra, VA, Italy
Abstract: Data are presented on the corrosion resistance of metallic alloys to hydrated salts, which may be utilized as phase change materials (PCM) for heat storage. With the same experimental apparatus, tests on the thermal performance reliability of PCM after repeated thermal cycling were carried out. Commercially available latent heat storage components containing the following salt hydrates with melting points between 15°C and 32°C have been considered: Na2SO4 · 10H2O, CaCl2 · 6H2O, Na2SO4 · 1 2NaCl · 10H2O, NaOH · 3,5H2O. The containment materials tested were stainless steel, carbon steel, Al alloys, and Cu. As many as 5650 thermal cycles involving repeated melting and freezing of the phase change materials were carried out. The most corrosion-resistant alloy to all the hydrated salts tested was stainless steel. Only the two commercial CaCl2 · 6 H2O tested showed good thermal stability after repeated thermal cycling. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; METALS AND ALLOYS - Corrosion Resistance; STAINLESS STEEL; LATENT HEAT STORAGE; PHASE CHANGE MATERIALS; SALT HYDRATES; THERMAL CYCLING STABILITY; SALTS

Title: Fuel cells: the present state of the technology and future applications, with special consideration of the alkaline hydrogen/oxygen (air) systems
Affiliations: Technische Universität Graz, A-8010 Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Kordesch, K., Technische Universität Graz, A-8010 Graz, Austria; Oliveira, J.C.T., Technische Universität Graz, A-8010 Graz, Austria
Abstract: Fuel cells are electrochemical energy converters which have a principal advantage over heat engines: they can utilize the chemical energy of fuels with a high efficiency. Space power systems operating on hydrogen and oxygen have been built successfully. A need exists today to develop a small power plant for the propulsion of automobiles and larger stationary power plants within a city, eliminating pollution problems. During the last decade catalyst costs have been reduced drastically, mass production possibilities have opened up. The combination of water electrolysis and hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells still looks very attractive for space-energy storage applications. © 1988.

Title: ROLE OF GLACIERS IN A CLIMATIC CHANGE.
Source title: Mitteilungen der Versuchsanstalt fur Wasserbau, Hydrologie und Glaziologie an der Eidgenossischen Technischen Hochschule Zurich
Authors with affiliations: Ohmura, A.
Abstract: The role of the latent heat in glacier ice in climatic changes is examined. The change in the heat stored in the climate system from the last glacial maximum to the present is evaluated and compared against the extraatmospheric solar radiation. The fraction of the energy which goes into storage in the course of the climatic change is evaluated. The phase-difference between the solar radiation flux and temperature is expressed in a simple manner.

Title: FIELD EXPERIENCE WITH AQUIFER THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Energy Technology: Proceedings of the Energy Technology Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kannberg, Landis D., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA,, USA, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: Aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) has the potential to provide storage for large-scale building heating and cooling at many sites in the U. S. However, implementation requires careful attention to site geohydraulic and geochemical characteristics. Field tests in the U. S. have shown that over 60% of the heat injected at temperatures over 100 degree C can be recovered on a seasonal cycle. Similarly, aquifer storage of chilled ground water can provide building cooling with annual cooling electrical energy reductions of over 50% and a reduction in summer peak cooling electrical usage by as much as a factor of 20.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Cooling; ENERGY UTILIZATION; GEOCHEMISTRY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HEATING - Heat Storage; AQUIFER THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ELECTRICAL ENERGY REDUCTIONS; FIELD EXPERIENCE; AQUIFERS

Title: PREPARATION AND SPECTROSCOPY OF MAGNETO-OPTICAL THIN FILMS.
Source title: Siemens Forschungs- und Entwicklungsberichte/Siemens Research and Development Reports
Affiliations: Siemens AG, West Ger, Siemens AG, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Weller, D., Siemens AG, West Ger, Siemens AG, West Ger; Reim, W., Siemens AG, West Ger, Siemens AG, West Ger
Abstract: Thin films deposited in ultrahigh vacuum by ion-beam sputtering are in situ characterized by optical, magneto-optical and electron spectroscopy. In situ composition determination and magneto-optics of amorphous Nd-Fe-Co are presented. The transition metal alloy system Fe-Co is studied by ultraviolet photoemission spectroscopy and Kerr-effect measurements in the 0. 5 eV to 5 eV (2. 5 mu m to 240 nm) photon energy range. Results are interpreted in terms of spin-polarized band structure features of body-centered cubic Fe-Co. Magneto-optical spectroscopy and the correlation of the temperature dependence of H//c and thermomagnetic write/read properties of Tb-Fe-Co are discussed and experimental results of domain patterns written in quasistatic tests are given.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC - Thin Films; NEODYMIUM IRON COBALT ALLOYS - Amorphous; SPECTROSCOPY, ULTRAVIOLET - Applications; SPUTTERING; MAGNETIC DISKS; MAGNETOOPTICAL STORAGE DEVICES; ULTRA-HIGH VACUUM DEPOSITION; ULTRAVIOLET PHOTOEMISSION SPECTROSCOPY; MAGNETOOPTICAL DEVICES

Title: POTENTIAL ENERGY SAVINGS FROM AQUIFER THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE.

Abstract: This paper summarizes a study conducted for the U. S. Department of Energy's ATES Program. Pacific Northwest Laboratory conducted the study to estimate the overall potential energy savings from ATES utilization in the U. S. This estimate included the potential short- and long-term savings from both heating and cooling applications of ATES. The results can be used in determining the direction of research conducted on ATES, specifically whether the primary focus of research should be on heat or chill storage, and which end markets are the primary users and sources of heat or chill ATES.

Affiliations: School of Chemical Engineering and Industrial Chemistry, University of New South Wales, P.O. Box 1, Kensington, NSW 2033, Australia

Abstract: The construction and performance of an all-vanadium redox flow system is described. The battery employs vanadyl sulphate in sulphuric acid solution as the electrolyte, carbon felt as the electrode material, and an ion-selective membrane as the separator. Working parameters, storage life, and a comparison of the characteristics with other battery systems are also presented. The cost of manufacture of a 1 kW battery of 5 kW h, 15 kW h, or 50 kW h capacity has been evaluated and the practical application of the system in large stationary installations and electric vehicles is also discussed. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; BATTERY STACK; INERT ELECTRODES; POWER SOURCES; SOLUBLE REDOX COUPLES; ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY

Authors: Rowles Peter A., Brilliant Ron L.
Title: HEAT PUMP HEAT RECOVERY SYSTEM AT TEND-R-FRESH.
Source title: Research and Development Report - Canadian Electrical Association
Affiliations: Best Energy Systems Inc, Oakville,, Ont, Can, Best Energy Systems Inc, Oakville, Ont, Can
Authors with affiliations: Rowles, Peter A., Best Energy Systems Inc, Oakville,, Ont, Can, Best Energy Systems Inc, Oakville, Ont, Can; Brilliant, Ron L., Best Energy Systems Inc, Oakville,, Ont, Can, Best Energy Systems Inc, Oakville, Ont, Can
Abstract: Best Energy Systems Inc. of Oakville, Ontario, has installed a heat recovery system at the Tend-R-Fresh poultry plant. The system recovers waste heat from refrigeration condensers using heat pump technology to produce hot water for processing and plant cleaning. The heat recovery system consists of these components: three shell and tube heat exchangers which also act as ammonia condensers (heat is recovered from the shell and tube heat exchangers by way of a glycol circulation loop), a plate type heat exchanger which preheats incoming water, two 60 hp heat pumps capable of heating water up to 65 degree C (150 degree F) and a 23,000 litre (5,000 gallon) thermal storage tank. Benefits include an increase in refrigeration capacity, an increase in supply of hot water, a reduction in water consumption by evaporating condensers and a reduction of maintenance for refrigeration equipment in general. The system has a payback of less than three years.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Condensers; HEAT SINKS; REFRIGERATING MACHINERY - Condensers; AMMONIA CONDENSERS; HEAT PUMP RECOVERY SYSTEM; REFRIGERATION CONDENSERS; SHELL/TUBE HEAT EXCHANGERS; THERMAL STORAGE TANK; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Abstract: The coloration and erasure properties of the F-center in cathodochromic sodalite as a function of a various chemical substitutions are studied. Several chemical compositions of halogen (Br,Cl,I)- and Ge-doped sodalite:Br are grown by the hydrothermal growth technique. The absorption energy and the thermal activation energy of the electron in the F-center are measured as a function of the material lattice parameter a//0.

Title: MODEL FOR THE OPTIMISATION OF THERMAL INSULATION THICKNESS IN A COLD STORE.
Affiliations: Kwara State Coll of Technology, Ilorin, Nigeria, Kwara State Coll of Technology, Ilorin, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Adeodu, O.A., Kwara State Coll of Technology, Ilorin, Nigeria, Kwara State Coll of Technology, Ilorin, Nigeria
Abstract: The model is a method for optimizing thermal insulation thickness in a cold store from the point of view of economics. The insulation purchase cost generally increases with its thickness. In contrast, the refrigeration load and the cost of removing heat from the refrigerated space decrease as the insulation thickness increases. The minimum value of the combined cost determines the optimum thickness. Such a model was applied in the optimization of the thickness of polyurethane insulation to be used in a cold store in Zaria, Nigeria. The results of the simulation, which was carried out on a computer, are also presented in this paper. The Fibonacci Search Technique was employed in the optimization.

Abstract: Predictions of thermocline development in thermocline thermal storage tanks can be made by accounting for turbulent mixing at the inlet region. A practical measure for quantifying this mixing is obtained by introducing an effective diffusivity factor in a one-dimensional flow model. Thus, a tool for characterization of turbulent mixing caused by different inlet configurations is now available. This should facilitate the selection of diffusers for achieving a high degree of stratification in thermocline thermal storage tanks. © 1988.

Authors: Angelis J.W., Birnbreier H., Haase H.
Title: HIGH-ENERGY BATTERY FOR ELECTRIC ROAD VEHICLES.
Affiliations: Brown-Boveri GmbH, West Ger, Brown-Boveri GmbH, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Angelis, J.W., Brown-Boveri GmbH, West Ger, Brown-Boveri GmbH, West Ger; Birnbreier, H., Brown-Boveri GmbH, West Ger, Brown-Boveri GmbH, West Ger; Haase, H., Brown-Boveri GmbH, West Ger, Brown-Boveri GmbH, West Ger
Abstract: Brown Boveri have developed a sodium-sulphur battery designed to give a medium-sized saloon car a range of 150-250 km, acceleration from 0 to 50 km/h in 7 s and a cruising speed of 120 km/h. The battery has a storage capacity of 32 kWh (2 h rate), a maximum output of 50 kW and an energy density of 120 Wh/kg. Details are given of the electrical and mechanical design of the battery, maintenance of operating temperature, changing arrangements, and the design of the main associated components: drive motor, transmission and power controller. The particular advantages of an electric over a conventional car are regarded as reduced air pollution, less noise and lower energy costs, as shown by a comparative analysis of the two vehicle types. It is anticipated that series production of battery-driven cars will begin in the 1990s.

Abstract: The quantum mechanical phenomenon of tunneling time has been the subject of much debate. We use a Wigner function description of a Guassian wave packet to study the tunneling process. By adjusting the parameters of the barrier and wave packet, a variety of cases can be studied. For the multiple barrier case, the tunneling time shows peaks at energies corresponding to resonant states of the system. This charge storage within the well is also found to be significant in studying the resonant tunneling diode, giving rise to kinks in the negative differential conductivity region of the I-V characteristic. © 1988.
Index Keywords: ELECTRONS - Tunneling; QUANTUM TUNNELING; TUNNELING TIME; WIGNER FUNCTION SIMULATION; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS

Affiliations: MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Casey, Leo F., MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA; Goldberg, Andrew F., MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA; Schlecht, Martin F., MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Abstract: Capacitive modeling issues are addressed, particularly with respect to minimizing leakage inductance. Reasonable assumptions about the winding configuration and the distribution of voltage around it are made. The total electrical energy stored in the winding when a voltage is applied is then calculated and partitioned into the differential- and common-mode parts. A description of how the common-mode current flows is discussed, and the tradeoff between leakage inductance and capacitance is quantified. Some experimental results are provided.

Abstract: A major study on solar central receiver systems for electric utility power production compared two competing plant concepts, both with external receivers and heliostat fields. The first involved an external sodium receiver with nitrate salt thermal storage and steam generation systems; power is transferred from the sodium loop to the salt loop through an intermediate heat exchanger. The second concept involved a nitrate salt receiver with nitrate salt thermal storage and steam generation systems. Comparisons of the levelized costs of energy show a 5 and 3 percent advantage for the salt receiver concept at plant sizes of 100 and 200 MWe, respectively.

Abstract: A study has been conducted to generate and evaluate advanced solar heat receiver concepts suitable for orbital application with Brayton and Stirling engine cycles in the 7-kW size range. The generated receiver designs have thermal storage capability. In addition to the baseline designs, four other receiver concepts were designed and evaluated with respect to Brayton and Stirling engines. These concepts include a higher temperature version of the baseline receiver, a packed bed receiver, a plate-fin receiver, and a heat pipe receiver.

Title: SUPERCONDUCTOR LANDSCAPE: VIEW FROM LOS ALAMOS.

Authors with affiliations: Mueller, Fred M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Abstract: Researchers at Los Alamos have used traditional superconducting materials to create strong magnetic fields for energy storage. The resulting superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system stores large amounts of electrical energy which can be released in times as short as six to ten milliseconds. The only drawback to today's SMES, difficulties with liquid helium cooling, could be overcome with application of the new warmer superconductors. To meet the diurnal variations in electric demand and the expected demand growth in the next 25 years, the generating capacity of the nation will have to be doubled. This will amount to nearly 700B or 6% of the total capital plant of the U. S. This expense can be reduced by the development of a reliable, low cost electrical energy storage device like SMES.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Materials; SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE; SUPERCONDUCTING MATERIALS

Abstract: A longitudinal active damping system was installed in the UVSOR electron storage ring in order to suppress a coupled-bunch instability due to higher-order-mode resonances of the RF cavity. The system consists of sixteen independent feedback loops each of them corrects the energy deviation of one of sixteen bunches, individually. The phase oscillation due to the instability was satisfactorily damped with this system. © 1988 The Japan Society of Applied Physics.

Abstract: A solar central receiver was designed, constructed, and tested in a program funded by the U. S. Department of Energy. The receiver tested is an advanced 5 MWt cavity receiver that uses molten salt as the working fluid. The receiver was solar tested during a six-month period at the Central Receiver Test Facility in Albuquerque, NM. The purpose of the testing was to characterize the operational capabilities of the receiver under a number of solar operating and stand-by conditions. This testing consisted of initial check-out of the systems, followed by steady-state performance, transient receiver operation, receiver operation in clouds, receiver thermal loss testing, receiver start-up operation, and overnight thermal conditioning tests. The results of this testing are presented in this paper.

Abstract: Research activities in Japan are reported of a compact electron storage ring (test ring) and on ways of making a compact synchrotron radiation (SR) system. In this test, the authors succeeded in obtaining an approximately 340 ma beam current storage at an injection energy of 160 Mev and made a significant start towards making the injector in the SR system more compact. Title: Energy and economic comparisons of a heat pump/heat store with conventional heating systems in the British climate
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Polytechnic of Central London, 115 New Cavendish Street, London, W1M 8JS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Votsis, P.P., School of Mechanical Engineering, Polytechnic of Central London, 115 New Cavendish Street, London, W1M 8JS, United Kingdom; Marquand, C.J., School of Mechanical Engineering, Polytechnic of Central London, 115 New Cavendish Street, London, W1M 8JS, United Kingdom; Tassou, S.A., School of Mechanical Engineering, Polytechnic of Central London, 115 New Cavendish Street, London, W1M 8JS, United Kingdom; Wilson, D.R., School of Mechanical Engineering, Polytechnic of Central London, 115 New Cavendish Street, London, W1M 8JS, United Kingdom
Abstract: The thermodynamic and economic performance of a heat pump combined with a water heat store has been examined. The thermal store contains electrical resistance heaters which can boost the water temperature to 95°C. By utilising the off-peak tariffs for electricity it has been shown that the heat pump/heat store can compete economically with conventional central heating systems, based on an oil-fired boiler, a coal-fired boiler, or night storage heaters. To stand comparison with gas central heating, however, the cost of gas would have to increase by 6%, the capital cost of the heat pump/heat store be reduced by 20%, or the seasonal performance of the heat pump/heat store be improved by 17%. © 1988.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Space Heating; HEATING - Costs; THERMODYNAMICS; CONVENTIONAL HEATING; HEAT PUMP/HEAT STORE; SEASONAL PERFORMANCE; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Title: HIGH SPEED DATA ACQUISITION AND ANALYSIS SYSTEM FOR ULTRASONIC ENERGY MEASUREMENTS.
Affiliations: Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale,, IL, USA, Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Botros, N., Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale,, IL, USA, Southern Illinois Univ, Carbondale, IL, USA
Abstract: A high-speed microcomputer-based data acquisition and analysis system has been interfaced to an ultrasound sector scanner (ATL scanner model MK-500). The primary application of the system is to measure the power spectrum of the backscattered (low-level) ultrasound signal from acoustic inhomogeneous media, such as soft biological tissues. The system digitizes the ultrasound signal with a sample rate of 16 Msample/s and stores the digitized data in temporary storage (static RAMS). When the temporary storage is full, the data are transferred to an IBM-PC where the fast Fourier transform algorithm is applied to calculate the power spectrum of the ultrasound signal. Noise-reduction algorithms are applied to the signal in the time and frequency domains. A theoretical model for the backscattered process has been developed. Investigation of the model shows that the attenuation coefficient of the tissue can be used as a discriminator between normal and abnormal tissues. The average acoustic attenuation coefficient, as a function of frequency, of 25 normal liver subjects is estimated from the power spectrum of ultrasound signal. Pattern recognition algorithms are applied to differentiate between normal and abnormal liver tissues for fifteen subjects with different types of abnormalities.
Index Keywords: BIOLOGICAL MATERIALS - Ultrasonic Applications; COMPUTER AIDED ANALYSIS; PATTERN RECOGNITION - Medical Applications; ULTRASONIC EQUIPMENT - Computer Interfaces; ULTRASONICS - Measurements; BACKSCATTERED (LOW-LEVEL) ULTRASOUND SIGNAL; NORMAL AND ABNORMAL LIVER TISSUES DIFFERENTIATION; ULTRASOUND SECTOR SCANNER; DATA PROCESSING

Title: INTERACTION OF NATURAL CONVECTION AND THERMAL RADIATION IN SQUARE CAVITIES.
Affiliations: Univ Simon Bolivar, Caracas, Venez, Univ Simon Bolivar, Caracas, Venez
Authors with affiliations: Lacoa, Ulises, Univ Simon Bolivar, Caracas, Venez, Univ Simon Bolivar, Caracas, Venez; Campo, Antonio, Univ Simon Bolivar, Caracas, Venez, Univ Simon Bolivar, Caracas, Venez
Abstract: A numerical study involving natural convection and thermal radiation in gas-filled square cavities having isothermal vertical walls and adiabatic horizontal walls has been conducted. The major assumptions invoked in the analysis are the Boussinesq approximation in the bouyancy term and the gray gas model for the participating gaseous medium. The two-dimensional method of moments is adopted for the formulation of the radiation transport equation. The coupled system of governing equations (conservation of mass, horizontal momentum, vertical momentum, energy and radiative transfer) is implemented by a combination of the SIMPLER algorithm and the MSI algorithm, This innovative combination reduces substantially the computational time and storage requirements generally associated with these problems.
Index Keywords: GASES; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Differential Equations; CAVITIES; NUSSELT NUMBER; RADIATION TRANSPORT EQUATION; THERMAL RADIATION; HEAT TRANSFER

Abstract: Among the gas‐solid adsorption processes the zeolite water adsorption seems to be very interesting for use in thermodynamic systems such as chemical heat pump, heat transformer and cooling systems. This work evaluates theoretically the best type of zeolite for use in each system on the basis of the adsorption data of zeolites using prefixed operative conditions. Results obtained indicate that thermodynamically a given zeolite type achieves better results than the others for each of the abovementioned systems. Methodology and criterion of comparison used can be applied to other gas‐solid processes aiming at realizing chemical heat pump, heat transformer and cooling systems. Abstract: During the last decade hydrogen has attracted world wide interest as a secondary energy carrier resulting in a lot of research work on its production, storage and use. The incorporation of hydrogen into thin film form discussed in this article is a relatively new field of research. The main advantages of thin film metal hydrides are that these provide large surface area with fast charging discharging rate for hydrogen, pulverization is slower, both critical pressure and critical temperature are significantly lower, better heat transfer arrangements, protective surface coating could be done to stop poisoning by oxygen and activation of thin film hydrides is possible by coating with a layer of catalytic material. © 1988.

Title: Studies on collector‐cum‐storage type solar water heaters under arid zone conditions of india
Affiliations: Central Arid Zone Research Institute, Jodhpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Nahar, N.M., Central Arid Zone Research Institute, Jodhpur, India; Gupta, J.P., Central Arid Zone Research Institute, Jodhpur, India
Abstract: Conventional natural circulation type solar water heaters are very costly. Though manufactured in India, they are beyond the reach of the common man. To reduce the cost, a collector‐cum‐storage type solar water heater has been developed and its detailed study has been carried out and reported. The heater can provide 100 1 of hot water at a temperature of 55–60°C in the evening which can be retained at 40–45°C until the next morning. The efficiency of the heater varies from 57.4 to 66.0 per cent depending on design parameters. Copyright © 1988 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Testing; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; ARID ZONE CONDITIONS; WATER HEATERS

Title: ESTIMATION OF PRESSURE, TEMPERATURE, MASS AND ENERGY STORED IN CNG CYLINDERS.
Affiliations: Ministry of Energy, Wellington, NZ, Ministry of Energy, Wellington, NZ
Authors with affiliations: Patel, V., Ministry of Energy, Wellington, NZ, Ministry of Energy, Wellington, NZ
Abstract: This paper describes how the real gas equation of state can be used to generate graphs of constant gas density as a function of pressure and temperature for CNG. It then describes how this graphical information can be used to predict how pressure changes with temperature and vice versa. The amount of CNG and energy stored in a cylinder of given size can also be predicted. Relative estimates of these properties for the different reticulated gases may also be made by use of the graphs generated.
Index Keywords: CYLINDERS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GAS STORAGE; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; NATURAL GAS

Authors: Selvam P., Viswanathan B., Swamy C.S., Srinivasan V.
Title: Studies on the thermal characteristics of hydrides of Mg, Mg2Ni, Mg2Cu and Mg2Ni1-xMx (M = Fe, Co, Cu or Zn; 0 < × < 1) alloys
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India
Authors with affiliations: Selvam, P., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India; Viswanathan, B., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India; Swamy, C.S., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India; Srinivasan, V., Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, 600 036, India
Abstract: X-ray results on the alloys of the composition Mg2Ni1-xMx (M = Fe, Co, Cu or Zn; 0 < × < 1) suggest a Mg2Ni-type structure. The alloys, Mg2Ni0.75M0.25(M = Fe, Co, Cu or Zn) upon hydriding lead to the formation of quarternary hydrides while on dehydriding yield the starting ternary alloys except for copper containing alloys which show multi-phase regions and follow a different path way for the hydriding-dehydriding process. Thermal studies (TG-DTA) on the hydrides indicate the amount of hydrogen evolved as well as the desorption temperatures. The thermodynamic quantities, namely the enthalpies and entropies of formation of the hydrides were deduced from the DTA peak maximum temperature data. The kinetic parameters such as activation energies, reaction rates and orders of the reaction for the decomposition of the hydrides formed from Mg, Mg2Ni and Mg2Cu alloys were evaluated from the DTA data. As to the modified Mg2Ni system, the copper substituted alloys show lower thermal stability and also presents some interesting properties. Hence, it is considered as one of the promising ternary combinations (Mg-Ni-Cu) for hydrogen storage purposes. © 1988.

Title: Modelling the potential of thermal storage for cooling under time‐of‐use electricity rates: An economic‐engineering simulation approach
Affiliations: Center for Economics Research, Research Triangle Institute, Research Triangle Park, North Carolina, 27709, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, K.H., Center for Economics Research, Research Triangle Institute, Research Triangle Park, North Carolina, 27709, United States; Miedema, A.K., Center for Economics Research, Research Triangle Institute, Research Triangle Park, North Carolina, 27709, United States
Abstract: An economic‐engineering simulation model was developed to examine the economic feasibilities of using thermal energy storage systems to help cool commercial‐scale buildings under time‐of‐use (TOU) electricity rates. The analysis results showed that the financial viability of thermal energy systems would be greatly enhanced under TOU rates. The simulation analysis also revealed that the results would be significantly affected by various parameters, such as the length of on‐peak period, capital costs, building size and configuration, space availability, and weather conditions. Title: Behavior of a household absorption-diffusion refrigerator adapted to autonomous solar operation
Affiliations: Instituto de Ingeniería, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Apartado postal 70-472, México, D.F. 04510, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Gutiérrez, F., Instituto de Ingeniería, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Apartado postal 70-472, México, D.F. 04510, Mexico
Abstract: This article presents a study on the thermal performance of a solar refrigerator that is simple to use. The unit was developed from a commercial absorption-diffusion type refrigerator that had a flat plate collector substituted for its generator. An ammonia-water solution and hydrogen was used in the system. Since there is no hot thermal storage to operate the system continuously, cooling occurs during daytime only. The heat is rejected by natural air convection. A series of experiments was performed in which the system was solar powered and also operated in a solar simulator, in order to know the effects of the ambient temperature on the behavior of the apparatus. © 1988.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Design; HYDROGEN - Absorption; SOLAR ENERGY; ABSORPTION-DIFFUSION REFRIGERATOR; REFRIGERATION

Title: Development of beta batteries for utility application: progress update
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Advanced Power Systems Division, (Report) EPRI AP
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This report summarizes the development of a 100-MWh battery design for load-leveling utility application; to demonstrate cell manufacturing repeatability; and to transfer NaS7 cell technology to the utility FII cell. The project team designed a 100-MWh load-leveling unit battery, based on 1-kWh FII cells. Unit battery tests demonstrated adequate temperature uniformity and acceptably low heat losses with a predicted overall ac-to-ac energy efficiency of 69%. All 15 TDC passed the 250-cycle milestone established for the test. By the end of the year, 12 of the cells still operated after 420 cycles, the other 3 having failed after 306, 360, and 397 cycles. The cells displayed higher capacity, lower resistance, and a lower resistance rise with time than predicted. Although the NaS7 technology was partially transferrable to the larger FII cells, the first group of tested cells displayed unsatisfactorily short cycle lives. However, the last two FII cells tested in the program had significantly improved lives of 96 and 161 cycles. Tests suggested that sulfur electrode design might shorten cell life and that new designs for this component could yield longer lives.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Load Management; Electrolytes, Solid; Energy Storage; Sodium Compounds--Applications; Sulfur Compounds--Applications; Beta Batteries; Load Leveling; Sodium Sulfur Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Development of beta batteries for utility application: final report
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute, Advanced Power Systems Division, (Report) EPRI AP
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This report summarizes the progress made toward the development of an economically competitive sodium/sulfur battery for utility load leveling. A 1-kWh sodium/sulfur cell, designated as the FII cell, was based on an earlier NaS7 electric vehicle cell for which cost projections had been favorable. The major results of the project included improvements in production of the solid, beta alumina electrolyte, including changes in composition. Protective coatings improved the resistance of the sulfur container to corrosion, and changes in fabrication improved the kinetic performance of the sulfur electrode. Other improvements involved the quality of the sodium used and the safety of the sodium containment. Using larger numbers of cells in each test group reduced experimental error and increased confidence in test results. Finally, a 100-MWh battery plant based on FII cells was designed and analyzed, and its cost was estimated. Based on these developments, the FII sodium/sulfur system represents an attainable approach to load leveling.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems--Load Management; Electrolytes, Solid; Energy Storage; Sodium Compounds; Sulfur Compounds; Beta Batteries; Load Leveling; Sodium Sulfur Batteries; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Title: Finite Element Analysis of Thermal-Hydraulics in Upper Plenum of Pool-Type LMFBR
Source title: Nippon Genshiryoku Gakkaishi/Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: Fac. of Eng., Univ. of Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Eguchi, Y., Fac. of Eng., Univ. of Tokyo, Japan; Yagawa, G., Fac. of Eng., Univ. of Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The pool-type LMFBR (liquid-metal cooled fast breeder reactor) is characterized by the unpredictably complex flow because of the complicated arrangement of structural components immersed in the liquid sodium. Such flow behavior must be fully understood for the sophisticated design of the LMFBR. Furthermore, the thermal-hydraulic feature of the pool-type LMFBR is one of the most important key issues from the viewpoint of reactor safety. The present study is devoted to the numerical analyses of the thermal-hydraulic characteristics of the pool-type LMFBR. The finite element method (FEM) is chosen for the spatial approximation, taking an advantage of the FEM's flexibility for the approximation of the complicated geometry. Considering the fact that the efficient computation is essential for the FE analysis of complicated three-dimensional flow, an efficient FE scheme for the incompressible viscous flow is proposed in the present paper. Focus of attention is placed on the time integration algorithm and some techniques for the reduction of storage demand. The proposed computational scheme is applied to the three-dimensional thermal-hydraulic problem in the upper plenum of the pool-type LMFBR to demonstrate the feasibility of the present FE strategy. © 1988, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Sandstrom O., Neuman E., Karas P.
Title: Effects of a bleached pulp mill effluent on growth and gonad function in Baltic coastal fish
Affiliations: National Swedish Environment Protection Board, Marine Section, S-740 71 Oregrund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Sandstrom, O., National Swedish Environment Protection Board, Marine Section, S-740 71 Oregrund, Sweden; Neuman, E., National Swedish Environment Protection Board, Marine Section, S-740 71 Oregrund, Sweden; Karas, P., National Swedish Environment Protection Board, Marine Section, S-740 71 Oregrund, Sweden
Abstract: Growth and reproductive capacity in perch and roach were studied during 1983, 1984 and 1985 in a coastal area of the Bothnian Sea affected by bleached pulp mill effluents. Comparative investigations were made at a mill producing unbleached pulp. In perch exposed to bleachery effluents effects were observed on length increase rates, somatic condition factors and on gonad development. The fraction of fishes displaying inhibited gonadal recrudescence was high close to the mill, and the size of developing gonads was comparatively small. Growth was faster in exposed fishes, in young-of-the-year as well as in older fish. Effects on length growth could be distinguished as far back as in 1975. Energy storage, expressed as the condition factor, was highest in exposed fishes. The effect pattern was more diffuse in roach, but examples of reduced gonad growth were noted. In conclusion, these studies provided evidence for changes in the energy allocation system in fish exposed to a bleached pulp mill effluent.Growth and reproductive capacity in perch (Perca fluviatilis L.) and roach (Rutilus rutilus (L.)) were studied during 1983, 1984 and 1985 in a coastal area of the Bothnian Sea affected by bleached pulp mill effluents. Comparative investigations were made at a mill producing unbleached pulp. In perch exposed to bleachery effluents effects were observed on length increase rates, somatic condition factors and on gonad development. The fraction of fishes displaying inhibited gonadal recrudescence was high close to the mill, and the size of developing gonads was comparatively small. Growth was faster in exposed fishes, in young-of-the-year as well as in older fish. Effects on length growth could be distinguished as far back as in 1975. Energy storage, expressed as the condition factor, was highest in exposed fishes. The effect pattern was more diffuse in roach, but examples of reduced gonad growth were noted. In conclusion, these studies provided evidence for changes in the energy allocation system in fish exposed to a bleached pulp mill effluent.

Title: Storage of apheresis platelets in ethylene-vinyl acetate copolymer bags: Relationship between the bag size and the number of platelets maintaining aerobic metabolism
Affiliations: Research Division, Aichi Center, Japanese Red Cross, 539-3, Minami-Yamaguchi, Seto, 489, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kouketsu, K., Research Division, Aichi Center, Japanese Red Cross, 539-3, Minami-Yamaguchi, Seto, 489, Japan; Shimizu, T., Research Division, Aichi Center, Japanese Red Cross, 539-3, Minami-Yamaguchi, Seto, 489, Japan
Abstract: The present study was designed to determine whether a bag made from ethylene-vinyl acetate copolymer (EV) with superior flexibility at subzero temperature is suitable for a storage container of single-donor apheresis platelets. Apheresis platelets were stored with 100 ml plasma in 1-liter bags made of EV or standard polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plastic at 22 °C with constant agitation. The oxygen permeability of the 1-liter EV bag averaged 1447 nmol/min/atm, which was about 1.5 times higher than that of PVC bags. The partial oxygen tension (PO2) of platelet concentrates (PC) has linearly decreased to 16 mm Hg with increasing platelet counts. The level of the partial carbon dioxide was always higher in EV bags than in PVC bags. Oxygen consumption rates of platelets stored in EV and PVC bags with a sufficient oxygen supply averaged 1.25 and 1.20 nmol/min/109 platelets, respectively. The rates of glucose consumption and lactate production were not changed in two bags. Ninety percent of the total ATP production of about 8 nmol/min/109 platelets were generated through the aerobic metabolism. The platelet counts in the 1-liter EV and PVC bags, at which PO2 is 16 mm Hg, were 2.2 and 1.5 × 1011 platelets, respectively. The study indicates that apheresis platelets stored in EV bags at 22 °C have no different metabolic changes when compared with those of PVC bags. In addition, the number of platelets maintaining the aerobic metabolism is 1.5 times higher than that of PVC bags. © 1988.

Authors: Acheson K.J., Schutz Y., Bessard T., Anantharaman K., Flatt J.-P., Jequier E.
Title: Glycoprotein storage capacity and de novo lipogenesis during massive carbohydrate overfeeding in man
Affiliations: Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Acheson, K.J., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Schutz, Y., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Bessard, T., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Anantharaman, K., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Flatt, J.-P., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Jequier, E., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: The metabolic balance method was performed on three men to investigate the fate of large excesses of carbohydrate. Glycogen stores, which were first depleted by diet (3 d, 8.35 ± 0.27 MJ [1994 ± 65 kcal] decreasing to 5.70 ± 1.03 MJ [1361 ± 247 kcal], 15% protein, 75% fat, 10% carbohydrate) and exercise, were repleted during 7 d carbohydrate overfeeding (11% protein, 3% fat, and 86% carbohydrate) providing 15.25 ± 1.10 MJ (3642 ± 263 kcal) on the first day, increasing progressively to 20.64 ± 1.30 MJ (4930 ± 311 kcal) on the last day of overfeeding. Glycogen depletion was again accomplished with 2 d of carbohydrate restriction (2.52 MJ/d [602 kcal/d], 85% protein, and 15% fat). Glycogen storage capacity in man is ~15 g/kg body weight and can accommodate a gain of ~500 g before net lipid synthesis contributes to increasing body fat mass. When the glycogen stores are saturated, massive intakes of carbohydrate are disposed of by high carbohydrate-oxidation rates and substantial de novo lipid synthesis (150 g lipid/d using ~475 g CHO/d) without postabsorptive hyperglycemia.

Authors: Schomig A., Kurz T., Richardt G., Schomig E.
Title: Neuronal sodium homoeostasis and axoplasmic amine concentration determine calcium-independent noradrenaline release in normoxic and ischemic rat heart
Affiliations: Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, 69 Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schomig, A., Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, 69 Heidelberg, Germany; Kurz, T., Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, 69 Heidelberg, Germany; Richardt, G., Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, 69 Heidelberg, Germany; Schomig, E., Department of Cardiology, University of Heidelberg, 69 Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: Calcium-independent noradrenaline release was studied in the isolated perfused rat heart under conditions of normoxia, cyanide intoxication, and ischemia. The release of endogenous noradrenaline and dihydroxyphenylglycol were determined by high-performance liquid chromatography. The release of dihydroxyphenylglycol, the main neuronal noradrenaline metabolite, was used as an indicator of the free axoplasmic amine concentration. When storage function of neuronal vesicles was disturbed by Ro 4-1284 or trimethyltin, high dihydroxyphenylglycol release was observed without concomitant overflow of noradrenaline. If, however, these agents were combined with inhibition of Na+,K+-ATPase or with veratridine-induced entry of sodium into the neuron, both dihydroxyphenylglycol and noradrenaline were released. Noradrenaline release was independent of extracellular calcium and was suppressed by blockade of neuronal catecholamine uptake (uptake1), indicating nonexocytotic noradrenaline liberation from the sympathetic nerve ending. This release critically depended on two conditions: 1) increased cytoplasmic concentrations of noradrenaline within the sympathetic neuron and 2) intraneuronal sodium accumulation. Both conditions together were required to induce noradrenaline efflux across the plasma membrane using the uptake1 carrier in reverse of its normal transport direction. A disturbed energy status of the sympathetic neuron, induced by cyanide intoxication or ischemia, likewise caused calcium-independent noradrenaline release by interfering with both vesicular storage function and neuronal sodium homoeostasis. Again, release was sensitive to uptake1 blockade. Since neuronal sodium accumulation was the rate-limiting step, release was further accelerated when residual Na+,K+-ATPase activity was inhibited. Na+-H+ exchange was identified as the predominant pathway of sodium entry into the sympathetic nerve ending in ischemia, and its inhibition by amiloride and ethylisopropylamiloride markedly suppressed ischemia-induced noradrenaline release.

Abstract: The rapid changes and crises in the field of energy during the 1970s and 1980s have forced us to examine the use of energy more critically and to look for new ideas. Seasonal aquifer thermal energy storage (T < 100°C) on a large scale is one of the grey areas which have not yet been extensively explored. However, projects are currently underway in a dozen countries. In Finland there have been three demonstration projects from 1974 to 1987. International co-operation under the auspices of the International Energy Agency, Annex VI, 'Environmental and Chemical Aspects of Thermal Energy Storage in Aquifers and Research and Development of Water Treatment Methods' started in 1987. The research being undertaken in 8 countries includes several elements fundamental to hydrochemistry and biochemistry.

Authors: Eyer P., Hagedorn I., Ladstetter B.
Title: Study on the stability of the oxime HI 6 in aqueous solution
Affiliations: Walter-Straub-Institut für Pharmakologie, und Toxikologie der Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Nußbaumstrasse 26, München 2, D-8000, Germany; Eisenlohrstrasse 30, Freiburg, D-7800, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Eyer, P., Walter-Straub-Institut für Pharmakologie, und Toxikologie der Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Nußbaumstrasse 26, München 2, D-8000, Germany; Hagedorn, I., Eisenlohrstrasse 30, Freiburg, D-7800, Germany; Ladstetter, B., Walter-Straub-Institut für Pharmakologie, und Toxikologie der Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Nußbaumstrasse 26, München 2, D-8000, Germany
Abstract: HI 6 (Pyridinium, 1-[[[4-(aminocarbonyl)pyridinio]methoxy]methyl]-2-[(hydroxyimino)methyl]-dichloride is an effective antidote against poisoning with extremely toxic organophosphates. Because of conflicting reports on the stability of HI 6 in aqueous solutions, we studied the factors influencing its stability. HI 6 has been shown to be most stable in acidic solution between pH 2 and 3. At that pH, HI 6 decomposes probably by attack of nucleophiles on the methylene carbon atom of the aminal-acetal bond of the "ether bridge". HI 6 decomposition follows first order kinetics. From Arrhenius plots of the decay of HI 6 at various concentrations it became obvious that the rate of decomposition increased with increasing HI 6 concentration with simultaneous decrease in the energy of activation. To decide whether the pyridinium compound itself or its anions are responsible for the enhanced decomposition, we studied the influence of chloride, phosphate and iodide. These anions stimulated the decay of HI 6 at increasing strength; their effect, however, was small as compared to that brought about by the pyridinium oxime itself. Since 1-methylisonicotinamide chloride had virtually no effect in contrast to 1-methylpyridinium-2-aldoxime chloride, we conclude that the oximate anion is responsible for the intermolecular attack on HI 6. At present, we recommend storage of HI 6 at concentrations not exceeding 0.1 M in aqueous solution at pH 2.5 and low temperatures. Under these conditions an apparent shelf-life of 20 years is calculated when HI 6 is stored at 8° C. © 1988 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Regulation of gene expression in the adipocyte: implications for obesity and proto-oncogene function
Affiliations: B.M. Spiegelman is in the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, the Department of Biological Chemistry and Molecular Pharmacology, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA 02115, United States

Abstract: Adipose cells are the principal site for the storage of energy in the form of triglycerides in vertebrates. Marked changes in adipocyte-specific gene expression occur during cell differentiation and in disordered states of systemic energy balance, such as obesity and cachexia (wasting). Proteins related to the products of the fos and jun oncogenes have been implicated as trans-acting factors in the differentiation-dependent control of fat cell gene expression. © 1988.
